title: Multivariate Power Load Forecasting Model Considering Meteorological Feature-Load Dynamic Forward Lag and Turning Points
authors: Yunbo Niu, Pei Yong, Juan Yu, Zhifang Yang
abstract: Due to building thermal inertia and delayed user behavioral responses, power load often lags behind meteorological changes, particularly drops in temperature and humidity. Existing models tend to overlook this dynamic lag relationship. To address these challenges, this study proposes a power load forecasting model that integrates three key mechanisms: a dynamic forward lag mechanism, a turning point attention mechanism, and a temporal and channel hybrid mechanism. These components collectively enable the forecasting model to adaptively align meteorological lags, focus on abrupt load transitions, and capture both global temporal dependencies and local feature interactions, thereby enhancing its ability to model complex load behaviors and improve prediction accuracy. Seven experiments were conducted using load data from Singapore and Calgary, Canada, to validate the effectiveness of the proposed model. Numerical results show that the proposed method achieves higher forecasting accuracy compared to existing load forecasting approaches.

title: Rugged GaN UV-APDs via Engineered Bevel-Edge Angle under Accelerated Avalanche Stress
authors: Wangping Wang, Huiye Qiu, Jinkai Lan
abstract: The avalanche ruggedness of GaN ultraviolet avalanche photodiodes (UV-APDs), critical for reliable Geigermode operation, is systematically evaluated for the first time via an accelerated stress methodology. APDs with an ultra-shallow bevel edge termination (2.5°) exhibit superior ruggedness, withstanding a static avalanche current density of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> A/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> at room temperature and accelerated avalanche stress at 175 °C. In contrast, inherent instabilities are revealed in APDs with a conventional-shallow (12°) bevel edge. Degradation modes observed under stress included avalanche current increase after room-temperature stress and destructive breakdown at high temperature. The degradation mechanism is attributed to the trap-assisted charge dynamics at the mesa sidewall, a process driven by the high local electric field at the mesa sidewall. This degradation is effectively mitigated by the ultra-shallow 2.5°-bevel structure, which significantly reduces the sidewall electric field. The resulting high stability establishes a new benchmark for GaN APD reliability.

title: Density-Driven Progressive Shape Formation for Swarm Robots in Dynamic Environments_supp1-3640978.mp4
authors: Xingguang Peng
abstract: This letter presents a novel density-based control framework for shape formation in swarm robotic systems, operating exclusively on local perception without requiring communication or identity recognition among robots and targets. Inspired by Smoothed Particle Hydrodynamics (SPH), each robot estimates a local spatial density using kernel functions and regulates its motion based on the gradient of a constructed target density field. Unlike existing methods that depend on global coordination or explicit target assignments, the proposed approach enables fully distributed shape formation through local density regulation alone. By adjusting the reference density, the system supports autonomous scaling in both the number of robots and the geometric size of the target shape, seamlessly transitioning among shape-surrounding, double-layer contour, and boundary-conformal formations. A composite control law integrates density-driven forces, repulsive interactions for collision avoidance, and damping for dynamic stability. The effectiveness and robustness of the method are validated through extensive simulations and physical experiments with 50 robots under a motion capture laboratory setup. Results demonstrate the scalability, resilience, and practicality of the approach for decentralized swarm shape formation.

title: A Novel Non-Isolated Three-Port BBB DC-DC Converter for Multifunctional PV, Battery, and DC Grid Interfacing Applications
authors: Sunil Mandal, Prajof Prabhakaran, Shreyas S Aney
publish: IEEE Journal of Emerging and Selected Topics in Industrial Electronics
abstract: This paper presents a novel non-isolated bidirectional buck-boost (BBB) DC-DC converter without employing a transformer or coupled inductor. An active switched inductor (ASL) network is integrated into the front-end section of a modified SEPIC converter, facilitating a wide voltage conversion ratio while reducing voltage stress on the major switches. The proposed converter offers multifunctional capabilities, enabling seamless integration with photovoltaic (PV) systems, battery storage, and DC grids. The battery can be charged either from the PV system or directly from the DC grid, enhancing system flexibility. Furthermore, synchronous rectification is implemented using complementary switching to improve conversion efficiency. The steady-state analysis is presented for both continuous conduction mode (CCM) and discontinuous conduction mode (DCM). A dynamic model of the converter is developed, and its performance is validated under both open-loop and closed-loop conditions using SiC MOSFETs. Experimental results verify the enhanced performance and practicality of the proposed converter for energy storage systems in DC grids, electric vehicles (EVs), and other industrial power conversion applications.

title: An early warning system with intelligent collision and deviation alerts for liver tumor resection
authors: Long Chen, Wei Zhan, Zhiyong Ma, Lin Chang, Tong Qiu, Li Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: During traditional open surgery for liver tumor resection, surgical failures often occur because surgical tools touch the tumor or deviate from the surgical path. To solve these problems, this paper proposes an intelligent early warning system for tumor resection based on surgical navigation. Firstly, to address the issue of collisions between surgical tools and tumors, a safe area for surgical tools to cut tumors is established. A mechanism for early warning of collisions between surgical tools and tumors has been constructed. Secondly, the characteristics of surgical paths of different shapes are analyzed. A mathematical calculation model for the distance of surgical tools deviating from surgical paths of different shapes during tumor resection is proposed. Then, a warning model for the deviation of surgical tools from the surgical path is constructed. Finally, experiments are designed to verify the relevant performance of the early warning system proposed in this paper. The experimental results show that the accuracy of the early warning system proposed in this paper is about 95%, and the scope of tumor resection is controlled within 4 mm.

title: Impact of Surfactant in Enhancing Electrostatic Stability and Dielectric Response of Mixed Oil-Based AlN Nanofluids Under Impulse Conditions
authors: Susmita Ghosh, Leena Gautam, R. Sarathi, I. Fofana
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: This study investigates the synergistic effects of Aluminium Nitride (AlN) nanoparticles and cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) surfactant on the performance of mixed insulating oil composed of 20% rapeseed oil and 80% mineral oil. A Taguchi-based grey relational analysis is utilised to identify the optimal nanoparticle-surfactant concentration based on various parameters. The identified optimal nanofluid is further validated using the Derjaguin-Landau-Verwey-Overbeek (DLVO) theory to confirm the stable suspension phenomenon. The DLVO-based total interaction potential energy indicated a higher potential barrier at the optimized concentration of 50 mg/L AlN and 1 mg/L CTAB, supporting enhanced nanofluid stability. The degradation behaviour of nano fluid studied under standard impulse current (standard 8/20μs waveform) was studied. Simultaneously, optical emission spectroscopy (OES) was employed during impulse application to capture real-time spectral changes. The results demonstrate that the nanofluid exhibits enhanced suspension stability, reduced acidity and improved resistance to electrical degradation. The negative polarity impulses induce a more pronounced destabilizing effect compared to positive impulses, emphasizing the asymmetric impact of surge conditions on nanofluid performance. This work highlights the critical role of nanoparticle-surfactant interactions in advancing the reliability of transformer insulating systems.

title: Touch: A New Paradigm Based on Machine Tactile Sensation for Surface Microdefect Detection
authors: Zerui Xi, Xinyu Li, Liang Gao, Yiping Gao
abstract: Surface microdefect detection is a major challenge in advanced manufacturing, while the existing computer vision-based methods struggle to detect micrometer-scale defects, which are invisible to the naked eye. To overcome this problem, this article develops a novel system based on machine-tactile-sensation (MTS) to detect the microdefect. The MTS-based inspection system uses vision-based tactile sensor to convert the tactile signals into visual image, which can capture the fine geometric morphology of the microdefects. Furthermore, considering the limited resolution of the transformed signal, TouchNet, which integrates a label-guided diversity contrastive learning method with an adaptive receptive field selection module, is introduced for defect recognition, which can leverage prior knowledge to guide hyperspherical clustering and employs Gram regularization to prevent feature degradation. The experimental results on the HUST-Tactile dataset indicate that the proposed method can detect the microdefects as small as 0.01 mm with 97.06% accuracy. It also outperforms the state-of-the-art models by 1.33% and 8.46% on the public NEU-CLS and RSW-C datasets, respectively.

title: Predicting Neurological Recovery After Cardiac Arrest Using MLP and Histogram-Based RR Interval Features
authors: Sebastián Loeza-Saldaña, René Luna-García, Blanca Tovar-Corona
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Recovery in comatose patients after cardiac arrest is uncertain, and in the absence of information supporting the likelihood of functional recovery, premature decisions may be made to withdraw life-sustaining treatment, potentially leading to avoidable death. This work proposes the analysis of RR interval histograms from electrocardiogram recordings during the first days of hospitalization in the intensive care unit from 137 patients. A fitting approach is proposed using three components: one exponential and two Gaussian functions. A subset of patients from the PhysioNet Challenge 2023 database was used to calculate the nine parameters of the proposed model, which were then used as input to a Multilayer Perceptron. Results show that the proposed method associates the RR interval behaviour along the hours with the outcome provided in the database achieving a precision of 0.74, recall of 0.88 and f1-score of 0.80 for the poor class, while getting a precision of 0.78, recall of 0.58 and f1-score of 0.67 for the good class, with an overall specificity of 0.88. These preliminar results suggest that using a larger dataset can improve the performance to predict functional recovery in comatose patients.

title: Graph-Theoretic Approaches to Quantifying Power System Resiliency
authors: Mahdi Rouholamini, Caisheng Wang
abstract: Although gaining growing importance, the subject of power system resiliency still lacks a commonly acknowledged metric. As a contribution to solving this complication, in this paper we leverage the concepts of spanning trees and Fiedler value from graph theory to propose two topology-based indices for quantifying the resiliency of power systems. The proposed indices require least information and may be applied to any other flow network, such as water or gas pipeline networks.

title: Discriminative Dictionary Learning based NILM with Spectral Features Extraction using FFT
authors: Muhammad Zubair Ghafoor, Malik Intisar Ali Sajjad
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Energy Conservation and Efficiency (ICECE)
abstract: The purpose of Non-Intrusive Load Monitoring (NILM) is to de-aggregate the overall power use of the household to a per-appliance use without the use of intrusive sensors; nevertheless, the traditional time-domain methods often experience a challenge when there are overlapping appliance signatures. This paper presents a Discriminative Dictionary Learning (DDL) model that is boosted with spectral feature extraction using Fast Fourier Transform (FFT) in order to achieve better appliance-level disaggregation. This algorithm learns representative dictionary atoms, and a discriminative classifier in a sequence of alternating optimisation of sparse codes, dictionary updates, and classifier updates. Two modes are considered, a base time-domain DDL and the suggested time-frequency DDL to supplement input windows with spectral characteristics obtained by FFT. The experiment on the Pecan Street data indicates that the addition of spectral information significantly increases the accuracy, recall, and F1 -scores, especially on appliances with unique frequency patterns, including microwaves and refrigerators, hence proves that spectral features can boost the discriminative ability of dictionary learning to predict NILM.

title: Low-Resource RAG Pipelines for Arabic Domain-Specific Corpora
authors: Abdelkrim Aarab, Ahmed Oussous, Mohammed Saddoune
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: This study presents a comprehensive pipeline for enhancing natural language processing systems in Arabic legal and administrative domains by integrating external knowledge sources into language generation models. While such approaches have demonstrated strong performance in highresource languages like English, their extension to Arabic has been limited due to linguistic complexity, lack of curated datasets, and poor document structure. Arabic legal documents often appear in unstructured formats such as scanned multicolumn files, making text extraction and processing particularly challenging. To address these issues, we propose a multi-stage system that includes robust text extraction, semantic segmentation, and retrieval of relevant content prior to language generation. We evaluate several multilingual embedding and generation models on a manually curated dataset of legal examples drawn from a corpus of over 225,000 pages. Our experiments show that a multilingual embedding model trained for semantic similarity outperforms alternatives in both accuracy and efficiency. We also find that a widely available language generation model produces the most reliable answers under limited computational resources. Furthermore, we demonstrate that our chosen retrieval infrastructure achieves significantly lower latency compared to alternative systems. These results confirm that it is feasible to deploy knowledge-enhanced language generation systems in Arabic legal domains, even in low-resource settings. This work contributes practical methods and insights for extending language technologies to underrepresented languages and complex document types.

title:
Performance Assessment of FACsSnI
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Perovskite Solar Cells via Deep Learning
authors: A. Maoucha, F. Djeffal, T. Berghout
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: The development of lead-free perovskite solar cells (PSCs) presents a promising path for sustainable energy and engineering applications such as embedded and aerospace systems. However, understanding and mitigating photovoltaic mechanisms while optimizing device performance remain significant challenges. In this study, we employ numerical simulation techniques combined with deep learning (DL) techniques to gain insights into both the design optimization and performance analysis of high-efficiency lead-free FACsSnI <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$_{3}$</tex> solar cells. By using SCAPS-1D numerical simulations, we analyze key-performance parameters such as open-circuit voltage, short-circuit current, fill factor, and power conversion efficiency (PCE) under varying conditions influenced by photogeneration and interfacial loss processes. Our approach based on the investigation of the impact of the mole fraction variations of the absorber layer on the device performance. This approach can predict critical performance pathways and identify the most effective structural configurations for enhancing the efficiency. The results demonstrate that the proposed investigation not only improves the accuracy of performance predictions but also accelerates the design process, reducing development time and cost. This study provides a new framework for developing the future efficient lead-free photovoltaic systems.

title: Enhancing Grid Resilience Through Pre-positioning and Private Resource Incentives
authors: Feng Chen, Zongjie Wang
abstract: With the increasing electric vehicle (EV) permeability and battery duration, private EVs have the potential to improve the power grid resilience by restoring loads during high-impact low-probability (HILP) events. In this paper, a chance-constrained (CC) optimization model is proposed to integrate public and private resources in different load restoration phases: 1) mobile energy storage systems (MESSs) are pre-located before the HILP events; 2) after the HILP events, radial sub-networks are reconfigured according to distribution line damages and energy injection locations; and 3) private EVs will participate in demand response (DR) under an incentive design. Piecewise linearization and second-order cone relaxation methods are employed to improve the solution efficiency. Simulation case studies on 15-bus radial power systems and the Sioux Falls transportation network have demonstrated the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed CC models by showing a comparable restoration level with a lower budget compared to the solution that ignores uncertainty.

title: Hybrid RF-FSO/FSO-RF Multihop Relay Performance in Presence of Hyper-Rayleigh Fading
authors: Aleksey S. Gvozdarev, Tatiana K. Artemova, Anton A. Afonin
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: The presented study delivers a comprehensive evaluation of the joint quality-reliability analysis of a hybrid 3-hop amplify-and-forward wireless communication relay system integrating 2 radio frequency (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R F}$</tex>) and 1 free-space optical (FSO) channels. The RF links were characterized using the recently proposed Inverse Power Lomax fading model, while the optical channel was modeled using the Màlaga- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathcal{M}$</tex> distribution. The analysis was conducted specifically under hyper-Rayleigh fading conditions to assess system robustness in severe propagation environments. Key performance metrics, including average bit error probability and outage probability, were jointly analyzed across varying model parameters representing different signal propagation scenarios. The findings identified parameter configurations that ensure high-performance and reliable communication. Additionally, the study highlighted scenarios requiring decoder adjustments or operational modifications to sustain acceptable transmission quality, as well as conditions where reliability could not be achieved even with degraded performance. The study provides possible insights for designing resilient hybrid communication systems under challenging fading conditions, offering guidelines for parameter optimization and system adaptation.

title: Chaotic Systems: Generalized Quasi-Synchronization
authors: Lorenz Oliva-Gonzalez, Rafael Martínez-Guerra, Israel de Jesus Hernandez-Saldaña
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: In this paper, we study the generalized quasisynchronization of chaotic systems, which can be of different dimensions. The proposed approach considers the chaotic system's structure to be unknown. However, it can be approximated through an estimator. As a consequence, a dynamic controller is introduced which, along with the estimation of the chaotic system's structure, ensures the generalized quasi-synchronization. Additionally, through a stability analysis, an attraction region is obtained where the synchronization error function converges asymptotically and holds. Finally, a numerical example is given to show the properties of this approach.

title: Power and Cross-Section Optimization for an FPGA-Based Cosmic Radiation Sensor
authors: Stefan Popa, Andrei Bertescu, Cristian Furtună, Artur Kazak, Mihai Ivanovici, Alexei Martiniuc, Viorel Carbune, Vladimir Melnic, Nicolae Secrieru
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: We evaluate the power optimization strategies for a Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) -based cosmic radiation sensor printed circuit board (PCB) intended for future nano-satellite missions. We analyze the trade-off between power consumption and radiation sensing capability, aiming to maximize the number of radiation detection elements while minimizing energy usage. We tested several variations of the proposed detection design by changing key parameters such as clock signal frequency, memory utilization and memory polling rate. Through these optimizations, we achieved an FPGA power consumption of 0.5 W while using all available memory resources. The power consumption of the entire PCB and the FPGA device in particular is estimated using a software tool and measured using real-world instruments. We compare the results, explain any discrepancies between the estimations and the measured data and identify the most power-efficient configuration suitable for space-constrained, low-power nano-satellite platforms, that also maximizes the total cross-section of the radiation sensing elements.

title: Zoborg: Locomotion Control for Cyborg Beetles with Leg Impairment
authors: H. Nhan Le, Lachlan Fitzgerald, P. Ross McAree, T. Thang Vo-Doan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Cyborg insects have emerged as potential robotic platforms for search and rescue missions due to their small size, naturally agile structure and functions of the living insects. In post-disaster environments, collapsed debris poses a significant risk to these cyborg insects, as physical impacts may inadvertently damage body parts. This paper demonstrates the ability to control Zoborg, a terrestrial cyborg employing Zophobas morio platform, even when its middle legs are damaged. Electrical stimulation of corresponding antenna could induce right and left turns, respectively, in Zoborg with leg impairment. Graded response in turning control was partially preserved after removing the middle legs. The results highlight the potential of cyborg insects for practical applications by mitigating the effects of physical damage and demonstrating their capability to adapt, making them promising platforms for search and rescue operations.

title: AI-Driven Approaches to Wildfire Prediction and Control: Methods, Challenges, and Future Direction
authors: Farishta Rahman, Sriram Prabhakara Rao, Catherine A. Finley, David T. Flynn, Prakash Ranganathan, Hossein Salehfar
abstract: Wildfires are increasing in number due to the combination of several factors, such as climate change, human infiltration, ecological mismanagement, etc. The historical methods for forecasting and controlling forest wildfires are not capable of immediate forecasting of a short-term event. At the current moment, machine learning (ML) and artificial intelligence (AI) have been promising approaches for prediction, early detection, real-time monitoring, and risk assessment. AI can better predict wildfires, while also identifying closely with its trends, by leveraging sources such as large-scale satellite, meteorological station, and sensor network data sets. Deep learning methodologies could be applied for smoke detection, predicting fire expansion, and supporting the decision-making of emergency responders. These are accomplished with methods such as image processing and time series prediction. Recent AI and ML developments in wildfire management are discussed in this review. It includes new physics-informed neural networks (PINNs) for coupling subgrid fire-dynamics and atmosphere-dynamics. This paper also provides state-of-the-art case studies from around the world and addresses issues for data quality, model interpretability, and computational cost.

title: Real Time Child Abduction and Detection System
authors: Tadisetty Sai Yashwanth, Yangalasetty Sruthi Royal, Mayank Kashyap, Vankayala Rajeshwari Shreya, Divyaprabha K N
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: The safety of children is a worldwide concern, and the threat of child abduction remains a frightening reality for families and communities everywhere. This paper introduces a practical solution: a real-time child abduction detection and alert system that is affordable and privacy-focused. The system relies on several smart agents, each running on a compact Raspberry Pi computer equipped with a camera. These agents use advanced algorithms to continuously watch and understand the interactions between children and adults, right as events happen. If the system detects suspicious behavior or a possible abduction attempt, it sends immediate alerts via SMS, WhatsApp, or automated phone calls using Twilio's communication service. Not only does the approach catch threats with high accuracy and minimal delays, but it also keeps user data safe by processing everything locally on the device. By combining multiple intelligent agents, the system gains a better grasp of context, improving its reliability compared to older, single-model surveillance solutions. In short, this technology gives families and communities a low-cost and easy way to monitor vulnerable children in real time and sound a fast alarm if something goes wrong.

title: A Hybrid Machine Learning and TOPSIS-Based MCDM Framework for Optimized Inventory Classification
authors: Raghad Albarghash, Manar Abu Talib, Mahdi Jemmali, Talel Ladhari
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Effective inventory classification plays a crucial role in optimizing supply chain management, influencing decisions related to stock control, resource allocation, and demand forecasting. Traditional inventory classification methods, such as ABC analysis, have long been the standard but often oversimplify complex decision-making scenarios by focusing on a limited number of criteria. Previous research has attempted to enhance classification accuracy by incorporating multi-criteria decisionmaking (MCDM) methods, but challenges remain when dealing with conflicting factors like cost, lead time, and usage. This paper integrates machine learning models with the TOPSIS MCDM approach to optimize inventory classifications by enhancing the weight assignment and ranking processes. Using a benchmark dataset of 47 inventory items, four configurations were compared: equal weights, lead-time-prioritized weights, and machine learning-based weights derived from Random Forest and Gradient Boosting. The results showed that the lead-time-prioritized TOPSIS achieved complete alignment with the expert-based ZF model, outperforming the other configurations. These findings demonstrate that incorporating domain-relevant weighting can substantially improve classification accuracy and decision-making reliability. The study contributes to the development of adaptive, data-informed Decision Support Systems (DSS) for dynamic, real-world inventory environments.

title: Biomimetic Auxetic Compliant Tensegrity Metamaterial with Tunable Poisson's Ratio for the Application as a Soft Robotic Skin
authors: Lukas Lehmann, David Herrmann, Leon Schaeffer, Mohammed Albaik, Emily Müller, Gianluca Rizzello, Valter Böhm
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: The use of compliant tensegrity grids offers significant potential for adaptive and lightweight systems for applications in soft robotics. This paper presents foundational investigations into a new class of auxetic tensegrity metamaterials. This work demonstrates that the auxetic behavior of a tensegrity grid can be realized and tuned solely through the mechanical properties of tensioned members, without altering the equilibrium geometry, offering a key advantage over conventional auxetic structures with fixed topologies. To validate the concept, 3D-printed demonstrators are manufactured, tested and a possible application as a cylindrically shaped soft robotic skin is shown.

title: Enhancing Grid Flexibility by Providing Ancillary Services Using Heavy-Duty Electric Vehicles
authors: Muhammad Faisal Baig, Yuanrui Sang, Golbon Zakeri
abstract: The increasing penetration of nondispatchable renewable energy requires power systems to enhance their flexibility. Meanwhile, emerging technologies integrated in energy systems, such as electric vehicles (EV), can help meet this need by providing ancillary services, such as regulation reserve and demand response. Heavy-duty electric vehicles (HDEV) have great potential for this purpose because of their large battery capacity and highly predictable travel patterns. To study the effectiveness of providing flexibility using HDEVs, this paper proposes a reserve and flexible load scheduling model considering the characteristics of HDEVs. Case studies were performed on the IEEE RTS-96 24-bus system with wind energy and ten HDEV depots, and the impact of managing HDEV charging on system operating costs and wind energy integration were analyzed. Results show that optimally scheduling the charging and discharging of HDEVs can reduce power system operating costs by up to 3.7% and wind curtailment by up to 57%.

title: Enhanced Voltage Reference Circuit Design Using Quadratic Function Modeling of MOSFET Characteristics in the Saturation Region
authors: Shuya Isawa, Kawori Sekine, Kazuyuki Wada, François Rivet, Hervé Lapuyade, Yann Deval
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper investigates a voltage reference circuit that incorporates an equivalent MOSFET, which adjusts the threshold voltage and its temperature coefficient using a Proportional To Absolute Temperature (PTAT) voltage generation circuit. In previous designs, the relationship between the drain current I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</inf> and the gate-source voltageV<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">GS</inf> was derived based on the threshold voltage V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</inf> from the gradual channel model of MOSFETs. However, this method led to discrepancies between theory and simulation. We propose a new approach where the I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">D</inf> - V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">GS</inf> characteristics are modeled using simulation data from a single NMOSFET, fitted to a general quadratic function. This model significantly reduces the error between theoretical calculations and simulation results. Additionally, the temperature coefficient of the reference voltage V<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">ref</inf> is improved from 498 ppm/K to 32 ppm/K.

title: Comparison of Two Hole-Transport Layers for Hybrid Perovskite Solar Cells
authors: D. Mateus Torres-Herrera, Rosa Nava-Sánchez, Arturo Morales-Acevedo
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: High-efficiency hybrid perovskite solar cells require hole transport layers (HTL) that enable efficient charge transfer, minimizing interfacial losses, and enhancing device stability. The (HTL) material can produce effects that significantly affect the photovoltaic device's performance. In this study, as a way of understanding such effects, a fast analytical method is shown to extract the saturation current density (J<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf>) and the light-generated current density (J<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">L</inf>) from the illuminated J-V curves. Together with approximate estimates for the series (R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">s</inf>) and shunt (R<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">sh</inf>) resistances, the method enables a fast and more comprehensive evaluation of the HTL related effects, facilitating the design of mitigation strategies for undesired effects. The method was applied to hybrid perovskite solar cells with the architecture FTO/TiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>/CsFAPbI<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>/HTL/Au, comparing two HTLs: CuSCN and Spiro-OMeTAD. Devices employing SpiroOMeTAD exhibited significantly higher performance (PCE = <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10.7 \pm 1.2 \%$</tex>) than those using CuSCN (PCE =<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.5 \pm 0.8 \%$</tex>), which is attributed to the higher resistivity and increased density of interfacial traps for the CsFAPbI<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>/CuSCN devices. Based on this analysis, strategies can be devised to achieve better device performance.

title: Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) Based Fault Detection and Classification (FDC) Models in Power Systems: A Comparative Review
authors: Remon Das, Adam Harris, Tarek Kandil
abstract: Fault detection and classification (FDC) play a vital role in ensuring the reliability and safety of modern power systems. With the rapid expansion of intelligent power networks and smart grids, the need for accurate, fast, and automated protection schemes has become increasingly important. Moreover, the rising power demand driven by AI data centers and industrialization has led to more complex transmission and distribution networks, making fault detection and classification more challenging. Traditional machine learning models often depend on manual feature extraction and tend to struggle with nonlinearities and noise. In contrast, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs), a powerful subset of deep learning, are well-suited for complex feature extraction and have been widely applied in power system protection. This paper provides a comprehensive review of CNN-based approaches for FDC in power systems. It examines various network architectures, methodologies, optimization techniques, and evaluation metrics, and also compares the performance of recent CNN models.

title: Visualization and Analysis of United States Independent System Operator Generator Interconnection Requests
authors: Selorm Dzakpasu, Thomas J. Overbye, Jonathan M. Snodgrass
abstract: This paper explores the process of consolidating interconnection queue data from seven Independent System Operators (ISOs), CAISO, SPP, PJM, ERCOT, ISO-NE, NYISO, and MISO, into a comprehensive and unified database for use in power systems research. The goal is to create a single, large-scale dataset that captures all interconnection requests across these ISOs, facilitating in-depth analysis of trends in generation capacity seeking to connect to the U.S. grid. This unified database enables the visualization of the evolving energy mix within these requests, assesses potential impacts on the US transmission network, and supports informed decision making on future investments in the regions governed by these ISOs. In addition to merging these data sources, this paper details the data cleaning and processing steps necessary to ensure the resulting data set is accurate, reliable, and actionable for stakeholders in grid planning, energy policy, and infrastructure development.

title: Voltage Probability Density Function Shaping Control Strategy Considering Grid Operational Uncertainties
authors: Yonghao Gui, Hong Wang, Yaosuo Xue
abstract: It is well-known that power systems operation always affected by various uncertainties which make the bus voltage a random process that can be characterized by its probability density function (PDF) at any time instant. In this context, this paper presents a novel PDF-based voltage control framework for power systems. By modeling voltage as a stochastic process, we formulate a stochastic differential equationthat captures grid uncertainties. The associated Fokker-Planck-Kolmogorov equation is derived to describe the evolution of the voltage PDF, which enables the formulation of a PDF-shaping control strategy. To simplify the PDF control formulation, a B-spline neural network is introduced for real-time estimation and regulation of the voltage distribution. The proposed PDF control law updates voltage references for energy storage systems and synchronous generators using real-time PDF measurements and feedback signals. The proposed method is validated on a modified Kundur’s two-area system. Simulation results demonstrate that the controller can significantly improve the voltage stability under stochastic conditions, highlighting its effectiveness in modern inverter-rich grids.

title: Web-Based Predictive Tool for CA19-9 Levels Using Selected Urine Biomarkers via Ensemble Learning Techniques
authors: Michael James F. Gnilo, Jonathan Russell D. Bunquin, Cliff Marvic M. Coligado, Marco Allen A. Gianan, Jezreil V. Lumbera
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: CA 19-9, medically known as carbohydrate antigen 19-9 or cancer antigen 19-9, is a widely used and well-validated tumor marker for diagnosing and monitoring various cancers. Its levels can increase significantly in cancer or certain benign conditions [1] This study aimed to create a predictive model using selected urine biomarkers to predict the levels of CA19-9 and integrate the model into the web application that will be used by the medical technologists. A four-phase methodology was employed: (1) Data Preparation, (2) Modeling and Model Validation, (3) Development of Web Application, and (4) Testing and Analysis. The datasets from a pancreatic cancer-related study were used to validate the model’s accuracy and assess its generalizability. The model was then integrated into a web application developed using Django framework, featuring the prediction of CA19-9 levels, history of the patient’s data, and data visualization for the patient analytics. Usability testing was performed to evaluate the model’s usability at Balibago Polyclinic and Hospital Inc. In terms of usability and functionality, the testing consisted of a 4-point Likert scale questionnaire, yielded positive feedback, achieving a mean score of 3.23 (Agree).

title: Quantum-Enhanced Sliding Mode Control for Robust and High-Performance Industrial Robotic Manipulation
authors: Mehdi Fazilat, Nadjet Zioui
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Providing robust and precise control of robotic systems, particularly those handling nonlinear dynamics and exposure to external disturbances, remains a problematic challenge in advanced robotics. This study proposes and critically evaluates a quantum-inspired sliding mode control (Q-SMC) framework to improve classic SMC approaches' robustness, precision, and computational efficiency. The research contains developing comprehensive dynamic models of a six-degree-offreedom articulated robotic arm, followed by an in-depth comparative assessment of classical SMC and the novel Q-SMC methodology. Simulation results highlight the superiority of QSMC in managing the chattering, achieving better trajectory tracking accuracy, and reducing energy consumption by approximately 2.97%. These findings establish Q-SMC as an advantageous advance in control strategies, with significant implications for high-precision and energy-efficient robotic manipulation in involved operational conditions.

title: Glitch Happens: Attacking the AMD-Xilinx PLL with a Clock Glitch Generator
authors: Lukas Leuenberger, Roman Willi, Dorian Amiet, Paul Zbinden
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: Cryptographic algorithms are indispensable from today’s world and often require high-throughput implementations accelerated by specialized hardware like field programmable gate arrays (FPGAs). However, these implementations are vulnerable to passive and active side-channel attacks. This paper presents a clock glitch generator designed to inject precise glitches into a clock signal, enabling an active side-channel attack. The generator uses only FPGA clocking resources to maintain signal integrity. An FPGA-internal calibration method is incorporated to generate consistent glitches, independent of the implementation run and the physical device characteristics. The start and width of the glitches can be set with a step size of 0.53°, equal to 14.8 ps, for a 100 MHz clock. The generator’s architecture allows glitches to be inserted in the positive and negative phase of the clock. This increases the versatility of possible attacks. The clock glitch generator was used to attack both the mixed-mode clock manager (MMCM) and phase-locked loop (PLL) primitives within the 7-Series and Ultrascale+ FPGAs from AMD-Xilinx. Despite the PLL’s ability to filter out clock glitches, an attack scenario was successfully identified that stealthily increased the output frequency of a 7-Series MMCM and PLL by up to 68%.

title: MFE-MTL: Simultaneously Force Estimation and Gesture Classification Based on Low-Channel sEMG for Stroke Rehabilitation
authors: Andong Li, Jie Zuo, Lujie Yi, Xinxing Chen, Jian Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: This study proposes MFE-MTL, a multi-task learning framework based on low-channel surface electromyography (sEMG) signals for stroke rehabilitation. The method combines manual feature extraction with a joint classification-regression model to simultaneously perform hand gesture recognition and grasp force estimation. Compared with three widely used neural networks (FCN, CNN, and LSTM), MFE-MTL achieved the best performance under low-channel conditions, reaching a pearson correlation coefficient of 0.89 for force prediction and 95.41 % precision for gesture classification. The integrated multi-task design significantly improved recognition performance, demonstrating the effectiveness and practicality of MFE-MTL in resource-constrained rehabilitation scenarios.

title: MultiModal Human-Robot Interaction for Cobot-Assisted Disassembly: A Comparative Study of Voice, Gesture, GUI, and Brain Signal Control
authors: Soufiane Ameur, Kaouter Karboub, Mohamed Tabaa, Mohamed Hamlich, Richard Bearee
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: The increasing request for sustainable treatment of electronic waste highlights the need for intelligent disassembly systems enhanced by proper human-robot interaction (HRI). This paper presents a comparative study of four human-robot interaction modalities: Hand Gesture (HG), Voice Command (VC), Graphical User Interface (GUI) and EEG-based interaction in the framework of a cobot-assisted disassembly setup. The system was first validated in simulation using RoboDK and then deployed in a real environment to assess performance in four representative scenarios: noisy conditions, precision tasks, hands-free operation and emergency intervention. The gesture emerged as the most balanced and robust modality achieving a recognition rate of 95% with a response time of 1.3 seconds and demonstrating great adaptability in all scenarios. The graphical interface offers the highest recognition rate and fastest response time (0.8 s) but requires full visual attention. Voice control performed moderately well while EEG showed the lowest reliability. This study concludes that rather than completely eliminating a single modality each HRI method is valuable when properly integrated and selected according to the specific requirements of the task.

title: A Systematic Literature Review on Automatic Correction for Arabic Text Using Language Models and Deep Learning
authors: Asmae Regraguy, Saida Laaroussi, Si Lhoussain Aouragh, Said Ouatik El Alaoui
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Automatic correction for Arabic text is challenging due to Arabic's complex morphology and orthographic rules, similar to the difficulties encountered in low resource languages. This systematic literature review investigates developments in Arabic text correction from 2015 to 2025, with a particular emphasis on methods leveraging language models and deep learning. The present advancements in Arabic grammatical error correction is represented by the AraBART model. It achieved an F1 score of 92.1 % when evaluated on the QALB-2014 dataset. For grammatical error detection (GED), a Bi-LSTM-based system attained an Fmeasure of 95.19%, while spelling correction systems reached an auto-correction rate of 96 % using a hybrid approach combining edit distance and probabilistic language models. In addition to benchmarking performance, this review highlights key limitations such as data scarcity, the need for high-quality annotated corpora, and the handling of contextually ambiguous errors. Expected outcomes include the identification of research gaps and recommendations for future work, particularly in developing more robust models and richer datasets to advance automatic Arabic text correction.

title: Emission-Aware Flexible Data Center Load Scheduling
authors: Charlee Sue Dreisbach, Irfanul Hasan, Yuanrui Sang
abstract: With increasing demand for digital infrastructure, there is an increasing need for electricity by data centers, consequently increasing emissions associated with data center operations. To reduce the environmental impact of these operations, this study proposes a model that optimally schedules the best-effort (BE) workload of data centers to minimize the emission of carbon dioxide (CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), methane (CH<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>), and nitrous oxide (N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O). By optimally scheduling the BE workload, computing demand can be shifted away from peak usage periods while still meeting essential system requirements. Case studies were carried out over 24 hours with 5-minute time intervals on the IEEE 24-bus RTS-96 system, and the results show that the proposed load scheduling model can effectively reduce emissions from the system, regardless of the location of the data center. The model can be used to enhance the flexibility of the modern computing infrastructure, considering its environmental impacts.

title: Deep Learning Based Techniques for Medical Ultrasound Images Enhancement: A Comprehensive Review
authors: Chaymae Taib, Zineb Aqachmar, Najiba El Amrani El Idrissi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Ultrasound imaging (US) has proven to be a crucial technique in modern medicine, as it is noninvasive, provides real-time images, it is free of ionizing radiation, and cost-effective. However, ultrasound images often have poor quality due to low resolution, low contrast, and speckle noise. This can make it hard to make a correct diagnosis. Recently, artificial intelligence, particularly deep learning, has demonstrated remarkable capability to enhance ultrasound images, surpassing traditional methods. This work presents a comprehensive review. It covers the latest deep learning methods developed for ultrasound image enhancement. We classify these techniques according to their main purpose: speckle reduction, super-resolution, and multi-objective enhancement. We assess recent studies in each category, reviewing the strengths, datasets, evaluation metrics, and clinical utility of each technique. The review also highlights current challenges, including limitations in real-time processing and poor application to diverse patient data. Finally, we suggest future steps to successfully integrate DL-enhanced ultrasound imaging into real-world clinical practice.

title: A Modular Architecture for Agentic Decision-Making in Industrial Analytics
authors: Achraf Ballari, Omar Souissi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Business intelligence went from static reports to real time analytics, while agentic artificial intelligence evolved to autonomous agents able to use call tools. Yet these parallel advancements rarely found a common ground in order to converge: today's business intelligence dashboards still depend on analysts to interpret insights and trigger actions. Also, agentic artificial intelligence flows rarely integrate with enterprise business intelligence pipelines. This paper reviews and attempts to dig into this persistent gap. Building on our proof of concept internet of things decision support framework, we propose results that show that we can build architectures adapted for a business intelligence centric context. Sensor data is streamed via Message Queuing Telemetry Transport, then an agentic layer is implemented with Langchain and local large language models subscribes to the same data, enriches it through retrieval augmented generation for a domain specific vector store, and issues autonomously decisions back into the business intelligence ecosystem. In addition, we highlight the urge to examine if artificial intelligence agents can act like business analysts deciding which plots or visualizations are most appropriate for each use case to maximize insight delivery. Thus, dashboards transition from passive monitors to actionable control panels. The results show that merging advanced business intelligence with agentic artificial intelligence is technically feasible and operationally beneficial, it raises at the same time questions about security, governance, explainability and ethics. This study provides a concrete blueprint for closing the gap between business intelligence and agentic artificial intelligence and it outlines a research agenda for truly autonomous business analytics in industry settings.

title: IRIG-B Synchronized EMT-EMT Co-Simulation Framework for OPAL-RT/RTDS Integration
authors: Lokesh Saravana, Jianhua Zhang, Thomas Ortmeyer, Tuyen V. Vu, Victor D. Paduani
abstract: This paper proposes a time-synchronized hybrid co-simulation framework for distributed electromagnetic transient (EMT) and EMT-domain power system simulations, integrating OPAL-RT and RTDS real-time simulators through a Transmission Line Model (TLM) interface and high-speed Aurora protocol. An IRIG-B-based synchronization scheme aligns the internal clocks of both platforms, ensuring deterministic operation and reducing numerical instabilities during hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) scenarios. The framework is evaluated on two representative test systems—a simple transmission network and an offshore wind farm connected via HVDC link—subjected to transient conditions. Comparative results demonstrate that precise time synchronization significantly improves numerical stability, minimizes solver step mismatches, and suppresses transient artifacts. The findings confirm that combining the TLM-Aurora interface with IRIG-B time synchronization provides reliable and accurate co-simulation performance for both simple and complex grid configurations, offering a scalable solution for future large-scale distributed real-time simulation and digital twin applications.

title: Identification of Novel Potential Anticancer Peptides in the Genome of Periplaneta Americana (American Cockroach) Using Bioinformatics Tools
authors: Paola Rondón-Villarreal
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: The high number of cancer-related deaths around the world is alarming. Projections indicate that this number will rise significantly by the year 2025. Current treatments are often ineffective and come with unbearable side effects for patients. Therefore, there is an urgent need for new, effective, and safer cancer therapies. In this search, anticancer peptides have emerged as a promising solution due to their high selectivity, biocompatibility, high tissue penetration, low risk of developing resistance, low toxicity, and low production costs, among other advantages. Recently, multiple natural peptides with anticancer activity have been identified from edible insects. For instance, peptides derived from Periplaneta americana (the American cockroach) have exhibit different mechanisms of action in their anticancer activity. This study proposed a computational protocol that uses bioinformatics and machine learning tools to analyze the genome of this insect, with the aim of identifying novel potential anticancer peptides. The results suggest two short candidate peptides for further experimental testing. Notably, these peptides were not found in the APD, CAMP, and DBAASP databases, suggesting that they may not have been previously tested for any biological activity. Due to their high similarity to known anticancer peptides, it is likely that they could exhibit anticancer activity in different cancer cell lines.

title: Soft Magnetic Microrobots Assembled by Mechanical Microtweezers
authors: Longzhe Huang, Yihang Zhu, Yue Zhao, Xiyue Liang, Zhuo Chen, Tatsuo Arai, Xiaoming Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: This paper presents an micro-assembly system based on microtweezers for fabricating soft magnetic microrobots. The system achieves precise three-dimensional positioning through a three-degree-of-freedom manipulator. The end-effector design incorporates micro-tweezers and a tweezer box. A dedicated transmission mechanism mechanically couples the stepper motor to the microtweezers, enabling reliable manipulations of grasping and releasing. The tweezer box accommodates microtweezers of varying dimensions while ensuring operational stability during assembly processes. To demonstrate the capability of assembly, magnetic particles approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$800 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> in diameter were successfully manipulated to assemble quadrupedal soft magnetic microrobots. Experimental results confirm that the system can fabricate magnetic microrobots with superior locomotion performance. This assembly approach offers potential applications in precision manufacturing and biomedical manipulation.

title: The Anatomy of Success: A Knowledge Management Model for Predicting Graduate Employability Placement
authors: Parham Porouhan, Wichian Premchaiswadi
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: A persistent "employability paradox"—the disconnect between high academic achievement and real-world job readiness—plagues higher education. Universities possess vast student data but often lack the framework to convert this data into the strategic knowledge needed to guide student success. This research addresses this data-to-knowledge gap by applying an Organizational Knowledge Management (OKM) framework. The primary objective is to move beyond simple prediction and construct an interpretable, "white-box" knowledge model that anatomizes the hierarchical factors and compensatory pathways leading to successful graduate placement. Following a Knowledge Discovery in Databases (KDD) process, this study utilizes a public "Graduate Employability Dataset" (n=661) within the AI Studio platform. We implement a C4.5 Decision Tree classifier, selected specifically for its high interpretability. The model was trained on an 80% data partition and validated against a 20% hold-out test set to ensure predictive fidelity. The resulting model achieved a high-fidelity accuracy of 96.97% with a robust F1-Score of 90.00% for the positive placement class. More significantly, the qualitative analysis of the "white-box" model revealed a clear "anatomy of success." IQ was identified as the root-node "gateway" factor. For high-IQ graduates, the model uncovered three distinct and compensatory pathways to placement: high CGPA (Path 1), high Communication_Skills (Path 2), or a high number of Projects_Completed (Path 3). Critically, the model rendered Internship_Experience (as a binary attribute) statistically redundant, suggesting its value is captured by other, more measurable skills. This study successfully transforms a static dataset into a dynamic, actionable knowledge asset. The findings provide a data-driven blueprint for institutional intervention, enabling universities to move from reactive advising to a personalized, predictive strategy. It offers a clear, evidence-based roadmap for students and curriculum designers, demonstrating that multiple, distinct profiles can lead to a successful career outcome.

title: Behavioral Intention to Use an e-Marketplace for Upcycled Products: Machine Learning based Analysis
authors: Patricia Anne J. Dela Cruz, Luis Emmanuel P. Hofileña, Jerry Reivrick C. Nares, John Edwin C. Reyes, Alexander A. Hernandez, Jay-ar P. Lalata
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: Upcycling is a sustainable solution that mitigates environmental changes, focusing on climate action, by extending the lifecycle of products and reducing wastage. This study investigates Filipino consumers’ behavioral intention to use an upcycling e-marketplace, highlighting the intersection of sustainability, consumer psychology, and digital platforms. Despite growing interest in circular economy models, adoption drivers in this domain remain underexplored and are rarely modeled with predictive analytics. To address this gap, the study collected data from 500 Filipino participants capturing environmental knowledge and concern, perceived ease of use and usefulness, attitude toward use, perceived behavioral control, subjective norms, user demand, and intention, then analyzed using multiple machine learning algorithms, namely, Decision Tree, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, XGBoost, K-Nearest Neighbors, and Support Vector Machine. Among these, the Decision Tree model demonstrated the best balance of predictive accuracy (95%), precision (96%), and recall (91%), suggesting strong classification capability. Analysis of the importance of features revealed that Perceived Usefulness, Attitude Toward Use, and Subjective Norms were the most influential predictors of adoption, outweighing traditional environmental concerns. These findings underscore the importance of designing upcycling platforms that emphasize practical value, user convenience, and social validation. The study concludes that sustainable behavior is more likely when aligned with personal benefits and peer influence, rather than relying solely on environmental appeals.

title: PMU-Based Electric Grid Disturbances Detection by Leveraging Reinforcement Learning
authors: Diego Gandara-Mendez, Paras Mandal
abstract: This paper presents an approach leveraging reinforcement learning (RL) to address the challenging issue of detecting disturbances in power systems in more accurate manner. The RL agent operates within a Q-learning environment to identify disturbances in dataset from Phasor Measurement Units (PMUs), which provide comprehensive feedback including voltage in per-unit, voltage angle, and frequency for each bus, making them highly suitable for RL models. The proposed approach involves designing an environment using OpenAI Gym for effective observation and interaction for the process of training the Q-learning agent on normal PMU data to establish a baseline understanding. The agent is then evaluated on dataset containing disturbances of varying magnitudes to test its detection capabilities. Test results show that the RL agent performs more effectively for distinguishing normal and disturbed states. This advancement highlights the potential of RL application to offer more accurate disturbance detection in electric grid.

title: Design and Performance of $\text{BaHfSe}_{3} / \text{SnS}_{2}$ Heterojunction Solar Cells: A SCAPS-1D Study
authors: Dhineshkumar Srinivasan, Aruna-Devi Rasu Chettiar, Latha Marasamy
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Chalcogenide perovskites (CPs) have recently drawn significant attention as viable replacements for lead-based halide perovskites, due to their strong structural stability, attractive optoelectronic features, and environmentally friendly nature. In this work, we report for the first time, a numerical investigation of a BaHfSe3-based solar cell design incorporating <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{S n S}_{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> as a buffer layer. SnS <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }_{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> stands out for being both non-toxic and abundant in the earth's crust. Using the SCAPS-1D simulation tool, we examined the device's behavior by methodically tuning critical parameters of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{S n S}_{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> layer, including donor concentration, defect density, and thickness. The initial device, Ag/AZO/IZO/SnS <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }_{2}$</tex> /BaHfSe <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }_{3}$</tex> / <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Cu}_{2} ~\mathrm{S} / \text{Ni} / \text{SLG}$</tex>, showed a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2. 2 6 \%}$</tex>, with an open-circuit voltage (Voc) of 1.00 V, short-circuit current density (Jsc) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$23.58 ~\text{mA} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex>, and a fill factor (FF) of 51.77 %. Through optimization, we found that increasing the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{S n S}_{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> donor density beyond the absorber's acceptor level improved energy band alignment and charge separation, raising built-in potential (VB) to 1.27 V. Additionally, lowering the defect density helped reduce interfacial recombination, and optimizing the buffer thickness (up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$140 ~\text{nm})$</tex> contributed to better light absorption and carrier generation. These improvements led to a significantly higher PCE of 17.06 %, with Voc of 1.11 V, Jsc of 24.25 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mA} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex>, and FF of 62.84 %. Overall, this study demonstrates the promise of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{BaHfSe}_{3}$</tex> as a lead-free absorber and identifies <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{S n S}_{\mathbf{2}}$</tex> as an efficient and sustainable buffer material for next-generation thin-film solar cells.

title: Model Predictive Control with State Observer for DC Microgrid Voltage Regulation Using a Bidirectional Sepic/Zeta Battery Interface
authors: Jhoan A. Montenegro-Oviedo, Jesus D. Vasquez-Plaza, Carlos A. Ramos-Paja, Fabio Andrade Rengifo, Niranjan Bhujel
abstract: This paper presents a control strategy for DC bus voltage regulation in microgrids using a bidirectional Sepic/Zeta converter interfacing a battery system. The proposed approach integrates a Kalman filter-based state observer and a nonlinear Model Predictive Control (MPC) algorithm implemented using the CasADi optimization framework. The observer estimates internal converter states using only DC bus and battery voltage measurements, reducing sensor requirements without compromising control accuracy. Unlike previous works based on LQG/LQI control and linearized models, the proposed MPC formulation uses the full nonlinear averaged model of the converter to achieve improved transient response, and to ensure robustness under a wide range of operating conditions. Simulation results under different voltage conversion modes (buck, boost, and unitary gain) demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed method when compared with classical LQG strategies. Moreover, the use of CasADi toolbox enables symbolic modeling and automatic differentiation, facilitating future deployment in real-time embedded platforms.

title: Combined Bound Tightening on McCormick Relaxations of AC Optimal Power Flow
authors: Xiangxin An, Constance Crozier, Santanu S. Dey, Santiago Grijalva
abstract: This paper investigates the effectiveness of combining valid inequalities and feasibility-based bound tightening (FBBT) to strengthen linear programming (LP) relaxations for the AC Optimal Power Flow (ACOPF) problem. We focus on reformulations using McCormick envelopes applied to the Second-Order Conic Programming (SOCP) relaxation of ACOPF. Several classes of valid inequalities, including ring cuts, reverse cone envelopes, and arctangent envelopes, are integrated into the relaxation. A combined tightening framework is proposed, beginning with bound tightening via SOCP relaxations, followed by adding valid inequalities and successive refinement of the McCormick envelopes with FBBT. Experimental results show that integrating arctangent envelopes with FBBT yields a tighter and more scalable relaxation. This approach significantly reduces the average SOCP gap from 8.14% to 4.11%, thereby improving the practical performance of convex relaxations for ACOPF.

title: Scalable Unit Commitment for Large Power Grids: Relaxation, Tightening, and GPU-Based Solvers Evaluation
authors: Hussein Sharadga, Javad Mohammadi
abstract: This paper introduces a set of relaxation and tightening techniques to enhance the computational efficiency of unit commitment optimization in large-scale power grids. The computational complexity of this problem stems from binary decision variables, millions of optimization variables, and the need for multi-period scheduling. To address these challenges, we propose methods such as constraint relaxation, tightened power bounds, tighter cost-block formulations, and lazy constraint techniques. In addition, GPU-based optimization methods were tested to evaluate their potential for accelerating computation. Results demonstrate significant computational speedups while preserving solution quality, highlighting the practical applicability of these methods for real-world power grid operations.

title: A New Online Fault Detection Mechanism for Neural Network Applications
authors: Luca De Paola, Giuseppe Esposito, Juan-David Guerrero-Balaguera, Matteo Sonza Reorda
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel strategy for detecting hardware-induced misbehaviors during the execution of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). The fault detection strategy relies on an auxiliary lightweight Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) acting on the outputs of the first layer of the monitored CNN as an early exit instrument, and enabling the detection of faults possibly affecting the CNN computations. Specifically, the outcomes of the CNN and the MLP are compared across a sequence of observations (observation window), calculating the level of agreement between them. As a result, an incorrect prediction from a CNN caused by a hardware fault can be identified when the agreement drops below a set threshold. This mechanism was implemented and evaluated using a set of representative CNNs and datasets. The results showed that the system can detect between 78.60% to 97.79% of faults, depending on the CNN and the dataset.

title: A Framework for the Development of Sustainable Smart Services for the Countryside
authors: Francesco Blefari, Gabriele D’Angelo, Stefano Ferretti, Angelo Furfaro, Paolo Giaccone, Moreno Marzolla, Francesco Aurelio Pironti, Luca Serena
abstract: The recent spread of smart city technologies has enabled the development of smart services and applications for citizens living in urban areas. However, deploying similar services sustainably in decentralized zones is challenging, primarily due to the lack of a stable communication infrastructure.
