title: Safe Sliding Mode Control in Position for Double Integrator Systems
authors: Marco A. Gomez, Christopher D. Cruz-Ancona
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: We address the problem of robust safety control design for double integrator systems. We show that, when the constraints are defined only on position states, it is possible to construct a safe sliding domain from the dynamic of a simple integrator that is already safe. On this domain, the closed-loop trajectories remain robust and safe against uncertainties and disturbances. Furthermore, we design a controller gain that guarantees convergence to the safe sliding domain while avoiding the given unsafe set. The concept is initially developed for first-order sliding mode and is subsequently generalized to an adaptive framework, ensuring that trajectories remain confined to a predefined vicinity of the sliding domain, outside the unsafe region.

title: A compact QRNG for IoT applications
authors: Nicola Massari, Luca Parmesan, Alessandro Tontini
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: The present paper describes a new QRNG based on the arrival time of photons. The device needs an external light source to fully control the generation of random bit. This allows to ensure an almost constant data rate, regardless possible environmental parameter variations, and a minimization of the contribution of other unwanted sources of noise (DCR). To increase the output rate, the QRNG is split up into several e lementary generators organized in an array working simultaneously. Moreover, an embedded post-processing block allows to improve the output entropy for a high quality random sequence. The device, now under test, has been designed in a standard 150nm CMOS technology. Preliminary results showed an average activity of about 30 Mbps (raw data).

title: Cybersecurity in Robotic Telesurgery: Securing Robot-Console Communications for Safe Remote Surgery
authors: Yassine Gounine, Pr. Khalid Minaoui, Pr. Mohamed Elaroussi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Robotic telesurgery stands as one of healthcare's most promising frontiers, offering the remarkable possibility for expert surgeons to perform intricate procedures on patients separated by thousands of kilometers. Yet this revolutionary leap forward brings with it unprecedented cybersecurity challenges that could directly jeopardize patient safety and surgical success. Our research delves into what we term the “Security-Performance-Reliability Trilemma”—a complex balancing act between implementing robust security measures, maintaining ultra-low latency performance, and ensuring unwavering system reliability. We present an innovative multi-layered defense framework that seamlessly integrates lightweight cryptographic protocols with AI-driven intrusion detection systems, while harnessing cutting-edge technologies like 5G network slicing and blockchain authentication. This comprehensive approach ensures compliance with IEC 80001-1 standards without compromising the stringent real-time requirements that make safe surgical procedures possible. Through rigorous experimental validation, our framework demonstrates an impressive 99.4% attack detection accuracy while introducing less than 12% performance overhead, maintaining haptic feedback latency below 1ms and achieving 99.98% system availability.

title: Design of a fusion scheme for linear analysis methods under differences in grouped cipher structures
authors: Mengjie Tian, Jiafeng Zhou, Zhixing Qin, Bo Liu, Laifeng Lu, Hongmin Liu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: As a fundamental cryptanalysis method, linear cryptanalysis (LCA) has undergone significant advancements since its introduction in 1993, with numerous hybrid approaches emerging to enhance its effectiveness. This paper systematically reviews the state-of-the-art integration of LCA with other cryptanalytic techniques, particularly focusing on its combination with differential cryptanalysis to improve attack efficiency. Furthermore, we investigate the application of automated search tools—such as MILP, SAT/SMT, and constraint programming (CP)—to optimize linear approximations in modern cryptographic algorithms. By transforming the search for optimal linear characteristics into mathematical constraint problems, these methods address the challenge of manual trail analysis and provide efficient solutions. We summarize current research progress in this area and outline future research directions. Additionally, we examine the integration of LCA with other analytical techniques, including linear fault analysis, integral cryptanalysis, and linear algebraic methods. Finally, we propose a framework for selecting optimal attack strategies based on the structural properties of block ciphers, offering valuable insights for enhancing resistance against linear cryptanalysis. This work not only consolidates existing methodologies but also provides a structured reference for advancing hybrid cryptanalytic approaches.

title: Real-Time Controller HIL Simulation for Motor Starting Studies
authors: Stan R. Simms, Gabriel Braga, Thomas A. Farr
abstract: In this paper a virtual plant is combined with the hardware controllers of a reduced voltage soft-starter and adjustable frequency motor drive to simulate motor starting interactions. During across the line motor starts, as well as reduced voltage starting, a sag condition typically occurs as the shaft comes up to full speed. In industrial power systems adjacent loads such as adjustable frequency motor drives may be impacted by this transient disturbance. The situation can be further aggravated when the common bus is fed from a back-up diesel-generator set. Using a real-time controller hardware-in-the-loop simulator this starting condition will be examined. The goal is to determine if the power flow remains in the safe operating area of the diesel-generator set and capture how the adjustable frequency drive’s hardware controller reacts to the disturbance. Multiple starting scenarios are examined including reduced voltage primary reactor starting, reduced voltage solid-state soft-starter starting, and the number of parallel generators to determine how the adjustable frequency drive already operating a motor responds.

title: Covert Distribution Load Tripping Attacks
authors: Betelihem Kebede Ashebo, Samuel Talkington, Saman Zonouz, Daniel K. Molzahn
abstract: The increasing integration of distributed energy resources (DERs), particularly solar photovoltaic (PV) systems, has introduced new cybersecurity challenges in distribution networks. This paper presents a data-driven attack model that examines how an adversary can exploit direct load control (DLC) mechanisms to selectively disconnect downstream loads during periods of high solar generation. Such targeted load tripping forces excess PV output to flow back toward the substation transformer, potentially causing power imbalances and transformer overloading. We model both PV output and load demand as multivariate Gaussian distributions to capture their inherent temporal and spatial uncertainties. A probabilistic power imbalance metric is defined to quantify the extent of reverse flow under compromised conditions. To identify the most impactful combinations of load disconnections and timing, we employ a multi-armed bandit approach based on the Upper Confidence Bound (UCB) algorithm. Simulation results demonstrate the feasibility and effectiveness of the attack strategy under realistic variability in solar output and demand.

title: NanoRULNet: An Efficient and Interpretable Deep Learning Framework for Remaining Useful Life Prediction in Smart Manufacturing
authors: Aman Sharma, Kwan Yong Sim, Sivachandran Chandrasekaran
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Accurate Remaining Useful Life (RUL) prediction plays a pivotal role in enabling Predictive Maintenance (PdM) for industrial machinery, reducing unplanned downtime and optimizing operational efficiency. This research presents NanoRULNet, a lightweight and interpretable deep learning framework designed for real-time RUL estimation in edge-enabled PdM environments. NanoRULNet integrates statistical pooling, bidirectional gated recurrent units (Bi-GRU), and a compact Transformer encoder to achieve high accuracy with low computational overhead. This research evaluates the model on all four subsets of the C-MAPSS dataset (FD001-FD004), achieving Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) values of 35.91, 37.08, 102.07, and 37.79, respectively. The corresponding Mean Absolute Errors (MAE) range from 34.45 to 90.86, with CalibDiff ranging from 31.77 to 89.51. Despite its strong performance, NanoRULNet maintains an ultra-low inference latency and parameter count, making it well-suited for real-time deployment in constrained environments, especially in low-powered edge devices. To further enhance interpretability, Integrated Gradient (IG) was applied on selected FD001 samples, providing transparent insight into the model's decision-making process and reinforcing the model's reliability for high-stakes industrial applications.

title: A Negative Feed-Forward Technique to Recover Bioelectric Signals Contaminated by Artifacts
authors: Rabin Raut, Kwabena Asamoah
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Bioelectric signals, such as EEG, ECG, have been routinely processed in the past using various numerical algorithms and extensive computing resources. In this article we are proposing a technique for the same purpose, using analog circuits and system components. In this work a proof of concept with EEG signals is presented. Instead of collecting artifact signals data by adaptive filtering we isolated the artifact signals from the intended signals using band stop filtering. One could then apply the remaining (i.e., the artifact) signal in a negative feed-forward loop to the overall mixture, to recover the intended signal.

title: Air Quality Checking and Tracking for Environmental Compliance: An IoT-based Air Quality Monitoring System
authors: Leonnel dela Paz de Mesa, Ivan Kenneth Arevalo Alvarez, Brian Xavier del Rio Hipolito, Jason Rey Buce Miran, Reiner Gabrielle Requina Valdez
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: This study presents ACHTECO (Air Quality Checking and Tracking for Environmental Compliance), an IoT-based air quality monitoring system developed to address the lack of real-time air quality data in emerging cities, with a focus on Cabuyao City. Despite mandates from the Philippine Clean Air Act of 1999, local implementation has been hindered by budgetary, logistical, and siting challenges, as noted by the Department of Environment and Natural Resources – Air Quality Management Section and the City Environment and Natural Resources Office (CENRO) Cabuyao. ACHTECO is designed to fill this gap by continuously monitoring and reporting air quality levels across selected locations. The system detects key environmental indicators including Carbon Monoxide (CO), Carbon Dioxide (CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), Sulfur Dioxide (SO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), Nitrogen Dioxide (NO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>), temperature, and humidity. Data is transmitted to a centralized database and visualized through a dedicated web application, enabling efficient and transparent reporting. Developed using iterative testing methodologies such as self-calibration, third-party validation, stress testing, unit testing, and user acceptance testing, ACHTECO demonstrated high accuracy and reliability. Positive feedback from local stakeholders emphasized its potential to enhance local enforcement of environmental policies. Ultimately, ACHTECO provides a scalable and effective solution for real-time air quality monitoring, empowering local governments with critical data to promote public health and environmental compliance.

title: Decentralized Federated Learning for Distributed Energy Resources and Networks
authors: Muhammad Hamza Karim, Sriram Prabhakara Rao, Prakash Ranganathan
abstract: Distributed Energy Resources (DER) and related assets, such as solar photovoltaics (PV), energy storage systems (ESS), and electric vehicles (EVs), generate large volumes of sensitive operational data that challenge traditional centralized machine learning (ML) approaches due to privacy, bandwidth, and scalability concerns. This paper reviews federated learning (FL) as a decentralized solution that keeps data local while collaboratively training models across DER assets. We compare a range of key FL algorithms, examining their ability to handle non-independent and identically distributed (non-IID) data, fairness, robustness, and communication efficiency. The review also covers various FL architectures, including serverless frameworks that demonstrate notable performance improvements. We highlight practical FL applications in DERs, including anomaly detection and load forecasting, and discuss real-world challenges such as data heterogeneity, security vulnerabilities, and communication bottlenecks.

title: A Low-Power Analog Integrated Decision Tree Classifier Architecture for Apnea-Ecg Detection
authors: Vassilis Alimisis, Konstantinos Cheliotis, Anna Mylona, Vasileios Moustakas, Paul P. Sotiriadis
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This work presents a low-power analog integrated decision tree classifier for real-time Apnea-Ecg detection. The design achieves exceptionally low power consumption of 891 nW and a classification speed of 620K inferences per second by utilizing sub-threshold analog circuitry, including a Re-Lu circuit, Sigmoid function circuit, current comparators and a tunable current mirror. The classifier is implemented using the TSMC 90 nm CMOS process. When tested on a dataset representative of electrocardiogram signals for apnea, it consistently demonstrated robust performance across variations in process, voltage, and temperature, achieving an average accuracy of 93.16%. It is also tested using Monte Carlo analysis, and its behavior proved to be robust. The model is trained in software and compared with literature related implementations. This approach enables efficient, edge-based, real-time classification for biomedical applications, particularly in the detection of apnea-ECG.

title: A Reconfigurable Multiview CNN for Breast Tumor Classification Using Intra- and Peritumoral Regions
authors: W. Gómez-Flores, W. C. A. Pereira
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: This study introduces a reconfigurable multiview convolutional neural network (CNN) for tumor classification in mammography and breast ultrasound images. The model processes intra- and peritumoral regions of interest through two parallel CNN branches, merging deep feature maps at various levels of abstraction using switchable fusion blocks. This flexibility enables the identification of an adequate configuration for improved classification performance. Five configurations are tested by incrementally activating the number of fusion blocks. The results indicate that employing a single fusion block, which combines feature maps from the final stages of both branches, is sufficient to achieve high classification accuracy. Specifically, this configuration yields a sensitivity of 0.856, a specificity of 0.906, and an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.955 for mammography. For breast ultrasound, this configuration achieves a sensitivity of 0.813, a specificity of 0.904, and an AUC of 0.933. These findings demonstrate that reconfiguring the multiview CNN architecture helps determine the simplest architecture that enhances breast tumor classification performance.

title: From Ports to Protocols: A Survey on Cyber Threats in Energy Storage Platforms for Microgrids
authors: Khandaker Akramul Haque, Mohamed Massaoudi, Katherine R. Davis, Mahmoud Kabalan, Hassan Salamy
abstract: Energy storage control systems (ESCS) equipped with integrated energy storage platforms (IESPs) serve as vital components in modern microgrids and distributed energy systems. However, these systems also inherit a range of vulnerabilities common to industrial control systems (ICS), rendering them susceptible to cyber threats. This paper investigates the key cybersecurity weaknesses in platforms, including open or misconfigured ports, weak or default credentials, insecure communication protocols, and known software vulnerabilities. Drawing on recent real-world advisories and documented CVEs, we highlight how these flaws may be exploited to compromise operational integrity, cause grid instability, or enable lateral attacks within critical infrastructure networks. The findings underscore the urgency of adopting robust defense-in-depth strategies and secure configurations for proactive vulnerability management of IESPs.

title: Improved Robot Path Planning Integrating Bidirectional Alternating JPS and SA Algorithms
authors: Yang Xu, Guojun Chen, Baocheng Yu, Wenxia Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: To address the issues of excessive waypoints and longer path lengths in the traditional Jump Point Search (JPS) algorithm for robot path planning, this paper introduces the Simulated Annealing (SA) algorithm and proposes an integrated approach, the Integration of Bidirectional Alternating JPS and SA Algorithms (SA-JPS), to ensure global path optimality. The SA-JPS algorithm optimizes the jump point search strategy, refines the path cost function, and incorporates random perturbations to eliminate redundant points and reduce path length. This algorithm utilizes a bidirectional alternating JPS algorithm to rapidly generate an initial collision-free path in a structured grid map, thereby reducing search time through a bidirectional search strategy. The introduction of random perturbations and the annealing strategy from the simulated annealing algorithm helps to minimize redundant points in the path and prevent it from converging to a local optimum. In comparative experiments against the JPS algorithm, the algorithm proposed in this paper reduced the average path length by 10.1% and the average path point count by 67.7% during the path search process. This study validates the feasibility of an improved path planning method that fuses the Bidirectional Alternating JPS and Simulated Annealing algorithms, offering a novel solution for path planning with high smoothness and shorter path lengths.

title: A Proximal Multi-Objective Optimization Method for Incorporation of Polygenic Breeding Values in Genomic Prediction
authors: Patrik Waldmann, Yuhua Fan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Biology and Bioinformatics
abstract: Traditional quantitative genetics rely on known pedigrees for estimating polygenic breeding values and variance components. With the advent of high-throughput sequencing, estimation of empirical relationships between individuals have become feasible. The single-step genomic BLUP procedure integrates polygenic and genomic information but requires intricate pedigree connections, leading to computationally demanding matrix operations. Here, we propose DYpREG, a flexible proximal operator multi-objective regularization method. DYpREG is a splitting algorithm that accommodates two distinct loss functions and a regularization function that can be chosen as LASSO, ridge regression (RR) or elastic net (EN). Notably, it incorporates pre-calculated breeding values without the need for extensive relationship matrix computations. Evaluated on two traits with different heritabilities from mice and pig, DYpREG with RR regularizer showed the best predictive performance compared to DYpREG with LASSO and EN regularizers as well as to all methods lacking polygenic information. The mean squared error (MSE) reduction was notable for both mice traits (1.5% and 24.77%) and both pig traits (2.8% and 2.1%). Comparative analyses with Bayesian reproducing kernel Hilbert space (RKHS) and spike-and-slab (BayesC) regression also revealed consistent improvements. Hence, DYpREG effectively integrates polygenic information, enhancing prediction accuracy in genomic evaluations.

authors: Patricia Da Silva Souza, Sonia Maria Malmonge, Nasser Ali Daghastanli, Patricia A. Ana
publish: 2025 SBFoton International Optics and Photonics Conference (SBFoton IOPC)
abstract: This study evaluated the effect of UVC radiation, associated or not with riboflavin, on the crosslink of type-B gelatin, aimed at biomedical applications. UVC radiation alone was a more promising alternative to the traditional chemical method to promote this effect.

title: Causality-based Visual Analytics of Sentiment Contagion in Social Media Topics_supp1-3633839.mp4
authors: Renzhong Li
abstract: Sentiment contagion occurs when attitudes toward one topic are influenced by attitudes toward others. Detecting and understanding this phenomenon is essential for analyzing topic evolution and informing social policies. Prior research has developed models to simulate the contagion process through hypothesis testing and has visualized user–topic correlations to aid comprehension. Nevertheless, the vast volume of topics and the complex interrelationships on social media present two key challenges: (1) efficient construction of large-scale sentiment contagion networks, and (2) in-depth explorations of these networks. To address these challenges, we introduce a causality-based framework that efficiently constructs and explains sentiment contagion. We further propose a map-like visualization technique that encodes time using a horizontal axis, enabling efficient visualization of causality-based sentiment flow while maintaining scalability through limitless spatial segmentation. Based on the visualization, we develop CausalMap, a system that supports analysts in tracing sentiment contagion pathways and assessing the influence of different demographic groups. Furthermore, we conduct comprehensive evaluations——including two use cases, a task-based user study, an expert interview, and an algorithm evaluation——to validate the usability and effectiveness of our approach.

title: MoARNN-AM: Multi-Objective Automated Recurrent Neural Network with Attention Mechanism for Cyber-Attack Detection of UAV
authors: Kang-Di Lu, Bing-Xu Zhang, Yong Xu, Ying Shen, Zheng-Guang Wu
abstract: As one of consumer unmanned electronic systems, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) have become ubiquitous in daily life, essential for numerous tasks, and will play a pivotal role in future wireless networks and Internet-of-Things. However, their widespread adoption and connectivity make them vulnerable to various cyber threats. Although deep learning-based attack detection models offer promising solutions for enhancing UAV network security, these models typically rely on manual trial-and-error approaches for determining hyper-parameters and neural architectures, resulting in limited generalization capability and often overlooking model lightweightness. To address these limitations, this paper proposes an innovative automated multi-objective recurrent neural network (RNN) with attention mechanism, called MoARNN-AM, to effectively solve attack detection problems in UAV systems. In MoARNN-AM, we consider six typical RNN variants and three widely-used attention mechanisms as core classification models for feature extraction and data learning of UAV systems. First, an effective encoding mechanism is developed to represent different combinations along with their corresponding hyper-parameters and neural architectures. Subsequently, considering both attack detection performance and model lightweightness as two objectives, we elaborately design an efficient non-dominated sorting genetic algorithm II (NSGA-II)-based evolutionary operation to evolve various combinations with their associated hyper-parameters and neural architectures for discovering optimized RNN with attention mechanism model. The performance of the proposed MoARNN-AM method is validated using two datasets, i.e., UAV-INDD dataset and WSN-DS dataset collected from different UAV systems. Experimental results demonstrate that MoARNN-AM outperforms five state-of-the-art manually designed attack detection models in terms of accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score metrics while maintaining superior model lightweightness.

title: Neural Empathy-Aware Behavior Trees Meets Knowledge Graphs for Affective Human-AI Teaming
authors: Glenda Amaral, Stefania Costantini, Giovanni De Gasperis, Lorenzo De Lauretis, Pierangelo Dell'Acqua, Giancarlo Guizzardi, Francesco Gullo, Andrea Rafanelli
abstract: We propose a novel architecture for agents to be employed in Human-AI Teaming in various, even critical, domains. The architecture is based on affective computing, empathy, and Theory of Mind (ToM) and uses a description of the user profile and the operational, professional, and ethical requirements of the domain in which the agent operates. Moreover, it encompasses: a Knowledge Graph (KG), which is aimed at representing the various kinds of knowledge of the scenario at hand; a Behavior Tree (BT) enhanced with empathy-aware capabilities; a neural component, which elaborates sensor input from devices that monitor the user and input from the KG. The enhanced BT is the component that interacts with the user, making actions or providing suggestions. It also returns feedback to the KG to update it based on user experience. This two-way interaction between KG and BT is a major novelty of our work. As further contributions, we showcase an application of the proposed architecture on a driver co-pilot scenario and provide an early stage implementation of our architecture, mainly based on a Prolog implementation of the BT component.

title: Prescribed Time Prescribed Performance Control for Direct-Drive Wave Energy Conversion System
authors: Shizhan Dong, Zhongqiang Wu
abstract: To solve the problem of maximum power point tracking control of a wave energy conversion system (WECs), a prescribed time prescribed performance controller is designed. The mathematical model of direct-driven WECs considering actuator fault, internal parameter variations, and external perturbations is established. A prescribed time prescribed performance controller based on an adaptive sliding mode observer is proposed. The designed controller has the following three advantages: 1) The actual convergence time is only prescribed by a design parameter and is independent of the initial condition, and the convergence speed of the system is improved. 2) The adaptive sliding mode observer is designed to estimate the lumped uncertainties within a prescribed time and to compensate for them in the controller; it needn't to predict the upper bound of the derivative of lumped uncertainties, and the robustness of the system is improved. 3) By integrating a new asymmetric prescribed performance function with a prescribed time function, where the initial error has been incorporated into the envelope function, the problem of the initial error exceeding prescribed boundaries is resolved, and system transient performance is improved. Compared with conventional proportional-integral control and prescribed performance control, the designed controller has stronger robustness and faster response.

title: RAP: Role-Aware Joint Prediction and Planning in Autonomous Driving
authors: Xiaolong Tang, Meina Kan, Shiguang Shan, Xilin Chen
abstract: Planning the trajectory for an autonomous vehicle (AV) requires considering both the AV's objectives and the behaviors of surrounding agents, which interact in a dynamic process. Joint prediction and planning (JPP) methods have been proposed to model this bidirectional interaction and generate compatible joint futures. However, existing methods often overlook the fundamental differences between the two tasks and treat them almost identically, thus limiting the effect of planning. In this work, we revisit JPP from a role-aware perspective and identify three inherent asymmetries between prediction and planning: information, objective, and feedback. Based on these insights, we propose the Role-Aware Joint Prediction and Planning (RAP) framework, which explicitly differentiates the treatment of the ego vehicle and surrounding agents through three lightweight asymmetric designs. Specifically, RAP introduces a route–identity token pairing mechanism for route-aware yet agent-agnostic conditioning, ego-only vectorized auxiliary losses for safety-constrained planning, and dropout and perturbation applied to the ego's history and kinematic state to improve closed-loop robustness. Comprehensive experiments on the nuPlan benchmark demonstrate that RAP achieves state-of the-art performance on both open-loop and closed-loop metrics, validating the effectiveness of asymmetric modeling in unified prediction and planning.

title: Adaptive Change Detection in Partially Observable Dynamic Networks
authors: Jie Guo, Haijie Xu, Chen Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Knowledge and Data Engineering
abstract: Sequential change detection in high-dimensional dynamic networks has attracted growing attention in modern applications. A major challenge is that as network scale increases, limited sensing resources make it difficult to fully observe links at each time point, resulting in partial observability and complicating detection. To tackle this, we propose a Latent Bi-Transit Network (LBTN) that learns unobserved edge formation, latent node states, and the evolution mechanisms of dynamic networks. Based on LBTN, we design a variational Bayesian method to infer sparse node-level changes and employ a likelihood ratio test as the detection statistic. By further formulating the statistic as the reward function of a combinatorial multi-armed bandit (CMAB) problem, we develop a Thompson sampling strategy to adaptively select edges for observation, balancing exploration and exploitation. Comprehensive simulations and real-world experiments show that our method consistently outperforms existing baselines and its variants across diverse scenarios.

title: An Analytical Model of Mismatch Dominance Crossover in High-Speed Flash ADC Cores
authors: Shatadal Chatterjee, Jitumani Sarma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Systems
abstract: The flash analog-to-digital converters (ADCs), essential for high-speed embedded systems, face inherent linearity constraints due to device mismatch in the resistor ladder and comparator stages. While individual analytical models exist for these mismatch sources, designers rely on Monte Carlo simulations to evaluate the combined errors. This brief introduces a unified analytical framework with closed-form expressions that capture both mismatch sources, enabling efficient estimation of root mean square (rms) integral nonlinearity/differential nonlinearity (INL/DNL). Validated against circuit simulations, the model achieves a mean absolute error (MAE) of 2.71% (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\boldsymbol {\sigma _{\textbf {DNL}}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>) and 2.51% (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\sigma _{\text {INL}}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>), and the maximum absolute error (MaxE) remains within 5.44%. This predictive capability guides high-yield, precision, power, and area (PPA)-optimized system-on-chip (SoC) design, enabling over <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$3{\times }$</tex-math> </inline-formula> silicon area reduction through application-specific optimization.

title: An Efficient Multi-Level and Cross-Domain Conditional Anonymous Authentication Scheme in V2G
authors: Jing-yi Yang, Run-hua Shi, Yu Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dependable and Secure Computing
abstract: In vehicle to grid (V2G), electric vehicles face the risk of privacy leakage when performing cross-domain authentication because of the openness and instability of mobile network. Although the existing conditional anonymous authentication schemes can both protect the vehicles' anonymity and trace the vehicles' real identity in case of malicious behaviors, the commonly used group signature and ring signature methods have limitations, such as high costs. Therefore, how to effectively apply conditional anonymous authentication in the V2G cross domain scenario to meet the high real-time requirements of V2G has become a key challenge. To address this challenge, we propose innovatively an efficient multi-level and cross-domain conditional anonymous authentication scheme in V2G. The scheme designs a unique multi-level architecture. The first level faces grid servers and uses the group signature whose group key is generated based on the Chinese Remainder Theorem for grid servers, and the second level faces vehicles and uses the proxy signature to generate conditional anonymous cross-domain signatures for vehicles. To further improve efficiency, our scheme also uses the online/offline signature. Thus, our scheme has less computational, communication, and storage costs compared to existing schemes. Through formal security model and analysis, the security of the proposed scheme is shown.

title: Fuzzy Logic-based PMDC Motor Speed Control
authors: Yasha Pirani, Hossein Salehfar, Jayandra Sai Kumaran, Prakash Ranganathan
abstract: This paper investigates the performance of Fuzzy Logic-based controllers in regulating the speed of Permanent Magnet DC (PMDC) motors, comparing them against conventional Proportional and PI controllers. Four control strategies - Proportional, PI, P-FLC, and PI-FLC - are implemented and evaluated under varying speed references and load disturbances. Simulation results show that Fuzzy Logic-based controllers outperform their conventional counterparts, with P-FLC and PI-FLC achieving better rise times, settling times, and disturbance rejection. Notably, P-FLC yields the best overall performance in three out of five scenarios. These results support the integration of Fuzzy Logic into PMDC motor control systems to improve precision, adaptability, and robustness.

title: Arabic Handwriting Recognition at Line-Level: A Comprehensive Review and Hybrid Modeling Strategy*
authors: Omar Arjafellah, Yousfi Abdellah, Azhar Hadmi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Arabic Handwriting Recognition (AHR) constitutes a challenging research problem primarily due to the cursive form of the script, the context-dependent character shape variations, and high inter-writer variability. We introduce a comprehensive review of recent progress on AHR, with a special emphasis on line-level recognition, where word- and character-level intricacies are folded into a smooth sequence. We discuss the development of AHR methods, from early segmentation-based pipelines to deep learning strategies with CNNs, RNNs, and, more recently, Transformer-based architectures. To illustrate the state of the art, we review the current systems, compare their architectures and performance, as well as their advantages and limitations. Motivated by these observations, in this work, we propose our ongoing work: a hybrid CNN-Transformer model which can leverage CNNs' strength in spatial feature extraction, and the long-range context modeling power of Transformers. In this, we try to increase the recognition accuracy and efficiency especially for real-life line-level handwriting situations.

title: Sensitivity Analysis of Power Flow Solution in Distribution Network Using Differentiable Convex Programming
authors: Salim Kameshki, Atefeh Alirezazadeh, Hieu T. Nguyen
abstract: The increasing integration of renewable energy sources introduces significant uncertainty in distribution networks, necessitating advanced tools for assessing system flexibility. This paper presents a differentiable optimization-based framework for quantifying flexibility in distribution systems through implicit sensitivity analysis. By formulating the Optimal Power Flow (OPF) problem using a convexified Branch Flow Model (BFM), we enable gradient computation via the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions and implicit differentiation. These gradients provide insight into how active power variations impact system variables such as branch flows and bus voltages. The proposed method constructs flexibility envelopes that bound system responses with a specified confidence level, enabling real-time evaluation of network adaptability under uncertainty. Simulation results on the IEEE 15-bus, 33-bus, and 141-bus systems demonstrate the accuracy and interpretability of the sensitivity-based estimation, highlighting its potential for planning and operational decision-making in power distribution systems across networks of varying sizes and complexities.

title: Electricity Price-Aware Scheduling of Data Center Cooling
authors: Arash Khojaste, Jonathan Pearce, Golbon Zakeri, Yuanrui Sang
abstract: Data centers are becoming a major consumer of electricity on the grid, with cooling accounting for about 40% of that energy. As electricity prices vary throughout the day and year, there is a need for cooling strategies that adapt to these fluctuations to reduce data center cooling costs. In this paper, we present a model for electricity price-aware cooling scheduling using a Markov Decision Process (MDP) framework to reliably estimate the cooling system’s operational costs and facilitate investment-phase decision-making. We utilize Quantile Fourier Regression (QFR) fits to classify electricity prices into different regimes while capturing both daily and seasonal patterns. We simulate 14 years of operation using historical real-time electricity price and outdoor temperature data, and compare our model against heuristic baselines. The results demonstrate that our approach consistently achieves lower cooling costs. This model is useful for grid operators interested in demand response programs and data center investors looking to make investment decisions.

title: Methodologies in Game Theory for Optimizing Collaboration in Microservices
authors: Mouhcine Boutinzer, Hatim Guermah
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: This article presents a literature review on the implementation and optimization of collaborative strategies in microservices architectures, with a focus on game theory and agent-based models approaches. As microservices systems become increasingly complex, effective collaboration between services is critical for performance and scalability. We explore how game-theoretic concepts and agent-based modeling have been applied to improve decision making, coordination between the microservices, and resource allocation in distributed environments. The review highlights key approaches, compares methodologies, and identifies gaps in current research to suggest directions for future work.

title: Low-power Asynchronous Comparator with Current Feedback for Emerging-Memory-based Computing
authors: Paolo Gibertini, Erika Covi
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper presents a low-power asynchronous comparator specifically designed for integration with emerging memory devices in analog hardware accelerators for spiking neural networks. The comparator was originally designed to address the stringent requirements of ferroelectric-based neurons, which demand asynchronous operation, ultra-low static power consumption, fast switching capabilities, and minimal input capacitance to avoid perturbation of neural dynamics. The proposed design employs current feedback techniques integrated into an operational transconductance amplifier (OTA) architecture, enabling subthreshold operation with tail currents in the order of pA while providing high current drive capability during transitions. The comparator achieves high energy efficiency with an average static power consumption of 47 pW and dynamic energy consumption of 3 fJ per operation. Statistical analysis on 360 circuits across 180 dies demonstrates robust performance characteristics. The measured performance establishes new benchmarks for asynchronous comparators in neuromorphic applications, demonstrating six orders of magnitude improvement in static power consumption compared to existing static comparator designs.

title: Development of Membranes Based on Recycled Polyethylene Terephthalate (PET) Functionalized with ZNO/GO for the Removal of Methylene Blue by Adsorption
authors: Rocío M. Sánchez-Albores, Roliber Escobar-Velazquez, Adillanet R. Farelo Toledo, Odín Reyes-Vallejo, E.F. Vázquez-Vázquez, C.A Meza- Avendaño, H.H Torres-Ventura, Wilber Montejo-López
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: The development of sustainable and low-cost materials for water treatment is a key priority in environmental research. In this study, membranes based on recycled polyethylene terephthalate (rPET) functionalized with a zinc oxide and graphene oxide (ZnO/GO) nanocomposite were synthesized for the removal of methylene blue via adsorption. The membranes were fabricated using a phenol-based fusion-precipitation process, combining rPET, polyethylene glycol (PEG), and ZnO/GO. Characterization techniques including FTIR, XRD, EDS, and FESEM confirmed the effective incorporation of the nanocomposite into the polymer matrix, as evidenced by FTIR (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Zn}-\mathrm{O}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{C}=\mathrm{C}$</tex> bands) and EDS (Zn <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=24.87 \text{wt} \%$</tex>), together with a morphological transition toward porous, sponge-like structures. Adsorption experiments showed that the functionalized membrane reached a cumulative removal efficiency of 93.70% after nine reuse cycles (15 mL at 10 ppm), with contact times of only 10 minutes per cycle. Although the nonfunctionalized membrane achieved a slightly higher total removal (98.84 %), it required a much longer contact time (120 min) and exhibited greater fouling. These results indicate that rPET/ZnO/GO membranes provide a faster, reusable, and more stable alternative for dye-contaminated wastewater treatment, aligning with circular economy and sustainable material development principles.

title: Comparitive Analysis of Bulk-Driven and Gate-Driven Self-Cascode OTA in Subthreshold MOS
authors: Salvatore Pennisi, Marco Privitera, Muhammad Omer Shah
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper presents a comparative analysis of two ultra-low-power, two-stage operational transconductance amplifiers (OTAs) designed for subthreshold MOS operation and employing a self-cascode topology to achieve very high DC gain. The first OTA uses a bulk-driven (BD) input stage and operates with a 400-mV supply, while the second adopts a gate-driven (GD) approach, incorporating an additional tail-current transistor to bias the differential pair, and thus requires a 500mV supply. Analytical modeling and simulation results are used to assess the trade-offs between the two architectures in terms of main performance parameters. In particular, the expected disadvantages in dc gain and gain-bandwidth for BD OTAs are found to be less severe than typically assumed, while their smaller required compensation capacitor enables improved Slew Rate. Noise performance remains a major drawback.

title: Simulation-Based Real-Time Object Detection and Autonomous Vehicle Tracking in UAVs Using YOLOv13 and DeepSORT Within ROS 2 Framework
authors: Murat Bakirci
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: This study presents the development of a fully integrated, simulation-based UAV system designed for automated object detection, multi-target tracking, and autonomous flight control in visually dynamic environments. Leveraging deep learning and real-time robotics frameworks, the system combines a scene-specific YOLOv8n model for object detection, the DeepSORT algorithm for identity-preserving tracking, and a PIDbased control mechanism for target-following behavior. Implemented within the ROS 2 ecosystem and tested in the Gazebo Classic simulation environment using ArduPilot's Software-in-the-Loop (SITL) infrastructure, the system is capable of detecting and tracking vehicles such as ambulances, buses, and SUVs in urban traffic scenarios while autonomously adjusting UAV motion based on real-time visual deviations. Experimental results demonstrate that the system achieves an object detection accuracy of 88.4 % (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mAP}^{0.5}$</tex>), a multi-object tracking accuracy (MOTA) of 79.2 %, and a low ID-switch rate of 0.04 switches per second. End-to-end latency remains within an average of 114 milliseconds, meeting strict real-time performance criteria. The PID controller, operating at 50 Hz, enables rapid corrective actions and achieves target alignment within 1.2 seconds on average. 3D flight path visualizations confirm stable and consistent tracking behavior, validating the control system's precision and the perception pipeline's reliability.

title: Estimating Probabilistic Load Coincidence Factors for Distribution System Operation
authors: Yanqing Weng, Andrew Musgrave, Bo Chen, Yu Christine Chen
abstract: The standard definition of the load coincidence factor relates the maximum coincident demand from a set of customers in a distribution network to the sum of their individual peak demands. As a complement to the standard usage, this paper presents the concept of a minimum load coincidence factor characterizing the lower bound of coincident demand from a set of customers as it relates to the sum of their individual peak demands. Such a characterization can help to avoid unnecessary curtailment of local generation available in distribution networks in order to mitigate potential over-voltage issues possible under low loading conditions. We further examine statistical properties of both the standard maximum and proposed minimum load coincidence factors using publicly available data sets of household demand drawn from realistic distribution networks. The statistical analyses validate probabilistic modelling of both types of load coincidence factors for a large number of customers as a ratio of two Gaussian random variables. Probabilistic models of load coincidence factors are potentially useful in uncertainty-aware operational decision making via the solution of a robust or chance-constrained optimal dispatch.

title: IoT-Based Hemoglobin Level Detection System for Anemia Patients with Image Processing
authors: Md. Hasib Hasan, Mir Salman Rahman, Mahady Hasan, Mohammad Rejwan Uddin
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Red blood cells contain a protein called hemoglobin, which the body needs to carry oxygen. Monitoring hemoglobin levels is essential for general health since they may indicate a variety of medical problems. Because there aren't enough healthy red blood cells, anemia, a frequent blood condition, lowers the body's capacity to deliver oxygen. Hemoglobin levels need to be measured precisely and promptly to identify and cure anemia. In this paper, hemoglobin levels in anemic individuals are accurately detected by a novel Internet of Things (IoT)-based device. This system monitors hemoglobin levels in a noninvasive, economical, and effective manner. The system uses image processing techniques to process conjunctival images from IoT devices. This innovative method correctly distinguishes between anemic and non-anemic conjunctival images using potent Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN). Proteus Design Suit used for circuit simulation and the hardware was developed accordingly. System performance and result show the proper detection and the anemia diagnosis will be enhanced by further validation using bigger datasets and system accuracy enhancements.

title: Low-Power Low-Complexity 10-Bit Single-Ended SAR ADC in 65-nm CMOS for Biomedical Applications
authors: Kawther I. Arafa, Dina M. Ellaithy, Mohamed Abouelatta, Heba Shawkey, Abdelhalim Zekry
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper demonstrates a 10-bit low-power low-complexity successive approximation register analog-to-digital converter (SAR ADC) suitable for biomedical applications. The architecture of the proposed SAR ADC includes a low-distortion CMOS bootstrap sample and hold (S/H) switch, a pair of PMOS with double-tail single-ended dynamic latch comparator, a bridge binary weighted capacitor array digital to analog converter (DAC) with an efficient-energy switching scheme, and a modified successive approximation register (SAR) controller logic. The proposed converter is implemented using TSMC 65-nm CMOS technology, 1.2 V supply voltage with a sampling rate of 500 KS/s. According to the post-simulation results, the proposed SAR ADC consumes 3.353 µW and achieves a spurious-free dynamic range (SFDR) of 59.4 dB without supplementary calibration. The ADC core occupies an active area of 0.007 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> with a figure of merit (FoM) of 15.8 fj/conv.step.

title: SCS-Seg: A Novel Algorithm for Protocol Field Boundary Segmentation
authors: Xiaoxue Liu, Kai Zhao, Yaling Zhangs, Yichuan WangB, Yeqiu Xiao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: In modern computer networks, network protocols define the transmission rules of data packets. With the development of network communication technology, a large number of private protocols have emerged. The lack of public documentation makes it particularly difficult to analyze these protocols. Accurate protocol field segmentation is a key step in the analysis of unknown protocols. Traditional methods usually rely on known protocol formats, static rules, or template matching, which often do not work well when dealing with unknown protocols. To address this problem, this paper proposes a network protocol field segmentation method based on sequence common subset (SCSSeg). This method combines sequence alignment and iterative optimization to accurately extract static fields and effectively distinguish dynamic fields. By utilizing message correlation analysis, this method further improves the segmentation accuracy. Experimental results show that this method can efficiently and accurately extract field information in unknown protocols, which is superior to existing methods.

title: Comparison of Parameter Estimation Techniques in Permanent Magnet DC Motors
authors: Alexis Castelan-Perez, Francisco Beltran-Carbajal, Ivan Rivas-Cambero
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: This paper presents a comparison of parameter estimation techniques commonly used in dynamic systems, such as Recursive Least Squares, the Extended Kalman Filter, and the Algebraic Parameter Estimation Method. These methodologies are applied to the identification of parameters in a permanent magnet direct current motor. The study is conducted through computational simulations under noisy signal conditions to evaluate the robustness and performance of each method. The main objective is to determine which approach provides the best parameter estimation performance in terms of speed and accuracy.

title: Frequency Secure Optimal Scheduling of Microgrids with Energy Storage Support
authors: Ram Prasad Pandey, Nga Nguyen
abstract: Due to the decreased system inertia caused by the increasing use of inverter-based renewable energy sources in MGs, frequency stability is becoming a greater concern during disruptions, such as unintentional islanding and generator failures. This paper presents an analytical framework for frequency-secure scheduling in microgrids (MGs) under unintentional islanding conditions, considering the frequency support from an energy storage system (ESS). A swing equation-based model is developed to capture the fast transient frequency response, incorporating both inertial and primary frequency support (PFS) from synchronous generators and ESS. Closed-form expressions for key frequency security metrics—the rate of change of frequency (RoCoF), frequency nadir, and steady-state frequency—are derived and embedded as constraints within generator scheduling optimization. The proposed formulation minimizes operating costs and load curtailment while ensuring frequency stability without explicitly imposing load shedding after unintentional islanding.

title: Next-Generation Power Systems Education: A Data-Driven Curriculum Framework
authors: Syed Khaleduzzaman, Jignesh Solanki
abstract: The transformation of power systems into data-rich cyber-physical infrastructures demands engineers with strong analytics skills. Traditional coursework, however, still emphasize deterministic modeling, creating a gap between education and industry needs as today’s power grids are too complex for purely deterministic approaches. This paper presents a specialized curriculum developed at West Virginia University (WVU) to integrate data analytics into power systems education. The course combined theoretical instruction with hands-on projects using simulation tools, different coding platforms, and real-world datasets such as synthetic grids and PMU measurements. Key topics covered data interpretation, anomaly detection, optimization techniques, and predictive modeling. Students applied machine learning and data-driven methods to real-world grid challenges and demonstrated their learning through diverse assessment activities. The paper details the curriculum design, implementation, and outcomes, offering a replicable model for modernizing power engineering education in the era of grid digitalization.

title: Real Time Adaptive Protection for Active Distribution Networks: A Review
authors: Muhammad Zubair Ghafoor, Muhammad Faisal Nadeem Khan, Faisal Hammad Khan, Muhammad Shahzaib Shah, Syed Waqas Hussain Shah, Syed Irtaza Ali Naqvi
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Energy Conservation and Efficiency (ICECE)
abstract: Active distribution networks (ADNs) have been developed by integrating distributed energy resources (DERs), intelligent automation and bi-directional power flows as an addition to passive distribution networks. Such developments disrupt the traditional protection systems, which were based on a fixed environment and the unidirectional assumption of fault. In dynamic conditions, static schemes tend to fail, which results in loss of coordination, fault misdetection and decreased reliability of the system. This review is a detailed review of real time adaptive protection strategies applicable to ADNs. We discover the architectural development of ADNs and the new protection issues first, including variable fault currents, dynamic topologies, and islanding. Hereafter we categorize protection systems of adaptation into centralized, local, and distributed strategies. The important technologies are analyzed, such as ML algorithms, multi agent systems, and hardware in the loop validation platforms. A comparative analysis shows trade-offs between response time, scalability, and communication dependency. Real-life examples of world pilot projects reveal implemented practices and existing restrictions. Lastly, the paper establishes research gaps that are outstanding in the area of latency management, cybersecurity, and standardization, and gives future development paths, including edge-computing architectures and plug-and-play protection of distributed energy resources (DERs). The review should also help design resilient and intelligent protection systems in response to the changing distribution grid.

title: $\mu \text{CP}$- and DLP-Based 3D Bioprinting for Liver Tumor Microenvironment Construction
authors: Anping Wu, Wenbo Li, Jincheng Hu, Yanting Liu, Xinyang Zhang, Zhiqiang Zheng, Yaozhen Hou, Huaping Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: The in vitro reconstruction of an authentic liver tumor microenvironment holds significant promise for drug screening and clinical research. However, current 3D tumor models, such as those cultured in U96-well plates or via bioprinting, exhibit limitations in recapitulating dynamic cell-matrix interactions. This study presents a stepwise fabrication approach: liver tumor cells are first cultured via microcontact printing to form spheroids, followed by digital micromirror device-based microfluidic channel photopolymerization to encapsulate the spheroids within a tumor-stromal compartment, thereby constructing a physiologically relevant liver tumor microenvironment. This model enables systematic investigation of tumor-stroma crosstalk and high-throughput anticancer drug screening, providing a controllable in vitro platform for precision oncology and metastatic mechanism analysis.

title: Dealing with Non-Idealities of Power-Clock Generation for Adiabatic Systems
authors: Himadri Singh Raghav, Sachin Maheshwari, Mike Smart, Themis Prodromakis, Alexander Serb
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Although the energy efficiency of synchronous LC-based Power-Clock Generators (PCGs) is well documented, the influence of non-idealities and associated loss mechanisms remains comparatively under-explored. This paper addresses that gap by analysing how practical imperfections give rise to both adiabatic and non-adiabatic losses, thereby shaping the performance of the entire adiabatic system. We demonstrate that the designed PCG is highly sensitive to load-induced "spillover," quantify its impact on energy dissipation, and expose the trade-offs among load variation, duty cycle, bypass-transistor width, and operating frequency. The resulting design guidelines high-light critical interdependencies and provide a framework for mitigating non-idealities, enabling optimised PCG operation and smoother integration of additional circuitry.

title: Activated Clay Can Be Produced as Supplementary Cementitious Material Through Different Processes: Promising News for Cement Industry’s Decarbonization
authors: Luc Rudowski, Hendrik Möller
abstract: Activated clay can be produced as a supplementary cementitious material (SCM) through two different processes. Both offer promising good news for cement industry’s decarbonization efforts.One of the major cement industry’s decarbonization challenges is to reduce the clinker content in cement and substitute it by SCMs. With a projected decrease of the availability of granulated blast furnace slag and fly ash, clay has logically been considered as a relevant, abundant, and accessible natural resource to produce artificial pozzolans as SCM - activated clay.Beyond numerous academic project research programs, the development of industrial technologies to activate clay by calcination has gained a significant momentum in the cement industry. Know-how has been quickly progressing, but many challenges were also faced related to various process technology topics, proper equipment selection, as well as cement and concrete quality issues. Another promising clay activation process technology is currently under industrial development as an alternative to thermal clay activation. It is based on an already well-described process in the research literature for decades: mechanochemistry.The aim of the present paper is to characterize and compare both clay activation technologies.

title: Droplet Characterization and Particle Encapsulation Using Sodium Alginate Solution in a Microfluidic Device
authors: Donatien Sinzinkayo, Eric Kwame Owusu, Yue Wang, Na Liu, Tao Yue
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Droplet-based encapsulation is widely used in biomedical engineering and materials science; however, most current systems utilize mineral or fluorinated oils that can be harmful to the environment and may pose toxicity risks. In this work, we present a more sustainable method that uses sodium alginate as a viscoelastic medium and food-grade fish oil as the continuous phase. Fish oil is biodegradable and biocompatible, supporting the formation of stable droplets. Other food oils, like sunflower or olive oil, can also be used. Our tests confirmed that alginate exhibits shear-thinning properties and weak elasticity that help organize particles before they reach the junction. Under these conditions, we achieved single-particle encapsulation rates that we estimate to be statistically significant, and these rates are likely related to how particles align and synchronize with droplet formation. This method has practical advantages over electrospray and chitosan-based systems, including gentle gelation, scalability, and improved encapsulation accuracy. Overall, our approach offers a reliable and environmentally friendly method for encapsulating particles and cells in microfluidic systems.

title: Multiresolution Ensemble Consensus Graph Learning for Phase Identification in Power Distribution Systems
authors: Mihir Malladi, Daniel L. Lau, Yuan Liao
abstract: A power grid is a poly-phase network that transports electricity through transmission lines and feeders, typically using three phases. Phase identification—the task of determining which phase a consumer is connected to—is essential for reliable power system analysis, operation and control. Traditionally performed on-site, this task has evolved with the proliferation of smart metering infrastructure into a data-driven process using time-series voltage data and unsupervised learning techniques like clustering. Spectral clustering, in particular, depends on how effectively one can construct a graph to observe similarities and dissimilarities of voltage patterns. Graph-based methods thus have become powerful tools for analyzing complex networks, and time series, where graph construction techniques such as similarity, ensemble Co-Association, and spatial smoothness are commonly used. However, these often overlook volatility a critical feature of smart meter data, where minor spikes or shifts can significantly alter clustering outcomes. To address this, we propose a new method of constructing graphs through multiresolution analysis using the Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT), enabling the decomposition of signals across multiple frequency bands. We then infer graph structures within each band and fuse them using a spectral perturbation-based approach, weighted by graph partitioning metrics like modularity. Our experimental results show that the multiresolution ensemble consensus graph learning is an effective method in addressing the phase identification problem.

title: Sub-Synchronous Oscillations Suppression in Weak Grids Using Adaptive Control and High-Pass Filter
authors: Behnam Zamanzad Ghavidel, Yuan Liao
abstract: This paper proposes a control strategy to mitigate sub-synchronous oscillations (SSO) in inverter-based power systems by integrating adaptive control and a high-pass filter (HPF) into the phase-locked loop (PLL) structure. Based on the enhanced PLL model, the positive-sequence impedance (Z<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">pp</inf>) of a grid-connected inverter with an LCL filter is analytically derived, capturing the dynamic influence of control loops. While conventional PLL configurations are vulnerable to SSO, the proposed method, combining adaptive control tuning with HPF, effectively suppresses these oscillations. Theoretical analyses and frequency-domain simulations demonstrate improvements in system stability and dynamic performance, especially in scenarios with low short-circuit ratios (SCR).

title: Aerial Intelligence for Ecosystem Protection Through AI-Enhanced UAV Surveillance of Invasive Flora
authors: Cecilie Simona Pulkrabek, Janek Otilie Kostelecky, Evelina Vladislava Kratochvil, Behiye Sahin
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: The unchecked spread of invasive plant species poses escalating challenges to agriculture and biodiversity, demanding timely and accurate detection methods. This study introduces a technologically integrated workflow that leverages aerial imaging, spatial data processing, and deep neural networks to monitor invasive vegetation across diverse ecosystems. Utilizing unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) equipped with high-resolution sensors, large-scale image datasets were gathered and refined through advanced enhancement techniques to counteract environmental variability. These images were processed using a custom-trained deep learning model optimized for multiclass plant classification. By aligning object detection results with RTK-enhanced GPS coordinates, the system generated precise geospatial maps delineating the distribution and density of harmful plant species. The analysis uncovered species-specific clustering patterns and revealed areas where beneficial vegetation mitigates invasive encroachment. With robust classification accuracy and spatial fidelity, the framework offers a scalable solution for ecosystem monitoring and land-use planning. The findings underscore the potential of combining real-time drone analytics with AI-based mapping for proactive, data-driven ecological management.

title: Real-Time Voltage Security Assessment via Contingency Analysis Using a Mixture-of-Experts Under Varying Power Network Topologies
authors: Rehan Nawaz, Santiago Grijalva
abstract: This paper presents a deep learning-based framework for real-time voltage security assessment considering various topology configurations of the transmission system. Leveraging a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) machine learning architecture, the proposed approach captures the statistical heterogeneity induced by topological variations of the power system. This enables obtaining contingency analysis voltage violation metrics without relying on explicit AC power flow computations. The methodology is validated using the B37 test system under both conventional and renewable-integrated scenarios. The results demonstrate strong predictive performance, with R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> scores reaching up to 0.9900 and inference times ranging from 90 to 105 ms, thereby enabling new opportunities for real-time power system control and cybersecurity applications.

title: A Timing Complementary Ternary Content-Addressable Memory Based on Memristor
authors: Haodong Hu, Hui Xu, Jiali Liu, Zhiwei Li, Haijun Liu, Yinan Wang, Sen Liu
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Ternary content-addressable memory (TCAM) is crucial for high-speed search applications. However, the existing TCAMs suffer from excessive circuit area overhead and static power dissipation due to the topologically complementary twin branches. This paper proposes the timing complementary ternary content-addressable memory (TC-TCAM) to eliminate redundant branches. The time-domain complementary bias stages and precharge-discharge scheme are utilized to implement the XNOR-like ternary logic of TCAM. Simulation results indicate that TC-TCAM achieves the cell size reduction of over 30% compared to other RRAM-based designs, with 1.5 pJ average search energy and 0.3us match speed. It demonstrates that TC-TCAM is a promising solution for high-density, energy-efficient applications in data-intensive and edge computing environments.

title: ML for Insurance Risk Prediction: Models, Metrics, and Insights with a Graph-Causal-Transformer Approach
authors: Hamza Errahibi, Fatima Zahra Abbour, El mehdi Lghaouch, Chemlal Yman, Mohamed Azzouazi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Nearly all insurance operations are dependent on risk prediction, the accuracy and fairness of which is paramount. Traditional models of underwriting and risk assessment generally fail to exhibit the complexity and interrelationships associated with an interconnected portfolio. This paper proposes the Graph-Causal-Transformer (GCT) an innovative machine learning architecture that employs graph neural networks, causal inference, and transformer based attention to allow for a more holistic and interpretable consideration of insurance risk. Whereas conventional models assume policyholders represent independent risks, the GCT augments its models of risk by directly modeling relationships between policyholders, assets, and their context, such as supply chains or relative distance. It also distinguishes true causal drivers (or influences) from false correlations. The GCT is evaluated using a very large scale auto insurance dataset augmented with alternative datasets. The GCT model performed better than Generalised Linear Models, XGBoost, Graph Neural Networks and Actuarial Transformers depending upon the performance metric employed, namely AUC, Gini, loss-ratio uplift and fairness. The GCT provides a high degree of interpretability through SHAP based local explanations and causal path insights, therefore supporting those firms who need to comply with emerging regulations associated with the rise of AI. The findings of this study demonstrate that the GCT provides predictive performance benefits while enhancing transparency and governance whilst making it an important candidate for future algorithmic underwriting applications in regulated insurance markets.

title: Evaluation of Open-Source Small Vision–Language Models for Medical Prescriptions Understanding
authors: Yasine Lehmiani, Saad Frihi, Abdelhak Mahmoudi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Typed, French-language prescriptions are rapidly gaining traction in Morocco as clinics adopt electronic health records, creating a high-impact opportunity for automatic drug-field extraction. Cloud-hosted vision-language models (VLMs) such as Amazon Nova Pro deliver great results for schema-aware prompts-but raise CNDP data-transfer and cost concerns. We ask whether sub-5 B-parameter open-source VLMs can achieve comparable performance on a single RTX-class GPU. To this end, we generated a corpus of 1500 synthetic French prescriptions and benchmarked five sub-5B-parameter opensource VLMs against Amazon Nova Pro with five evaluation metrics. The results establish a baseline for fully on-premise, privacy-preserving prescription parsing and motivate lightweight fine-tuning to further close the gap with large-scale APIs.

title: Reinforcement Learning for Dynamic RDF Schema Evolution in NoSQL Databases
authors: Saad Belefqih, Mohammed Barchane, Ahmed Zellou, Karim Doumi, Elhabib Benlahmar
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Reinforcement learning offers a promising foundation for adaptive schema extraction from heterogeneous NoSQL data. This work presents a dynamic framework for RDF schema evolution, where schema construction is modeled as a sequential decision-making process. Semantic representations of extracted (Subject, Predicate, Object) triplets are computed using Sentence-BERT embeddings, capturing contextual and lexical similarities across documents. These embeddings inform the decisions of a reinforcement learning agent, which incrementally updates the schema by selecting among actions—Add, Merge, Modify, or Ignore—based on long-term optimization of semantic coherence, structural compactness, and constraint compliance. A reward function guides policy learning by incorporating constraint violations and redundancy metrics. The framework also supports the continuous inference and refinement of cardinality and datatype constraints, enabling the schema to adapt over time to evolving data structures in schema-less NoSQL environments.

title: A CNN-Based Continuous Authentication Framework for Enhancing Mobile Device Privacy Protection
authors: Guozhu Zhao, Chenxi Yang, Renzhi Ji, Yu Chen, Yaxin Wang, Qicheng Wang, Yichen Li, Chuanzhen Ju
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: This paper presents a CNN-based continuous authentication method designed to protect personal privacy on mobile phones. The proposed system integrates multiple biometric features, including fingerprints, nail covers, finger joint epidermis, and the entire finger, to enhance the accuracy of identity verification. Leveraging the powerful feature extraction capabilities of Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), the method achieves high authentication performance. Experimental results demonstrate that single-feature authentication using fingerprints and nail covers yields excellent accuracy (AUC $=1.00$), while multi-feature fusion further enhances overall performance. Additionally, increasing the proportion of training samples generally improves model effectiveness. Despite its promising results, the system’s performance is influenced by environmental and device-specific factors. Future work will focus on enhancing system robustness and exploring advanced CNN architectures to further improve authentication accuracy and computational efficiency.

title: Bridge Structural Damage Detection Based on Covariance-Driven Stochastic Subspace Identification
authors: Jiajia Zhou, Yi Jiang, Yanchi Wu, Guohui Zhao, Ruonan Zhang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: With the rapid development of urban construction and infrastructure, bridges serve as critical transportation hubs, and their structural integrity is directly linked to public safety. This paper presents a bridge structural damage detection method based on Covariance-driven Stochastic Subspace Identification (Cov-SSI) and hypothesis testing. A vibration sensor network is deployed to collect bridge vibration data, providing high-quality input for subsequent modal analysis. The proposed method performs modal identification using the long-term bridge vibration data, extracts stable modal frequencies using the Density-Based Spatial Clustering of Applications with Noise (DBSCAN) algorithm, and ultimately applies the two-sample two-tailed t-test to determine the damage state of the bridge. This study utilizes data from the Swiss Z24 bridge for validation. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method effectively mitigates the influence of environmental factors, accurately identifies bridge damage in a timely manner, and provides a reliable basis for preventive maintenance. The proposed method can be applied to the long-term health monitoring of various critical infrastructures, enhancing safety assessments and maintenance decision-making.

title: Measuring Power Grid Resilience in the Era of Flexible Resources Using Multi-time-step Dispatch Models
authors: Yuhan Du, Maureen Golan, Javad Mohammadi
abstract: The evolution of power systems is driven by the growing integration of flexible resources, including distributed energy storage, responsive loads, and generators. The increasing penetration of these resources is stressing current dispatch models. Furthermore, the compounding impact of increased climatic disruptions has given new impetus to resilient dispatch, enabling better planning for, absorption of, recovery from, and adaptation to chronic and acute climate hazards. We apply a multi-time-step framework and DC Optimal Power Flow (DCOPF) to the IEEE 30-node network, infused with flexible resources, to measure unserved load under generation and transmission line derating scenarios, thereby capturing the impacts of extreme heat on power flow. Our results demonstrate the effectiveness of multi-time-step flexible resource management in enhancing system resilience and the impact of decision time windows. We also provide an overview of additional potential physical and cyber disruptions, as well as guidance on resilience formulation and implementation.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Reinforcement Learning and Evolutionary Algorithms for Effective Analog Circuit Sizing
authors: E. Papageorgiou, C. Vişan, A. Buzo, G. Pelz, H. Cucu, T. Noulis
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This work compares two modern optimization approaches for analog integrated circuit sizing: evolutionary algorithms (EAs) and reinforcement learning (RL). While EAs have demonstrated consistent performance with minimal configuration effort, RL offers a data-driven alternative that can learn adaptive strategies through interaction. Both methods are evaluated within a unified framework that accounts for multiple process, voltage, and temperature (PVT) corners. The comparison highlights differences in efficiency, convergence behavior, and generalization capability. Results aim to clarify the strengths and limitations of each approach and guide their applicability in automated analog design.

title: Improving Power Flow Convergence By Leveraging Region of Attraction Visualization
authors: Kseniia Zhgun, Sanjana Kunkolienkar, Farnaz Safdarian, Thomas J. Overbye, James D. Weber
abstract: This paper both highlights the ease with which the Newton-Raphson power flow can converge to undesired alternative solutions and then presents techniques that can be used to improve power flow convergence by leveraging insights gained from visualizing the power flow solution region of attraction. The paper shows that, particularly for large-scale power systems, the common "flat start" initial voltage guess of one per unit with an angle of zero may not be in the region of attraction (ROA) for the desired power flow solution. Computationally tractable solution options are presented to reduce the likelihood of the power flow converging to an undesired solution. Results are demonstrated on power systems ranging in size from two to 23,600 buses.
