title: Resource-Saving Navigation Algorithm Based on Random Sampling Search
authors: Chao Feng, Lingxin Wu, Haibo Luo, Rui Ming, JianShan Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: In recent years, micro-miniaturization, swarm intelligence, and intelligent control have become mainstream trends in robotic systems research. Micro-robot systems are gaining attention due to their flexibility, robustness, and scalability. However, limited computing and storage resources pose challenges for applying traditional path planning and collaboration algorithms in such platforms. In addition, many existing solutions assume simplified environments and reliable communication, which are often unrealistic. This thesis investigates a collaborative diffusion-based search strategy tailored for microrobot systems. To address resource limitations, a DBT-RRT* path planning algorithm is proposed. It integrates a target biasing mechanism and bidirectional search with dynamic step size, while applying the triangle inequality for post-processing path optimization. The algorithm achieves efficient planning in complex environments with minimal computational cost. Its effectiveness is validated through experiments.

title: Baseline Hydropower Generation Offer Curves
authors: Jon Pearce, Arash Khojaste, Golbon Zakeri, Geoffrey Pritchard
abstract: We outline a mathematical model for pricing hydropower generation. The model involves a Markov decision process that reflects the seasonal variation in historical time series of water inflows. The procedure is computationally efficient and easy to interpret.

title: Language-Enhanced Mobile Manipulation for Efficient Object Search in Indoor Environments
authors: Liding Zhang, Zeqi Li, Kuanqi Cai, Qian Huang, Zhenshan Bing, Alois Knoll
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Enabling robots to efficiently search for and identify objects in complex, unstructured environments is critical for diverse applications ranging from household assistance to industrial automation. However, traditional scene representations typically capture only static semantics and lack interpretable contextual reasoning, limiting their ability to guide object search in completely unfamiliar settings. To address this challenge, we propose a language-enhanced hierarchical navigation framework that tightly integrates semantic perception and spatial reasoning. Our method, Goal-Oriented Dynamically Heuristic-Guided Hierarchical Search (GODHS), leverages large language models (LLMs) to infer scene semantics and guide the search process through a multi-level decision hierarchy. Reliability in reasoning is achieved through the use of structured prompts and logical constraints applied at each stage of the hierarchy. For the specific challenges of mobile manipulation, we introduce a heuristic-based motion planner that combines polar angle sorting with distance prioritization to efficiently generate exploration paths. Comprehensive evaluations in Isaac Sim demonstrate the feasibility of our framework, showing that GODHS can locate target objects with higher search efficiency compared to conventional, nonsemantic search strategies. Website and Video are available at: https://drapandiger.github.io/GODHS.

title: Anomaly Detection Method for Industrial Network Data Based on Multi-Scale Feature Clustering
authors: Zhongmin Wang, Zhongjian Yuan, Cong Gao, Yanping Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: With the increasing intelligence and complexity of industrial control systems, industrial network data exhibit high dimensionality and complex inter-feature correlations. This poses significant challenges for traditional anomaly detection algorithms, including high computational complexity and the curse of distance concentration, making it difficult to accurately identify anomalous samples. Subspace partitioning has emerged as a common and effective solution to alleviate the challenges posed by high-dimensional data. However, traditional subspace partitioning methods often rely on simplistic similarity metrics or fixed parameters, which limits their representational capacity and impairs their ability to capture intricate feature relationships. To address these limitations, this paper proposes a novel anomaly detection method based on multi-scale feature clustering. First, a multi-scale feature similarity metric is designed by integrating mutual information with a Gaussian kernel function. Second, a density estimation-based adaptive cluster center initialization algorithm is introduced to effectively partition high-dimensional data into subspaces. Finally, a feature entropy-based weighted ensemble strategy is employed to integrate anomaly detection results across subspaces. Experimental results on three industrial network datasets demonstrate that the proposed method effectively performs subspace partitioning and consistently outperforms existing subspace-based approaches in terms of detection performance.

title: Techno-economic Analysis of Power Supply Under Population Uncertainty in Ethiopia
authors: Negin Mansoori, Judith B Cardell
abstract: The estimates of national electrical demand planning typically focus on loads that belong to permanent populations, resulting in overlooking the electricity needs of displaced people such as those who are inhabiting long-term refugee settlements. This paper explores this issue through investigating the technological feasibility of expanding the national power grid of Ethiopia and designing a microgrid in order to facilitate increased access to electricity for the displaced population of 395,000 people in Gambela, Ethiopia. The study demonstrates that the current national hydro-powered electric grid is able to accommodate increased access to electricity for its displaced population.

title: Adaptive PI-PBC Performance via Proportional Gain Scaling in Single-Phase PWM-CSC under Linear Current Demand
authors: Angélica Mercedes Nivia-Vargas, Oscar Danilo Montoya, Nelsón Leonardo Díaz
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: This paper presents the design and performance evaluation of a passivity-based proportional-integral control (PIPBC) strategy for a single-phase pulse-width modulated current source converter (PWM-CSC) supplying a linear load. The control law is derived from a port-Hamiltonian representation of the converter in order to ensure asymptotic stability using a Lyapunov-based approach with component-wise error signals. To improve the transient response and the method's robustness under varying operating conditions, various gain scheduling strategies are examined, including constant gains, inverse scaling, and proportional scaling based on stored energy, as well as interpolation techniques using polynomial functions. The simulation results show that the proportional gain scaling method outperforms the other approaches in terms of the output current's dynamic response and its total harmonic distortion (THD). This strategy strikes a superior balance between settling time, overshoot, and harmonic attenuation, making it a strong alternative for high-performance power electronics applications. This study concludes with a comparative analysis of the implemented control schemes and provides some considerations for future hardware validation.

title: Modeling Fragility Curves for Substation Components Based On HILP Events Intensity
authors: Saksham Tiwari, Zongjie Wang
abstract: The increasing intensity and occurrence of high impact low probability (HILP) events require improved resilience in power grids, particularly through accurate modeling of fragility curves for critical infrastructure. This paper reviews existing methodologies for developing fragility curves for substation components under HILP events. Simulations are conducted in MATLAB to illustrate and analyze fragility curves specifically for wildfires, ice storms, and floods, examining how these curves evolve with changes in event intensity. The results demonstrate detailed impacts of varying event intensities on the probability of component failures, clearly identifying the vulnerabilities of substations, transformers, and distribution poles. The paper concludes by suggesting future research directions for developing proactive grid management strategies.

title: A Highly Compatible Variable-Diameter Spherical Shell Based on Arc-Shaped Four-Bar Linkage Mechanism
authors: Qiqi Xia, Xuechao Chen, Jiahao Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Conventional spherical robots that employ rigid monolithic shells face constraints in environmental adaptability. This paper proposes a novel morphing spherical shell based on arc-shaped four-bar linkage mechanism, which enables the shell's diameter to change within the range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40-50 ~\text{cm}$</tex>, enhancing the robot's adaptability in complicated environments. The morphing spherical shell constitutes an independent system exhibiting high compatibility with various driving methods. It also provides adequate placement space for internal components with a high internal space ratio of 70% in its contracted state. And the soft outer covering film of the shell ensures the sealing and waterproof properties. This paper primarily encompasses the geometric model of the morphing spherical shell, mechanical structure of the morphing spherical shell system and prototype experimental validation through deformation testing.

title: Massively Parallel Burrows-Wheeler Alignment for Microbiome Analysis over Plant Genomic Data
authors: Peerasu Puttakul, Kundjanasith Thonglek, Chakrit Bunyoo, Supaporn Erjongmanee, Chantana Chantrapornchai, Arinthip Thamchaipenet
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: Analyzing plant microbiomes from genomic data begins with sequence alignment. Sequence alignment is a significant step in removing host genomic sequences from mixed deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) reads. Tools based on the Burrows– Wheeler Alignment algorithm, such as Bowtie 2, are widely used for sequence alignment due to their balance of speed and accuracy; however, they can become computational bottlenecks when applied to large-scale sequencing data. We introduce a Message Passing Interface based (MPI)-based parallel Bowtie 2 framework using the MapReduce paradigm to accelerate the alignment process. By distributing workloads across multiple processing nodes, our approach significantly reduces execution time while maintaining accuracy. Unlike traditional parallelized approaches that rely on specific cloud-based infrastructures or software frameworks such as Hadoop, our implementation is designed to run efficiently on general-purpose, high-performance computing environments without requiring such dependencies. This makes it suitable for academic and resource-constrained settings. Beyond alignment, the system improves the overall plant microbiome analysis pipeline. It can be integrated with downstream tasks such as taxonomic classification and functional gene prediction. This allows for concurrent processing of multiple datasets and a more streamlined, scalable workflow. As a result, the proposed method reduces the total runtime by approximately 48.85 percent compared to the traditional method, without any loss in alignment quality. These findings highlight the potential of our approach to make microbiome analysis faster, more scalable, and more accessible to researchers.

title: Self-Supervised Image Classification Method Based on Multi-Attention Contrastive Learning
authors: Xun Chu, Peiwen Zuo, Min Qi, Mu Pan, Feng Wang, Dan Luo, Xin Liu, Yujie Zhang, Zixun Ji, Xinlei Wang, Jiehu Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: With the advent of the big data era, deep learning techniques have achieved remarkable success in image classification. However, their heavy reliance on large-scale annotated data limits the generalization capability of models on unseen data types, particularly in complex scenarios where traditional methods face challenges such as low annotation efficiency and strong subjectivity. To address these issues, this paper proposes a multi-attention contrastive learning-based image classification algorithm. By improving the ResNet50 architecture in the SimCLR framework with the Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM), our method improves the model’s ability to extract finegrained image details. CBAM uses channel and spatial attention mechanisms to focus on the importance of feature channels and key spatial regions, respectively, thereby enhancing the model adaptability to complex scenes. Experiments conducted on the CIFAR-10 and STL-10 datasets demonstrate that our improved SimCLR model outperforms conventional SimCLRRes18 and SimCLR-Res50 models in both Top-1 and Top-5 accuracy. By incorporating CBAM into ResNet50, our approach significantly enhances the performance of the model in image classification tasks. The results indicate that this method not only reduces dependence on labeled data but also improves generalization capability and classification precision, showcasing broad application potential.

title: Beyond Specs—Requirements Engineering for a Trusted Future
authors: Christof Ebert
abstract: With volatile markets, fast-changing dynamic systems, and growing liability risks, requirements engineering (RE) and product management must evolve. By providing flexibility while ensuring transparency, RE remains vital for delivering value and trust.

title: Prevention through Design: Reducing risk in Absence of Voltage Testing to Improve Safety in Low Voltage Distribution and Control Equipment
authors: Jim Allen, Marc Elliott, Alan Bond, Herrney Gonzalez
abstract: Advancements in the electrical safety culture have led to increased awareness of electrical hazard exposure in the workplace. This attention has led to an emphasis on proper hazard identification and incorporation of safety by design concepts to enable risk reduction. These efforts closely examine worker tasks and how controls might be applied in the design process. Performing risk assessment as defined by NFPA 70E, requires that exposure to electrical hazards is evaluated prior to working on energized equipment. A critical step such as verifying the absence of voltage is part of establishing electrical safe work conditions. Still, the task presents a challenge to electrical workers when exposure to live buses and connections is inevitable. A variety of technologies exist such as the use of permanently mounted voltage testing products to assist employees in verifying the absence of voltage within the electrical circuit before gaining access for maintenance or troubleshooting; however, each of them provides different levels of functionality and capabilities. This paper discusses the importance of the absence of voltage testing, available technologies, and its key role in the electrical maintenance program (EMP) and compliance with NFPA 70B. A rigorous EMP provides a framework to safeguard people, which in turn reduces the risk of downtime and equipment failure.

title: Reservation-Based Optimization of Electric Vehicle Charging Considering Dynamic Pricing and Operating Envelopes
authors: Jackson Morgan, Abdullah Al Mehadi, Arifa Sultana, Hongjie Wang, Regan Zane
abstract: The transition to electric vehicles depends on availability of low-cost charging. This paper describes and validates the performance of an optimizer to reduce the cost of charging electric vehicles using a reservation-based linear program. It considers both dynamic energy prices and peak demand costs while complying with a dynamic operating envelope. Using real-world charging station operation data, this work shows a 31% reduction in charging costs without disrupting the schedule of the charging sessions, or a 40% reduction if the vehicle departures are delayed by one hour.

title: Analysis of Factors Contributing to Runs Conceded by Starting Pitchers in Innings Immediately Following Their Own Team’s Offensive Scoring
authors: Toshiya Kase, Yoshiro Yamamoto
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: Using data published on MLB’s Baseball Savant, we categorized the factors that contribute to runs scored by starting pitchers who throw overthrows and three-quarter throws. We identify starting pitchers who are more likely to give up runs immediately after their own team scores a run and identify factors that cause the "flow" of the game to deteriorate. The purpose of this study is to grasp the trend of the run-scoring factors for each cluster through visualization by a web application using R-Shiny.

title: What Congtive Evaluation Theory Teaches Us About Effective Demand Response Program Design
authors: Jackson Moller, Mostafa Ardakani
abstract: Demand response (DR) is increasingly expected to supply the fast, low-cost flexibility needed for decarbonizing the power system. Yet, field programs rarely achieve their technical potential. This paper argues that part of the shortfall is an over reliance on small financial incentives that are not sufficient to promote behavioral change. The paper explores alternative paths through cognitive evaluation theory and the theory of planned behavior. The paper reviews relevant literature and analyzes some of the results. Our synthesis reveals three consistent patterns. First, poorly calibrated monetary incentives can crowd out intrinsic and pro-environmental motives, causing engagement to decay after initial participation. Second, attitudes toward environmental benefit and perceived behavioral control explain more variance in enrolment and load-shifting than expected bill savings. Third, social-norm feedback and home-automation technologies amplify these positive drivers when they enhance rather than diminish users’ sense of autonomy. Guided by these insights we propose a pathway for further research on psychology-informed design framework that combines motivationally aligned incentives, identity-based messaging, and privacy-preserving feedback. We expect that integrating behavioral theory with engineering practice is pivotal for turning DR from a limited resource into a dependable balancing grid tool.

title: Hybrid Method with Reinforcement Learning for Solar Irradiance Forecasting
authors: Ninh Nguyen, Thanh Bui, Huong Pham, Yem Vu, Nga Nguyen
abstract: The increasing demand for electricity has positioned renewable energy as a trend due to its advantages in energy sustainability and its impact on the environment. However, renewable energy sources are heavily dependent on weather and environmental conditions, resulting in fluctuating power output and causing significant challenges to effective monitoring and management. This study proposes a deep learning framework that integrates Convolutional Neural Networks, Long Short-Term Memory networks, and Actor-Critic to enhance the accuracy of solar irradiance forecasting results. The results demonstrate that the proposed model is significantly better than other approaches in this paper. The method has a considerable potential for extending solar irradiance forecasting to longer time horizons.

title: Approximating CCCV charging using SOC-dependent tapered charging power constraints in long-term microgrid planning
authors: Hassan Zahid Butt, Xingpeng Li
abstract: Traditional long-term microgrid planning models assume constant power charging for battery energy storage systems (BESS), overlooking efficiency losses that occur toward the end of charge due to rising internal resistance. While this issue can be mitigated at the cell level using constant current– constant voltage (CCCV) charging, it is impractical at the pack level in large-scale systems. However, battery management systems and inverter controls can emulate this effect by tapering charging power at high state-of-charge (SOC) levels, trading off charging speed for improved efficiency and reduced thermal stress. Ignoring this behavior in planning models can lead to undersized batteries and potential reliability issues. This paper proposes a tractable and scalable approach to approximate CCCV behavior using SOC-dependent tapered charging power (TCP) constraints. A MATLAB-based proof of concept demonstrates the energy delivery and efficiency benefits of tapering. The method is integrated into a long-term planning framework and evaluated under a synthetic load and solar profile. Results show tapering significantly affects BESS sizing, cost, and reliability under dynamic operating conditions that demand fast charging. These findings highlight tapering as a critical modeling factor for accurately capturing BESS performance in long-term microgrid planning.

title: Visualization of Performance Indicators Influencing Rugby Union Match Outcomes Using R Shiny
authors: Takahisa Miyamoto, Sanetoshi Yamada, Yoshiro Yamamoto
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: This study aimed to determine the performance indicators (PIs) that affect match results in Rugby Union and to present them through more interpretable data visualizations using the R Shiny package. Data from 91 matches of the 2024 Super Rugby Pacific, provided by Stats Perform, were analyzed. The dependent variable was defined as the points difference, and 26 independent variables were selected: 11 attacking indicators, 5 defensive indicators, 3 penalty-related indicators, 4 set-piece indicators, and 3 other indicators. Two machine learning algorithms, Random Forest and XGBoost, were employed to identify the key PIs affecting match outcomes.The results demonstrated that in both the Random Forest and XGBoost models, more than eight out of the top ten variables were offensive performance indicators. Specifically, higher values of LineBreaks, MetresGained, DefendersBeaten, and PostContactMetres and lower values of TurnoverConceded and MissedTackles were shown to be associated with maximizing match outcomes. Furthermore, the use of Shiny, a package of the statistical software R, enabled the development of more accessible and interpretable data visualizations. In conclusion, leveraging tools such as Shiny to strengthen and continuously monitor these performance indicators may hold substantial potential for enhancing the overall performance and success of rugby teams.

title: A Roadmap for Multimodal Fusion in IoT-Enabled Context-Aware Recommender Systems
authors: Mohamed El Amine Chafiki, Oumaima Stitini, Soulaimane Kaloun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: The ubiquity of the Internet of Things (IoT) has unlocked the potential for recommender systems to become truly context-aware, moving beyond historical preferences to understand a user's immediate, dynamic situation. However, a primary challenge remains: dynamic context modeling—specifically, the acquisition, representation, and fusion of multimodal data streams generated by IoT sensors. While direct research into multimodal data fusion for IoT-based Context-Aware Recommender Systems CARS is still nascent, a wealth of established techniques exists in adjacent “smart systems” domains such as healthcare, activity monitoring, and smart manufacturing. This review article bridges this critical gap. We first establish a taxonomy of multimodal context relevant to recommendations, sourcing data from environmental, physiological, and kinematic IoT sensors. We then review data fusion architectures—from early and late fusion to modern hybrid approaches such as attention mechanisms and graph-based models—drawing on concrete examples from established literature in smart health, activity recognition, and industrial IoT. Finally, we synthesize these findings to propose a structured roadmap for Multimodal IoTbased CARS. This work culminates in a conceptual framework that maps established fusion techniques to recommendation tasks and outlines a research agenda to address key future challenges, including privacy and real-time performance.

title: Raising Awareness of Energy Consumption in Machine Learning
authors: Samara Santos, Laís Medeiros, André Ottoni, Rita Borgo, Erivelton Nepomuceno
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: The increase in carbon footprint of Machine Learning (ML) models has raised concerns about their environmental impact, as growing computational demands lead to increased energy consumption. While ML is used as a tool to mitigate climate change, its sustainability remains a challenge due to the trade-off between model performance and energy efficiency. However, there is a gap in the literature on the good practice of building a Green Machine Learning (GML) system. To address this gap, this study presents ECOVIS, a platform concept for energy-aware visual analysis to help understand ML energy consumption through an interactive dashboard. Allowing users to configure experiments by selecting datasets, ML models, and preprocessing options, then visualize results, including energy consumption, execution time, and estimated CO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> emissions. By making ML energy consumption more accessible and interpretable, this study contributes to sustainable computing practices and promotes awareness of the environmental impact of AI technologies.

title: Nail: Not Another Fault-Injection Framework for Chisel-generated RTL
authors: Robin Sehm, Christian Ewert, Rainer Buchty, Mladen Berekovic, Saleh Mulhem
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: Fault simulation and emulation are essential techniques for evaluating the dependability of integrated circuits, enabling early-stage vulnerability analysis and supporting the implementation of effective mitigation strategies. High-level hardware description languages such as Chisel facilitate the rapid development of complex fault scenarios with minimal modification to the design. However, existing Chisel-based fault injection (FI) frameworks are limited by their coarse-grained, instruction-level controllability, which restricts the precision of fault modeling. This work introduces Nail, a Chisel-based open-source FI framework that overcomes these limitations by introducing statebased faults. This approach allows fault scenarios based on specific system states instead of just instruction-level triggers, removing the need for precise timing of fault activation. For greater controllability, Nail allows users to arbitrarily modify internal trigger states via software at runtime. To support this, Nail automatically generates a software interface, offering straightforward access to the instrumented design. This enables fine-tuning of fault parameters during active fault-injection campaigns, a feature particularly beneficial for FPGA emulation, where synthesis is time-consuming. Utilizing these features, Nail narrows the gap between the high speed of emulation-based FI frameworks, the usability of software-based approaches, and the controllability achieved in simulation. We demonstrate Nail’s state-based fault injection and software framework by modeling a faulty general-purpose register in a RISC-V processor. Although this might appear straightforward, it requires statedependent fault injection and was previously impossible without fundamental changes to the design. The approach was validated in both simulation and FPGA emulation, where the addition of Nail introduced less than $1 \%$ resource overhead.

title: Post-Disaster Home Energy Management with Prioritized HVAC and Synthetic Load Modeling
authors: Arshid Ali, Timothy M. Hansen, Tanveer Hussain
abstract: In energy-constrained residential contexts, particularly following disasters such as hurricanes, effective load scheduling and comfort-aware energy management become critical, yet detailed appliance-level and aggregate load profile data may not always be available. This paper proposes a smart home energy management system (HEMS) that integrates an M<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">t</inf>/G/∞ queueing-based synthetic load model to address data unavailability, enabling criticality-aware appliance scheduling alongside a comfort-based smart thermostat. The proposed CACHE-EMS-QUENCH framework aims to maintain user-defined thermal comfort, mitigate the lack of actual load data, and prioritize critical loads under constrained energy conditions typical of post-disaster scenarios. The system employs an M<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">t</inf>/G/∞ queueing model to generate realistic synthetic load profiles. Load categorization and prioritization are accomplished using mixed-integer linear programming (MILP), ensuring high-priority appliances receive energy allocation while maintaining indoor temperature within user-specified comfort bands. The HVAC system employs band-based operation, significantly penalizing deviations from the comfort zone to enhance occupant comfort and safety while prioritizing other critical loads. The effectiveness of the proposed system is demonstrated via a case study of a residential setting in Puerto Rico over a 72-hour period, using a solar-plus-battery energy setup and quadratic binary optimization implemented in Julia’s JuMP framework. Simulation results confirm the system’s capability to replicate realistic load curves, efficiently allocate limited energy to critical appliances, manage HVAC operations effectively, and support overall residential energy resilience.

title: Approximating Eigenpairs With Neural Networks by Loss Function Minimization
authors: Luis Elias Salgado Solano, Oliverio Arellano Cárdenas, Luis Martín Flores Nava, Felipe Gómez Castañeda
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: At present, the usage of machine learning (ML) tools as a means for including intelligent tasks in engineering disciplines is becoming common. Moreover, these tasks belong mainly to classification and regression processes, from where the numerical process point of view the matrix-vector multiplication is dominant. This operation belongs to the product between the weighting matrix in a layer of a neural network and input vectors, computing in this way the values of arguments of activation functions of neurons. Moreover, the weighting matrix is obtained by efficient optimization gradient-descent methods. In this work, we approximate all the eigenvectors and their eigenvalues of symmetric matrices by minimizing an appropriate loss function, along with linear single layer neural networks. The numerical accuracy of this neural computational method was evaluated confirming its effectiveness for the cases of medium and large dimension matrices along with using the Adam optimizer.

title: Decoding Ship Signatures in SAR Imagery Using Deep Learning for Maritime Surveillance
authors: Braidy Mason Oliverson, Wali Bandyopadhyay, Sefton Mottershead, Irem Bayraktar
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Maritime domains represent vast and dynamic environments where the timely discovery of vessels can alter the trajectory of critical events, from safeguarding national waters to protecting fragile marine ecosystems. This study examines the contrasting pathways by which two deep learning paradigms, one emphasizing speed, the other precision, perceive and interpret the restless seascape captured through Synthetic Aperture Radar. By exploring how these detectors unravel the intricate tapestry of ships amidst waves, cluttered coastlines, and shifting weather, we reveal not merely their technical divergences but their potential to reshape strategies for oceanic awareness. Our analysis ventures beyond numeric evaluations, focusing instead on the unique operational footprints each approach leaves in scenarios ranging from tranquil open waters to labyrinthine harbors.

title: A Cost-Resilience Trade-Off Framework for Optimizing Microgrid Resource Allocation
authors: Usama Aslam, Md Khairul Islam, Farzad Ferdowsi, Terrence Chambers
abstract: This paper outlines a strategy to optimize resource allocation in microgrids while maintaining specified levels of resilience. Although increasing the capacity of resources helps to develop resilience during emergencies, this study focuses on striking a cost-resilience trade-off. The method includes multiple resilience metrics to optimize investments for emergency scenarios. By incorporating Fixed and Mobile Battery Energy Storage Systems (FBESS and MBESS), the strategy ensures flexibility, making the microgrid both cost-effective and resilient. The performance of the strategy is tested at low, moderate, and high resilience levels, which translate to varied critical load coverage and solar availability levels. In association with this framework, a novel Marginal Cost of Resilience (MCR) analysis is introduced to quantify the cost versus the resiliency value of marginally distributed energy resources (DER) expansions. This process allows for the determination of the most cost-effective strategies for the sizing of DER to achieve specified resiliency targets. The results highlight the importance of the simultaneous evaluation of resilience and cost in microgrid planning, providing useful information to grid operators and planners.

title: Integrating Outage and Restoration Time Disparities in Social Vulnerability
authors: Alok Sharma, Zhiqing Li, Wei Zhang
abstract: During and after extreme storm events, power outages and corresponding restoration delays create hardship among people in the affected region. While previous research has focused on predicting outages and restoration times, their integration with social vulnerability has been less studied. In this study, outage and restoration predictions were coupled with social vulnerability index (SoVI) to develop new composite vulnerability maps. Outages were predicted using a physics-based outage prediction model, and restoration times across different census blocks were estimated using agent-based modeling. SoVI was computed using principal component analysis which combined 24 socioeconomic and sociodemographic indicators derived from the available census data. The framework was implemented in the city of New London, Connecticut following Hurricane Sandy. The composite vulnerability helped to identify several vulnerability cases such as regions with high power vulnerability with less social capacities indicating the necessity for resilience improvements. This framework can be used to illustrate the spatial disparities in power outages and restoration delays in conjunction with socioeconomic disparities and can help inform equitable decision-making for approaches such as implementing grid hardening measures.

title: GIS-Based Flood Management System Using Remote Sensing
authors: Dahlia S. De Mesa, Carlos Miguel A. Corrales, Mark Jefferson M. Elizaga, Chelsea Franzine C. Lauron, Martin A. Nevalga, Kenneth Denzel E. Villas
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: This study aims to develop a GIS-Based flood management system by utilizing remote sensing and real-time monitoring. Ultimately, the purpose is to mitigate flood related threats experienced by communities such as Purok 5, Barangay San Cristobal, Calamba, Laguna. San Cristobal Flood Management System (SCFMS) is a multi-platform system that integrates Geographic Information System (GIS) techniques with data collected by LiDAR (light detection and ranging) sensor to track real-time water levels. Additionally, the data from LiDAR facilitates the visualization of flood-prone areas and the broadcast of announcements to strengthen readiness for future calamities. The system includes core features including news feed announcements, river-level visualization, weather forecasts and trends, flood hazard mapping, visualization for flood history, SOS feature, and alerts from SMS and app notifications. Agile methodology assists the developers in iterative development to ensure the project aligns with users’ needs. Through usability testing and feedback, the system was evaluated for its functionality, accessibility, usefulness, and swift communication. Results indicated that the platform effectively provides timely communication on awareness and response in times of calamities, addresses the delay in gathering information and decision making, and ultimately, improves preparedness, mitigation, response, and recovery efforts in the community. The developers concluded that all objectives of the study were successfully achieved, and the system provided a reliable tool for proactive flood management and local decision-making.

title: Impact of Contention-Aware Placement in Heterogeneous Edge Devices
authors: Jeremy Giesen, Ibai Irigoyen, Enrico Mezzetti, Jaume Abella, Francisco J. Cazorla
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: Time predictability is an increasing concern in functionally-rich mixed-criticality applications at the Edge, which often carry different timing requirements. Edge devices, in turn, are increasingly complex to sustain the increasing computational requirements, which hinders providing predictable performance without seriously affecting performance. One of the main threats to predictable performance is the impact of timing interference arising from contention in an increasing number of shared hardware resources. The impact of software to hardware mapping on performance is a well-studied topic, seeking optimal memory mappings to reduce average and worst-case performance, and, more recently, to control and limit timing interference. These methods normally focus on code and data placement, especially in relation to specific properties of the memory hierarchy, either architectural (e.g. heterogeneous memory modules) or obtained through partitioning techniques. In practice, however, these works build on a uniform memory hierarchy model, where the source of a memory request, namely, where a task accessing a given memory is eventually executed, is not directly relevant. In this work, we consider a large class of systems (e.g., TriCore families) where memory hierarchies are non-uniform, and access latency depends on the computing element issuing the request. In those architectures, the impact of code and data placement on timing interference cannot be addressed without considering architectural constraints and task locality. Through empirical exploration, we show that code, data, and locality collectively have a substantial impact on contention bounds, leading to a significantly expanded optimization space compared to approaches considering only code and data placement under the uniform memory assumption. Our results motivate the need for novel, efficient optimization approaches that integrate task mapping and architectural constraints to reduce timing interference.

title: A Surety Microgrid Architecture for Rural Area Applications in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania
authors: Hao Ha, Matthew Knowles, Salem Elsaiah, Sina Zarrabian
abstract: This paper presents a part of an ongoing research at the undergraduate level in a senior course titled: Modern Power Systems. This undergraduate research contributes to the broader understanding of renewable energy solutions, focusing on improving the resilience and reliability of power systems in rural settings. On the technical side, this study aims at designing a hybrid microgrid system to be initially deployed at remote locations and farmlands in the state of Pennsylvania. The primary focus of this study is the integration of solar panels as an alternative power source, ensuring continued electricity supply during service interruptions of the primary grid. The study includes an analytical approach for microgrid design and the configuration of solar panels and storage systems to meet the community’s energy needs. A seamless transition mechanism is proposed to switch between the primary power source and the secondary power source in the form of energy storage.The proposed topology is consisted of a series of photovoltaic generators (solar panels) connected to the load via power electronic interfacing. The sample system utilizes three DC/DC power converters connected to a full-bridge DC/AC inverter circuit via an energy storage device. The AC output signals are going through a filtering stage in order to smooth them out and get ride of unwanted ripples in the voltage and current at the receiving-end. In this research, three DC/DC power converters have been elected to achieve lower device stress ratio and due to their availability. Even though this work is still underway and is being implemented physically (prototype), primarily results from modeling and simulation are presented in a step-by-step fashion to support the proposed research. The findings from this study are promising thus far and we aim at implementing and using the designed microgrid at one of the local areas in Schuylkill County, PA.

title: Enhancing Frequency Response Using Deep Reinforcement Learning-Controlled Battery Energy Storage Systems
authors: Abu Shouaib Hasan, Rui Fan, Di Wu
abstract: As the transition from traditional fossil fuels to inverter-based resources advances, grid operators are increasingly concerned about the reduction in power system inertia. A significant consequence of reduced inertia is the rapid and severe decline in power system frequency following a large disturbance. This can lead to grid instability, unnecessary activation of under-frequency load shedding (UFLS) relays, or even blackouts. This paper proposes a reinforcement learning-based control scheme for battery energy storage systems (BESS) to provide fast frequency control, stabilize the system, and prevent unnecessary UFLS relay operations. The proposed approach employs the state-of-the-art reinforcement learning algorithm, surrogate-gradient-based evolution strategy for continuous control of the BESS output. Parallel computing is employed to accelerate the training process. Detailed time-domain simulations on a modified IEEE 39-bus test system demonstrate that the proposed scheme can reliably support system frequency, prevent rapid frequency declines, and avoid unnecessary load shedding, improving overall system stability and reliability.

title: Bayesian Inference of Three-phase Line-to-ground Faults Using Synchrophasor Measurements
authors: Alexa Fernando, Yu Christine Chen
abstract: This paper presents a Bayesian method to infer the occurrence of a three-phase line-to-ground fault, its location along the faulted line, and the short-circuit fault current, all using noisy synchrophasor measurements of nodal voltages and currents. Central to the proposed method is a linear, complex-valued circuit model representing the faulted power network that comprises the known pre-fault system admittance matrix and an unknown fault signature to be inferred. The linear model combined with a (complex-valued) Gaussian prior enables a conjugate family where the fault signature posterior can be computed in closed form. This offers significant computational savings over standard sampling-based inference that can require many simulations to arrive at the posterior distribution. The posterior distribution of the fault signature further reveals probability distributions of the fault location along the affected line and the short-circuit fault current that could have led to the observed synchrophasor measurements. We illustrate key features of the complex-valued circuit modelling approach and the effectiveness of the proposed Bayesian inference via numerical case studies involving three-bus and nine-bus test systems.

title: A Reflective Study on Deep Learning in Brain Tumor Segmentation
authors: Tarek Berghout
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Brain tumor segmentation is a critical step in medical image analysis, aiding in diagnosis, treatment planning, and outcome prediction. Accurate segmentation can significantly impact patient care, yet it remains a complex and demanding task due to heterogeneous nature of tumor structures and imaging modalities. In recent years, deep learning has emerged as a powerful tool in medical imaging, offering state-of-the-art performance in segmentation tasks. While numerous studies have introduced advanced models and achieved impressive results, the specific practical challenges encountered during basic implementations are often underreported. For beginners and researchers new to the field, understanding these foundational obstacles is essential for building robust and effective models. This reflective study addresses that gap by exploring the application of a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for brain tumor segmentation using Brain Tumor Segmentation (BraTS) dataset. The CNN model was trained with hyperparameters optimized through Bayesian optimization to improve performance. Rather than focusing solely on metrics, this work emphasizes the difficulties faced throughout the process, including data variability, class imbalance, and preprocessing sensitivity. The aim is to shed light on common yet underdiscussed issues and provide practical insights to help guide new researchers in the field of deep learning for medical image analysis.

title: Design and Experimental Evaluation of an ESP32-Based Power Quality Analyzer with Introduction to Supra-Harmonic Analysis
authors: Axel Uriel Martínez Jacobo, Alejandro Villegas Ortega, Pedro Martínez Ortiz
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: This paper presents the design and validation of a three-phase power quality analyzer based on the ESP32 platform, featuring a maximum sampling frequency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$61.44 \text{kS} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> per channel. Unlike conventional approaches, the proposed analyzer emphasizes the detection and quantification of high-order harmonics (beyond those typically addressed in IEEE power quality standards) and interharmonics up to the Nyquist limit. The prototype was validated through synthetic tests using a KoCoS® source capable of emulating harmonic distortion, as well as a field test involving a motor coupled to an electric generator. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed system provides enhanced spectral characterization of industrial switching loads, where high-order harmonics and sideband components frequently occur.

title: Two-tier Certificate Service for Vehicle-Road Collaboration Based on Edge Proxy and Devices Mobility Features
authors: Song Li, Zhenwan Peng, Hong Ye
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: The cloud-edge collaborative architecture can effectively mitigate the network transmission burdens inherent in cloud architectures which is suitable for time-sensitive applications like assisted driving. However, the communication between continuously expanding IoT devices (network connected vehicles, traffic signals and charging stations etc.) in edge has led to blurred network boundaries and need strict communication protection. However, with the increasing of computing, storage and intelligent resources in edge creates an imbalance capacity which has not been accompanied with corresponding security architecture adjustment. Security transmission protocols like authentication or encryption for vehicle-road collaboration system still predominantly rely on Vehicular Public Key Infrastructure (VPKI), traditional Certificate Authority (CA) architectures for Web or static IoT scenarios deployed in MEC-VANET environment generates substantial communication overhead like periodic Certificate Revocation List (CRL) distribution across whole network. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a two-tier certificate service for VPKI environment based on edge proxy and devices mobility features modeling. The solution decentralizes partial CA functionalities to edge thereby enhancing network performance and security.

title: HSM-YOLO: Hierarchical Screening and Multi-scale YOLOv8
authors: Xudong Yang, Sugang Ma, Xiaobao Yang, Yang Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: Small object detection in complex scenes is challenging due to low resolution, weak features, and background interference. Existing detectors, such as YOLOv8, often fail to preserve fine-grained details for small objects during multi-scale feature fusion and lack sufficient multi-scale representation capabilities. To address these issues, this paper proposes HSM-YOLO, an enhanced YOLOv8 model for improved small object detection. We introduce two innovations: first, a High-level Screening Feature Pyramid Network (HS-FPN) that uses high-level semantic guidance to enhance low-level features, improving multi-scale fusion for small objects. Second, an Enhanced Multi-Scale feature learning C2f module (MSC2f) replaces standard C2f blocks in the backbone to boost multi-scale representation and optimize model efficiency. Experiments on the VisDrone2019 dataset show that HSM-YOLO significantly outperforms YOLOv8 and other advanced detectors, achieving a $25.8 \%$ gain in overall mAP@.5:.95 and a $14.4 \%$ gain in small object APs. This validates the effectiveness of HS-FPN and MSC2f and provides a robust solution for small object detection in complex scenes.

title: Quantifying Power Systems Resilience Using Statistical Analysis and Bayesian Learning
authors: Apsara Adhikari, Charlotte Wertz, Anamika Dubey, Arslan Ahmad, Ian Dobson
abstract: The increasing frequency and intensity of extreme weather events is significantly affecting the power grid, causing large-scale outages and impacting power system resilience. Yet limited work has been done on systematically modeling the impacts of weather parameters to quantify resilience. This study presents a framework using statistical and Bayesian learning approaches to quantitatively model the relationship between weather parameters and power system resilience metrics. By leveraging real-world publicly available outage and weather data, we identify key weather variables of wind speed, temperature, and precipitation influencing a particular region’s resilience metrics. A case study of Cook County, Illinois, and Miami-Dade County, Florida, reveals that these weather parameters are critical factors in resiliency analysis and risk assessment. Additionally, we find that these weather variables have combined effects when studied jointly compared to their effects in isolation. This framework provides valuable insights for understanding how weather events affect power distribution system performance, supporting decision-makers in developing more effective strategies for risk mitigation, resource allocation, and adaptation to changing climatic conditions.

title: Automatic Enrichment of Biometric Databases with Metadata Using LLMs
authors: Maha Zerroug, Mohamed Radouane
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Biometric systems are essential in security, healthcare, and forensic applications, and they increasingly depend on large-scale databases containing biometric traits such as iris images for identification and verification. However, these databases typically suffer from a lack of comprehensive and semantically rich metadata, which limits their utility for advanced machine learning tasks, interpretability, and efficient data retrieval. This study investigates the ability of large language models (LLMs) to automatically generate meaningful, reliable, and context-sensitive metadata from iris images, thereby enhancing the value and usability of biometric data sets. We propose a novel processing pipeline that combines classical visual feature extraction techniques with textual embeddings derived from state-of-the-art pre-trained LLMs, including BERT, GPT, and LLaMA. By leveraging the multimodal nature of these embeddings, our approach enriches the iris image representations beyond raw pixel data, capturing nuanced image quality attributes, illumination conditions, occlusions, and other biometricrelevant factors. Experimental validation is performed on two widely used iris biometric datasets: CASIA-IrisThousand and UBIRIS. We demonstrate that integrating LLM-generated metadata with visual features leads to improved classification performance in subject identification tasks, compared to using visual features alone. The approach also facilitates semantic search and supports advanced analytics by providing interpretable metadata descriptors. Furthermore, our results reveal critical challenges such as domain adaptation of LLMs to specialized biometric imagery, efficient fusion of textual and visual modalities, and managing limited labeled data for supervised fine-tuning. These findings highlight important directions for future research aimed at automating the annotation and enhancement of biometric databases using large pretrained language models. Overall, the paper introduces a multimodal pipeline that fuses visual and textual embeddings for biometric data enrichment. Experimental results on CASIA-Iris and UBIRIS confirm the effectiveness of integrating LLMs into biometric recognition systems.

title: Leveraging Design Static Analysis for Vertical Reuse in Functional Verification
authors: Petr Bardonek, Marcela Zachariášová
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: The Portable Test and Stimulus Standard (PSS) is an emerging standard enabling higher abstraction for simulation-based verification through graph-based stimulus generation, promoting modular reuse. However, achieving vertical reuse—integrating block-level PSS models into top-level ones—remains a significant challenge due to the manual effort required. This paper introduces static analysis as an essential phase in automating vertical reuse. It applies data and control flow analyses combined with a Satisfiability Modulo Theories solver to trace signal paths from the top-level design to its submodules. Experimental validation demonstrates the applicability of the approach on the execution stage of a RISC-V processor. Its scalability and efficiency are further evaluated using a configurable benchmark with varying design sizes and hierarchy levels. The findings suggest that the static analysis provides sufficient information about interconnections and dependencies in the top-level design to determine connections necessary for automating the vertical reuse of PSS models.

title: Classification of Arrhythmic Heart Sound Signals
authors: Eduardo A. Bernal-Bonilla, Álvaro Anzueto-Ríos, Blanca Tovar-Corona, Armando Juárez-Valdés, Juan C. Pino-Padrón, María del Pilar Cruz-Dominguez
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: This work presents a comprehensive approach for the automatic classification of heart sound signals as rhythmic or arrhythmic using signal processing and machine learning techniques. A balanced database was constructed from public recordings by applying a preselection process based on objective metrics such as signal-to-noise ratio, kurtosis, and spectral entropy to ensure acoustic quality. The signals were transformed into the spectral domain using the Fast Fourier Transform, and relevant features were extracted as input for a Multilayer Perceptron. The model demonstrated stable behavior during training, with consistent loss and accuracy curves across both training and validation sets. An accuracy of 95.65 % was reached, with 100 % of specificity and 96 % of precision. These results suggest the feasibility of developing efficient, low-cost computer-aided diagnosis systems based on phonocardiographic recordings, with potential applications in both clinical and research environments.

title: Evaluation of DPU-Accelerated CNNS for Emergency RF Signal Classification in Future Rescue Systems
authors: Carlos Alexander Osorio Quero, Jose Martinez-Carranza
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Time-critical analysis of RF emissions in disaster zones can alert responders to survivor locations and infrastructure status. This work evaluates DPU-accelerated convolutional neural networks (CNNs) for emergency RF signal classification as a building block for future rescue systems. We prototype a cost-effective pipeline that couples low-cost RTL-SDR front ends with FPGA-based processing on Xilinx Artix devices and RFSoC platforms for real-time inference. The system ingests complex baseband (I/Q) streams and classifies ten modulation types commonly encountered during emergencies. We implemented and compared three CNN architectures tailored for FPGA Deep Processing Units (DPUs) via hardware-aware optimizations. In data sets representative of field conditions, the best model achieves an accuracy of 96 % classification while sustaining real-time throughput on the embedded hardware. These results indicate that compact, energy-efficient DPU deployments can deliver reliable RF situational awareness and are suitable for integration into SWaP-constrained UAVs to support autonomous and timely search-and-rescue missions.

title: Portable Impedance Microfluidic Platform for 60-Minute Antibiotic Susceptibility Testing
authors: Hanane Tissir
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: We present a portable, low-cost microfluidic impedance platform for rapid phenotypic antimicrobial susceptibility testing (AST). The system computes a calibration-free relative impedance metric (Δ_rel = V(0)/V(t) − 1) from real-time voltage ratios to distinguish bacterial growth from antibiotic inhibition within 60 minutes (n = 6). Using only 100 μL samples and open-source electronics, the platform achieves sub-millivolt precision at a total cost below $50. Compared with conventional culture-based AST (> 18 h), this approach provides a 15−20× reduction in diagnostic time, supporting decentralized, point-of-care applications in resource-limited settings.

title: Load Matching Potential of Urban Renewables during Extreme Heat in New York City
authors: N.W. Elgalad, K. Sookdar, S. Madhusmita, J.E. González-Cruz, M.P. Jensen, M. Yue
abstract: Integration of renewable resources to meet growing energy demand is becoming a global priority under decarbonization mandates. This study contributes to ongoing efforts on the matter by assessing the feasibility of using offshore wind and rooftop photovoltaic systems to meet electricity demand during a period of thermal stress in New York City—August 2019. A unified modelling framework, based on the Urbanized Weather Research and Forecasting model, is used to simulate climate, renewable resources and energy demand variables. Findings show significant energy load miss-match, ranging from 3 to 5 GW, between the demand and the composite renewable generation outcome.This study provids a transferable framework for evaluating renewable integration in dense urban regions and highlights the need for additional strategies to support grid resilience during extreme heat events, while clarifying the role of local resources in fully managing NYC’s load.

title: Wireless Human-Machine Collaboration in Industry 5.0
authors: Gaoyang Pang, Wanchun Liu, Dusit Niyato, Daniel E. Quevedo, Branka Vucetic, Yonghui Li
abstract: Wireless Human-Machine Collaboration (WHMC) represents a critical advancement for Industry 5.0, enabling seamless interaction between humans and machines across geographically distributed systems. As the WHMC systems become increasingly important for achieving complex collaborative control tasks, ensuring their stability is essential for practical deployment and long-term operation. Stability analysis certifies how the closed-loop system will behave under model randomness, which is essential for systems operating with wireless communications. However, the fundamental stability analysis of the WHMC systems remains an unexplored challenge due to the intricate interplay between the stochastic nature of wireless communications, dynamic human operations, and the inherent complexities of control system dynamics. This paper establishes a fundamental WHMC model incorporating dual wireless loops for machine and human control. Our framework accounts for practical factors such as short-packet transmissions, fading channels, and advanced HARQ schemes. We model human control lag as a Markov process, which is crucial for capturing the stochastic nature of human interactions. Building on this model, we propose a stochastic cycle-cost-based approach to derive a stability condition for the WHMC system, expressed in terms of wireless channel statistics, human dynamics, and control parameters. Our findings are validated through extensive numerical simulations and a proof-of-concept experiment, where we developed and tested a novel wireless collaborative cart-pole control system. The results confirm the effectiveness of our approach and provide a robust framework for future research on WHMC systems in more complex environments.

title: Task-Oriented Integrated Sensing and Semantic Communications for Multi-Device Video Analytics
authors: Yinghui He, Xin Li, Jun Luo
abstract: Video analytics plays a vital role in modern applications such as public safety and smart cities, yet transmitting high-resolution video over wireless networks is severely constrained by bandwidth and latency. Existing semantic communication approaches alleviate communication overhead by discarding irrelevant content, but they often impose prohibitive computational costs on resource-constrained surveillance devices. To overcome this limitation, we propose SenSem, a sensing-assisted semantic communication framework that uniquely leverages channel state information (CSI) to reduce both communication and computation overhead. SenSem first exploits location cues embedded in CSI to estimate the region of interest and crop frames before upload. On the cropped frames, a lightweight semantic evaluator scores blocks, and a joint block selection and transmit power control algorithm maximizes the analytics performance for multi-device uplink; at the edge, a sensing-assisted analytics network injects spatial cues to further boost inference. Extensive evaluations on the WARP platform demonstrate that SenSem consistently outperforms state-of-the-art baselines, achieving superior video analytics accuracy under strict latency constraints. By seamlessly reducing both transmission and device-side computation overhead, SenSem, offers a scalable and efficient solution for next-generation wireless video analytics systems.

title: A Lightweight Cascade Network for Wideband Signal Detection and Recognition in Aerial Degraded Electromagnetic Scenarios
authors: Xikang Wang, Hua Xu, Zisen Qi, Qingwei Meng, Dan Wang, Hongcheng Fan, Yunhao Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: In recent years, object detection methods have achieved promising results in the field of wideband signal detection and recognition (WSDR). However, for resource-constrained airborne platforms and degraded electromagnetic environments, existing methods still face challenges such as high computational overhead and insufficient noise robustness. In this article, we propose a lightweight cascade network based on YOLO (LC-YOLO) and apply it to tackle the WSDR challenge under complex electromagnetic environments or resource-constrained scenarios. Specifically, we design a lightweight hybrid attention enhancement module (HAEM), which is constructed by channel attention (CA), pixel attention (PA), and mixed-shape separable convolution groups. It is cascaded at the front of the backbone network to enhance the representation ability of targets in images. To further improve the network's detection performance for targets with extreme aspect ratios, we propose a feature extraction module for optimizing the backbone network, named cross stage partial with strip module (C2SM). This module inherits the gradient shunting advantage of the efficient layer aggregation network (ELAN) and integrates the receptive field characteristics of large strip convolution, significantly improving the detection accuracy of slender signal targets while reducing the number of parameters. Furthermore, we reveal that the coordinate discretization in distribution focused loss (DFL) limits complete boundary regression for slender targets, and propose an enhanced approach integrating coordinate continuous regression with Smooth L1 Loss. Experimental results show that the N, S, and M configurations of LC-YOLO outperform the current mainstream lightweight state-of-the-art (SOTA) object detection methods on the WidebandSig53 dataset (WBSig53). The smallest configuration, LC-YOLO-N, outperforms the baseline model YOLOv8-N by 3.9% in mAP, while maintaining only 2.5 M parameters and an inference speed of 113 FPS.

title: A Linear Programming Framework for Optimal Event-Triggered LQG Control
authors: Zahra Hashemi, Dipankar Maity
abstract: This letter explores intelligent scheduling of sensor-to-controller communication in networked control systems, particularly when data transmission incurs a cost. While the optimal controller in a standard linear-quadratic Gaussian (LQG) setup can be computed analytically, determining the optimal times to transmit sensor data remains computationally and analytically challenging. We show that, through reformulation and the introduction of auxiliary binary variables, the scheduling problem can be cast as a computationally efficient mixed-integer linear program (MILP). This formulation not only simplifies the analysis but also reveals structural insights and provides clear decision criterion at each step. Embedding the approach within a model predictive control ( MPC) framework enables dynamic adaptation, and we prove that the resulting scheduler performs at least as well as any deterministic strategy (e.g., periodic strategy). Simulation results further demonstrate that our method consistently outperforms traditional periodic scheduling.

title: DA-Net: A Double Alignment Multimodal Learning Network for Point Cloud Quality Assessment
authors: Xinqiang Wu, Zhouyan He, Ting Luo, Gangyi Jiang, Wujie Zhou, Linwei Zhu, Weisi Lin
abstract: Existing multimodal point cloud quality assessment (PCQA) methods usually integrate 3D and 2D information to simulate human visual perception of distortions. However, due to the lack of consideration of spatial correspondence, they have difficulty to learn consistent distortion representations from different modalities in the same region of the PC. In addition, they also ignore the heterogeneity of modalities and rely on complex fusion mechanisms (e.g., attention) to integrate multimodal features. Both lead to limited performance and increased computational complexity. To address these limitations, we propose a novel double alignment multimodal learning network (DA-Net), which introduces two key alignment strategies. Specifically, the first is spatial pre-alignment strategy, which generates informative 2D patch for each 3D patch via an adaptive patch projection module (APPM), ensuring accurate spatial correspondence of different modalities prior to feature extraction. The second is a uniform feature alignment strategy, which includes feature disentanglement module (FDM) and feature mapping module (FMM) to relieve heterogeneity of modalities and guide the optimization of 2D and 3D encoder. Finally, multimodal features are simply integrated and regressed to obtain the quality score. Experimental results demonstrate that the DA-Net exhibits outstanding performance and generalization ability. It also achieves lower computational complexity compared with other multimodal PCQA methods. The source codes of DA-Net will be available at https://github.com/Rphone/DA-Net.

title: Wireless Multi-Port Sensing: Virtual-VNA-Enabled De-Embedding of an Over-the-Air Fixture
authors: Philipp Del Hougne
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: We develop a multi-port-backscatter-modulation technique to determine, over the air (OTA), the scattering parameters of a linear, passive, time-invariant multi-port device under test (DUT). A set of “not-directly-accessible” (NDA) antennas can be switched between being terminated by the DUT or by a specific, known, tunable load network (TLN). Waves can be radiated and captured via a distinct set of “accessible” antennas that couple OTA to the NDA antennas. First, we characterize the OTA fixture between the accessible antennas’ ports and the DUT’s ports. We achieve this based on our recently introduced “Virtual VNA” technique; specifically, we connect the NDA antennas to the TLN and measure the scattering at the accessible antennas’ ports for various configurations of the TLN. Second, we connect the NDA antennas to the DUT and measure the scattering at the accessible antennas’ ports. Third, we de-embed the OTA fixture to retrieve the DUT’s scattering parameters. We experimentally validate our technique at 2.45 GHz for 1-port DUTs and 5-port DUTs, considering a rich-scattering OTA fixture inside a reverberation chamber. We systematically study the influence of the number of accessible antennas and various conceivable simplifications in terms of the system model as well as the properties of the TLN. Our wireless multi-port sensing technique can find applications in areas like RFID and wireless bioelectronics.

title: Enhanced Entity Matching between PubMed Authors and Research Institute’s Employees using Machine Learning
authors: Sifei Han, Lingyun Shi, Paul Kingsbury, Fuchiang R. Tsui
abstract: This study aimed to develop an automated entity matching system for linking a research institute’s employees with their PubMed publications, reducing reliance on manual processes. Such entity matching is critical for research productivity review and collaboration fostering. The corpus comprised 121,447 employees and 75,546 PubMed publications (2012-2023) from a quaternary care pediatric hospital. We developed and evaluated three models: a Random Forest (RF) model, an ad-hoc rule-based model, and a hybrid approach combining both. Features included author name, affiliation, and medical subject headings (MeSH) terms. The RF and hybrid models were robust in handling incomplete or missing data by leveraging MeSH terms that were not included in the rule-based model due to data complexity. The open researcher and contributor identifiers (ORCIDs) served as the reference standard for the entity matching. Evaluation metrics include F1-score, precision, and recall. The F1-score of the rule-based model was 0.95 (95% C.I., 0.94-0.97); of the RF model, 0.98 (95% C.I., 0.97-0.99) [P<0.05, rule-based as the reference model]. The precision of the rules-based model was 1; of the RF model, 0.97 (95% C.I., 0.95-0.98), [P<0.05, rule-based as the reference model]. The recall of the rules-based model was 0.91 (95% C.I., 0.88-0.95); of the RF model, 0.99 (95% C.I., 0.98-1), [P<0.05, rule-based as the reference model]. The hybrid model had the same performance as the RF model. This retrospective study demonstrates that machine learning models incorporating MeSH terms and effective missing data handling improved entity matching performance in linking researchers with their publications.

title: Uniaxial Piezoresistive Stress Sensor With Near-Zero Transverse Sensitivity
authors: Xinbo Lu, Bin Peng, Tao Wang, Kaituo Wu, Kun Liu, Yuexing Wang, Shuairong Deng, Xiangyu Sun, Linwei Cao
abstract: Prognostic health management (PHM) of microsystems is of great importance in the forward design of reliability. Piezoresistive stress sensors are gaining increasing attention in PHM research. In order to measure stress in specific directions, a stress sensor with near-zero transverse sensitivity is proposed in this work. The stress sensor is based on a Wheatstone bridge consisting of different sensing units. It is found that the magnitude of stress transferred to the sensing unit is not the same as the stress applied to the sensor chip. This affects the sensitivities of the sensing units. The transverse sensitivity is reduced to nearly zero by optimizing the geometry parameters of the sensing units while taking into account the stress transfer coefficients derived in this work. The experimental results show that the longitudinal sensitivity coefficient of the optimized stress sensor is 0.092 mV/MPa, and the longitudinal to transverse sensitivity ratio in absolute value is 168. The proposed stress sensor has excellent uniaxial response characteristics. These advantages indicate that the proposed sensor has potential applications in PHM-oriented microsystem research.

title: Design and Implementation of a Low-Power Memristor-Based Piccolo-80 Lightweight Encryption Algorithm Using VTM Logic Gates
authors: Farzad Mozafari, Majid Ahmadi
publish: IEEE Canadian Journal of Electrical and Computer Engineering
abstract: Lightweight cryptography (LWC) has become increasingly critical for ensuring secure communication in energy-constrained Internet of Things (IoT) systems. Memristor-based architecture provides a promising approach for secure communication in energy-sensitive and hardware-constrained applications. Piccolo is a lightweight encryption algorithm that offers high security while enabling compact hardware implementation. In addition, Piccolo is specifically designed to operate efficiently in resource-limited environments, making it a strong candidate for low-energy applications such as IoT devices. However, earlier implementations of the Piccolo algorithm on field-programmable gate array (FPGA) platforms, CMOS, and hybrid memristor-CMOS (MeMOS) technology have faced challenges with high power consumption, hardware overhead, and limited scalability. This article presents a novel architecture for implementing the Piccolo-80 encryption algorithm using the voltage-to-memristance (VTM) approach, in which the design maps Piccolo’s primary operations onto VTM stateful logic gates. This enhances performance, reduces switching activity, and leverages the nonvolatile properties of memristors. The proposed design introduces VTM-based memristor logic gates that significantly reduce hardware complexity and power consumption compared with previous implementations. The results from comparing CMOS and hybrid MeMOS implementations in terms of area and energy consumption demonstrate that hardware implementation of Piccolo’s lightweight algorithm using the VTM approach not only improves energy efficiency but also enables the design of optimized, low-power circuits. The design achieves a power consumption of 17.4 mW at 1.8 V and 133 MHz, with only 1214 gate equivalents (GEs), reducing power by up to 32% and area by nearly 20% compared with state-of-the-art hybrid MeMOS designs.

title: Synthetic Data Generation for Microalgal Cultivation Using Variational Autoencoders, GANs, and Copula-Based Models: A Case Study on Nannochloropsis oculata
authors: Antonio García-Domínguez, Hans Christian Correa-Aguado, Carlos E. Galván-Tejada, Gloria Viviana Cerrillo-Rojas, Jacqueline S. Ortiz-Letechipía, Jorge I. Galván-Tejada
abstract: The microalga Nannochloropsis oculata was cultivated under controlled laboratory conditions, but cost and time constraints limited the number of experimental replicates to only 17. Previous studies have demonstrated the value of synthetic data generation in domains with limited experimental access, including biomedical research, water resource modeling, and genomics. However, applications in microalgal biotechnology remain scarce, despite the high cost and complexity of empirical trials in this field. To overcome this limitation, synthetic data generation methods based on artificial intelligence were used to simulate additional experimental conditions and expand the dataset 100-fold, resulting in 1700 synthetic samples. Three generative approaches were evaluated: variational autoencoders, generative adversarial networks, and copula-based models. The quality of the synthetic data was evaluated by comparing it to the original experimental dataset using statistical divergence measures and the predictive performance of Random Forest models trained to estimate biomass and lipid content. The variational autoencoder method achieved the highest similarity to the original dataset, yielding the lowest divergence score and predictive error in biomass and lipid content. While this study focuses on a single real-world dataset, the proposed approach could be extended to other biological contexts where data scarcity is a limiting factor. These findings suggest that artificial intelligence techniques can effectively augment small-scale biological datasets, providing a valuable strategy to enhance experimentation and analysis in resource-limited conditions.

title: Voxel-Level Brain States Prediction Using Swin Transformer_supp1-3613793.docx
authors: Jinglei Lv
abstract: Understanding brain dynamics is important for neuroscience and mental health. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) enables the measurement of neural activities through blood-oxygen-level-dependent (BOLD) signals, which represent brain states. In this study, we aim to predict future human resting brain states with fMRI. Due to the 3D voxel-wise spatial organization and temporal dependencies of the fMRI data, we propose a novel architecture which employs a 4D Shifted Window (Swin) Transformer as encoder to efficiently learn spatio-temporal information and a convolutional decoder to enable brain state prediction at the same spatial and temporal resolution as the input fMRI data. We used 100 unrelated subjects from the Human Connectome Project (HCP) for model training and testing. Our novel model has shown high accuracy when predicting 7.2s resting-state brain activities based on the prior 23.04s fMRI time series. The predicted brain states highly resemble BOLD contrast and dynamics. This work shows promising evidence that the spatiotemporal organization of the human brain can be learned by a Swin Transformer model, at high resolution, which provides a potential for reducing the fMRI scan time and the development of brain-computer interfaces in the future.
