title: An Analogue Counter Using Memristor for Single Photon Detectors
authors: Hao Qian, Shengchao Zhang, Zidu Li, Paul C.-P. Chao, Bhaskar Choubey
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: A novel memristor-based analogue counter has been proposed by using a single-photon avalanche diode (SPAD) for the single-photon detection. The initial results of the counter circuitry are demonstrated by utilising physics-based redox non-volatile memristor simulation model under room temperature. The proposed counter circuitry currently achieves a precision of 3 bits. The potential for higher bit resolution in this system is also discussed. This novel analogue counter enables reduced circuit complexity and improved performance in low-light, high-speed imaging.

title: Multimodal Motion Magnetically Actuated Microrobot Based on Heterogeneous Magnetization Design
authors: Haotian Yan, Wenbo Li, Haotian Yang, Jincheng Hu, Zhenteng Ma, Sunshi Huang, Yiaozhen Hou, Huaping Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Magnetically actuated microrobots have shown great promise in medical diagnosis and therapeutic applications due to their miniature size and non-invasive controllability. However, conventional rigid microrobots face significant challenges in navigating natural orifices, exhibiting limited adaptability and struggling to perform complex biomedical tasks. Flexible magnetic microrobots, while offering better compliance with biological environments, often suffer from poor environmental adaptability, limited controllability in multimodal locomotion and difficulties in integrating actuation and functional operations. To address these limitations, this study proposes a novel design strategy combining heterogeneous magnetization and soft-material fabrication techniques to develop two functional microrobots: a quadruped crawling microrobot and a starfish-inspired grasping microrobot. Under the control of a triaxial Helmholtz coil system that generates programmable dynamic magnetic fields, the microrobots demonstrate versatile locomotion modes, including rolling and crawling. A real-time vision-based servo system is integrated to monitor the microrobot's motion and enable autonomous decision-making at branched pathways via predefined motion judgment points. Furthermore, the proposed system supports adaptive mode transitions in response to complex and unstructured environments, paving the way for intelligent operation of flexible microrobots in biomedical scenarios.

title: Extended Charge-Pump Pulser for Bipolar 5-Level Operations in Medical Ultrasound
authors: Marco Rossano, Gianfranco Avitabile, Antonello Florio
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: The transmission chain is an essential part of medical ultrasound imaging systems, having a direct impact on the quality of the transmitted signal and power efficiency. This paper presents an enhanced 5-level bipolar pulser architecture based on a charge pump design that has been extended with additional switches to enable charge retention and dual-supply operation. Simulations using ideal components demonstrate several potential improvements, including reduced power consumption, improved harmonic rejection, and increased fundamental output voltage. The proposed solution also reduces the need for external components, making it suitable for future full on-chip integration and advanced imaging applications.

title: CORA-OpAmp: A Compact Open-Source Reinforcement-Learning Approach for Operational Amplifier Optimization in IHP SG13G2
authors: Maximilian Scherzer, Mario Auer
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Automated optimization of operational amplifiers is a complex task that demands efficient methods. This paper presents a compact, open-source reinforcement learning approach for op-amp optimization within the IHP SG13G2 process. Our approach adopts and compares the TD3 and SAC algorithms against DDPG, showcasing more reliable learning and faster progression. Using a compact MLP rather than a GNN for the agent reduces complexity and computing effort, while still achieving competitive results. The proposed framework makes use of the g<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m</inf>/I<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">d</inf> design method as the primary state input for the RL agent, thereby effectively embedding well-known analog design principles to improve guidance. We also apply online normalization to the agent inputs, thus enhancing stability and significantly reducing the initial random search phase. Reward functions are specifically designed to address op-amp performance metrics. Findings from an experimental folded-cascode optimization study demonstrate that, compared to DDPG-based methods, convergence is rapid and learning rates are stable. Compared to prior GNN-based RL approaches, our lightweight framework offers improved usability, reproducibility, and accessibility as an open-source tool.

title: Evaluating Electric Charge Variation Sensors for Camera-free Eye Tracking on Smart Glasses
authors: Alan Magdaleno, Pietro Bonazzi, Tommaso Polonelli, Michele Magno
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Contactless Electrooculography (EOG) using electric charge variation (QVar) sensing has recently emerged as a promising eye-tracking technique on wearable devices. Q-var enables low-power and unobtrusive interaction without requiring skin-contact electrodes. Previous work demonstrated that such systems can accurately classify eye movements using onboard TinyML under controlled laboratory conditions. However, the performance and robustness of contactless EOG in real-world scenarios—where environmental noise and user variability are significant—remain largely unexplored. In this paper, we present a field evaluation of a previously proposed QVar-based eye-tracking system, assessing its limitations in everyday usage contexts across 29 users and 100 recordings in everyday scenarios, such as working in front of a laptop. Our results show that classification accuracy varies between 57% and 89% depending on the user, with an average of 74.5%, degrading significantly in the presence of nearby electronic noise sources. Our experimental results show that contactless EOG remains viable under realistic conditions, though subject variability and environmental factors can significantly affect classification accuracy. The findings inform the future development of wearable gaze interfaces for human-computer interaction and augmented reality, supporting the transition of this technology from prototype to practice.

title: Quantum Federated Learning Based Power System Stability Assessment: A Noise Robust Approach
authors: Sijia Yu, Yifan Zhou
abstract: The integration of distributed energy resources requires effective distributed transient stability assessments (TSA) that can capture complex stability dynamics through localized data processing. In this paper, we propose a Quantum Vertical Federated Learning (QVFL)-enabled TSA framework. Our core innovation is a quantum average pooling-based distributed TSA method (QdTSA-AP), which enables data-driven transient stability prediction in a resource-efficient manner while being robustness-by-design against quantum noise, thus ensuring practical applicability in the current Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) era. Key contributions include: 1) A quantum average pooling method for effective information extraction from local TSA data while minimizing the communication overhead of transferring quantum information; 2) A lightweight noise-robustness evaluation method, which, for the first time, applies the Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR) concept from signal processing to assess the noise robustness of QdTSA-AP, which can be generalized to a wide range of quantum machine learning (QML) tasks; 3) A theoretical proof, based on SNR, showing that average pooling enhances the noise resilience of QVFL through its architectural design rather than requiring additional computational overhead. Extensive numerical experiments validate the accuracy and noise robustness of QdTSA-AP and the effectiveness of the proposed average pooling strategy.

title: Comparison of Static, Dynamic, and Stochastic Economic Dispatch Models
authors: Shishir Lamichhane, Anamika Dubey
abstract: This paper presents and compares four economic dispatch models: Static Economic Dispatch (SED), Dynamic Economic Dispatch (DED), Stochastic Static Economic Dispatch (SSED), and Stochastic Dynamic Economic Dispatch (SDED). The SSED and SDED models are formulated as two-stage stochastic optimization problems that incorporate uncertainty arising from both load and wind power, while accounting for their temporal correlations. Scenarios are generated using a method motivated by importance and stratified sampling, utilizing the cumulative density functions of the sub-hourly levels. All models are then implemented and tested using the standard test system. The results show that, between SED and DED, the DED model proactively dispatches out-of-merit order generators early to minimize the overall dispatch cost by reducing curtailment costs over the planning horizon. In contrast, the myopic nature of SED leads to higher dispatch costs over the entire horizon due to its lack of foresight. Among all four models, SDED demonstrates the best performance under uncertainty, as it effectively captures both uncertainty and look-ahead decision-making capability.

title: A Realistic Cyber-Physical Power System Testbed and Use Case of an AMI Mesh Network
authors: Vinicius Bobato, Adel Heidari-Akhijahani, Kumpanat Thongmai, Ana Goulart, Karen Butler-Purry
abstract: Power distribution systems and communication networks are inter-dependent. Remote data collection and control of distributed energy resources (DERs), such as windmills, solar panels and battery energy storage systems, employ Smart Meters, Repeaters, Collectors, and Distribution System Operators (DSOs). These devices exchange data through an Advanced Metering Infrastructure (AMI) network. To study this communication network and the impact of a cyber attack on the distribution system, this paper presents two attack scenarios on a cyber-physical power system testbed that uses the Real Time Digital Simulator (RTDS) and Common Open Research Emulator (CORE). Using realistic load and generation data from SMART-DS synthetic dataset, an Adversary performs a denial-of-service attack (DoS) on the Collector in the first scenario. In the second scenario, the Adversary performs a Man-in-the-Middle (MITM) attack in the network that connects the Collector to the utility’s DSO. The results show how these attacks impact the integrity of the load values the energy utility receives.

title: Analysis and Simulation Verification of Locust Jump-Flying Motion
authors: Zhiyuan Wu, Qi Li, Jin Yu, Yi Xu, Qing Shi
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Locusts exhibit stable jump-flying locomotion with remarkable environmental adaptability. However, prior designs failed to integrate jumping and flying modes effectively due to insufficient kinematic model inspired by the locust, leading to motion instability. In this study, we utilized the Kinovea and MATLAB software to calibrate and analyze the jump-flying data of locusts, revealing that its linear velocity profile exhibits three distinct linear phases. Before flapping their wings, locusts experience a rapid increase in jumping linear velocity. In the ascending stage after flapping their wings, the resistance increases, and the linear velocity decreases slowly. Due to the jumping speed being much greater than the speed required for level flight, the linear velocity further decreases. Subsequently, we conducted simulations grounded in locust motion data. The results demonstrate that the robot's linear velocity profile similarly manifests three distinct linear phases, establishing direct kinematic similarity to locust locomotion. This discovery will enable locust-inspired robots to more accurately replicate biological prototypes, achieving stable and long-time jump-flying locomotion.

title: Influence of Precursor Milling Time on the Photocatalytic Performance of ZnO Thin Films in Methylene Blue Degradation
authors: G. Bobadilla-Barrón, E. B.-Ramírez Martínez, M. De La L.O. Amador, Ángel Eduardo Zamora-Suárez
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Zinc oxide (ZnO) thin films were synthesized via the ultrasonic chemical spray technique, using zinc acetate as a Zn precursor, subjected to a mechanical milling process at different times, namely, 15, 30, 45, 60, 120, 240, and 300 minutes. All films were deposited onto glass substrates at a fixed temperature of 475°C and constant deposition time of 8 minutes. Structural characterization via X-ray diffraction confirmed the presence of the hexagonal wurtzite structure with a preferred orientation along the (002) plane. Scanning electron microscopy revealed significant changes in surface morphology as a function of milling time, and atomic force microscopy was used to correlate surface morphology with the photocatalytic activity of the synthesized samples. The photocatalytic activity of the films was evaluated by monitoring the degradation of methylene blue under UV irradiation. ZnO films prepared with a precursor milled for 45 minutes exhibited the highest photocatalytic efficiency, suggesting an optimal balance between crystallinity, surface area, and charge carrier dynamics. These results highlight the critical role of precursor milling time in tuning the physicochemical and photocatalytic properties of ZnO thin films for environmental applications.

title: Using Automatic Code Generation to Streamline the Real-Time FPGA Deployment of DNNs at the Edge
authors: João Rodrigo Faria, Fábio D. L. Coutinho, Arnaldo S. R. Oliveira
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper explores the automatic code generation of Deep Neural Networks (DNNs) for accelerating the real-time deployment of DNNs on Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) at the network edge. Using a language-based High-Level Synthesis (HLS) tool, we present a generator that produces HLS-compatible source code for user-defined DNN architectures. The tool enables rapid prototyping and deployment of machine learning-based physical layer functions in communication systems. It supports diverse DNN configurations, including fully connected, convolutional, and pooling layers, as well as various activation functions, providing flexibility for edge applications. By releasing the generator as open source, we aim to lower the entry barrier for DNN development and promote reproducibility in the design of hardware-accelerated neural networks.

title: Grid Strength Metrics Comparison for Voltage and Frequency Stability Study
authors: Md Amimul Ehsan, Badrul Chowdhury
abstract: Studying grid strength is useful for understanding challenges related to grid integration of inverter-based resources (IBR). While weak grid conditions may drive the grid to its voltage and/or frequency stability limits, and there are different methods to identify grid strength, the lack of a standard around these methods may lead to misleading conclusions. In this paper, we study and summarize a list of metrics to define and characterize grid strength and discuss their efficacy for small and large signal stability cases. We investigate voltage and frequency at IBR points of interconnection (POI) for different operating conditions in an IEEE test system using a well-known electromagnetic transients simulation platform. Our results show that some advanced metrics indicate stability concerns for a selected IBR integration scheme, while another metric exhibits higher accuracy in determining frequency instability.

title: A Secure and Lightweight Deduplication Encryption Scheme for Edge-Assisted AIoT
authors: Xinhua Cui, Hongwei Lin, Huanhuan Xu, Xinyu Zhang, Youliang Tian
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: With the rapid advancement of Artificial Intelligence of Things (AIoT) and the exponential growth of data, secure storage of sensitive data faces serious challenges. However, existing encryption schemes struggle to balance lightweight design with robust security, leading to inefficient data storage. In this paper, we propose a novel lightweight assisted encryption scheme that enhances security without compromising device efficiency. Using edge-assisted encryption, the scheme prevents direct server access to user information and alleviates the computational burden on smart devices. Furthermore, the scheme leverages edge servers to assist in generating deduplication tags for the cloud server, facilitating efficient and secure deduplication without revealing the original data. Experimental analysis demonstrates that this scheme offers superior security performance compared to similar systems, while maintaining low computational overhead for AIoT devices.

title: Graph-Based Attention Mechanisms for Solving the AC Optimal Power Flow Problem in Electrical Power Networks
authors: Ali Trigui, Mohammed Olama, George Siopsis, Hatem Eldakhakhni, Marouane Salhi
abstract: With the increasing complexity and data availability in modern power systems, learning-based approaches to AC Optimal Power Flow (AC OPF) have garnered significant attention. In particular, the structure of smart grids lends itself naturally to graph-based representations, where Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) can capture spatial and relational dependencies. This paper investigates attention-based GNN architectures tailored to heterogeneous graph representations of electric grids. We evaluate two major paradigms: relational attention, which distinguishes between edge types during message passing, and meta-path attention, which captures high-level semantics through multi-hop, typed paths. Using a large corpus of public AC OPF scenarios, we benchmark representative models of each type of attention. Our results demonstrate the benefits of heterogeneous attention-based models in accurately capturing grid dynamics; heterogeneous attention models achieve superior performance in both standard and perturbed settings. The findings highlight the importance of semantic-aware architectures for improving prediction robustness and interpretability in power system applications.

title: Integrated Communication Protocols for Substation Automation: HiL Validation of IEC 61850, IEEE C37.118 and IEC 60870-5-104
authors: Tommy Christopher Gaede, Eric Glende, habil Martin Wolter
abstract: The increasing integration of renewable energy sources and the decentralization of power generation pose major challenges for contemporary energy systems. Substations play a central role in this transformation and must be operated with high flexibility, reliability, and efficiency. Automation of substations requires seamless communication across heterogeneous devices, often realized via the standardized protocols IEC 61850, IEEE C37.118, and IEC 60870-5-104. This paper analyzes the characteristics and integration of these protocols, demonstrates their practical deployment in a hardware-in-the-loop setup using OPAL-RT and Siemens SIPROTEC 5 IEDs, and validates interoperability, real-time performance, and robustness under failure scenarios. Recommendations for implementing integrated communication systems in substations are given based on these findings.

title: To Be Forgotten
authors: Joanna F. DeFranco, Jeffrey Voas
abstract: In broad terms, we value being remembered for legacy and accountability. Yet we might also need the option to be virtually forgotten, to protect privacy and retain control of personal data.

title: FetchFlare: An Open-Source Strided Data Prefetcher for High-Performance Cache Hierarchies
authors: Golnaz Korkian, Neiel Leyva, Arnau Bigas, Noelia Oliete-Escuín, Abbas Haghi, Alireza Monemi, César Fuguet, Lluc Alvarez
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: In recent years, the rise of open-source hardware has transformed the landscape of technology development. In particular, RISC-V has offered hardware designers the possibility of designing processors in a much cheaper way by leveraging a rich ecosystem of open-source designs that can be easily reused, extended, and customized. Although the RISC-V ecosystem is rapidly growing and open-source processors are becoming increasingly sophisticated, some advanced architectural techniques typically employed in commercial high-performance processors are still not prevalent in RISC-V open-source architectures. Among them, hardware prefetchers have been ubiquitous in highend processors for many years, but they are not as commonly found in open-source RISC-V processors. To bridge this gap, this work presents FetchFlare, a stride prefetcher for highperformance cache hierarchies. FetchFlare is able to capture the memory access patterns of applications, predict future memory accesses, and issue prefetch requests for them. We provide an open-source RTL implementation of FetchFlare and integrate it into a complete open-source setup formed by the OpenPiton framework, the Sargantana core, and the High-Performance Data Cache (HPDCache). Compared to a baseline system without prefetching, FetchFlare achieves an average speedup of $63 \%$, avoids cache misses in the L1D and the L2 caches, and presents an average accuracy, coverage, and timeliness of $86 \%, 39 \%$, and 99%, respectively.

title: Viability of Green Ammonia Production in an Islanded Microgrid
authors: Matthew Egan, Mohammed Benidris
abstract: One of the main methods of decarbonization cited at the moment is known as "green hydrogen", or the production of hydrogen, or hydrogen carriers, via the process of electrolysis, which may then be turned back into energy via the use of fuel cells. One potential site for this which can have a great deal of potential is Alaskan hydroelectric sites. Alaskan dams, like others in the Pacific Northwest region, spill significantly during Summer and still have enough reserves to power their entire community on almost exclusively hydroelectric sources. Spilled water represents lost potential energy that could instead be stored seasonally or used in other applications, such as marine or automotive fuels. They have a large potential reserve in their dams, each of which spills significantly from the months of June to December, and are capable of producing between 230 and 3300 metric tons of ammonia, well over their current consumption levels, and a large number of small docks which may benefit from a cheaper, locally sourced fuel, from which to build a potential market. This paper looks into broader uses, as well as into potential evaluation schema based on Bernoulli’s principle to determine the spill amount over a full year. The aforementioned metric tons of ammonia could drive between $100,000 to $1,600,000 in additional yearly revenue to the utility, depending on the system installed.

title: An Analytical Approach for Designing Passive Matching Networks
authors: Owen Casha
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper presents an analytical approach for designing three-component T-section or π-section passive matching networks by using a direct and generic impedance or admittance network analysis. This approach is proposed as an alternative technique for designing such networks, which can be achieved through either a graphical approach using an impedance-admittance Smith chart, a back-to-back L-section-based matching network design, or a phase-shift-based approach. The proposed approach provides all possible T-section or π-section passive matching network configurations and their respective component values with high accuracy by analytically solving three equations, as demonstrated by the implemented algorithm.

title: Retrofitting Grid-Following IBRs for Better Fault Ride-Through
authors: Tamoghna Banerjee, Zhixin Miao, Lingling Fan, Deepak Ramasubramanian
abstract: This paper evaluates the performance of a hybrid power plant (HPP) with multiple inverter-based resources (IBRs). The IBRs are equipped with either grid-following (GFL) or grid-forming (GFM) control strategies. Four testbeds have been built and compared for their performance when the HPP is subjected to weak grid conditions and low-voltage ride-through (LVRT) scenarios. The results reveal that when only GFL-IBRs are deployed, there are notable limitations and operational constraints under these challenging conditions. However, when some of the IBRs are replaced by GFM-IBRs, the system demonstrates significantly improved robustness. The operational limits become broader, and the system’s ride-through capabilities are enhanced, offering smoother performance after fault-clearing. The retrofitted controller is a fairly new virtual admittance based GFM control emulating a voltage source behind an impedance. The simulation is performed in PSCAD and data acquisition and graphical representation was done using MATLAB.

title: Battery Parameter Calibration Using EKF and UKF for Equivalent Circuit Model
authors: Varsha Sen, Anurag K. Srivastava
abstract: The reliable performance prediction and health-aware control in battery management systems (BMS) require accurate calibration and tracking of battery model parameters. Battery ageing and operating under varying temperature and load conditions cause internal parameters such as ohmic resistance, dynamic polarization, and diffusion elements to keep changing over time, limiting the effectiveness of static parameter models. This work presents an application and a comparative study of the Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) and Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF) for real-time calibration of second-order (2RC) and third-order (3RC) battery equivalent circuit models (ECMs). A unified nonlinear state-space framework is developed to jointly estimate model parameters across multiple time constants, capturing transient and long-term dynamics that reflect battery degradation. The model parameters are assessed across a range of perturbations and noise levels to estimate accuracy and robustness. Results show that, when properly tuned, EKF and UKF can effectively track health-sensitive parameters. This work formulates a scalable approach for moderately high-order ECMs, facilitating aging-aware diagnostics and predictive control for high-end battery applications in the future.

title: Modular 1 Gbps Hardware TCP/IP FPGA Readout for MPGD Applications with APV25
authors: Fatima Bzeih, Chiara Micheli, Paolo Musico, Evaristo Cisbani
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: The APV25 front-end chip is widely used in Micro Pattern Gaseous Detectors (MPGDs), including Gas Electron Multiplier (GEM) systems, due to its robust performance and integration flexibility. Traditional readout architectures based on the VME bus impose limitations in bandwidth, scalability, and compatibility with modern data acquisition frameworks. This work presents a fully hardware-integrated 1 Gbps Ethernet-based DAQ system implemented on an Xilinx Kintex-7 FPGA. The design replaces the VME back-end with a memory-mapped TCP/IP interface and an optional streaming mode, enabling deterministic, real-time data transmission without embedded processors. The system was validated using real detector signals from a µRWELL chamber, with successful capture of cosmic events and multi-channel charge readout. Benchmarking confirms reliable multi-word transactions over TCP and a sustained streaming throughput of up to 100 MB/s using generated data. The complete architecture, including deserialization, event building, histogramming, and TCP interface, fits comfortably within available FPGA resources and provides a scalable upgrade path toward 10 Gbps Ethernet for high-luminosity experiments.

title: PING: Physics-Informed Graph Neural Networks to Generalize False Data Injection Attack Localization in Power Grids
authors: Meem Tasfia Zaman, Hui Lin
abstract: Data-Driven approaches based on machine learning models emerge as promising methods to detect and localize false data injection attacks (FDIAs) in power grids. However, generalizing machine learning models for various grid topologies and attack strategies faces tremendous obstacles. To overcome the research gaps, we introduce PING, a physics-informed graph neural network to generalize FDIA localization. We encode physical properties and measurements into node and edge features of a graph and leverage self-attention neural networks to generalize knowledge from various power grids. Furthermore, we introduce a mask variable into the node/edge features to explicitly indicate measurement availability that accidents or cyberattacks can disrupt. These original designs enable an inductive learning capability that makes PING automatically adaptive to various power grids and attack strategies without runtime retraining. Our evaluation integrating real operation data in eight IEEE test systems demonstrates that PING can accurately localize FDIAs, i.e., 97% accuracy on average with complete measurements and 88% accuracy even with 40% missing measurements. More importantly, its performance can maintain 95% accuracy when the model is tested in completely different power grids.

title: Offline Vehicle Tracking System Using GPS, GSM and Android
authors: Md Zannatul Iftear, Mohammed Obyead, Nurul Amin, Mohammad Rejwan Uddin, Mahady Hasan
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: In developing countries such as Bangladesh, the utilization of emergency vehicles encounters notable impediments. Despite the availability of ambulances, the process of deploying them in response to medical emergencies is suboptimal and particularly pronounced in urban centers like Dhaka. The prevalent preference for motorcycles, rickshaws, and CNGs over ambulances for hospital conveyance reflects this inefficiency. To address this challenge, we propose implementing a smart vehicle tracking system leveraging GSM and GPS technologies. This project entails the integration of a low-cost Arduino microcontroller with a combined GPS and GSM module. Of significance is the incorporation of an offline GPS tracking feature using an Android Mobile Application, implementing a novel approach of displaying the ambulance location and ETA on a map - without the use of internet. Committed to cost-effectiveness, we have meticulously curated the system to ensure a budgetary constraint of $ 60, while optimizing performance efficacy.

title: Bridging Analytics and Interoperability: A Standardized Digital Twin Solution for Enhanced Enterprise Resource Planning
authors: Suman De, Pabitra Mitra
abstract: Manufacturing industry relies on software systems for better optimization of core processes via digitally representing equipment data. The rapid development of Industry 4.0 has accelerated demand for interoperable systems, where seamless exchange of equipment data between Original Equipment Manufacturers (OEMs) and ERP systems is critical. This paper explores the standardisation of Digital Twins, addressing a key research gap in their uniform representation identified through an expert survey. The primary research question addressed in this paper is how standardized Industrial Digital Twin supports decentralized analytics for predictive maintenance while improving interoperability with ERP systems. The research presented here presents a solution to this issue by using the industry standard of Asset Administration Shell and enhancing its functionalities for ERP integration. It presents an innovative plugin to enhance Digital Twin representation in ERP systems, web browsers, and other pertinent platforms while maintaining uniform data formats that promote analytics. This technology improves OEMs' capacity to disseminate real-time equipment information across stakeholders, facilitating more actionable insights and enhanced operational efficiency. The survey results emphasize the significance of standardized Digital Twins as a basis for strong analytical frameworks, fostering transparency, interoperability, and innovation across industrial ecosystems.

title: Development and Evaluation of an Ice-Embedded Irradiance Profiler for Seasonally Measuring Solar Irradiance Distribution Within Sea Ice
authors: Haocai Huang, Hang Zhou, Hangzhou Wang, Jingyang Li, Jialiang Zhu, Xuanyi Guo
abstract: An ice-embedded irradiance profiler was developed for autonomous, in situ observations of solar irradiance distribution within sea ice, potentially over a seasonal scale. This profiler employs a transparent tube embedded within the ice to transmit the solar radiation signal from the ice to the tube. It utilizes a spectrometer, capable of moving up and down within the tube, to measure the solar irradiance signal at various ice depths. The temperature dependence of the spectrometer was investigated across a temperature range from −50°C to +25°C. In addition, a dark output prediction model was developed with an overall prediction uncertainty of ±2.5%. A signal output correction model was also proposed to correct the temperature-induced bias in the spectrometer readings, and this was further incorporated into the calibration of the profiler’s output. A prototype of the profiler was deployed in 160-cm-thick Arctic ice during the 13th Chinese National Arctic Scientific Expedition, where it measured the downwelling irradiance distribution in the sea ice at 13 different depths over 35 days. The overall performance of the profiler was validated, and the obtained optical properties of the sea ice are comparable to those measured by other commercially available optical sensors.

title: Interference-Avoidance and Low-Latency Cross-Layer Multipath Routing for Underwater Acoustic Communication Networks
authors: Yufan Yuan, Foyuan Nie, Jiayi Su, Jingyu Qian, Yan Wei, Fengzhong Qu, Xiaoxiao Zhuo
abstract: Due to the specific characteristics of underwater channels and the hostile ocean environment, it is challenging to provide reliable data transmissions in underwater acoustic communication networks (UACNs). Multipath routing (MR) has emerged as a promising solution to enhance transmission reliability by leveraging redundant paths to transmit data concurrently. However, MR is prone to cross-path interference, which will degrade transmission latency performance. To this end, this paper proposes an interference-avoidance and low-latency cross-layer multipath routing (ILMR) protocol to address the tradeoff between reliability and latency in MR. Specifically, ILMR considers the transmission latency as the optimization objective and formulates a constrained optimization problem that jointly optimizes path selection at the network layer and transmission scheduling at the medium access control layer. By cross-layer joint design, ILMR can reduce cross-path interference and achieve reliable MR with lower latency in UACNs. Furthermore, unlike most previous works on routing for UACNs that are only verified through simulations, we have also carried out field experiments, including an experiment in Minghui Lake, and a sea trial near Dongju Island in the Zhoushan Archipelago. Experimental results show that the proposed cross-layer MR scheme can improve network performance. Specifically, the transmission latency performance is reduced by about 30% and the packet delivery ratio performance is increased by about 5%.
