title: High-transmittance single-mode optical nanofibers in the full visible spectral range
authors: Keying Liu, Jianbin Zhang, Xinyue Zhang, Wei Fang, Xin Guo, Limin Tong
abstract: Broadband optical waveguiding in an optical nanofiber can give great versatility to nanofiber-optic technology. To date, high-transmittance single-mode waveguiding in a single optical nanofiber in the full visible spectral range remains challenging. Here, by using a commercially available silica fiber with a single-mode cut-off wavelength smaller than 400 nm (Nufern, 405-HP) as the fiber preform, and taper-drawing the fiber into a nanofiber with a standard fabrication technique, we show that the nanofiber can support broadband single-mode waveguiding with high optical transmittance in the full visible spectral range. Quantitatively, a silica nanofiber with a uniform diameter between 210 and 270 nm can support single-mode optical waveguiding with transmittance higher than 96% (i.e., less than 0.18 dB in loss) from 400 to 800-nm wavelength. Such a broadband single-mode nanofiber may find applications including near-field optical coupling, optical interconnection, optical sensing, atom optics and fiber lasers in the broad visible spectral range.

title: A Chain-Type Magnetic Wheeled Robot for In-Situ Inspection of Integrated Pipeline-Valve-Vessel Systems_supp2-3630272.mp4
authors: Zhiguang Xing
abstract: Integrated pipeline-valve-vessel systems are essential in industrial processes but require periodic disassembly for inspection under extreme conditions. Robotic inspection offers an economical and efficient alternative to manual disassembly. However, existing robots are limited to inspecting pipelines or vessels separately. Continuous traversal through small-to-medium diameter pipelines (80–150 mm), valves, and into vessels remains challenging due to irregular and confined chambered structure. To overcome this limitation, we propose a chain-type magnetic wheeled robot featuring two key innovations: 1) the integration of a serial gear chain (SGC) with magnetic adhesion mechanism ensures the robot’s adaptability to irregular surfaces, reducing force-control dependency during complex valve navigation. Leveraging this characteristic, a distributed dual-end drive configuration within the SGC addresses power insufficiency caused by the robot’s suspension in the hollow regions and 2) the traditional force-angle stability margin is modified to serve as a criterion for tipover instability. Based on this, a predictive instability control framework is developed, integrating offline-computed posture thresholds with real-time attitude monitoring to enhance motion stability. Experimental results demonstrate that the robot achieves robust, stable traversal, and nondismantling inspection across pipelines, valves, and vessels without disassembly. This work provides valuable insights for industries, such as nuclear power and chemical engineering.

title: Annealing Processing System Capable of Simultaneous Updates of All Spins Using Transition-Based Multi-State Spin
authors: Kazuma Kanai, Takayuki Kawahara
abstract: Annealing processors (APs), which can efficiently solve combinatorial optimization problems (COPs), have attracted attention. APs that have fully-coupled spin coupling are the focus of active research due to their ability to handle a wide range of COPs. However, since a single spin is updated by referring to the states of all other spins, sequential spin updates are necessary. This makes it difficult to achieve both faster computation time and stable solution quality. We propose transition-based multi-state pseudo annealing (TMSPA), which is an annealing method that enables discrete spin states between ±1 and maps the conventional two spin states to different transition directions. By using TMSPA, we solved the Max-cut problem and the traveling salesman problem (TSP). We found that TMSPA enables all-parallel annealing for both COPs. In terms of solution quality, TMSPA performed comparably to or better than simulated annealing and pseudo annealing. For the TSP, TMSPA reached better minimum values with less than one-third the number of Monte Carlo steps than previous all-parallel annealing methods. We also propose an all-parallelized annealing processing system using TMSPA. By using the proposed system with 1024- and 2048-spin configurations, we achieved better solution quality and 6.25 times faster computation time while operating at half the frequency and limiting the increase in circuit-resource utilization to 1.03–5.70 times compared with a previous parallelized AP. This result indicates that reducing circuit complexity using TMSPA is highly effective in the implementation of parallelized APs.

title: Synthesis-Aided Design of Strictly Inline MEMS Planar Filters With Flexible Transmission Zeros
authors: Yi Zeng, Yang Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: This article introduces nonresonating nodes (NRNs) and dangling resonators into inline interdigital micro-electromechanical system (MEMS) filters to achieve customized transfer functions with flexibly assigned transmission zeros (TZs). With the advanced synthesis-aided design theories and high-precision MEMS technology, filters with sophisticated structures can be manufactured without post-production tuning. Physical realization of NRN modules based on the MEMS platform is proposed to produce TZs at desired frequencies. Additionally, the intrinsic dispersion effects of the MEMS structures can be employed to form frequency-dependent couplings (FDCs), thus generating extra TZs in the upper stopband. In this way, multiple TZs can be specified to enhance selectivity and attenuation under the inline configuration. Moreover, to address the strong interference between adjacent modules, parasitic couplings are added to the modified circuit prototype, and the corresponding synthesis method is presented. Aided by the updated circuit, the geometry dimensions can be refined to recover the filter response from the unavoidable parasitic effects. The design and synthesis theories are demonstrated via multiple examples. Two inline MEMS filters with TZs are fabricated and measured to verify the developed theories and technologies.

title: Collaborative Localization Using Multiple UAVs: A Deep Denoising Autoencoder-Based Data Compression Approach
authors: Jiajing Chen, Lu Bai, Xiang Cheng, Xuesong Cai
abstract: In recent years, the deployment of multiple Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) for source localization has significantly increased in military, civil, and commercial domains. The transmission of data from the source to each UAV introduces channel noise, which affects localization accuracy. Furthermore, since direct estimation of time of arrival is impractical, signal processing at a central UAV is essential to estimate time difference of arrival to achieve a precise source localization. This processed localization information is subsequently shared among the UAV network. However, transmitting original data to a central point presents challenges due to its time-consuming and low energy efficiency, and highlights the importance of efficient data compression in multiple UAV systems. Consequently, it is recommended that low-dimensional data be transmitted across UAV networks instead of the original high-dimensional signal samples to realize the reconstruction of the original data for source localization. However, as the compression rate (CR) increases, accurately reconstructing the original data becomes challenging. This paper proposes a deep denoising autoencoder (DAE) approach for high-ratio data compression in multiple UAV systems. The DAE not only effectively reduces noise from signals but also significantly decreases the volume of data required for transmission, enabling accurate reconstruction of the original data. Simulations were performed to assess the localization accuracy of the proposed DAE approach. The results indicate that the approach achieves high localization accuracy, particularly in challenging scenarios of low signal-to-noise and high CRs.

title: Optimal Placement of Capacitors in Electrical Networks with Renewable Energy Sources to Improve Power Quality and Reduce Costs
authors: Javad Khajouei, Sina Shakeri, Mohammad Nasir Uddin, Amir Ameli
publish: 2025 IEEE Industry Applications Society Annual Meeting (IAS)
abstract: This paper presents a novel method to optimally place capacitors in power systems that incorporate renewable energy resources and sensitive non-linear loads, considering system uncertainties. A voltage severity index is introduced to assist system operators in the planning and programming of capacitors. The effectiveness of the proposed method is evaluated on a real large copper mine network in Iran, equipped with sensitive loads to voltage sags and doubly fed induction generators (DFIGs). The results indicate that the control mode of DFIGs and their output power influence the optimal location and size of capacitors. The proposed capacitor placement method enhances voltage profiles, reduces total harmonic distortion, minimizes grid losses, and lowers the costs associated with capacitors. Furthermore, the results underscore the necessity of selecting the appropriate control method based on the system’s operational priorities and conditions. The proposed capacitor placement method successfully reduced financial losses due to voltage sags up to 62%, leading to more secure operation of sensitive loads.

title: MHNet: A Multi-Head GNN Architecture for Efficient Network Modelling
authors: Sandushan Ranaweera, Ren Ping Liu, Ying He, Beeshanga Jayawickrama
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: In recent years, Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) have emerged as a powerful tool for network modeling due to their ability to learn complex relationships in graph-structured data. However, the existing GNN-based network models are designed to predict only a single performance metric at a time, leading to computational inefficiencies. Moreover, existing approaches lack effective methodologies for interpreting the learned relationships in a networking context. We present MHNet, a multi-head GNN architecture capable of simultaneously predicting delay, jitter, and packet loss in network traffic flows. To train MHNet, we propose an adaptive optimization strategy that constructs a balanced update direction to update the weights of the model at each epoch using the normalized gradients of the individual loss functions correspond to performance metric outputs. To interpret the relationships learned by the model in the network graph, we construct a gradient-based analysis framework that integrates networking domain knowledge to assess the influence of input features on the prediction outputs. Experimental results show that MHNet achieves prediction accuracy comparable to the state-of-the-art RouteNet model across all metrics, while reducing inference-stage Floating Point Operations (FLOPs) cost by 67%. The interpretation analysis further reveals that MHNet mitigates oversmoothing and selectively focuses on the most relevant substructures of the network feature graph when predicting performance metrics for traffic flows.

title: Taylor Weighting Method of Curved Sources and Its Applications to Conformal Arrays
authors: Yuanchen Zeng, Xun Li, Jie Wu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: Taylor weighting is a typical low-sidelobe pattern synthesis method that is widely used for continuous sources and discrete arrays. Unfortunately, the traditional Taylor weighting method is unsuitable for curved sources due to curvature, which leads to unclear boundaries between the main lobe and sidelobes, and it fails to reach a prescribed sidelobe level. This paper presents a modified Taylor weighting method for curved sources and conformal arrays. First, it is demonstrated that a curved source is equivalent to a three-dimensional (3D) virtual source. Thus, the Taylor pattern of curved sources can be established using the pattern of virtual 3D sources. Subsequently, a correlation model between the Taylor pattern of a curved source or a conformal array and its Taylor distribution is determined using the iterative least squares (ILS) method. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method is verified via numerical examples and experiments.

title: An FPGA Architecture for Authentication and Key Agreement Protocol for 5G Networks
authors: Marios Papadopoulos, Kostas Lampropoulos, Paris Kitsos
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: The advent of 5G networks has revolutionized wireless communication by providing enhanced data rates, ultra-low latency, and massive connectivity. However, these advancements demand highly efficient, flexible, and scalable hardware solutions to meet the rigorous requirements of next-generation communication systems. Field-Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) have emerged as a pivotal technology in addressing these challenges, offering unparalleled reconfigurability, parallel processing capabilities, and hardware-level optimization for $5 G$ applications. This paper explores the integration of FPGAs in 5G infrastructure, focusing on their role in accelerating the security processing using the Authentication and Key Agreement (AKA) protocol. Additionally, the paper delves into design considerations, challenges, and future directions, highlighting FPGAs’ potential to drive innovation in 5G and beyond.

title: SEP-YOLO: A Multifaceted and Unified Algorithm for Comprehensive Classroom Behavior Recognition in Normal Lecture Recordings
authors: Chunyan Yu, Lan Gao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: Analyzing student behavior and seating distribution in classroom teaching activities helps to reveal student engagement and teacher-student interactions. However, real-world classroom scenarios pose significant challenges, including complex background interference, small-object detection difficulties, multi-task optimization, and the lack of publicly available datasets. To address these issues, we construct a real-world university classroom behavior dataset and propose SEP-YOLO, an improved YOLOv10n-based model. First, to mitigate complex background interference, we introduce the Edge Fusion Scale Attention (EFSA) module into the backbone network, enhancing the model’s ability to perceive student motion contours and boundary features. Second, to improve small-object detection, we integrate the Small Target Enhanced Pyramid (STEP) module into the Neck structure, which strengthens fine-grained feature modeling for small targets and progressively propagates them to higher-level feature maps, thereby enhancing detection accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that SEP-YOLO effectively applies to classroom behavior recognition tasks, outperforming Faster R-CNN, YOLOv5n, and YOLOv8n in handling complex background interference and small-object detection. Compared to the baseline YOLOv10n, SEP-YOLO improves Precision (P), Recall (R), mAP50, and mAP50:90 by 2.2 %, 3.4%, 2.2%, and 2.8%, respectively.

title: Prompt-based Semantic Communication with Large Language Models (LLMs)
authors: Jialun Zheng, Limei Peng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: This paper proposes a semantic communication system utilizing prompt-based methods with large language models (LLMs). We employ three state-of-the-art LLMs, GPT-4-Turbo, Gemini 2.0 Flash, and Claude 3.7 Sonnet to generate compressed representations of textual content from the Wikipedia dataset at varying compression ratios $(20 \%, 40 \%, 60 \%$, and $80 \%$). The compressed texts are subsequently encoded and transmitted over an additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel under different signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions $(0 \mathrm{~dB}, 6 \mathrm{~dB}, 12 \mathrm{~dB}$, and 18 dB). At the receiver, the LLMs utilize their inherent background knowledge as a shared knowledge base (KB) to decode the received bitstreams and reconstruct the semantic content via prompt-based inference. To evaluate semantic recovery performance, we employ cosine similarity based on a BERT embedding model. For baseline comparison, we include the classical unsupervised TextRank algorithm. Experimental results demonstrate that LLMs exhibit robust semantic reconstruction capabilities across varying compression rates and channel noise levels, highlighting their potential for enhancing semantic communication systems.

title: Musculoskeletal Model Analysis for Underwater Assist Suit for Elbow Joint
authors: Chiharu Ishii, Naoki Tachibana, Nozomi Yamamoto
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: In marine civil engineering, it is necessary to flatten the surface of the foundation in order to build marine structures. In most cases, this work is performed manually by divers. Since this work gives heavy burdens on divers’ body, in our previous study, the assist suit which can be used underwater was developed so as to reduce the burden on the elbow joint of divers. In the previous study, effectiveness of the developed underwater assist suit was demonstrated through measurements of surface electromyogram (EMG) of the biceps brachii muscle during the diver carrying the foundation stone. However, the influence of the underwater assist suit on the divers’ body was not investigated. Therefore, in this study, the influence of the underwater assist suit on the divers’ body was analyzed using the musculoskeletal model analysis software “AnyBody Modeling System”. The motion of lifting and lowering a heavy object was captured using the video motion capture system “Plask”. Then, by adding buoyant force and resistance force of water to the human body model, the dynamic analysis was executed under imitating the underwater situation using the “AnyBody Modeling System”. The amount of muscle activity of the biceps brachii muscle, the compressive force and shear force acting on the elbow joint were analyzed under the conditions of wearing and not wearing the underwater assist suit. The results of the analysis showed that the underwater assist suit can reduce the burdens on the elbow joint.

title: Unraveling Parallelism in Automated Workload Modeling for Distributed Cyber-Physical Systems
authors: Faezeh Sadat Saadatmand, Todor Stefanov, Andy D. Pimentel, Benny Akesson, Ignacio Gonález Alonso
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: Designing next generation distributed CyberPhysical Systems (dCPS) requires effective Design Space Exploration (DSE) methods to evaluate system design alternatives and their impact on performance. While existing DSE approaches focus on hardware optimization and software-to-hardware mapping, they often overlook parallel execution opportunities within software tasks. Current application workload models for complex dCPS assume fixed execution orders, limiting the ability to explore and exploit software parallelism. To address this issue, we propose refined workload models derived from execution traces that capture both inter- and intra-process dependencies. Building on these models, we present a method to identify tasks that can be safely reordered or executed in parallel without modifying the existing software implementation. We validate our approach through a case study on the ASML Twinscan lithography machine, demonstrating measurable performance improvements without impacting the system functional correctness.

title: Control of PV-Hydrogen System Using Inverter-Based Architecture for Clean Energy Transition with DSP TMS320F28379D
authors: Youness Hakam, Mohamed Tabaa
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper proposes a control architecture for a photovoltaic-hydrogen energy system that utilizes a bidirectional inverter.bidirectional inverter controlled by the DSP TMS320F28379D to regulate energy flow between PV arrays, electrolyzers, and storage units. The model ensures efficient hydrogen production. and utilization while maintaining grid stability. Simulation and hardware-in-the-loop tests validate the performance of the proposed system under dynamic load and irradiation profiles. This work contributes to the development of renewable-powered hydrogen production systems.aligned with clean energy goals

title: Path Duration-Aware Service Request Routing in Space-Terrestrial Integrated Networks
authors: Xin Guo, Lisheng Ma, He Zhu, Wei Su, Xiaohong Jiang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: Space-Terrestrial Integrated Networks (STINs) are emerging as a key architecture for providing seamless global connectivity in future 6 G networks. However, the dynamic nature of satellite topologies challenges the continuity of service request routing. Most existing algorithms only consider routing within a single timeslot, leading to frequent path switching and service disruptions. In this paper, we propose a Path Duration-Aware routing scheme that explicitly considers the duration time a routing path remains valid to support service requests with defined duration time. By assuming that each service request has a specific arrival time and duration time, a routing path may not be able to sustain the completion of a service request due to changes in satellite network topology. In the proposed scheme, the goal is to allocate routes that persist across multiple timeslots, enhancing service continuity and reducing rerouting overhead. For the set of service requests in each time slot including newly arrived and required rerouting service requests, a path selection scheme is designed that tries to allocate the path that can support service requests for the longest duration time. We implement the service request routing scheme based on an Integer Linear Programming (ILP) model. Extensive simulation results demonstrate that our proposed scheme is efficient for routing service request in STINs.

title: Evict+Spec+Time on RISC-V: Gem5-Based Implementation and Microarchitectural Analysis
authors: Mahreen Khan, Maria Mushtaq, Renaud Pacalet, Ludovic Apvrille
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: Microarchitectural side-channel attacks are a growing concern and have been widely studied on x86 and ARM architectures, but RISC-V’s susceptibility to similar attacks remains understudied. We present the first implementation and evaluation of the Evict+Spec+Time attack on RISC-V, previously demonstrated only on x86 [2]. This advanced variant of Evict+Time integrates three critical phases: eviction, speculation, and timing. First, the attack forcibly evicts target cache lines using RISC-V’s cbo.flush instruction via the Zicbom extension [6]. Next, it exploits out-of-order execution to manipulate microarchitectural resources such as the reorder buffer, limiting the processor’s ability to mask cache-miss latency. Finally, it infers secret-dependent memory access patterns through precise timing measurements. We validate RISC-V’s vulnerability by recovering secret keys from AES T-table implementations. Using the gem5 simulator [4], we provide the first detailed analysis of microarchitectural behavior during the attack, including cache contention, pipeline stalls, and latency variations. These insights establish foundational guidance for developing RISC-V-specific countermeasures against such attacks.

title: False Data Injection Detection in AC Power Systems Using ST-LSTM under Temporal and Spatial Distribution Shifts
authors: Chenhan Xiao, Mostafa Mohammadpourfard, Yang Weng, Chin-Woo Tan, Suhas Pol
abstract: The growing cyber-physical complexity of modern power grids has heightened vulnerability to False Data Injection Attacks (FDIAs), which can evade conventional Bad Data Detection (BDD) by aligning with the system’s physical model. While machine learning-based detectors offer promising alternatives, they often rely on assumptions of fixed topology and stationary data distributions, which do not hold under real-world conditions such as renewable integration and grid reconfiguration. This paper proposes a Spatial-Temporal Long Short-Term Memory (ST-LSTM) framework for real-time FDIA detection that jointly captures temporal dynamics and spatial correlations in AC power systems. To improve scalability in large networks, we introduce a symbolic decomposition technique that exploits the functional structure of AC power flow equations to construct a sparse spatial recurrence graph, enabling efficient localized information propagation without requiring access to line parameters. This structure-aware formulation enhances ST-LSTM’s ability to generalize under spatial and temporal distribution shifts. Extensive experiments on IEEE benchmark systems with realistic load profiles demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms existing approaches across a range of dynamic scenarios.

title: Characterizing Malware Behaviors through Deep Feature Profiling
authors: Kezhang Lin, Chengbo Zheng, Chenrun He, Honghui Fan, Haonan Yan, Bin Wang, Yulong Shen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: Malware poses a serious challenge to the security of network environments. Given the concealment and diversity of malware, accurate analysis has become extremely difficult. Machine learning and deep learning methods, such as random forest algorithms and convolutional neural networks, are widely adopted in malware analysis because of their excellent feature extraction capabilities. However, these methods struggle to capture the complex relationships between malware’s deep features and are challenging to adapt to classes with only a small number of samples. In this work, we propose an analysis method for malware attack behavior based on deep feature characterization. In our scheme, we first visualize the binary files of malware to more intuitively display their features. Subsequently, we use a large amount of unlabeled data to conduct contrast training, resulting in an AutoEncoder capable of characterizing the deep generalization features of malware. Finally, we employ a neural network to classify the outputs of the encoder, which significantly improves the classification effectiveness. We evaluated our method on the Malimg dataset, and the experimental results indicate that the classification accuracy of our method can reach over $97 \%$, with good classification performance across various types of malware.

title: Unmasking Deepfakes: Impacts, Detection Challenges, and Responsible Response
authors: Syed Rizvi, Anthony Demeri, Joanna F. DeFranco
abstract: Deepfake technology has yielded both benefits and harms; however, the negatives raise serious concerns. This article explores deepfake impacts, detection methods, and the need for improved policies to safeguard digital integrity.

title: High-Performance Pipelined NTT Accelerators with Homogeneous Digit-Serial Modulo Arithmetic
authors: George Alexakis, Dimitrios Schoinianakis, Giorgos Dimitrakopoulos
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: The Number Theoretic Transform (NTT) is a fundamental operation in privacy-preserving technologies, particularly within fully homomorphic encryption (FHE). The efficiency of NTT computation directly impacts the overall performance of FHE, making hardware acceleration a critical technology that will enable realistic FHE applications. Custom accelerators, in FPGAs or ASICs, offer significant performance advantages due to their ability to exploit massive parallelism and specialized optimizations. However, the operation of NTT over large moduli requires large word-length modulo arithmetic that limits achievable clock frequencies in hardware and increases hardware area costs. To overcome such deficits, digit-serial arithmetic has been explored for modular multiplication and addition independently. The goal of this work is to leverage digit-serial modulo arithmetic combined with appropriate redundant data representation to design modular pipelined NTT accelerators that operate uniformly on arbitrary small digits, without the need for intermediate (de)serialization. The proposed architecture enables high clock frequencies through regular pipelining while maintaining parallelism. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed approach outperforms state-of-the-art implementations and reduces hardware complexity under equal performance and input-output bandwidth constraints.

title: A Study on Performativity of Information Technologies
authors: Risa Kimura, Tatsuo Nakajima
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: The absence of adequate tools for examining the societal implications of newly developed information technologies has led to the neglect of many potentially superior technologies that were not widely accepted. To address this issue, the concept of performativity has been introduced in sociology, highlighting that artificial theories, concepts, and technologies do not exist in isolation but actively shape society. This paper aims to emphasize the significance of performativity as an analytical tool that can effectively analyze the impact of technology on society. Through six case studies exploring the social impact of information technology on performativity, the paper demonstrates the importance of performativity as an analytical tool. The key contribution of this study is to underscore that investigating tools for analyzing the influence of art on society is a crucial research area within computer science. By delving into this aspect, we can gain valuable insights and make informed decisions about the societal implications of various technologies, ultimately fostering more responsible and impactful innovations.

title: CFD-Driven Hydrodynamic Modeling and Model Predictive Control for Path Following of a Turtle-Inspired Biomimetic Robot
authors: Ang Liu, Xianrui Zhang, Guangming Cui, Yunjie Yang, Juntian Qu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: This paper addresses the path-following challenge for a turtle-inspired biomimetic robot propelled by 3 degree-of-freedom flippers. First, a high-fidelity hydrodynamic model is established through computational fluid dynamics (CFD)driven parameterization. Then a hierarchical control framework combining model predictive control (MPC) and fuzzy logic control (FLC) is proposed to address nonlinear hydrodynamic interactions, environmental uncertainties, and actuator mapping complexities. The upper-layer MPC optimizes reference forces and moments via receding horizon optimization, while the lower-layer FLC adaptively translates these references into actuator-specific commands through fuzzy rule-based signal allocation. Finally, comparative simulations in a U-shaped and 8-shaped path following task demonstrate the proposed strategy's superiority, achieving a 70 % reduction in average crosstrack error and 50% faster convergence than conventional PID and sliding mode controllers under randomized hydrodynamic disturbances.

title: Data-Driven Modeling of Temporal Dynamics Using Machine Learning: Application to Gas Turbine Generators
authors: Aaditya Pandey, Wenyuan Tang
abstract: Modeling dynamical systems is essential for understanding complex systems, particularly when the governing equations are either unavailable or inadequately parameterized, making it challenging to derive analytical models. Traditional system identification techniques primarily rely on input-output data; however, recent advancements in machine learning, particularly deep learning, have created new opportunities for modeling such systems. Despite their potential, deep learning models often suffer from limited interpretability, susceptibility to overfitting, and inconsistencies with physical laws. Incorporating prior knowledge of system physics into deep learning models has shown promise in mitigating these issues, yet identifying and effectively embedding such knowledge remains challenging. This paper proposes a robust alternative using a random forest regression (RFR) to model the system dynamics. The results demonstrate that by training the model using lagged endogenous and exogenous features, a Random Forest Regressor can achieve around 82.5% reduction in prediction error compared to an advanced deep learning model trained using knowledge of system physics. This approach is computationally efficient and highly effective, as demonstrated through its application to modeling the temporal dynamics of a gas turbine generator. These findings highlight the potential of classical machine learning techniques, such as a Random Forest Regressor, as an efficient alternative for modeling complex dynamical systems.

title: Neural Architecture Search for Over-the-Air Telecommunication Signal Classification
authors: F. D. Suárez Bonilla, J.M. de la Rosa, G. Liñán-Cembrano
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper presents a Neural Architecture Search (NAS) approach for automatic classification of telecommunication signals using Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs). Our optimized CNN architecture achieved 96.29% accuracy using Neural Architecture Search with only 91,367 trainable parameters, demonstrating improved computational efficiency compared to manually designed architectures. We explored 63 million possible architectural configurations using Bayesian optimization to systematically identify optimal network designs for spectrogram-based signal classification. The search process evaluated 20 different trials over approximately 1 hour and 21 minutes, ultimately discovering an architecture that balances accuracy and computational efficiency. This work demonstrates how automated architecture search can effectively optimize telecommunication signal processing applications for spectrum monitoring, electronic defense, and cognitive radio systems.

title: Contactless Droplet Mixing Based on Acoustic Tweezer
authors: Qiao Wang, Yuyan Liu, Bo Yuan, Jingwen Huang, Jiayin Li, Yunsheng Li, Xiaoming Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Droplet mixing research provides critical technical support for developing efficient and controllable complex chemical reaction systems. However, traditional methods and platforms pose inherent risks including cross-contamination and low energy conversion efficiency. Emerging alternative approaches, such as microfluidic chips, often entail complex fabrication processes and operational challenges. To address these limitations, this study proposes a non-contact droplet mixing platform. By applying a vortex acoustic field to droplets on a glass substrate, this system achieves stable droplet capture, precise manipulation, and rapid mixing. The platform significantly reduces contamination risks, minimizes reagent consumption, and enhances energy conversion efficiency, while featuring straightforward fabrication and operational simplicity. Experimental results demonstrate the system's efficacy in accelerating microvolume droplet mixing, offering a practical solution for advanced chemical research.

title: Dynamic Reactive Power Control of Modular Multi-Level Converter based STATCOM for High Penetration of Variable Renewable Energy Sources
authors: Zakaria Khalil, Brian K. Johnson
abstract: The increasing penetration of wind and photovoltaic (PV) presents significant challenges to existing power systems. High levels of wind and PV integration introduce stability concerns due to the inherent variability when controlled to track peak power output and the resulting short-term uncertainty in their power output. This has underscored the growing importance of providing dynamically controllable real and reactive power to maintain grid stability. The static synchronous compensator (STATCOM) is a well-established solution for enhancing voltage and system stability through fast and precise reactive power control. In this study, a shunt compensator based on a modular multilevel converter (MMC)-based STATCOM is proposed for reactive power compensation. Most new STATCOM installations use delta connected MMC topologies. Energy storage can be added to the dc side of the MMC in the form of supercapacitors, creating E-STATCOM. A double-wye MMC topology is more suitable for adding storage on the dc side of the MMC, and that topology is used in this paper. A modified version of the IEEE 12-bus system is modeled and simulated using an electromagnetic transient simulator to evaluate its dynamic response under various operating conditions, both without compensation and with the proposed STATCOM. The simulation results confirm that integrating the MMC-based STATCOM substantially improves system voltage by effectively suppressing voltage fluctuations and meeting reactive power requirements. To ensure voltage regulation at the point of common coupling (PCC), the reactive power output of the STATCOM was calculated, demonstrating its ability to dynamically respond to changing system conditions and maintain voltage levels within acceptable operational limits.

title: A Numerical Comparison of a Novel Postprocessing Technique and 4-LSB Extraction Based on a Chaotic Laser Source
authors: Itzel Sinaí Castillo-García, Min Won Lee, Ignacio Enrique Zaldívar-Huerta
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: True random bits are crucial for cryptographic systems, particularly in key generation and secure initialization. In this paper, we present a novel technique based on chaotic signals and the addition of pulse-amplitude modulation signals to generate random bits. This technique can be implemented directly in physical systems. The randomness of our generated bit sequences will be examined with the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) statistical test. The results will also be compared with a widely used technique reported in the literature.

title: Application of Artificial Intelligence for Enhancing Travel Preparedness
authors: Arpa Pramualsap, Poohridate Arpasat, Kwanchai Kungcharoen, Wichian Premchaiswadi
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: This research presents an iOS-based luggage management system designed to mitigate the risks of forgetting essential items and packing prohibited articles for international travel. The system architecture features a Flutter-based frontend, a FastAPI backend, and utilizes Firebase for data management and authentication. The prototype leverages two core Artificial Intelligence (AI) components: the Ultralytics YOLOv8 model for multi-object detection to verify luggage contents against aviation regulations, and OpenAI's GPT-5.0 to generate personalized travel checklists. The system's performance evaluation, conducted on a test dataset, demonstrated the YOLOv8 model's practical viability with a mean Average Precision (mAP@50) of 50% and an F1-score of 50%. These findings confirm that the application can effectively enhance the accuracy and confidence of users' travel preparations, highlighting the potential of AI in streamlining complex travel logistics.

title: The Growing Adoption of Electric Vehicles in New York State: Scenario-Based Future Annual and Diurnal Demand Across the NYISO Transmission Grid
authors: Kaiden P. Sookdar, Juan P. Montoya-Rincon, Harold Gamarro, Nour Elgalad, Jorge E. Gonzalez-Cruz, Tung Lam Nguyen, Rahul Kadavil, Hossein Hooshyar
abstract: Despite the potential implications, knowledge about quantifying the increase in electric demand due to growing electric vehicle (EV) adoption in New York State is limited. In this study, we derive annual demand from EVs using projected stocks from NYISO and current stocks from NYSERDA, leveraging a concept known as Fractional Vehicle Miles Traveled. We develop three scenarios, including a slower adoption scenario based on socioeconomic factors, and a faster scenario based on state emissions reduction mandates. For each scenario, we disaggregated annual demand into monthly and diurnal profiles per zone, using separate profiles for different vehicle types. We project significant increases in annual electric consumption solely from EVs in most load zones, exceeding 5 GWh in the highest-demand zones in downstate New York. We show that significant penetration of EVs will amplify the current peak total intraday loads driven by other demand sources, which occur in the late afternoons and early evenings. In some zones, this was as much as 1250 MW when aggregated on peak demand for a recent heat wave event. These results are critical for future grid management, especially in the era of increasing frequency of extreme weather events and the electrification of other demand features.

title: EssenceGuard: A Multi-Stage Framework for Enhancing Security in Large Language Models through Essence Analysis
authors: Yanfei Cao, Naijie Gu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: With the widespread application of Large Language Models (LLMs) in various scenarios, the issue of their security is increasingly drawing attention. Although these models are powerful, they are also vulnerable to malicious exploitation, such as bypassing security mechanisms to generate harmful content or executing unauthorized operations. Therefore, ensuring the security of LLMs is crucial for maintaining network security and user trust. To address this issue, we propose a multi-stage defense framework called EssenceGuard, aimed at enhancing the security of LLMs through essence analysis. The core of the EssenceGuard is essence analysis, which includes two main stages: intent analysis and strategy analysis. In the intent analysis stage, it aims to detect whether the user input attempts to mask the true intent, such as using indirect language, fictional scenarios, or other mask methods. In the strategy analysis stage, further analysis is conducted on the specific strategies that might have been used, such as encoding conversion, metaphor, or fictional scenarios. By combining the results of these two stages of analysis, EssenceGuard can more accurately assess the risk of user input and generate more secure responses. EssenceGuard introduces in-context learning and complex evaluation logic to maintain a low Attack Success Rate (ASR) while reducing the False Positive Rate (FPR) for benign user queries. Additionally, EssenceGuard provides a transparent feedback mechanism to explain to users why their queries are judged to be harmful or harmless, thereby enhancing user trust. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the EssenceGuard framework and show the framework excels in detecting malicious attacks and reducing false positive rate.

title: Quantum-Inspired Integer PSO for Graph Modeling of Electric Power Transmission Networks
authors: Rajan Ratnakumar, Yordanos Brhane Grmay, Ganesh K. Venayagamoorthy
abstract: The electric power transmission network (EPTN) can be modeled as a graph of interconnected nodes and edges, referred to as the transmission network graph model (TNGM). The TNGM can be constructed using synchrophasor measurements from substations without requiring any prior knowledge of network connectivity. This study explores the application of quantum-inspired integer particle swarm optimization (QI-IPSO) to construct TNGMs. The QI-IPSO algorithm efficiently searches for an optimal graph that replicates the underlying transmission network. Furthermore, QI-IPSO improves convergence and accuracy compared to classical IPSO. The quantum-inspired search algorithm guides PSO particles more effectively in the search space to arrive at the optimal TNGM. The performance of QI-IPSO for constructing TNGMs is illustrated on a two-area four-machine test power system. Typical results show that QI-IPSO constructs the TNGM accurately in fewer iterations and faster than IPSO. This study highlights the potential of quantum-inspired AI algorithms for EPTN modeling, particularly as the network size and complexity grow.

title: Assessment of SMR Load-Following Capabilities Leveraging Hybrid Deep Learning-Based Forecasted Load Demand Profiles
authors: Javier Bejarano, Paras Mandal
abstract: Small Modular Reactors (SMRs) are gaining increasing attention as flexible and low-emission energy sources capable of supporting the transition to a sustainable power grid. Their ability to perform load-following operations is critical for ensuring grid reliability in systems with high shares of variable energy resources, such as wind and solar. This paper presents a seasonal assessment of SMR load-following capabilities using forecasted load demand profiles obtained from hybrid deep learning models. Multiple forecasting models were evaluated to first identify the most accurate short-term electricity load demand forecast model. A hybrid deep learning model based on the combination of Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (BiLSTM), i.e., hybrid CNN+BiLSTM, achieved the best performance by generating more accurate week-ahead load forecasts based on historical temperature and load data. These forecasts were used to simulate the response of a dynamic SMR model developed in Simulink, incorporating realistic ramp-rate and control constraints. Performance of the models is evaluated across four seasonal scenarios and test results show that the SMR is able to effectively track forecasted load profiles year-round, with Mean Absolute Percentage Error (MAPE) below 1.5%. These findings demonstrate the potential of forecast-informed SMR operation as a reliable and dispatchable clean energy solution for future grid architectures.

title: Internet of Energy (IoE): a Literature Review Study
authors: Adulai Djalo, Sabi Y. M. Bandiri, Mariano Vunge, Sumae Embalo, Syntia R. R. Souza, Tales C. Pimenta
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This article deals with the study of Internet of Energy (IoE) and its growing evolution in the academic area, scientific and technological studies. This article was developed through a bibliometric study to map research trends in this area. These analyses included a number of publications and the most influential journals in this area, most cited authors and the most advanced countries in the Internet of Energy (IoE) study. Data is collected in the Web Of Science database and processed in VOSviewer. The results show that countries such as China, Germany, USA, Italy stand out as emerging countries in the study of this theme, as well as the author Mahmoud Kizir as the most cited and Abdullah Al Salemi with the highest number of documents published on IoE. The findings underscore the potential of IoE to optimize energy systems, especially in real-time monitoring of connected devices in the system and control of the intermittency of renewable energy sources.This bibliometric analysis offers a comprehensive review of the Internet of Energy (IoE) research field, highlighting key authors, influential journals, and emerging technologies such as smart grids, blockchain, and machine learning. It also identifies gaps and trends that can guide future research, contributing to the advancement of innovation, sustainable development, and efficient energy management.

title: A 1- to 5-Gb/s Adaptive Equalizer with Window-Specified Counter-Based Adaptation Method
authors: Yu-Wun Chao, Ming-Yan Xu, Soon-Jyh Chang
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper presents a 1- to 5-Gb/s adaptive equalizer that employs a novel window-specified counter-based adaptation method, targeting intra-panel interface applications. Unlike conventional counter-based adaptation technique that is limited to a fixed data rate, the proposed design supports a wide data rate range. To further enhance robustness against process variation, a dynamic window sizing mechanism is integrated into the adaptation loop. Measurement results over a 22 dB lossy channel at 2.5 GHz show that the output jitter is 0.16-UI at 5-Gb/s and 0.04-UI at 1-Gb/s. The prototype is fabricated using a 28 nm CMOS technology, occupying an active core area of 0.053 square millimeters. The power consumption is measured at 5.68 mW under 5-Gb/s operation with a 1-V supply.

title: Electrical and Optical Characterization of Sputtered and Annealed ZnO/Ag Structures for TCO Applications
authors: R. Nezzar, F. Djeffal, K. Kacha, A. Bendjrad, A. Benhaya
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: This study explores the optoelectronic properties of Indium Tin Oxide (ITO) and low-cost ZnO/Ag bilayer thiny films, with a particular focus on the effects of post-deposition annealing at 400°C. Optical analysis reveals that ITO exhibits strong UV absorption and high transparency in the visible-NIR range. In contrast, unannealed ZnO/Ag films show a distinct Surface Plasmon Resonance (SPR) peak in the visible spectrum, while annealing at 400°C enhances their transparency in the visible-NIR region. Electrical measurements demonstrate that ITO retains superior conductivity, whereas unannealed ZnO/Ag offers moderate transparent conductivity. However, annealing ZnO/Ag at 400°C increases its sheet resistance, altering its electrical behavior. This comparative study underscores the potential of cost-effective ZnO/Ag films as viable alternatives to expensive ITO, with tunable properties for specific transparent conductive applications.

title: Strategic Green Innovation for Sustainable Business Models in Emerging Economies: Framework and Case-Based Insights
authors: Rana Muhammad Amir Latif, Muhammad Shafiq-Ur-Rehman, Farhan Ullah, Sagheer Abbas, Umar Raza, Barra Touray, Muhammad Sheraz Tariq
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Energy Conservation and Efficiency (ICECE)
abstract: Green innovation will help enhance business competitiveness more efficiently while at the same time attaining the required environmental sustainability. The proposed content is an analytical study of the green innovation strategy and sustainable business model concerning developing countries. A framework is established to relate the drivers of innovation, enablers, and sustainability of the results of the business model integration. In order to demonstrate the number of organizations that apply the concept of green innovation into the practice, the study will use the qualitative approach, conducting a case study of Unilever, Interloop Limited, and Tesla Inc. By integrating sustainability into the strategy, businesses can minimize resource use, reduce environmental harm, and increase stakeholder confidence. Finally, the paper highlights the necessity and importance of digital technologies, decentralization, and cross-sector cooperation. Such analyses are required to scale green innovation adequately in various socio-economic environments.

title: Accelerating Stochastic Unit Commitment with Multifidelity Scenario Bundling
authors: Zachary Kilwein, Rachael M. Alfant, William E. Hart
abstract: Day-ahead commitment of generators, or unit commitment, is crucial for operating power grids. The problem of unit commitment can be modeled as a stochastic program, for which the uncertainties typically manifest in loads or renewable generation. However, stochastic unit commitment tends to be computationally challenging and therefore expensive to solve. In this paper, we present a modified progressive hedging algorithm that utilizes multifidelity modeling to rapidly generate high-quality solutions for large-scale stochastic unit commitment problems. Our methodology allows for the decomposition of the main problem into subproblems that bundle multiple high and low fidelity scenarios. This form of multi-fidelity bundling enables information sharing across subproblems that accelerates progressive hedging. We demonstrate the efficacy of our multifidelity scenario bundling approach on a RTS-GMLC unit commitment exemplar.

title: Multi-Interval Security-Constrained Optimal Power Flow Using an Enhanced Kalman Filtering Technique for Dynamic Line Rating
authors: Abdelwahab D. Bebars, Etornam Komla Ahorsu, Mahdi Mehrtash, M. Sami Fadali, Hanif Livani
abstract: Accurate forecasting of Dynamic Line Ratings (DLRs) is essential for enhancing grid reliability, maximizing transmission capacity, and integrating more renewable energy. This paper presents a robust, real-time DLR forecasting method using an enhanced Kalman Filter and the IEEE 738 standard for overhead transmission lines. The method improves thermal capacity estimates by reducing noise and error in ambient weather parameter inputs. It requires no prior training data, ensuring suitability for real-time use with traceable computational time. The model also incorporates diverse state variables, including weather, electrical, and mechanical conditions of the line, enhancing robustness. Its effectiveness is demonstrated through integration into a real-time, multi-interval Security-Constrained Optimal Power Flow (SCOPF) problem, using a modified IEEE 24-bus system. The problem is solved both as a Second-Order Cone Programming (SOCP) model using Gurobi and as a nonlinear model using the Interior Point Optimizer (IPOPT). The proposed testbed incorporates modern grid technologies such as energy storage units and distributed renewable energy generation. Case studies show improved accuracy, reduced operational costs and renewable curtailment, and effective real-time market balancing.
