title: Usability Assessment of a Mobile Application for Promoting Adherence to Speed Limits
authors: El Hafidy Abderrahim, Rachad Taoufik
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: This paper presents the usability assessment of a mobile application for promoting adherence to speed limits. Grounded in behavioral science, the app used several Behavior Change Techniques (BCTs) to address the social and psychological factors associated with speeding. To assess the usability of the developed mobile application, the ISO 9241-11 standard was adopted. A set of usage scenarios was conducted with participants from the field of computer science, enabling the collection of both quantitative and qualitative data. The assessment focused on three usability metrics: effectiveness, efficiency, and user satisfaction. Participants also provided constructive feedback for enhancing the app's interface and overall user experience.

title: Design and Stabilization of Uncertain T-S Fuzzy Systems via Fuzzy Controller and Fuzzy Observer
authors: Kaoutar Lahmadi, Khaddouj Ben Meziane
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: The creation of a nonlinear fuzzy control and observation approach for uncertain systems, described inside the Takagi–Sugeno (TS) fuzzy framework, is the main goal of this research. The suggested method combines a fuzzy observer that can handle parameter fluctuations with a reliable fuzzy state-feedback controller. Standard convex optimization techniques are used to solve a set of Linear Matrix Inequality (LMI) constraints that guarantee stability and resilience. Through simulations conducted on an inverted pendulum system, the efficiency and dependability of the suggested design are confirmed, showcasing its capacity to attain steady performance under uncertainty.

title: Advanced Clustering with High Resolution in Photovoltaic Systems and its Impact on Prediction Models
authors: Karla Mariel Fernández Fabián, David Gregorio Pacheco Salazar, Francisco J. Sánchez Sutil, Jesús de la Casa Hernández, Antonio Cano Ortega
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: This study proposes a hybrid framework that integrates advanced clustering techniques with deep learning models, designed to exploit very high temporal resolution data in order to increase the accuracy of short- and medium-term forecasts. The main objective is to demonstrate that the incorporation of clustering processes makes it possible to identify daily atmospheric variability, seasonality or other dynamic transitions, which in turn allows the training of more robust specialized models. A database with 10 -second resolution was used under varied weather conditions. The results show that the application of clustering optimizes data segmentation, facilitating more effective learning, improving the predictive capacity of the algorithms used. In terms of performance, it was observed that the clustered models outperformed the reference models (without clustering), reaching improvements in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$R^{2}$</tex> of up to 0.005 in short-term forecasts and an average of 0.031 for the medium term. Likewise, relative improvements were recorded in prediction errors: the MAE decreased on average by 18.79 % for the short term and 42.97 % for the medium term, while the RMSE showed average reductions of 8.37 % and 41.88 %, respectively, as well as a reduction in processing time of an average of 6.47 % for short-term predictions (robust method) and an average of 83 % for medium-term forecasts (less complex method). These findings demonstrate that high granularity and clustering bring considerable practical value in critical applications such as: (i) power availability estimation by time slots, (ii) intelligent programming of battery storage systems, and (iii) energy planning in PV systems.

title: A New Public Key Encryption with Keyword Search Against Side Channel Attacks
authors: Yu Qihong
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: Considering the needs of data security, the users in cloud storage will upload encrypted data to the server. Searchable encryption technology effectively solves the problem of searching encrypted data. Traditional searchable encryption requires one secure channel, while the searchable encryption proposed in this paper does not require this. In addition, existing searchable encryption methods have not taken into account the leakage of trapdoor information, and the solution proposed in this paper can resist the leakage of trapdoors. A security model about searchable encryption with leakage resilience is put forward, and the first searchable encryption scheme against side channel attacks is proposed. The security for the given scheme is demonstrated in the standard model by dual system encryption. This relative leakage rate about the trapdoor amounts to 1/3.

title: Linear State Estimation in Presence of Bounded Uncertainties: A Comparative Analysis
authors: Ayan Das, Anushka Sharma, Anamitra Pal
abstract: A variety of algorithms have been proposed to address the power system state estimation problem in the presence of uncertainties in the data. However, less emphasis has been given to handling perturbations in the model. In the context of linear state estimation (LSE), which is the focus of this paper, perturbations in the model come from variations in the line parameters. Since the actual values of the line parameters can be different from the values stored in a power utility’s database, we investigate three approaches in this paper to estimate the states in the presence of bounded uncertainties in the data and the model. The first approach is based on interval arithmetic, the second is based on convex optimization, and the third is based on generalized linear-fractional programming. The three algorithms are applied to multiple IEEE test systems and compared in terms of their speed and accuracy. The results indicate that the first two algorithms are extremely fast and give expected results, while the third suffers from scalability issues and is unsuitable for LSE.

title: Quantum SVM Algorithms for Efficient Defense Against Gradient-Based Adversarial Attacks
authors: Hakeem Quadri, Hua Wang, Sardar Islam, Bo Li, Xin Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: The growth of machine learning (ML) has revealed model vulnerabilities to adversarial attacks, where small data perturbations degrade performance. Classical defenses often struggle, especially with complex, non-linear data, and adversarial training is resource-intensive due to high computational demands. This research explores the use of quantum kernels in SVMs with ZZ feature maps to transform adversarial data into high-dimensional quantum spaces, showing quantum machine learning’s potential to surpass classical approaches. Testing on MNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets showed quantum SVM achieving 70.6% accuracy on adversarial data, outperforming classical SVM with RBF which achieved $51 \%$. This demonstrates the quantum SVM’s robustness against adversarial attacks.

title: A Reconfigurable Co-Simulation Framework for Dynamical Analysis of Grid-Connected Wave Energy Converters
authors: Alexander Barajas-Ritchie, Eduardo Cotilla-Sanchez, Saptarshi Bhattacharya, Diane Baldwin
abstract: In this work, we develop a co-simulation based software framework to evaluate the effects of grid-connected wave energy converters in power system operations that take into account system dynamics. Specifically our approach integrates the detailed hydrodynamic response of wave energy devices to equivalent electricity generation output under grid connected configurations. A Linear Power Take-Off (PTO) model is introduced, simulating the dynamic response of WECs as they connect to a modified IEEE 14-bus system. The results suggest that WECs do not significantly enhance or degrade grid stability, thus confirming their potential for seamless integration into renewable energy grids. Additionally, WEC systems offer marginal improvements in buffering sudden demand shifts, indicating its potential contribution to power grid resilience.

title: Balancing Resilience and Resource Allocation in Microgrids
authors: Usama Aslam, Kouhyar Sheida, Farzad Ferdowsi, Terrence Chambers
abstract: This paper proposes a novel dual-criteria approach to optimize resource allocation in microgrids while maintaining desired resilience levels. Although increasing resource capacity inherently improves microgrid resilience during emergencies, this study addresses the critical balance between resilience requirements and associated costs. The proposed method considers multiple dimensions of resilience measurement and aims to optimize investments for emergency scenarios. By integrating Fixed Battery Energy Storage Systems (FBESS) and Mobile Battery Energy Storage Systems (MBESS), the strategy provides adaptability, making the microgrid both resilient and cost-effective. The approach is tested in three practical resilience scenarios: low, moderate, and high, each reflecting different levels of critical load coverage and solar availability. This illustrates how the method adapts to the varying demands of the system while maintaining resilience without incurring unnecessary costs. The results highlight the importance of considering cost and resilience as dual objectives in microgrid planning and operation, providing valuable information to grid operators and planners seeking to improve system resilience while optimizing resource allocation.

title: Blind Source Separation for Visible Light Communication Using Gaussian Smoothing and Simplified Cost Function
authors: Pengfei Xu, Yinjie Jia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: Blind source separation (BSS) is a widely discussed research area in signal processing that aims to separate source signals from observed or mixed signals. This study utilizes Gaussian filtering to smooth well-defined mixed signals commonly found in communication signals. A simplified cost function based on signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is adopted, and the demixing matrix is obtained by solving a generalized eigenvalue problem without iterations. Gaussian filtering, also known as Gaussian smoothing (GS), effectively eliminates Gaussian noise and outlier effects by employing weighted averages of data points. This results in a modified data set with reduced frequency and magnitude of outliers. The proposed algorithm is straightforward to implement and is evaluated through simulation experiments involving communication signals of the same frequency, different frequencies, and various modulations in a visible light communication (VLC) system. Additionally, other commonly used independent component analysis (ICA) algorithms are introduced for comparative analysis. The study also investigates the algorithm’s performance as the number of sources increases. The simulation results demonstrate the proposed algorithm’s favorable performance, particularly in scenarios with high SNR.

title: Analysis of the Determinants of Spectator and Visualization of Regional Distribution in the Japan Men’s Handball League
authors: Rikuya Kawamura, Yoshiro Yamamoto
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: The evaluation of athletes is directly related to the management of sports teams, team organization, and the motivation of the athletes themselves, and is considered to be very important. In Japan, professional sports such as baseball and soccer use data-based player evaluation methods and strategies, but in handball, many teams evaluate, select, and direct their players based on traditional knowledge and past experience. Sabermetrics is a method of analysis in baseball. Since baseball plays are separated by each pitch and the open data of handball is play-by-play data, we considered that it has a high affinity with sabermetrics. In this study, we apply the sabermetric index. Specifically, we propose an evaluation index that focuses on players who increase the probability of winning a game by using their play-by-play data. In the field of handball, there have been few studies based on data concerning player evaluation as far as the authors have investigated.

title: An Improved AI-Based Micro-Single-Event-Latchup (Micro-SEL) and SEL Detection in a COTS System Against R/C/L-Induced (Power Management) Distortions
authors: Junkai Zhao, Caoyang Yu, Jiwei Wang, Yin Sun, Tony Zhang, Tong Ge, Kwen-Siong Chong, Wei Shu, Joseph S. Chang
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: In our envisioned "Chang’s Next Paradigm of New Space", Commercial-Off-The-Shelf (COTS) systems (embodying multiple COTS ICs, vis-à-vis individual COTS ICs) are employed in space applications. As the majority of COTS ICs are susceptible to radiation effects, particularly Micro-Single-Event-Latchups (μ-SELs) and SELs, COTS systems are likewise vulnerable. We had proposed a protection means involving the deployment of an AI-based μ-SEL/SEL detection on the input power rail (external to the COTS system) – hence, without needing physical modification to the COTS system. However, the input power rail’s R/C/L configuration, which varies across different COTS systems, obscures μ-SEL/SEL characteristics, thereby degrading detection accuracy. In this paper, we propose an improved AI-based μ-SEL/SEL detection approach that integrates R/C/L-aware data augmentation and temporal feature extraction to improve its robustness against R/C/L-induced distortions. We achieve high (86.6%) detection accuracy across different R/C/L configurations – improving by 23.4%-73.5% over prior works. Our proposed approach is hence appropriate for space applications, facilitating our said envisioned "Chang’s Next Paradigm of New Space".

title: A Hybrid Approach Using CNN Feature Extraction and SVM/XGBoost for Lung Nodule Classification
authors: Mouna Ajaani, Mohamed Radouane
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Early detection of lung cancer is highly beneficial for patient survival. This paper proposes a hybrid deep learning diagnostic pipeline for pulmonary nodules in chest CT. We constructed a new balanced dataset in which three publicly available CT datasets are incorporated: LUNA16, Data Science Bowl 2018 and a small fraction from 100 patients in LIDC-IDRI. After preprocessing and patch extraction, data were categorized into nodule and non-nodule classes. To extract features, we used six pretrained CNN architectures (ResNet50, VGG16, MobileNetV2, EfficientNetB0, DenseNet121, and InceptionV3). For feature training, traditional classifiers Support Vector Machines (SVM), and XGBoost were then utilized. We employed data augmentation techniques to improve model generalization and prevent overfitting. The most accurate pipeline we encountered utilized ResNet50 with SVM and reached 98% accuracy. These results demonstrate the benefits of using deep feature extraction alongside conventional machine-learning classifiers, and highlight the effectiveness and robustness of an easily adoptable approach to lung nodule detection in medical imaging.

title: Straight-Leg Walking and Standing on Complex Terrains with Reinforcement Learning
authors: Diyuan Liu, Chao Ji, Yaxi Zeng, Hanlin Zhu, An Mo, Jia Pan, Yanyong Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Most humanoid robots walk with crouched legs, in an effort to avoid the singularity problem in articulated robot control. In comparison, a human walks with straight legs. We used a reinforcement learning approach to enable human-like straight-leg walking for humanoid robots. First, we train different models to control the humanoid robot to walk and stand using reinforcement learning. Then we train a switching model to achieve smooth switching between walking and standing. After training in simulation, we deploy the model on a real humanoid robot. We bridge the gap between simulation and reality by combining visual characteristics for the robot state estimation. Thus, the humanoid robot can move stably on complex terrains with straightened legs, including walking in different directions, adapting to external disturbances, and standing still on discrete obstacles and slopes. Straight-leg locomotion is more human-like and can reduce 23% motor torques.

title: A Model for the Scheduling of Commercial eVTOL Flights Considering Grid Restrictions
authors: Eduardo Castillo Fatule, Fengyu Wang, Di Shi, Zhenping Guo, Kai Sun, Liang Sun
abstract: Electric aircraft are currently limited by battery capacity, making them unsuitable for long-distance flights. However, they are an excellent solution for short-distance travel, where their lower emissions and reduced operating costs can significantly benefit regional transportation. These aircraft are ideal for connecting cities and regions over shorter routes, offering a more sustainable alternative to traditional fuel-powered planes while supporting the growing need for eco-friendly travel options. However, gird restrictions affect the full capability of electric aircraft fleet. As part of NASA’s Advanced Air Mobility Mission, this study presents a mathematical model and a solution methodology which can create a flight schedule for eVTOLs in order to determine (i) passenger flows, and (ii) infrastructure requirements based on estimated travel demands, while (iii) analyzing the grid to maintain stability and security requirements. While many parameters still require further studies to accurately estimate, the results are promising for the test bed system modeling the Tennessee transmission network with ten candidate eVTOL charging locations in the state.

title: A Leaping Spider-Inspired Soft Bionic Actuator for Amphibious Movement Robots
authors: Yiwei Zhang, Chuang Zhang, Hengshen Qin, Lianchao Yang, Qi Zhang, Lianqing Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Soft actuators, as the core components of soft robots, play a crucial role in the entire robot system. However, due to the limited output force and response speed of soft actuators based on smart materials, soft robots have difficulty achieving effective movement in amphibious scenarios. Inspired by the hydraulic drive mechanism of leaping spiders, a flexible and controllable amphibious robot module is developed by designing a new type of joint actuator and introducing an efficient underwater encapsulation method. This new type of joint electro-hydraulic actuator can achieve a large swinging angle and a fast dynamic response speed. In addition, the crawling robot developed by using this joint actuator can not only realize fast crawling speed (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.3 \text{BL} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>) but also perform climbing motion at an angle of 30°. Moreover, it can be applied underwater and achieve rapid propulsion by splashing water, demonstrating excellent amphibious motion performance. This work not only contributes to the development of high-performance amphibious soft actuators but also provides essential references for the design of soft robots.

title: AI’s Appetite for Energy: How Data Centers Are Affecting the Environment
authors: Nina DeFranco Tommarello
abstract: Clean energy alternatives to fossil fuels for data centers are imperative. We need to address artificial intelligence’s growing energy consumption as it is the primary contributor to the rise in electricity consumption by data centers.

title: Contingency-Aware Transmission Flow Modeling for Corrective Security-Constrained Unit Commitment
authors: Gabriel Aldair Conejo Acosta, Dana Marina Gálvez García, Guillermo Gutiérrez-Alcaraz
abstract: Maintaining secure system operation under transmission contingencies is a core requirement in power system operation. This paper proposes a corrective Security Constraint Unit Commitment formulation that captures all N-1 transmission contingencies using an interval-based shift factor matrix. The methodology is evaluated on two benchmark systems: a 6-bus system, which facilitates a detailed inspection of dispatch and reserve, and the IEEE 57-bus system, which demonstrates the model's scalability and practical applicability. Simulation results confirm that the proposed approach enhances system security under any single-line outage conditions while preserving linearity and computational tractability.

title: Detecting Applicant Dropout in Job Applications: A Data-Driven ML Framework
authors: Fatima Zahra Abbour, Soufiane Ardchir, Soumaya Ounacer, Mohamed Azzouazi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Online recruitment platforms have transformed talent acquisition, yet they suffer from high candidate attrition: industry reports suggest that nearly 70 % of applicants abandon digital application forms before submission. Such dropout not only drains talent pipelines but also creates inefficiencies for recruiters. While predictive analytics has been applied to churn and dropout in domains like e-commerce and education, its systematic use in recruitment remains limited. This study introduces a data-driven framework for predicting candidate dropout using artificial intelligence techniques tailored to recruitment contexts. Leveraging a real-world dataset of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 4, 0 0 0}$</tex> job-application sessions, we integrate behavioral telemetry, user history, and job-posting metadata into a unified machinelearning pipeline. Five classifiers-Logistic Regression, Random Forest, Multi-Layer Perceptron, XGBoost, and LightGBM-were benchmarked. Gradient-boosted trees achieved the best results, with LightGBM reaching an F1-score of 0.76, precision of 0.79, and recall of 0.74, outperforming other methods across multiple random splits. Beyond performance, the framework emphasizes interpretability and fairness, crucial for AI systems in regulated hiring environments. SHAP analysis revealed that interaction-level features such as time per step, page revisits, and overall session length are the most influential predictors of dropout, offering transparent insights into candidate disengagement. By combining predictive accuracy with explainability, this work provides both a baseline and a roadmap for building human-centered recruitment platforms that move from passive monitoring to proactive candidateretention strategies. The study highlights how AI can not only predict dropout but also guide the design of real-time interventions, adaptive user interfaces, and fairer recruitment processes.

title: Toward Resilient Distributed Systems: A Survey of Failure Prediction
authors: I. Tarhri, D. Allaki, H. Kamal Idrissi
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: The increasing scale and complexity of distributed computing environments such as clouds, data centers, and edge computing systems have made failures a common occurrence that can dramatically undermine service reliability. Predictive failure monitoring has emerged as a promising approach to anticipate imminent failures and enable preventive or mitigation actions before outages occur. This paper provides a broad survey of predictive failure monitoring techniques in distributed systems. We survey the data sources and failure indicators utilized, ranging from system logs and performance metrics to sensor readings, and analyze the machine learning methods applied, ranging from classical supervised classifiers to advanced deep learning and ensemble models. We subsequently review representative proactive frameworks that integrate failure prediction with automated failure avoidance or recovery mechanisms. In addition, we discuss the evaluation metrics used to assess the effectiveness of the prediction and the impact of the system. Finally, after highlighting current challenges (data imbalance, operational overhead, and adaptability), we outline promising future research directions toward more robust and intelligent failure prediction in distributed computing environments. This work demonstrates measurable reductions in downtime, improved service availability, and reduced operational costs across various platforms, confirming the practical benefits of predictive monitoring in real-world systems.

title: Nonlinear Oscillators with Linear Solutions
authors: José Antonio Medina Hernández
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: The theory of linear oscillations was extensively developed throughout the last century. There is a vast bibliography on this topic [1]–[8]. In this article, a specific family of nonlinear oscillators will be described and their behavior will be confirmed by numerical simulations. We begin by analyzing the phase plane solution of a family of associated linear oscillators. It is then described how the nonlinear systems considered generate periodic waves that are completely different from those of the associated linear systems, even though the trajectories of both types of systems coincide in phase space.

title: Integrating Reinforcement Learning and Game Theory for Strategic Decision-Making in Cancer Therapy
authors: Dadda Karima, Raddouane Chiheb
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Cancer treatment faces significant challenges due to tumor adaptation, heterogeneity, and rapid resistance development, where sequential therapies often fail against the evolving dynamics of cancer cells. Traditional methods, such as fixed-dose regimens, overlook the adaptive, game-like interactions between oncologists and tumors, leading to suboptimal outcomes and limited personalization in precision medicine. To address these limitations, we introduce Nash-RL, an innovative framework that integrates game theory and reinforcement learning (RL) to enable optimized, evolutionarily informed cancer therapy. By modeling the oncologist-tumor interaction as a Stackelberg game, where the oncologist acts as an RL-trained leader optimizing strategies and the tumor as an evolutionary follower adapting to pressures, our approach anticipates resistance mechanisms and captures the sequential decision-making process inherent in adaptive treatments. Nash-RL combines key game-theoretic concepts, including Nash equilibrium, Stackelberg strategies, and evolutionary games, with multi-agent RL algorithms to develop robust, patient-specific treatment protocols. This integration not only enhances therapy efficacy by dynamically adjusting doses but also delays resistance development, advancing fields like adaptive therapy and precision oncology. We formulate the mathematical foundations, incorporating state-action-reward models and equilibrium computations, and outline computational implementation using deep Q-networks and policy gradient methods. Theoretical advantages over existing RL or game-theoretic approaches are analyzed, with proof-of-concept simulations demonstrating practical feasibility. Overall, Nash-RL provides a scalable foundation for sustainable strategies that collaborate with, rather than combat, cancer's adaptive nature, paving the way for intelligent, personalized oncology and potentially transforming clinical practice.

title: Unlocking Private Computation at Scale: The Acceleration of Homomorphic Encryption
authors: Jaiyoung Park, Sangpyo Kim, Jongmin Kim, Jung Ho Ahn
abstract: Homomorphic encryption (HE) promises a “perfect computational servant” that can process encrypted data, but its overhead has hindered its practical use. Key breakthroughs in HE acceleration are now bringing this powerful privacy-preserving paradigm from theory to reality.

title: Enhancing Hierarchical Reinforcement Learning with Symbolic Planning for Long-Horizon Tasks_supp1-3641255.mp4
authors: Jing Zhang
abstract: Long-horizon tasks, such as box stacking, pose a longstanding challenge in robotic manipulation, especially for Reinforcement Learning (RL). RL typically focuses on learning an optimal policy for completing an entire task, rather than determining the specific sequence of actions required to achieve complex goals. While RL finds a sequence of actions that maximizes the total reward of the task, the main challenge arises when there are infinite possibilities of chaining actions (e.g. reach, push) to achieve the same task (door-opening). In this case, RL struggles to find the optimal policy. In contrast, symbolic planning focuses on determining a sequence of actions to achieve the desired task. This paper introduces a novel framework that integrates symbolic planning operators with hierarchical RL. We propose to change the way complex tasks are trained by learning independent policies for actions defined by high-level operators instead of learning a single policy for the complete long-horizon task. Our approach easily adapts to various tasks by adjusting the learned operator set on demand. We developed a dual-purpose high-level operator, which can be used both in holistic planning and as independent, reusable policies. Our approach offers a flexible solution for long-horizon tasks, e.g., stacking and inserting a cube, and door-opening. Experimental results indicate that our method achieves high success rates of around 95% in policy chaining for comprehensive plan execution and excels in learning independent policies. Furthermore, it remains robust and scalable even with a small sample set evaluation, attaining an 84% success rate for planning and executing a new task (door-opening) and 85% when dealing with a new operator. Experiments in dynamic environments further demonstrate the robustness and adaptability of our approach, which sustains a high success rate of around 90% and outperforms all baselines.

title:
DAR
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    A-Net: Pixelwise Distance Aware Recurrent Residual Attention Net for Efficient Hyperspectral Change Detection
authors: Ramen Ghosh, Samiran Das
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Recent Deep Learning (DL) powered hyper-spectral change detection methods are limited by their ability to comprehend spatio-spectral features fully, reliance on large training datasets, and high computational resource demand. In this paper, we introduce a novel framework (DAR<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>A-Net) that initially computes an appropriate pixel-wise distance and subsequently utilizes a recurrent residual attention-based advanced DL model to detect changes accurately to transcend these bottlenecks. In this framework, we initially compute pixelwise similarity using heterogeneous distance metrics, extracting a coarse, low-level feature that is topologically consistent with the ground truth(GT) change map(CM). As the pixelwise distance feature may not accurately reflect consequential and background changes, we fine-tune the feature map using an advanced recurrent residual attention-based model to obtain an accurate CM. The recurrent residual attention net, included in the subsequent stage, comprehends local-global spatial contextual information and accurately identifies the CM. Empirical validation across three publicly available datasets revealed that the proposed Distance Aware Recurrent Residual Attention Net (DAR<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>A-Net) model achieved noticeable improvement in overall accuracy (OA), Kappa coefficient, and F1 score compared to the recent state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods for these datasets. Our proposed DAR<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>A-Net achieves a remarkable 40-fold decrease in learnable parameters and a 20-fold reduction in floating-point operations per second (FLOPs) compared to the SOTA methods.

title: Cooperative Beamforming for Covert Communications in MIMO Interference Channels
authors: Xing Lv, Manlin Wang, Chunqi Chen, Bin Xia
abstract: Public communication links can serve as shelters to facilitate covert transmissions. To improve the covertness performance, we regard multiple multi-antenna public users as friends and leverage their abundant spatial degrees of freedom (SDoF) to resist illegal surveillance. However, the resulting complex directional interference introduces challenges in measuring the covertness and optimizing the beamformers. Accordingly, this study investigates a covert communication system where multiple public user pairs coexist with one covert user pair in multiple-input multiple-output interference channels. Specifically, a covert rate maximization problem through joint transceiver beamforming is formulated, which is difficult to solve as it is a non-convex problem. To address this, a centralized algorithm is first developed based on the successive convex approximation method that transforms the problem into a convex optimization framework. Additionally, to alleviate the backhaul overhead, we develop a decentralized solution utilizing primal decomposition to decouple the interference management and the covertness metrics at each transmitter, relying only on local channel state information. Simulations demonstrate that our proposed algorithms fully exploit the SDoF jointly provided by the spatial distribution of public users and the employment of multi-antenna technology. Therefore, our algorithms achieve superior performance over baselines that do not effectively leverage these spatial resources.

title: AutoMOCHA: Automated Adaptation Hierarchy for Mobile Video Analytics Against Domain Shifts
authors: Maozhe Zhao, Rui Shen, Shengzhong Liu, Fan Wu, Guihai Chen
abstract: Mobile video analytics systems are often deployed in diverse environments, where domain shifts place higher demands on the responsiveness of adaptation for ”expert models” running on resource-constrained mobile devices. However, due to the lack of effective automated on-device model retrieval strategies and corresponding mobile adaptation mechanisms, most existing frameworks still rely on cloud-centric adaptation architectures rather than mobile-centric ones, leading to delayed responses to such domain shifts. We introduce a hierarchical mobile-cloud collaborative adaptation framework, AutoMOCHA, for continuous mobile video analytics in dynamically evolving environments. It includes three main contributions: (1) It facilitates efficient history expert model retrieval, without relying on dataset-based model validation, through an automatically constructed model taxonomy and indexing mechanism that does not require prior domain knowledge; (2) It proactively coordinates onboard lightweight model reuse and finetuning strategy with remote model retrieval and retraining to achieve responsive model adaptation with low latency; (3) It accelerates onboard model reuse and finetuning through designing a dedicated mobile model cache management strategy and sparse updating policy. Extensive evaluations on real-world video data across three DNN tasks demonstrate that AutoMOCHA improves model accuracy during adaptation by up to 3.4%, increases the post-clustering silhouette coefficient by up to 33%, and reduces retraining frequency by up to 10%, all while maintaining optimal response latency and retraining time.

title: Precision-Specific Efficient Designs and FPGA Implementation of Sigmoid for Machine Learning
authors: Pramod Kumar Meher, Supriya Aggarwal
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems I: Regular Papers
abstract: This paper presents a low-complexity design for generating the sigmoid function based on a novel piecewise linear approximation. We have proposed an iterative algorithm to break the whole argument space into the minimum number of intervals, for any given desired accuracy. The LUT address generator of the proposed design does not require any comparators since the breakpoints generated by the proposed algorithm contain only a few non-zero bits. Similarly, the slopes of the line segments are represented by a few non-zero bits, such that the multiplication with slope is realized using hardwired shift operations or a few shift-add operations without using any LUT to store the slope values and without using any conventional multiplier. For the computation of the sigmoid function with fractional accuracy of 7 bits, the proposed design involves only 6 line segments, which requires 2 adders and an LUT to store 6 intercept words. When implemented on an Xilinx Kintex-7 FPGA device, it is found to be 8 times faster than the fastest of the existing designs for the same accuracy and consumes less than half the resources used by the latter. Moreover, the proposed design for 9-bit fractional accuracy is approximately twice as fast and more resource-efficient than a recently reported design offering the same level of accuracy.

title: A Pattern-Dependent Pulse Filtering Technique for Low-Jitter Injection-Locked CDR in 28-nm CMOS
authors: Junhak Kim, Young-Wook Kim, Sinho Lee, Yoojin Jung, Min-Seong Choo, Kwanseo Park
publish: IEEE Transactions on Very Large Scale Integration (VLSI) Systems
abstract: This work presents a ring oscillator (RO)-based low-jitter injection-locked clock and data recovery (ILCDR) with a pattern-dependent pulse filtering (PDPF) technique. The conventional ILCDR has a drawback that data jitter is transferred to the recovered clock. To reduce jitter, the PDPF technique is employed to filter out the injection pulses occurring in data patterns that cause high data-dependent jitter (DDJ). Adopting the PDPF technique with an injection timing control loop, the ILCDR optimizes injection timing and maximizes timing margin. Fabricated in a 28-nm CMOS technology, the proposed ILCDR occupies an active area of 0.03 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> and consumes 13.6 mW at 10 Gb/s. The measured jitter tolerance (JTOL) is 1 UI<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">pp</sub> at 35 MHz with a bit error rate (BER) of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$10^{-12}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>.

title: Adaptive Container Characterization via Language Mapping for Video Integrity and Source Analysis
authors: Yuanman Li, Zhiwei Zhao, Jiaxiong Ye, Yulong Zheng, Bin Li, Rongrong Ni, Wei Wang, Xia Li
abstract: In the realm of video processing technology and artificial intelligence (AI), ensuring the integrity and provenance of video content is paramount. Recent advances have shown that video containers hold valuable forensic traces. However, the highly structured and heterogeneous nature of video containers presents substantial challenges for directly learning effective features through AI-driven methods. As a result, existing approaches have largely depended on manually extracted features of video containers, such as frequency vectors of symbols, subsequently processed using machine learning techniques like Random Forests. Consequently, they struggle to comprehensively capture task-specific information and suffer from limitations in feature adaptability and generalization. To address this challenge, we introduce a novel AI-driven container characterization approach for video integrity and source analysis, which eschews manual features entirely, enabling end-to-end training of the whole framework. Specifically, by modeling the video container as a semantic tree, we establish a lossless mapping relationship between the video container space and language space. This innovative container-to-language mapping significantly mitigates the heterogeneity challenges posed by video containers, enabling more effective analysis within a linguistic framework. Further-more, we develop a hierarchical language model that leverages this mapping to adaptively learn task-specific features from video containers without disrupting their structural and semantic information. Extensive experiments demonstrate the superiority of our method on video integrity verification and source identification tasks. Our source code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">“https://github.com/zhaozwszu/ACCLM”</uri>.

title: FBFL: Flexible Byzantine-robust Federated Learning with Privacy-preserving
authors: Yanxin Xu, Hua Zhang, Jianjin Zhao, Keke Gai, Zian Tian, Jianxin Yang
abstract: Privacy-preserving federated learning allows many clients to collaboratively train a machine learning model by sharing encrypted models. Among them, mask-based schemes have been widely applied due to their efficiency advantages. Unfortunately, as the invisibility of an individual local model, such schemes are vulnerable to poisoning attacks by Byzantine clients. Current work lacks a practical method to detect Byzantine clients within the mask-based scheme. We propose FBFL, a flexible Byzantine-robust federated learning scheme with privacy-preserving. While protecting the privacy of the client, we implement a defense against Byzantine clients without relying on an individual masked local model. Specifically, we design a secure distance computation method based on the Pedersen commitment. The exponential Manhattan distance we design is utilized to compute the malicious score of the client in order to distinguish the benign model from the abnormal model. Since the malicious score is obtained utilizing only the commitment value and not the masked local model, our Byzantine-robust method can be flexibly combined with other mask-based privacy-preserving methods. Security analysis shows that FBFL is Byzantine-robust and can ensure the data security of clients. Experimental evaluation shows that the robustness and efficiency of FBFL are great.

title: A Chain-Type Magnetic Wheeled Robot for In-Situ Inspection of Integrated Pipeline-Valve-Vessel Systems_supp7-3630272.mp4
authors: Zhiguang Xing
abstract: Integrated pipeline-valve-vessel systems are essential in industrial processes but require periodic disassembly for inspection under extreme conditions. Robotic inspection offers an economical and efficient alternative to manual disassembly. However, existing robots are limited to inspecting pipelines or vessels separately. Continuous traversal through small-to-medium diameter pipelines (80–150 mm), valves, and into vessels remains challenging due to irregular and confined chambered structure. To overcome this limitation, we propose a chain-type magnetic wheeled robot featuring two key innovations: 1) the integration of a serial gear chain (SGC) with magnetic adhesion mechanism ensures the robot’s adaptability to irregular surfaces, reducing force-control dependency during complex valve navigation. Leveraging this characteristic, a distributed dual-end drive configuration within the SGC addresses power insufficiency caused by the robot’s suspension in the hollow regions and 2) the traditional force-angle stability margin is modified to serve as a criterion for tipover instability. Based on this, a predictive instability control framework is developed, integrating offline-computed posture thresholds with real-time attitude monitoring to enhance motion stability. Experimental results demonstrate that the robot achieves robust, stable traversal, and nondismantling inspection across pipelines, valves, and vessels without disassembly. This work provides valuable insights for industries, such as nuclear power and chemical engineering.

title: Embedded-Oriented Open-Switch Fault Diagnosis and Localization for Dual Y-Connected PMSM Based on Deep Learning
authors: Shihan Xu, Yuan Zhu, Luca Zarri
abstract: The open-switch fault diagnosis speed of multiphase machines is generally no less than 1/4 of an electrical cycle, severely affecting the timeliness of fault-tolerant control intervention. To address this issue, this paper first proposes a cascaded triggering algorithm based on logical judgment, integrating optimized open-phase characteristic values with harmonic subspace current trajectories to enhance the stability of the logic-based method. The proposed data-driven method treats open-phase characteristic values and harmonic subspace currents as input features to reduce the computational burden of extracting open-circuit features in deep learning networks. Additionally, to improve the computational speed of the neural network on embedded platforms, a multi-target classification network is designed based on a simplified gated unit, and a lightweight solving algorithm for the activation function is applied. The dataset used in the deep learning network is labeled with the assistance of a designed Autoencoder while preserving the transition data between pre- and post-fault states. The effectiveness, accuracy, and fault localization speed of the proposed algorithms are validated through the dataset and the experiment on the motor bench. The results demonstrate that the proposed data-driven method can accurately locate the open switch fault within 10 sampling periods

title: Active RIS Enabled NLoS LEO Satellite Communications: A Three-timescale Optimization Framework
authors: Ziwei Liu, Junyan He, Shanshan Zhao, Meng Hua, Bin Lyu, Xinjie Zhao, Gengxin Zhang
abstract: In this letter, we study an active reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (aRIS) assisted low earth orbit (LEO) satellite communications under non-line-of-sight (NLoS) scenarios, where the aRIS is deployed to create visual line-of-sight links for reliable communication. To address the challenges of high energy consumption caused by frequent beamforming updates in aRIS, we propose a three-timescale optimization framework that jointly designs the transmit beamforming, RIS beamforming, and RIS orientation vectors based on their characteristics. The goal is to maximize the system achievable rate while reducing energy consumption by controlling the aRIS beamforming switching frequency. Then, a two-layer solution framework is developed, incorporating fractional programming, alternating optimization, successive convex approximation, and penalty function methods, to obtain the high-quality solution. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed scheme can effectively improve system performance and reduce the energy consumption of the aRIS.

title: Distributed Fixed-Time Optimization of Multiagent Systems With Nonlinear Unknown Disturbances
authors: Yanzhi Wu, Deqing Huang, Lei Ma, Jiangping Hu, Linying Xiang, Qingpeng Liang
abstract: In this article, distributed fixed-time optimization is investigated for multiagent systems (MAS) with unknown time-varying disturbances, where the global objective function is the sum of all local objective functions. The goal is to design a smooth distributed adaptive control algorithm that can collaboratively solve this optimization problem, with each node limited to accessing its neighboring states and its own nonconvex local cost function. The unknown disturbances are modeled using linearly parameterized models, and distributed adaptive laws are designed to estimate these parameters, ensuring fixed-time convergence of these estimations. A novel fixed-time distributed control method for consensus in MAS is introduced, which differs from traditional methods that rely on fractional power state feedback or signum functions (where the convergence time depends on initial conditions and the control action is nonsmooth or discontinuous). Specifically, this method is based on regular state feedback to facilitate a uniformly smooth control process. This approach is validated through simulations, demonstrating that each agent’s state converges to the optimal solution within a fixed time.

title: Extension of Unambiguous Doppler in High-Frequency Surface Wave Radar Based on Poisson Disk Sampling
authors: Boyuan Dong, Yingning Dong, Weibo Deng
abstract: In marine remote sensing, the phenomena of Doppler ambiguity widely exist in the velocity measurements of fast-moving targets in high-frequency surface wave radar (HFSWR) with frequency-modulated interrupted continuous waveform. The maximum Doppler that can be unambiguously measured for targets in HFSWR is restricted by the chirp repetition frequency. In this article, an approach for the extension of unambiguous Doppler in HFSWR is proposed based on Poisson disk sampling and sparse reconstruction. The start instants of adjacent chirps are set to be Poisson disk sampled. Taking advantage of the spectral antialiasing performance of the proposed nonuniform sampling strategy, the maximum unambiguous Doppler of HFSWR can be enlarged without decreasing the maximum aliasing-free range. The range-Doppler spectrum can be correctly reconstructed by utilizing a sparse reconstruction algorithm. Compared with the existing methods for resolving the Doppler ambiguity of HFSWR, the proposed method is able to monitor multitarget scenarios without introducing false alarms. The effectiveness of the proposed method is demonstrated by simulations and experiments based on measured HFSWR data.

title: Phase Modeling of Optical Components for Dispersion Compensation in Visible Light OCT
authors: Fuwang Wu, Xiang He, Hongtao Wei, Zhengkai Yao, Yi Wan, Weiye Song
abstract: To address the challenge of severe dispersion in visible light optical coherence tomography (vis-OCT), this paper proposes a simple yet effective digital dispersion compensation method based on phase modeling of optical components (PMOC). The PMOC can effectively compensate for higher-order dispersion without requiring complex computations or additional mirror-reflection measurements. It is also capable of compensating for spatially dependent dispersion (SDD). The performance of the method is validated through both interference signal analysis and vis-OCT images. Moreover, compared to the Taylor series iterative fitting (TSIF) method, the proposed method achieved a significant improvement in resolution and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR). The images obtained by PMOC are comparable to those acquired under dispersion-free conditions.

title: Fall Detection by Bimodal Sensing with Late Fusion
authors: Haythem Rehouma, Mounir Boukadoum
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: The timely detection of falls is a critical challenge in healthcare and assistive technology for the elderly. The existing systems typically use either inertial or vision-based methods, with well-known limitations. We propose a bimodal deep learning framework that combines inertial anomaly detection and video-based posture analysis with late fusion for improved performance. The system's evaluation on simulated nighttime falls reveals a 4.1% false positive rate in comparison to 8.9% for IMU-only and 6.9 to 10% for vision-only baselines, while maintaining high sensitivity. This result indicates a robust performance under low light and occlusions, and it supports continuous nocturnal monitoring in real-world settings.

title: ResNeSt50-Based Smoke Trace Recognition for Real-Time Photothermal Actuator Monitoring
authors: Kechen Li, Ruitong Yang, Yuanyuan Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Existing studies have demonstrated that the introduction of nanomaterials into carbon-based actuators can significantly enhance their photothermal conversion efficiency. However, excessively high photothermal conversion efficiency makes actuators prone to thermal damage under intense laser irradiation. To address this issue, this study constructs a vision-based dynamic monitoring platform to achieve real-time identification of the actuator's operational status and early warning of damage under photoexcitation. Actuators with enhanced photothermal conversion efficiency are susceptible to structural burnout due to localized heat accumulation under high-power laser exposure, typically characterized by abnormal high-brightness patches in the imaging area. The developed vision monitoring system employs image processing algorithms and machine learning models to conduct real-time analysis of photofield distribution characteristics and structural deformation patterns, enabling dynamic evaluation of actuator performance and prospective identification of abnormal states. Experimental data show that this monitoring platform can reliably capture deviations in operational parameters and effectively reduce the risk of laser thermal damage through a closed-loop feedback mechanism. This research integrates efficient light-driven actuation mechanisms with intelligent monitoring technologies, providing high-performance and high-reliability solutions for advanced soft robotics, biomedical devices, and precision optical manipulation applications.

title: Toward Multi-Source Sky-Ground Re-Identification: A New Benchmark and an Innovative Approach
authors: Hongxu Chen, Zhizhi Lu, Nailong Zhao, Yuli Huang, Lingxiao Yang, Xiaohua Xie, Jianhuang Lai
abstract: Person re-identification (Re-ID) aims to accurately match pairs of person images across different cameras. Existing Re-ID methods primarily focus on associations within single-type camera networks (e.g., ground-ground or sky-sky matching), which are ineffective in addressing the significant viewpoint discrepancies in multi-type camera networks. One key reason for this is the absence of suitable large-scale datasets for algorithm evaluation, which limits the applicability of Re-ID across more diverse scenarios, despite its critical importance. To expand the scope of visual coverage and facilitate search operations in the special locations, we construct a novel benchmark: Multi-Source Sky-Land person Re-ID dataset (MSSL), including 66,928 images from 2,099 volunteers in nearly 20 unique scenes. Additionally, we observe that existing Re-ID systems struggle with drastic viewpoint variations in sky-ground Re-ID, especially on MSSL. To address these issues, we propose Multi-Source Prompts (MSP), separately learning finer cross-modal features of pedestrians from both sky and ground perspectives. These refined features better represent the true appearance of pedestrians from different viewpoints. Subsequently, we employ Multi-Source Alignment Loss to mitigate the impact of drastic viewpoint changes. Extensive experiments demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on our MSSL, as well as on other benchmarks such as AG-ReID dataset. Our MSSL dataset and the code will be available at https://github.com/sysuchx/SkyGroundReID.

title: The Load-Dump Stress-Induced Degradation of p-GaN HEMT Under Different Gate Biases
authors: Yijun Shi, Zhipeng Shen, Lijuan Wu, Liang He, Guoguang Lu, Yuan Chen, Xinghuan Chen, Lei Wang
abstract: This work first reveals the robustness and degradation mechanisms of a 200-V p-GaN high-electron-mobility transistor (HEMT) under the load-dump stress with the gate biased at different conditions. The gate conditions involved in this work include the <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</small>-state (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V}_{\text {GS}} =0$</tex-math> </inline-formula> V), semi-<sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-state (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V}_{\text {GS}} =1.6$</tex-math> </inline-formula> V), and <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-state (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V}_{\text {GS}} =6$</tex-math> </inline-formula> V). The experimental results indicate that the device has the weakest tolerance to the load-dump stress in the semi-<sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-state compared with the <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">off</small>- and <sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-states. Specifically, in the semi-<sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-state, the device immediately failed when the load-dump stress was increased to 100 V. While under the other two conditions, the device still works even when the load-dump stress was increased to 150 V. This phenomenon is closely related to the high local current concentration phenomenon, companying with the high electric field peak at the gate region for the device in the semi-<sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-state. In addition, the devices’ threshold voltage (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${V}_{\text {TH}}\text {)}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and drain current (<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">${I}_{\text {DS}}\text {)}$</tex-math> </inline-formula> show different drift degrees after applying the load-dump stress under different gate biases. Among them, it is worth noting that the device exhibits the most significant degradation phenomenon after the load-dump stress is applied in the semi-<sc xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">on</small>-state.

title: Arbitrary Microwave Waveform Generation Based on Optical Domain Modulation
authors: Jiaxue Feng, Congcong Liu, Nan Zhou, Yunping Bai, Ya Jin, Huashun Wen, Kunpeng Zhai, Jiazheng Sun, Edwin Yue Bun Pun, Sha Zhu, Ning Hua Zhu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: Arbitrary microwave waveforms have become increasingly crucial for diverse applications, including high-capacity wireless communication, advanced radar systems, electronic countermeasures, and precision instrumentation. Generating arbitrary microwave waveforms with precise and flexible control over amplitude, phase, and frequency is critical to meet these applications’ stringent performance demands. In contrast to conventional electronic waveform generators, photonic generation methods overcome inherent limitations, offering substantial benefits like ultrabroad bandwidth, high-frequency operation, resistance to electromagnetic interference, and superior reconfigurability. This article reviews recent developments in photonic generation of arbitrary microwave waveforms, focusing on several prominent optical-domain techniques, including frequency-to-time mapping (FTTM), direct space-to-time mapping (DST), temporal pulse shaping (TPS), optical heterodyne technology, optical frequency combs (OFCs), optical injection, electro-optic modulation, and optoelectronic oscillation (OEO). We systematically analyzed the key characteristics, advantages, and application potential of these techniques, emphasizing recent research achievements and innovations. Moreover, photonic integration technology represents a pivotal step toward the practical arbitrary microwave waveforms generation. Integrated photonic microwave chips significantly reduce system size, weight, and power consumption, while enhancing stability and scalability. Such integrated systems are particularly promising for compact and portable arbitrary microwave waveforms generation in applications like on-chip radar, miniaturized communication modules, and flexible radio frequency (RF) testing platforms.

title: NA-UICDE: A Novel Adaptive Algorithm for Underwater Image Color Correction and Detail Enhancement
authors: Yuyun Chen, Wenguang He, Gangqiang Xiong, Junwu Li, Yaomin Wang
abstract: Underwater images often suffer from color distortion and detail loss due to light absorption and scattering, which degrades visual quality and limits practical applications. To address these issues, a novel adaptive algorithm for underwater image color correction and detail enhancement is proposed. The algorithm first applies threshold stretching to adjust the grayscale range, enhancing contrast while mitigating the risk of localized overcompensation. Based on the color distribution, images are categorized into bluish and greenish tones, providing the foundation for the adaptive color compensation method (ACCM). The ACCM is designed to separately compensate different color channels, using the green channel as a reference to restore the most degraded channels while maintaining overall color balance. The compensation process is further constrained by the minimum color loss criterion to ensure consistent color fidelity. Furthermore, an edge detail enhancement method is formulated to recover fine details by amplifying intensity differences between the original image and its smoothed version. Extensive experiments on multiple underwater image data sets demonstrate that the proposed algorithm consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods, achieving average improvements of 0.0021, 0.0646, 0.3677, and 0.0800 in underwater color image quality evaluation, underwater image quality metric, fog aware density evaluator, and colorfulness contrast fog density index metrics, respectively, underscoring its effectiveness and robustness across diverse underwater environments.

title: Series Editorial: Integrated Sensing and Communications
authors: Weijie Yuan, George C. Alexandropoulos, Giuseppe Caire, Carlos Cordeiro, Tao Gu, Pu Wang
abstract: We are delighted to introduce the inaugural issue of the IEEE Communications Magazine Series on integrated sensing and communications (ISAC). As a transformative paradigm in wireless systems, ISAC is poised to redefine the landscape of sixth-generation (6G) networks and beyond. By synergistically merging sensing functionalities, such as localization, mapping, and environmental awareness, with traditional communication capabilities, ISAC promises to enhance spectrum efficiency, enable new applications in autonomous systems, and support the proliferation of intelligent connected devices. This integration leverages shared hardware, waveforms, and spectrum resources to address the growing demands for high-precision perception, ultrareliable connectivity, and energy-efficient operations in diverse scenarios, from urban environments to low-altitude network deployment. As 6G standardization efforts accelerate, ISAC stands out for its potential to bridge the gap between communication networks and the physical world, fostering advancements in fields like robotics, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), and quantum-enhanced systems. This first issue features six timely articles that explore cuttingedge models, methods, opportunities, and challenges in ISAC, spanning theoretical frameworks, practical implementations, and emerging technologies.

title: Electro-Thermal Circuit Modeling and Practical Evaluation of GaN Power Switches for Mega-Hertz Soft-Switching Operation
authors: Mingshuo Zhu, Kerui Li, Siew-Chong Tan, Shu Yuen Ron Hui
abstract: This paper investigates the switching performance and electro-thermal behavior of gallium nitride (GaN) high-electron-mobility transistors (HEMTs) in megahertz (MHz) soft-switching operations, focusing on conversion efficiency, thermal stability, and electromagnetic interference (EMI). Contrary to the datasheets of GaN HEMTs manufacturers that highlight the reverse-conducting characteristics of the devices, this study finds that the performance of GaN HEMTs degrades significantly at MHz operations due to elevated reverse conduction losses, high-frequency oscillations, and thermal instability from self-heating. Toten-pole GaN inverters with and without antiparallel Schottky diodes are compared practically and with the help of an electro-thermal circuit model for operations at 1 MHz, 6.78 MHz and 13.56 MHz. Electro-thermal circuit modeling and experimental results demonstrate that GaN switches with antiparallel Schottky diodes can reduce dead-time switching power losses by 85% and improve overall converter efficiency by 2.7∼6.9% in prototypes of 24 W- 29 W. This approach also mitigates thermal runaway risks by lowering the junction temperature of GaN HEMTs, therefore increasing thermal stability. Furthermore, the junction capacitance of the diodes can dampen high-frequency dv/dt transients and reduce electromagnetic emission. The experimental results show reductions of 24.41 dBm in magnetic field emissions and 26.57 dBm in electric field emissions. These findings challenge the prevailing industry assumption that external antiparallel diodes are unnecessary for GaN HEMTs, providing a validated design framework for MHz-range applications.

title: Four-Element MIMO Antenna with Enhanced Isolation for Millimeter-Wave 5G and IoT Applications
authors: Fereshteh Fattahi, Changiz Ghobadi, Javad Nourinia, Majid Shokri
abstract: This paper focuses on the design and fabrication of a compact four-element multiple-input and multiple-output MIMO array antenna for the millimeter-wave frequency band (30–50 GHz), with a particular emphasis on enhanced isolation and reduction of mutual interference. The proposed antenna is designed on a Rogers RT/duroid 5880 substrate with overall dimensions of 23×23×0.5 mm3. This research employs advanced techniques, including Defective Ground Structures (DGS) and decoupling elements, to enhance isolation. The proposed design was analyzed using HFSS software and then confirmed through a measurement process that included its evaluation. According to the measured results, the results were well within the required frequency range. Specifically, the obtained average isolation was -34.43 dB, the return loss was below -10 dB, and the average radiation gain was 6.5 dBi at the target frequency. Additionally, the antenna demonstrated favorable performance in multipath environments, where the Envelope Correlation Coefficient (ECC) was consistently below 0.001. This result indicates excellent spatial diversity and minimal signal loss. The new features of the antenna that contribute to its performance, such as its small size and the use of parasitic elements and coupling reduction lines, make this antenna suitable for high-frequency density conditions. Additionally, the proposed antenna is well-suited for advanced applications, including high-speed, high-bandwidth, short-range Internet of Things (IoT) systems in the 24–39 GHz band, satellite communications, and 5G millimeter-wave networks (e.g., n260 band, 37–40 GHz), as well as other high-bandwidth telecommunication systems.

title: Effect of Phase Shift Errors on the Security of UAV-assisted STAR-RIS IoT Networks
authors: Mustafa Gusaibat, Mohammed Hnaish, Abdelhamid Salem, Khaled M. Rabie, Zubair Md Fadlullah, Wali Ullah Khan, Mohamad A. Alawad, Yazeed Alkhrijah
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV)-mounted simultaneous transmitting and reflecting reconfigurable intelligent surface (STAR-RIS) systems can provide full-dimensional coverage and flexible deployment opportunities in future 6G-enabled IoT networks. However, practical imperfections such as jittering and airflow of UAV could affect the phase shift of STAR-RIS, and consequently degrade network security. In this respect, this paper investigates the impact of phase shift errors on the secrecy performance of UAV-mounted STAR-RIS-assisted IoT systems. More specifically, we consider a UAV-mounted STAR-RIS-assisted non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) system where IoT devices are grouped into two groups: one group on each side of the STAR-RIS. The nodes in each group are considered as potential Malicious nodes for the ones on the other side. By modeling phase estimation errors using a von Mises distribution, an analytical closed-form expressions for the ergodic secrecy rates under imperfect phase adjustment are derived. An optimization problem to maximize the weighted sum secrecy rate (WSSR) by optimizing the UAV placement is formulated and is then solved using a linear grid-based algorithm. Monte Carlo simulations are provided to validate the analytical derivations. The impact of phase estimation errors on system’s secrecy performance is analyzed, providing critical insights for the practical realisation of STAR-RIS deployments for secure UAV-enabled IoT networks.

title: A Phase Control Method with RIM Suppression for PM Fiber-optic Time Transfer System
authors: Zhenyu Chen, Jiameng Dong, Zhaohui Wang, Qingwei Liu, Rui Zhang, Song Yu, Bin Luo
abstract: Fiber-optic interferometers are widely used in phase modulation (PM) time transfer systems. To achieve stable phase demodulation, resisting the phase drift within the interferometer is essential. Moreover, using lithium niobate phase modulator in the interferometer inevitably introduces residual intensity modulation (RIM) due to its inherent imperfections. A stable phase control method based on optical power detection is proposed to resist phase drift and concomitantly suppress RIM. Furthermore, the characteristics of phase control at the extremum point (EP) and near-extremum point (NEP) of the interferometric response curve are analyzed and compared. Analysis shows that EP control offers lower demodulation stability but higher sensitivity to intensity fluctuations than NEP control. A fiber-optic time transfer experiment validates the applicability and effectiveness of the proposed method and confirms the analysis. The proposed method enhances the interferometer’s demodulation stability and shows good application prospects in phase signal detection.

title: A Dynamic Redeployment System for Critical Care Paramedic Units in Qatar Utilizing Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Reem Tluli, Ahmed Badawy, Saeed Salem, Muhammad Hardan, Sailesh Chauhan, Guillaume Alinier
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Intelligent Transportation Systems
abstract: Timely ambulance allocation is essential for Emergency Medical Services (EMS) to deliver life-saving care effectively. Conventional methods often struggle to adapt to the unpredictable nature and locations of emergencies. Within EMS, efficient resource management is crucial for ensuring rapid and effective responses. While much emphasis has been placed on optimizing the deployment of ambulances from fixed stations, managing specialized critical care response units-known as Charlie vehicles in Qatar EMS-presents a distinct challenge. These rapid response cars are vital for providing advanced care in challenging situations, and their dynamic deployment requires a more flexible management strategy. Effectively relocating Charlie vehicles to areas with high anticipated demand after they have responded to an emergency introduces unique challenges that differ from traditional ambulance redeployment approaches. This paper proposes a novel dynamic redeployment system specifically for optimizing the allocation of critical care response vehicles, including those involved in patient transfers. Utilizing a Deep Reinforcement Learning (DRL) framework, we create a deep scoring network that prioritizes and navigates various dynamic factors at each station. Experiments using real-world data from Qatar EMS demonstrate that our system significantly outperforms existing methods. For instance, our approach achieves faster average response times and improved critical response rates compared to the leading baseline method. Notably, we observe a substantial 21.55% reduction in average response time (AveRT) and an 18.34% increase in relative response time (RelaRT) in comparison to actual operational metrics. Our approach effectively shortens the time needed to reach patients, thereby increasing the likelihood of timely treatment and improving overall patient care outcomes.

title: An Ergodic Approach to Robotic Surface Finishing With Learned Motion Preferences
authors: Stefan Schneyer, Korbinian Nottensteiner, Alin Albu-Schäffer, Freek Stulp, João Silvério
abstract: Surface finishing is a time-consuming, dangerous task, difficult to automate despite its necessity in many manufacturing processes. Its automation, particularly through robotics, increases productivity and relieves workers from health-critical tasks. However, challenges remain, as automated offline planning tools can result in certain areas being either neglected or overly processed. Ergodic control offers the possibility to cover target probability distributions in an online manner, by taking into account the observed coverage history. However, existing ergodic control approaches provide little flexibility in designing and adapting coverage strategies. Moreover, they come with simplifying assumptions, such as point-based dynamics, which are no longer valid for tasks where the robot is in contact with strongly varying curvatures on non-trivial surface geometries. In this work, we introduce a closed-form ergodic control framework that includes the tool imprint in the system modeling while simultaneously permitting the intuitive transfer of finish strategies, namely preferred motion directions. We build on the Spectral Multiscale Coverage (SMC) approach, augmenting it with a tool imprint model, as well as both target distributions and state-dependent movement directions extracted from human demonstrations. Through evaluations in a surface finishing task using a torque-controlled, 7-DoF, robot arm we show that our approach optimally covers surfaces according to the tool contact area, with robust error convergence.

title: Improving Light Shelf Performance by the Optimization of Tilt Angle
authors: Beatriz Miranda Viana, Daniela Pawelski Amaro Martins, Maria Jose Pontes, José Leandro Félix Salles, Jussara Farias Fardin, Marcelo Eduardo Vieira Segatto, Helder Roberto de Oliveira Rocha
publish: 2025 SBFoton International Optics and Photonics Conference (SBFoton IOPC)
abstract: This paper models the performance of light shelves in classrooms, to maximize average illuminance. System identification methodology is implemented using multivariate polynomial regression and the least squares method to find the best solutions. The simulation considered a classroom at the Federal University of Espírito Santo. Analysis SOL-AR, Relux and MatLab were used to collect illuminance data of the inclination angles to validate the model. Results indicate that the third-degree static model provided 655 lux at −40° (inner shelf) and 40° (outer shelf). This approach effectively optimizes natural lighting in urban environments, reducing reliance on artificial lighting and enhancing energy efficiency.
