title: Modeling Accurate Prediction of Junctionless Infrared Phototransistor Performance Using Explainable DL Regression Models
authors: R. Ouchen, F. Djeffal, T. Berghout
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: In this study, a deep learning (DL)-guided optimization strategy is developed to improve the optoelectronic performance of planar junctionless phototransistors. For this purpose, we have opted to combine accurate two-dimensional (2D) analytical and numerical simulations with advanced DL approaches to investigate key design parameters impact on device performance. So, we have simulated the current-voltage (I-V) characteristics of JLP devices under infrared illumination conditions and thoroughly analyze the influences of material property variations, channel doping levels, and device geometry on the phototransistor key performance metrics. And, diverse DL algorithms, including deep learning classification models, are used to evaluate and parameters significance. As well, feature importance analysis is performed to identify the key factors influencing the overall device responsivity (R). The results show that optimized doping and bias conditions yield a high responsivity with a reduced dark current. They reveal key design parameters that significantly impact phototransistor efficiency and provide valuable insights for optimizing device design. Furthermore, these findings highlight that the synergy between device physics and DL-based modeling provides a powerful methodology for the design of next-generation low-power, low-cost, and high-performance junctionless phototransistors (JLPs) for inter-chip data communication applications.

title: Unbalancing Executive Power and Unwinding Climate Laws
authors: Brian Farnen, Sara Cody
abstract: On January 20, 2025, the second Trump Administration froze $20 billion in Inflation Reduction Act funding for climate adaptation and mitigation measures and for key clean energy infrastructure measures through Executive Order 14154, "Unleashing American Energy." While the executive enjoys powers of discretion in how to enact Congress’s directives, unilaterally unwinding laws that have been passed through legislative and regulatory processes on policy bases is not one of them. Legislation endures precisely because it is enacted through statute. Executive orders and agency actions that unduly step outside of the authority designated to the executive branch and step into authority designated to the legislative branch puts any major legislation at risk of being effectively overturned by changing presidential administrations as their policy portfolios vary. At the same time that the Executive branch is overstepping into congressional authorities, the Supreme Court is expanding executive authority further by limiting the power of judicial review of Executive Orders – one of the few immediate checks available on executive action – in Trump v. Casa, Inc. This decision differs in effect from the Supreme Court’s decision in Loper Bright v. Raimondo, which narrowed executive administrative power by overturning Chevron Deference. This article will examine the bounds of the executive branch’s abilities to administer federal laws by executive order and by administrative rulemaking. It will explore, specifically, how the Appropriations Clause limits these powers and will dive deeper into constitutional arguments made in Climate United Fund v. Citibank, N.A., the court case brought by the Greenhouse Gas Reduction Fund recipients whose funds were frozen by Executive Order 14154. Then, this article will examine the stakes and likely consequences associated with the Supreme Court’s ruling in Trump v. Casa, Inc. as well as expanding the scope of this ruling by considering its ramifications in the context of Loper Bright v. Raimondo. Ultimately, this article will conclude that if the United States is to have lasting and effective energy legislation, it must be immune to the changing views of the executive branch by being principally made through marquee legislation – not easily reversible executive orders and agency regulation – that is designed to withstand the changing policy priorities and goals of the presidency. More broadly, this article will advocate for a refocusing of the executive overreach issue as one that cuts across party lines, threatening the essential checks and balances of a functioning democracy. To have laws that last, we not only need stronger laws but stronger institutions, shored up by the separation of powers.

title: Strengths and Trade-Offs of Deep Learning-Based Crack Detection in Smart Mechanical Inspection
authors: Walter Xylander, Sonnhild Camilla Fiedler, Eckart Gebhard Raskop, Zeynep Sahutoglu
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Crack detection in mechanical components is vital for maintaining structural integrity and ensuring operational safety. This study employs Faster R-CNN as the primary object detection algorithm and evaluates its performance against SSD and YOLOv5 under conditions representative of industrial inspection environments. Experimental results show that Faster R-CNN delivers the highest precision, recall, and mAP, confirming its superior detection accuracy. However, its slower inference speed limits its suitability for real-time applications. In contrast, YOLOv5 achieves the fastest processing time while maintaining competitive accuracy, making it well-suited for realtime monitoring tasks. SSD, while faster than Faster R-CNN, lags behind in detection performance, highlighting its limitations in high-precision use cases. The study also reveals that detection accuracy across all models is significantly affected by variations in lighting, underscoring the importance of robustness to environmental conditions. These findings offer practical guidance for selecting detection frameworks and inform future research on hybrid or adaptive approaches for reliable and efficient crack detection in dynamic industrial settings.

title: A Bias-Control Technique for Efficiency Improvement in CMOS Class-E Power Amplifiers
authors: Roberto Cancelli, Gianfranco Avitabile, Antonello Florio
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: The cascode topology in Class-E Power Amplifiers (PAs) is effective in reducing voltage stress on transistors, but introduces additional losses that degrade overall efficiency. This paper presents a Bias-Control technique that enables faster turn-off of the Common-Gate transistor, significantly reducing power dissipation. Simulation results demonstrate a Power Added Efficiency (PAE) of 61.78% and an output power of 24.36 dBm. The proposed approach shows a notable efficiency improvement over conventional Class-E operation, confirming its potential for high-performance RF power amplifier design.

title: Forecasting Data Server Energy Consumption Using LSTM Deep Learning Models
authors: Assia Taifi, El Mehdi Kandoussi, Mostafa Bellafkih
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: The rapid development of information technologies has moved the digital world from traditional local servers to cloud computing, offering scalable access to computational resources via the internet. This transformation has caused significant growth in cloud data centers, which serve as the key infrastructure for cloud services, resulting in a substantial rise in energy consumption. Recent estimates indicate that global data center electricity usage could more than double between 2022 and 2026. This trend poses critical economic and environmental challenges, highlighting the urgent need for effective energy management strategies. This study proposes a deep learning model based on Long ShortTerm Memory (LSTM) networks to forecast the energy consumption of a data server. The model is developed using a dataset collected from a data server running on an HP Z440 workstation. Experimental results demonstrate that our model excels in performance, surpassing classical regression methods in terms of prediction accuracy and significantly improving energy forecasting in cloud environments. Our approach provides accurate energy consumption forecasts to support optimization efforts, reduce operational costs, and promote sustainability in cloud computing environments.

title: Fusion of Head Pose and Facial Action Units for Automated Student Engagement Estimation: A Study on DAD-3DHeads
authors: Fatima Zahra Jobbid, Aissam Berrahou, Hassan Berbia
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: We present a reproducible pipeline for automated student engagement estimation using a multimodal fusion of head pose angles and facial action units (AUs) extracted from 3D facial images. Leveraging the DAD-3DHeads dataset, which captures rich variations in pose, expression, occlusion, and lighting, our method involves systematic preprocessing, robust feature extraction, and explainable decision-making. A proxy engagement score is computed for each sample based on neutral facial expression, frontal head orientation, and absence of occlusion—serving as an interpretable surrogate ground truth. After normalization, multiple supervised classifiers are evaluated, including Random Forest, Support Vector Machine, XGBoost, and Multi-Layer Perceptron. The best-performing model, XGBoost, achieves 77 % accuracy and an F1-score of 0.82 on the test set. Feature importance analysis confirms the complementary roles of pose and AUs in engagement prediction. This interpretable and fully reproducible framework offers a practical alternative to black-box deep learning and may be extended to broader contexts requiring non-intrusive behavioral assessment.

title: Health Monitoring of Photovoltaics System Using Type-Aware kNN with Confidence Score
authors: Md Moshfiqure Rahman, Anurag K. Srivastava
abstract: This work presents a health monitoring approach for photovoltaic (PV) systems using a modified k-Nearest Neighbors (kNN) algorithm, named as Type-Aware kNN (TA-kNN). Since PV systems operate under varying environmental and operational conditions, health monitoring must remain effective across all scenarios. TA-kNN improves robustness by comparing each data point only with data from similar conditions, referred to as the same "type," thus avoiding misleading comparisons across dissimilar operating states. The proposed model can operates on standard voltage and current measurements, requiring no additional sensors. A confidence score, derived using a sigmoid-based function, is introduced to quantify the certainty of anomaly detection. The effectiveness of the TA-kNN model is validated using a 1 MW PV plant modeled in a Real-Time Digital Simulator (RTDS) and further evaluated on SCADA data from an operational solar facility. Results demonstrate high accuracy in detecting abnormal behavior, making the approach suitable for deployment in both small rooftop systems and large-scale PV installations.

title: Magnetized Cellular Robots for Precision Cytokine Delivery: A Novel Approach to Tumor-Targeted Therapy
authors: Hongyan Sun, Chan Li, Zijin Zeng, Shengyuan Wang, Yuguo Dai, Chutian Wang, Jiaying Zhang, Shunxiao Huang, Jingwen Ye, Yingjian Guo, Wenyan Niu, Zaiyang Chen, Yunhan Hu, Bo Chen, Lin Feng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Cancer has become the second major health threat endangering human survival and represents a core challenge requiring urgent resolution in global public health. Immunotherapy is a novel therapeutic strategy that combats cancer by modulating the immune system. Although several immunotherapeutic agents have been clinically applied for cancer treatment, the presence of “cold” tumors in some patients leads to low response rates to immunotherapy. Potential off-target effects and other adverse events remain significant challenges in tumor immunotherapy. In this study, to address the limitations of immunotherapy for lymphoma, a highly heterogeneous and aggressive cold tumor, we designed chemokine (C-C motif) ligand 5 (CCL5)-loaded macrophagebased microrobots to remodel the tumor microenvironment. This strategy synergistically integrates the inherent phagocytic functionality and tumor-tropic properties of macrophages with the biosafety advantages, tetherless operational capacity, and spatiotemporal precision of magnetically navigated platforms. CCL5 mediates immune cell chemotaxis and enhances tumor cell infiltration and metastatic potential. We conjugated cytokines to the surface of magnetic nanoparticles using the carbodiimide method, achieving excellent biocompatibility and magnetic responsiveness. The transwell assay confirmed the engineered macrophages' innate tumor tropism and magnetic field-guided targeting capability toward EL-4 cells. These magnetically responsive macrophages demonstrate potential for advancing safer and more effective clinical translation of immunotherapies. Our strategy facilitates immune cell reprogramming and recruitment, establishing a novel platform for tumor immunotherapy.

title: Construction and Characterization of a Tendon-Sensor Driven Continuum Robot
authors: A.C. Coronado-Andrade, H.A. Moreno-Jiménez, J.E. Velázquez-Velázquez, L.M. Valentín-Coronado, N.G. Aldana-Murillo, G.R. Flores-Colunga
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Continuum robots have attracted significant interest due to their inherent flexibility, adaptability, and capability to operate in unstructured environments. In this context, the present work introduces the design, fabrication, and characterization of a novel tendon-driven continuum robot that enables continuous and flexible motion. The proposed robot consists of two serially connected sections, with each section actuated by three tendons arranged in a circular configuration and powered by motors positioned at the base. A key innovation of the proposed robot is the implementation of an intrinsic sensing system utilizing active materials, specifically leveraging intertwined nylon and “nichrome” (a nickel-chromium alloy) tendons. This approach eliminates the need for conventional external sensors and allows for local measurement of the length of each tendon. Additionally, the proposed architecture enables the independent contraction and movement of each segment, significantly enhancing the overall movement and versatility of the system. Experimental tests indicate that the system has an absolute error of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 3 ~\text{mm}$</tex> with respect to the target, demonstrating high precision in positioning tasks in three-dimensional environments.

title: Affected-Side Torque Prediction for Stroke Patients Based on GRU-TSSA-iTransformer Deep Learning Model
authors: Xinyu Zhang, Pu Zhang, Pei Shi, Jie Zuo, Wei Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: During the initial phase of stroke recovery, rehabilitative training can effectively boost the restoration of patients' lower limb function. To achieve bilateral coordinated assistance for the lower limbs, we designed a novel deep learning model to perform end-to-end prediction of the affected-side knee joint torque using bilateral joint angles and unaffectedside EMG signals. This model integrates Gated Recurrent Units (GRU), Token Statistics Self-Attention (TSSA), and an iTransformer encoder architecture. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed fusion model achieved the best predictive performance among the six subjects, with average Mean Squared Error (MSE), Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE), and Mean Absolute Error (MAE) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 5 1 8 ~ N} \cdot \mathrm{m}, \mathbf{0. 9 1 8 3 ~ N} \cdot \mathrm{m}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{0. 8 2 4 8} \mathrm{N} \cdot \mathrm{m}$</tex>, respectively. Compared with other mainstream models, it exhibits superior prediction accuracy and generalization capability.

title: LO Leakage Cancellation Using Upconverter Mixer Transistors Back-Gate Bias Control in a 22 nm FDSOI 39 GHz Transceiver
authors: Jerome Prouvee, Olivier Guille, Baudouin Martineau, Cedric Dehos, Abdelaziz Hamani, Dominique Morche
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Gilbert (or g<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m</inf>) cell mixers are widely used in millimetre-Wave (mmW) transmitters due to their versatility and performance. However, a persistent challenge in these circuits is Local Oscillator (LO) leakage, which can significantly degrade system performance, particularly by deteriorating the Error Vector Magnitude (EVM). This paper analyses the mechanisms behind LO leakage in g<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">m</inf> cell mixers and reviews mitigation techniques. A non-conventional approach based on back-gate polarization of transistors is used with 6 bits DAC only. The technique is demonstrated on a 22.4 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> 22 nm FDSOI 37-40 GHz quad front-end beamforming RFIC. measurements show a LO cancellation figure of -31.2 dB. 64QAM constellation results at 225Mbps validate a substantial improvement of EVM, dropping from -15,9dB to -29,4dB (rms).

title: Robustness of Memristor Neural Networks to Stuck-at Faults: A Two-Layer MNIST Case Study
authors: H. Aziza, K. Coulié, W. Rahajandraibe
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Memristor-based neuromorphic hardware is emerging as a promising solution for energy-efficient edge AI, offering high-density integration and parallel analog computing capabilities. However, its practical deployment is challenged by device-level non-idealities, particularly stuck-at faults (SAFs), which can significantly degrade inference accuracy. In this study, we investigate the impact of SAFs on a two-layer neural network trained on the MNIST image classification dataset and mapped onto a memristor crossbar array. We consider three fault types: hard stuck-at-0 (due to failed electroforming), stuckat-0 (due to a failed SET operation) and stuck-at-1 (due to a failed RESET operation). These faults are injected into the posttraining weight matrices mapped onto the crossbar arrays to simulate hardware-level defects more realistically. Experimental results show that inference accuracy drops below 50% at a 10% fault injection rate for stuck-at-0 faults, 9% for hard stuck-at-0 faults, and 5% for stuck-at-1 faults.

title: Designing Sparse AC False Data Injection Attack
authors: Mohammadreza Iranpour, Mohammad Rasoul Narimani
abstract: False Data Injection (FDI) attacks pose significant threats by manipulating measurement data, leading to incorrect state estimation. Although numerous studies have focused on designing DC FDI attacks, few have addressed AC FDI attacks due to the complexity of incorporating non-linear AC power flows in the design process. Additionally, designing a sparse AC FDI attack presents another challenge because it involves solving a mixed-integer nonlinear programming problem with nonconvex constraints, which is inherently difficult. This paper explores the design and implementation of a sparse AC FDI attack, where the attacker strategically selects a minimal set of measurements to manipulate while maintaining the nonlinearity and interdependence of AC power flow equations. The objective is to minimize the number of altered measurements, thereby reducing the attack’s detectability while achieving the desired state estimation error. The problem is formulated as a Mixed Integer Nonlinear Programming (MINLP) problem. Binary variables indicate the selection of measurements to be manipulated, and continuous variables represent the measurement values. An optimization problem is designed to minimize the number of binary variables, translating into a sparse attack, while ensuring the attack remains efficient and hard to detect. The big-M method and conditional constraints are utilized to handle the fixed and variable measurement parameters effectively. Simulation results on the standard IEEE 57-bus test system demonstrate the efficacy of the sparse AC FDI attack in terms of its impact on state estimation and the minimal number of measurements required for successful implementation.

title: An Adaptive Dynamic Routing Decision-making Method based on Communication-sensing-computing
authors: Xinhong Hei, Jing An, Yichuan Wang, Xiaoxue Liu, Yeqiu Xiao
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: Traditional static routing decision models struggle to adapt to dynamic network environments. This often leads to cascading issues such as information redundancy accumulation, critical services disruption, and so on. Moreover, they exhibit delayed responses and limited optimization effectiveness when coping with sudden traffic surges and changing network conditions, ultimately resulting in a systemic imbalance between resource utilization and quality of service (QoS) demands. To address these challenges, this paper proposes an adaptive path selection system based on deep reinforcement learning. Specifically, it integrates Deep Q-Networks (DQN) with the Actor-Critic algorithm to jointly optimize multiple network performance metrics, including link bandwidth, latency, and congestion. Furthermore, the system incorporates conditional mutual information as a dynamic weight adjustment mechanism, along with a partial-block attention mechanism and an experience replay buffer design, thereby enhancing the model’s capability in network state representation and training efficiency. Experiments are conducted in a simulation environment based on Mininet and the RYU controller. The proposed method demonstrates superiority in path selection and congestion control through comparative evaluations against ECMP, SPF, and baseline DQN algorithms. The results confirm that the proposed joint training architecture exhibits enhanced adaptability and robustness in dynamic network scenarios, offering an effective intelligent solution for traffic scheduling in 6 G networks.

title: Value-Based Grid Modernization: Project Evaluation by Social Benefits
authors: Khaled Bin Walid, Qingran Li, Yazhou Leo Jiang
abstract: Electric utilities face the challenge of modernizing aging distribution grids with limited annual budgets, necessitating strategic investment in upgrades that maximize societal benefits. While utilities traditionally prioritize reliability improvements (e.g., deploying SCADA-operated devices like automatic reclosers) considering cost effectiveness, a systematic framework is needed to evaluate these projects based on their social values not just costs. To meet this need, this paper developed a data-driven decision-support tool that ranks projects based on their social benefits. The tool calculates economic cost savings from avoided power interruptions, synergistically combining the value of lost load (VOLL) and avoided unserved energy. This enables utilities to justify investments based on transparent benefit-cost metrics. We validate this framework with data from two feeder circuits in upstate New York, demonstrating its practicality for utility planners.

title: Proposed a Ternary Multiplexer using CNTFET
authors: Ramzi A. Jaber, El Moucary Chady, Abdallah Kassem, Ali M. Haidar
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: The Multiple-Value Logic (MVL) circuit significantly enhances propagation delay and minimizes energy consumption relative to binary circuits. Furthermore, the Carbon Nanotube Field-Effect Transistor (CNTFET) shows improvements in energy efficiency and circuit speed in comparison to other transistor technologies. Consequently, this research presents a Ternary Multiplexer (TMUX) that employs CNTFET technology, which holds promise for the development of additional ternary circuits, such as ternary adders and multipliers. The proposed circuit and its investigation were simulated and evaluated using the HSpice simulator. The simulation findings highlight the advantages of this approach, achieving a reduction in power usage by more than 55% compared to the optimal design.

title:
Architectural Control of TiO
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    -GO Hybrids via Graphene Oxide Concentration: Balancing Adsorption and Photocatalysis
authors: Francisco J. Cano, A. Kassiba, S. Velumani, Enrique Lima, Odín Reyes-Vallejo, A. Ashok, Guillermo Aguilar
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Efficient water remediation by titanium dioxidegraphene oxide <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{TiO}_{2}-\text{GO})$</tex> nanohybrids is governed by their nanoscale architecture, which controls both adsorption and photocatalytic behaviors. In this study, the influence of GO concentration on the structural and functional properties of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{TiO}_{2}$</tex>-GO hybrids was systematically examined. Hybrids containing 2, 5, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \text{wt}. \%$</tex> GO were synthesized through a sonicationassisted assembly method. A progressive morphological transition was revealed by high-resolution transmission electron microscopy: partial core-shell structures at 2 wt.%, uniform encapsulation at 5 wt. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\%$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{TiO}_{2}$</tex> particles entrapped within extensive GO agglomerates at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \text{wt}. \%$</tex>. As a result of these transitions, a clear trade-off between adsorption and photocatalysis was observed. Methylene blue adsorption was enhanced monotonically with increasing GO content, whereas photocatalytic activity was maximized at 2 wt.% GO and subsequently diminished at higher loadings. This contrasting behavior was attributed to competing mechanisms, in which increased surface area promoted adsorption while excessive GO induced light shielding, diffusion barriers, and accelerated charge recombination. It is therefore demonstrated that optimal performance of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{TiO}_{2}-\text{GO}$</tex> nanohybrids is achieved not by maximizing GO content, but by engineering a finely tuned architecture that enables a synergistic balance between adsorption and photocatalytic efficiency.

title: Self-Tuning Optimal Control of Time-Varying Buck Converters Using the Extremum-Seeking Algorithm
authors: Santos Miguel Orozco Soto, Jose Ricardo Rojas Suastes
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: This paper presents a self-tuning optimal control technique, for voltage regulation of a Buck converter, based on the Extremum-Seeking algorithm. The proposed method employs this model-free optimizer to compute the optimal gains regardless time-varying parameters and uncertainty, which is a common operation scenario for step-down power converters. The proposed control approach was validated both mathematically and through simulations, and also contrasted to other state-of-the-art techniques, showing accurate reference voltage tracking. The successful assessment of the proposed technique is a step towards its implementation in actual hardware.

title: A Review on Smart Supply Chains: State of the Art and Opportunities
authors: Khalid Aouad, Fatima Ouzayd
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Water is a vital resource for human life and ecosystems, making the efficient management of water supply chains a critical priority for both water utilities and countries. The need for advanced supply chain management strategies is further emphasized by global challenges such as climate change, water scarcity, population growth, increasing water demand, and the expansion of industrial activities. In response, the development and implementation of smart systems, leveraging recent advancements in decision-making, the Internet of Things (IoT), and artificial intelligence, are transforming the water industry. This review aims to provide a comprehensive overview of the state-of-the-art and emerging opportunities in smart supply chain management techniques applied to the water industry. Through a systematic literature review, this work identifies key findings, persisting research gaps, and the main opportunities offered by this dynamic field of study. The results of this research will serve as a valuable reference for both researchers and practitioners, facilitating the selection of alternative methods to enhance water operations, improve supply chain management systems, and increase the overall efficiency of water utilities.

title: Accelerated Radiation Testing Method for Processor-based Computing Systems
authors: L. H. Laurini, L. Ost, S. Cuenca-Asensi, B. Cheymol, E. Atukpor, R. Possamai Bastos
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: The use of accelerated radiation testing is an invaluable tool for studying the behavior of computing systems under radiation effects. Despite the existence of relevant testing guidelines and standards, there are currently few published works dedicated to detailing methods for performing accelerated radiation tests on processor-based computing systems. This paper delineates the current form of the MultiRad project’s testing method, as well as the rationale behind its design. After continuous improvements and modifications since its inception in 2020, it has been used to test various computing systems – from resource-constrained 8-bit microcontrollers to highly capable 64-bit computers – under 14-MeV and thermal neutrons and can be quickly implemented for other computing system platforms. Notably, variations of the presented method have supported and enabled the publishing of 17 journal articles and 25 presentations in international conferences.

title: Target-Aware Automated RTL Generation for RISC-V SoC Designs: A Model-Driven Approach
authors: Mohamed Badawy, Jiulong Wang, Paritosh Kumar Sinha, Wolfgang Ecker
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Register-Transfer Level (RTL) generators streamline hardware design but often produce generic designs that fail to leverage platform-specific resources, resulting in suboptimal performance or non-deployable implementations. This paper introduces a novel model-driven methodology that enhances RTL generation by seamlessly adapting to the target platform’s unique capabilities. By incorporating platform-specific constraints, our approach automates the mapping of RTL constructs to optimized resources, overcoming the limitations of platform-agnostic designs. We validate the methodology through the implementation of a RISC-V-based System-on-Chip (SoC) on an AMD Zynq UltraScale+ MPSoC board. Experimental results demonstrate remarkable improvements, reducing lookup table (LUT) usage by up to 97%, flip-flop (FF) usage by up to 99%, achieving over 3× higher maximum frequency, lowering power consumption by approximately 10%, and reducing design implementation run time by up to 94% compared to platform-agnostic designs.

title: The Evolution of Ontology Merging: Historical Perspectives and Modern Approaches
authors: Naoual Smaili, Adil Kabbaj
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Ontology integration is a cornerstone for enabling semantic interoperability across heterogeneous systems in the context of the Semantic Web and Web 2.0 ecosystems. This paper traces the evolution of ontology integration techniques, from early rule-based approaches to contemporary methods leveraging machine learning and large language models (LLMs). We critically examine key methodologies, assessing their scalability, adaptability, and the challenges they face in decentralized Web 2.0 environments. By synthesizing state-of-the-art techniques and identifying open research gaps, this work provides a foundation to inform and guide future advancements in ontology integration for semantically-aware applications.

title: Application of Multi-Modal AI for Personal Outfit Analysis and Travel Recommendations
authors: Supametha Ngopratheep, Poohridate Arpasat, Wichian Premchaiswadi
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: This research presents the application of Multi-Modal AI to address the challenges in travel outfit planning. It integrates AI's capabilities in Image Analysis and Natural Language Processing (NLP) to provide suitable and personalized recommendations to users. The system was developed using Python and leverages the OpenAI library to interface with Generative AI models, such as GPT-4o and DALL-E 3 [1]. The automated workflow comprises the following steps: Data Collection, Multi-Modal Analysis, Recommendation Generation, and Visual Display and Shopping Sourcing. In the data collection phase, the system receives user travel information, including country, city, dates, and planned activities. Furthermore, users can upload photographs of their own clothing for AI analysis. During the multi-modal analysis, the system processes weather data from the OpenWeatherMap API and analyzes the uploaded clothing images to identify type, style, and color palette. Subsequently, in the recommendation generation phase, the AI creates outfit suggestions appropriate for both the weather and activities. It also assesses the suitability of the uploaded clothing and recommends necessary adjustments. Finally, the system can generate a 3D avatar image wearing the recommended outfit to help users visualize the look clearly [2], and it extracts keywords from the recommendations to generate shopping links for purchasing additional apparel [3]. The study's results, which were rigorously validated through statistical analysis, demonstrate that Generative AI holds significant potential to act as a personal assistant in travel planning, particularly in reducing the complexity of clothing preparation [4]. This enables users to make effective decisions and prepare for their journeys with confidence.

title: Learning-Based Predictive Virtual Inertia Control for Frequency Regulation in Low Inertia Power Grids
authors: Osarodion Emmanuel Egbomwan, Shichao Liu, Hicham Chaoui, Xiaozhe Wang
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Circuits and Systems
abstract: The increasing integration of renewable energy generators into the conventional power grid has lowered the overall power system inertia. Low inertia may adversely impact the grid’s stability and resilience, leading to unintended grid failure and total system collapse upon severe contingencies. Current methods of emulating power grid inertia to enhance stability under low inertia conditions have some drawbacks. For example, the proportional-integral (PI) control method suffers from high overshoot and settling time, while the performance of the conventional model predictive controller (MPC) is highly dependent on the accuracy of the system model. Consequently, a new learning-based predictive virtual inertia control (VIC) is proposed. This strategy incorporates a physics-informed neural network (PINN) predictive model with an optimization-based safety filter to mitigate the impact of increasing integration of renewable energy generators through a virtual inertia emulation strategy. Our proposed strategy leverages advances in deep learning by implementing a PINN-based model to predict the system’s future behavior. The proposed method is compared to the MPC and PI controller. The results demonstrate the superior dynamic performance of the proposed method. Our implemented technique achieved the least frequency deviations upon contingencies in the IEEE 34 bus and the IEEE 39 bus studied systems with integrated inverter-based generators.

title: Operational Resource Adequacy in Reliable Grid Operation with High Renewable Resources
authors: Logan Hobbs, Khaled Bin Walid, Yazhou Leo Jiang, Sushant Varghese, Matt Musto, John Meyer, Pradip G. Kumar
abstract: Fast incorporation of variable renewables introduces unprecedented uncertainties into power grids. Grid operators lack tools for situational awareness of loss-of-load risks in grid operation. To bridge this gap, an operational resource adequacy (OpRA) technology is proposed for control room applications. OpRA quantifies forecast uncertainties from load, land-based wind, and offshore wind. Markov Chain Monte Carlo is used to generate operational scenarios based on these uncertainties and the availability of committed generation. A DC-OPF assesses the loss-of-load by minimizing the unserved load subjected to grid conditions. To manage computational complexity, OpRA is structured to support parallel computing, enabling scalable execution of bulk DC-OPF simulations. Reliability metrics, i.e., loss of load probability (LOLP), loss of load hours (LOLH), and expected unserved energy (EUE) are calculated to evaluate resource adequacy. The technology is validated on the New York Power Grid and evaluates how uncertainty reserve quantile selection affects grid reliability and efficiency.

title: Energizing an Onshore Modular Multilevel Converter for DC Power Delivery in a Laboratory-Scale Environment
authors: Huazhao Ding, Rabi Kar, Zhixin Miao, Lingling Fan
abstract: Modular multilevel converter (MMC) is the state-of-the-art converter technology used in offshore wind HVDC delivery systems. It is essential to thoroughly understand operations and challenges of energizing onshore MMCs and connecting them to DC grids. In this research, we demonstrate the procedure of energizing an onshore MMC, establishing the DC-link voltage, and connecting to a DC source in a hardware testbed. Open-loop and closed-loop tests have been carried out to demonstrate the energizing and operation of the MMC. This paper presents the testbed setup and experiment results, as well as challenges faced during energizing, e.g., control parameter tuning, filter implementation, and control hardware prototyping.

title: A 4096-Channel, 1.13mW/Ch Pixel-Level Driver Circuits for Optical Phased Arrays with 12-Bit R-2R DAC and Cross-Coupled Push-Pull 15Vpp Voltage Output Amplifier
authors: Junfeng Wang, Kejun Wu, Qilin Liang, Qianfeng Zhang, Zhen Yu, Yihu Yu, Ning Ning, Jing Li, Zhong Zhang, Qi Yu
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper presents a 4096-channel, 1.13mW/ch pixel-level driver circuits for optical phased arrays. A 12-bit R-2R DAC is employed to provide high-precision digital voltage control. The cross-coupled push-pull amplifier and adjustable reference circuit are proposed to trade-off the limitations among the area, power consumption and accuracy. To verify the proposed technique, our work was fabricated using a 180nm BCD Process. The measurement results show that the power consumption is 4.48 W for 4096 channels. The chip area is 20mm*17mm. The DNL and INL are 0.56 LSB and 0.89 LSB, respectively. The maximum deviation between channels is 30mV under the 15Vpp output voltage.

title: Role of Dynamic Line Ratings in Enhancing Reserve Deliverability and Mitigating Congestion Rent
authors: Hamid Davoudi, Fengyu Wang
abstract: Static line ratings (SLR), which use conservative assumptions for line capacities, can underestimate actual transfer capability, leading to undeliverable reserves and increased congestion costs. Dynamic line ratings (DLR), by adjusting line capacities based on ambient conditions, have been shown to improve operational flexibility. This study evaluates the role of DLR in enhancing reserve deliverability and mitigating congestion rent. The cleared reserves from a day-ahead unit commitment (DAUC) are deployed in an optimal reserve deployment (ORD) model for each credible generator outage to assess deliverability. The procedure is applied to a subsection of the IEEE RTS 24-bus system, and results show that: a) DLR improves reserve deliverability by 10% to 55% by providing higher transmission capacity; b) DLR reduces congestion rent by 33% to 48% by decreasing the number of binding constraints and lowering the shadow prices of transmission constraints.

title: Dynamic Log-APF with Adaptive Virtual Guidance for 3D Obstacle Avoidance of Biomimetic Robotic Fish
authors: Zinuo Tian, Sai Deng, Zhengxing Wu, Chao Zhou, Jian Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Autonomous navigation in complex 3D underwater environments is crucial for biomimetic robotic fish. However, the traditional Artificial Potential Field (TAPF) suffers from limitations like susceptibility to local minima, target unreachability when obstacles are near the goal, and path oscillations unsuitable for biomimetic locomotion, hindering practical applications. To address these deficiencies, this paper proposes the Dynamic Logarithmic Artificial Potential Field with Adaptive Virtual Guidance (DL-APF-AVG) method, which integrates four key innovations: (1) a logarithmic attraction potential function ensuring target convergence even near obstacles; (2) a dynamic, state-aware repulsion potential considering relative velocity and angle for smoother, proactive avoidance; (3) an Adaptive Virtual Guidance (AVG) strategy to deterministically escape local minima traps; (4) a dynamic step adjustment mechanism to actively suppress path jitter. The synergy of these components enhances target reachability, generates smoother trajectories appropriate for biomimetic locomotion, and provides robust escape from various local minima traps. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed method over TAPF are demonstrated through 3D simulations.

title: A Semantic Provenance Graph-Based Detection Method for Ransomware Attacks
authors: Haocheng Han, Baitong Zha, Kaize Wang, Zhiwei Zhang, Yulong Shen, Jiandong Wang, Yufeng Kang, Xinghui Zhu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: Ransomware attacks encrypt victims’ critical files and data to extort ransom. Characterized by covert intrusion processes and fast intrusion speeds, compromised systems are difficult to recover. Such attacks pose severe threats to cybersecurity and cause enormous economic losses. However, existing detection methods suffer from issues such as poor accuracy and timeliness, insufficient generalization capabilities, and vulnerability to evasion by attackers. To address these challenges, we propose a rapid detection framework leveraging semantic provenance graphs, which enhances both detection accuracy and timeliness. Our methodology involves: 1) unified parsing of multisource logs with semantic feature extraction to construct semantic provenance graphs; 2) graph embedding vector mapping and GNN-based structural feature management; and 3) a hybrid detection mechanism combining static features and dynamic behavioral analysis for early-stage attack identification. To verify the accuracy and efficiency of the method, we conducted comprehensive performance comparison experiments and effectiveness analysis experiments. Theoretical and experimental evaluations demonstrate our method achieves superior detection accuracy $(98.49 \%)$, precision $(97.62 \%)$, and recall $(99.03 \%)$ compared to baseline approaches, while maintaining an average detection latency of $\mathbf{1 . 2 5}$ seconds.

title: Modeling and Scheduling of Composable Instruction Set
authors: Yu Yang, Paul Delestrac, Ahmed Hemani
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: State-of-the-art hardware accelerators with custom instruction set architectures (ISAs) are widely used in AI/ML applications. Despite the outstanding progress of modern accelerators, their performance potential is limited by their ISA. Recently, research around composable instruction sets (CIS) has emerged with the aim of improving the efficiency of modern accelerator ISAs. However, while CIS significantly outperforms existing ISAs with near-optimal PE utilization, no existing instruction scheduling approach supports the temporal composability requirements to correctly schedule CIS programs. The goal of this work is to propose a scalable scheduling algorithm that can meet CIS requirements. We propose a novel timing model structure built upon five fundamental concepts - operations, events, transformations, anchors, and constraints - that accurately capture CIS timing behavior and constraints. Using this model, we automatically formulate scheduling problems that can be solved using constraint programming (CP) solvers. In addition, we propose a methodology to synchronize scheduled instructions and generate functional CIS assembly code. Finally, we design experiments to study the scalability and quality of our scheduling approach. Across multiple dimensions of complexity, our approach scales linearly and produces near-optimal scheduling solutions.

title: AI-Driven Cell Monitoring and Automated Irrigation for Sugarcane Yield and Quality Prediction
authors: Anuwat Jaidee, Anake Nammakhunt, Tommanee Sooksai, Noppadon Sittilears, Mesawadi Sukkri, Suphalak Batpho
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: This research presents a Cell Monitoring Model (CMM) integrated with an Automated Irrigation System (AIS) to enhance water management and predict sugarcane yield and quality. The study focuses on Naklang District, Nong Bua Lamphu, representing the analytical center for the North-Eastern Sugarcane Planters Association, covering six provinces: Nong Bua Lamphu, Loei, Udon Thani, Nong Khai, Khon Kaen, and Chaiyaphum. The CMM collects real-time environmental and soil data from 62 distributed monitoring stations and fuses them with regional rainfall data from Thailand’s National Hydroinformatics Data Center. This integrated dataset is used to train a Deep Neural Network (DNN) that determines the optimal irrigation quantity (Iopt) for each monitoring cell. The system aims to maximize Adaptive Water Use Efficiency (WUE) while providing accurate pre-harvest predictions of yield (tons/rai) and Commercial Cane Sugar (CCS) values. Field trials demonstrated that the proposed CMM–AIS framework improved yield by 15–25% and achieved more consistent CCS compared with traditional irrigation practices. These results validate the potential of AI-driven, IoT-based irrigation systems to support precision agriculture and sustainable water management for sugarcane cultivation in Thailand’s Northeast region.

title: Data-Driven Assessment of Vehicle-to-Grid Capabilities in Supporting Grid During Emergencies: Case Study of Travis County, TX
authors: Kelsey Nelson, Javad Mohammadi
abstract: As extreme weather events become more common and threaten power grids, the continuing adoption of electric vehicles (EVs) introduces a growing opportunity for their use as a distributed energy storage resource. This energy storage can be used as backup generation with vehicle-to-grid (V2G) technology, where electricity is sent back from EV batteries to the grid [1]. With enough participation from EV owners, V2G can mitigate outages during grid emergencies. In order to investigate a practical application of V2G, this study leverages a vast array of real-world data, such as survey results on V2G participation willingness, historical outage data within ERCOT, current EV registrations, and demographic data. This data informs realistic emergency grid scenarios with V2G support using a synthetic transmission grid for Travis County. The results find that as EV ownership rises in the coming years, the simultaneous facilitation of bidirectional charging availability would allow for V2G to play a substantial role in preventing involuntary load shed as a result of emergencies like winter storms.

title: Energy-Saving Full-Body Control of Hybrid Vehicles through Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Jiaxin Chen, Xiaolin Tang, Yechen Qin
abstract: Deep reinforcement learning (DRL) algorithms have become an essential approach for enabling autonomous evolution in artificial intelligence (AI) models. As the representative form, autonomous vehicles equipped with new energy powertrains are expected to take into account the external dynamic environment, human-centered driving demand, and the internal power supply. This paper aims to integrate fundamental tasks of energy-saving and autonomous driving, realizing end-to-end self-learning-based improvements. Firstly, a Python-Simulink-Unreal Engine/Carla-based co-simulation framework is proposed after customizing 3D driving scenarios and enhancing vehicle modeling. Then, focusing on the vehicle-level embodied intelligence, a DRL-based energy-saving full-body control system is proposed, in which DRL agents are trained to collaboratively learn adaptive cruise control (ACC) and lane-keeping assist (LKA) at the vehicle driving layer, as well as energy management strategy (EMS) and transmission shift strategy (TSS) at the powertrain level. Moreover, to achieve the integration of energy-saving driving and end-to-end autonomous driving, Bird's Eye View (BEV) perception is incorporated into the state space. This not only constructs a dual-modal state space but also facilitates extensions to other end-to-end tasks. Finally, a hardware-in-the-loop (HIL) platform is established. The results show that the DRL-based energy-saving control system maintains a speed of 60 km/h while staying within the lane 3.82 m wide on a 7.041 km circular road. The complete drive lasts 557 seconds and achieves a fuel economy of 7.748 L/100 km.

title: A Piezoelectrically-Actuated Mesoscale Compliant Parallel Robot via Additive Manufacture_supp1-3641153.mp4
authors: Ryan Orszulik
abstract: Micro-positioning and pick-and-place applications at the millimeter scale are driving the development of smaller robots necessitating the use of alternative methods for design and manufacture. Additive manufacturing can enable significant cost and time savings in the fabrication of robots while having a low barrier to entry. Specifically, multimaterial 3D printing naturally lends itself to the creation of monolithic mechanisms by removing the requirement for manual assembly, in particular, when compliant joints can replace the rigid joints that are traditionally used. The lack of an assembly requirement naturally opens up the possibility of reducing the size scale of these mechanisms. In this work, the design, fabrication, and characterization of an additively manufactured mesoscale compliant parallel robot actuated by piezoelectric bimorphs through a compliant transmission mechanism is presented. The transmission mechanism is required to convert and amplify the small but rapid linear displacements of piezoelectric actuators into the large rotational motion that is required to create a large workspace for the compliant parallel robot. The developed planar parallel robot has a workspace with maximum planar extents of 14.36 mm by 8.66 mm, with a total area of 65.6 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. Three different trajectories are tracked at frequencies of up to 10 Hz, demonstrating the robot's capability to rapidly follow trajectories in its workspace.

title: Hybrid Predictive Network-Based Multiagent Reconnaissance Game with Limited Perception
authors: Xiangyuan Shen, Bin Hu, Zhi-Hong Guan, Dingxue Zhang, Tao Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive and Developmental Systems
abstract: Multi-agent games in complex adversarial scenarios have gained significant attention. Existing methods face challenges in modeling multi-stage games in complex reconnaissance environments and addressing incomplete information issues. Inspired by the results of brain science research, this paper proposes a hybrid predictive network coupled with a reinforcement learning algorithm with perceptual and environmental constraints. An impulsive long short-term memory network (ImpLSTM) is designed to simulate the brain’s short-term memory mechanism. A hybrid opponent decision prediction network combining ImpLSTM and Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) is established to enhance the prediction of opponent behavior under perception constraints. A reinforcement learning-based decision algorithm is developed to optimize decision strategies through various reward functions, enhancing the decision-making performance of agents in complex environments. Simulations and physical experiments demonstrate the performance and effectiveness of the proposed algorithm in complex games.

title: Variable-Gain Load-Independent Class-E Rectifier for High-Frequency Wireless Power Transfer
authors: Wenqi Zhu, Ayano Komanaka, Yutaro Komiyama, Kien Nguyen, Hirotaka Koizumi, Hiroo Sekiya
abstract: This paper proposes a variable-gain load-independent (LI) class-E rectifier for high-frequency wireless power transfer (WPT) systems. Featuring a reconfigurable resonant network, the proposed rectifier dynamically adjusts its voltage gain across multiple levels, enabling the system to maintain a nearly constant output voltage under varying load and coil misalignment conditions. Comprehensive circuit analysis is conducted to derive explicit expressions for both the voltage gain and input reactance of the LI class-E rectifier. Based on this analysis, a systematic design methodology is presented to realize dynamic gain adjustment while preserving zero-voltage switching (ZVS) and constant input reactance. A 6.78 MHz WPT prototype was constructed and evaluated. The rectifier effectively adapted its gain in response to coupling variations, eliminating the need for external regulators. Moreover, the rectifier not only achieved ZVS operation itself but also maintained ZVS in the transmitter by providing constant input reactance. As a result, switching losses were significantly reduced, and the system achieved a high overall efficiency of 88.0%.

title: Noise-Free Sensorless Control Based on Direct Speed Estimation and Virtual-Z-Pulse Zero-Crossing Correction for Both SPMSMs and IPMSMs
authors: Xinran Shi, Hao Chen, Zeyuan Gao, Chao Gong, Xing Zhao, Li Ding, Yihua Hu
abstract: This paper proposes a direct speed estimator based on the sliding mode principle (SM-DSE). Unlike conventional methods that rely on intermediary signals such as back electromotive force and high-frequency response current to obtain speed and position information, the SM-DSE achieves full speed range noise-free sensorless control without any intermediary signals. It is also applicable to both surface-mounted and interior permanent magnet synchronous motor. Firstly, the design process of the SM-DSE is introduced, along with explanations of how position is obtained through speed integration and how the initial position is determined. Secondly, by defining the tracking rate (TR) of the estimated speed, the paper analyzes the errors caused by speed integration and low-pass filter. The action states of the joint module are simulated to explore the relationship between the error, TR, and number of actions. Thirdly, to address these issues, this paper proposes a zero-crossing correction method based on the virtual-Z-pulse of the photoelectric encoder. By compensating the final position in each cycle based on the zero-crossing point, the accumulated integration error can be effectively eliminated. This enables the method to achieve high-precision, noise-free control over the full speed range, making it suitable for high precision control scenarios in robotic joint modules. Finally, experiments are conducted on both SPMSM and IPMSM to verify the effectiveness of the proposed sensorless control strategy.

title: Cross-Channel Specific Emitter Identification via Meta-Feature Augmentation-Enhanced Few-Shot Learning
authors: Xue Fu, Yu Wang, Xilong Liu, Jun Chang, Guan Gui
abstract: The rapid increase in wireless devices has raised significant security and privacy concerns, positioning Specific Emitter Identification (SEI) as a crucial physical-layer security technology. Although Deep Learning (DL) methods have been widely applied to SEI due to their powerful end-to-end nonlinear mapping capabilities, they generally require large amounts of high-quality signal examples, which are difficult to obtain in adversarial environments. Moreover, wireless channel perturbations induce a distribution shift between the training and testing signal examples from the same emitter. This shift prevents DL-enabled SEI models from learning emitter-specific, channel-agnostic features, leading to a severe degradation in identification performance. In this work, we propose a cross-channel SEI method based on Meta-Feature Augmentation-Enhanced Few-Shot Learning (MFA-FSL) to efficiently address the aforementioned challenges. To overcome the data scarcity, we use signal examples from base emitters with physical-layer characteristics similar to target emitters for pre-training. To overcome the channel perturbations, we employ meta-learning as the pre-training technique to learn a channel-agnostic feature embedding function. Considering that the function does not perform well in scenarios where signal examples of target emitters are extremely scarce, we approximate the target emitter’s feature distribution and sample augmented features from it. These augmented features, together with the raw features extracted from a few signal examples of target emitters, provide sufficient supervision to train a simple classifier. Experiments conducted on a Wi-Fi dataset comprising 16 emitter categories—10 as base emitters and 6 as target emitters—demonstrate that our proposed method achieves more than 85.63% identification accuracy with only 5 signal examples per target emitter, maintaining more than 83.35% accuracy even under varying wireless channel conditions. The code can be downloaded from https://github.com/lovelymimola/MFA-FSLIoTJ-Version.

title: A 145-GHz Self-Packaged Outphasing Transmitter Achieving 39-dBm EIRP at 11-pJ/b/m in 40-nm CMOS
authors: Jiapeng Wan, Yizhu Shen, Yifan Ding, Shizhe Xu, Yun Qian, Sanming Hu
abstract: This article presents a highly integrated, high-power outphasing transmitter with self-packaging technique in the D band. The transmitter achieves system-level optimization through the co-design of complementary metal–oxide –semiconductor (CMOS) active circuits, on-chip antennas, and off-chip packaged. By leveraging ultra-low-profile source-integrated metasurface technology, the design transforms an air-fed lens antenna into a cost-effective multilayer printed circuit board (PCB), effectively reducing the packaging height from one focal length to one-fifth, corresponding to an 80% reduction. This structural optimization significantly enhances the equivalent isotropic radiated power (EIRP) while maintaining power consumption, thereby realizing self-packaged. Furthermore, the concept of in-antenna power combining is extended to an outphasing power-combining network, facilitating the realization of a fully integrated D-band outphasing transmitter chip. This design ensures high fidelity and high output power even when transmitting advanced modulation signals. Measurement results indicate that this self-packaged outphasing transmitter achieves an EIRP of 39 dBm at 145 GHz with a power consumption of 924 mW, and a 3-dB EIRP bandwidth from 130 to 156 GHz, covering 18.2% of the frequency range. To the best of the authors’ knowledge, this D-band CMOS self-packaged outphasing transmitter achieves the highest EIRP.

title: A Miniaturized Ultra-Wideband Horn Antenna with Dielectric-guided Lens
authors: Zhongwei Hou, En Li, Pinhong Xie, Chong Gao
publish: IEEE Antennas and Wireless Propagation Letters
abstract: This letter proposes a miniaturized ultra-wideband double-ridged horn antenna with the dielectric-guided lens. Unlike conventional double-ridged horns, the proposed design employs a bidirectional-gradient ridge to achieve smooth impedance transformation along the horn. Moreover, a dielectric guiding structure with an exponential profile is embedded within the antenna aperture to guide electromagnetic (EM) waves and improve low-frequency Voltage Standing Wave Ratio (VSWR), while a hyperbolic lens at the horn aperture enhances high-frequency gain and suppresses beam splitting. Measurements and simulations indicate that the antenna achieves a VSWR below 2.2 across 2–44 GHz, with a peak gain of 18.5 dBi at 36 GHz. The optimized antenna measures 48 mm × 50 mm × 100 mm. Compared with conventional designs, the proposed antenna is more compact and suited to space-constrained ultra-wideband applications.

title: Goal-Reaching Control Synthesis for Neural Network Control Systems via Backward Reachability
authors: Hang Zhang, Abigail J. Winn, Yuhao Zhang, Xiangru Xu
abstract: This letter investigates goal-reaching control synthesis for neural network control systems. A backward reachability framework is developed based on constrained zonotopes, in which the graph set of a ReLU-activated feedforward neural network is encoded as a finite union of constrained zonotopes. Using this representation, under-approximations of backward reachable sets are computed for systems with nonlinear plant models, ensuring the feasibility of the goal-reaching task. Control sequences are then synthesized through an optimization procedure that exploits the under-approximated set. A numerical example demonstrates the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: DINet: Depth-guided and Iterative Refinement Network for Salient Object Detection in Optical Remote Sensing Images
authors: Xihang Hu, Fuming Sun, Xiaoli Zhang, Chuanmin Jia, Siwei Ma
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Optical remote sensing images (ORSI) feature unique scenes and complex imaging conditions. Specifically, they exhibit substantial variations in object scale, quantity, structure, and distribution. Consequently, salient object detection in ORSI (ORSI-SOD) is pivotal in ORSI content perception and understanding. Additionally, the limitations of the single modality impede the advancement of ORSI-SOD. To tackle these issues, we propose a Depth-guided and Iterative Refinement Network (DINet) for ORSI-SOD. By incorporating depth information as auxiliary cues, we introduce a multi-modal strategy for ORSI-SOD, resulting in improved accuracy in the localization and segmentation of salient objects. To address the variability of salient objects, we design an Aggregation Perception Enhancement (APE) Module. This module integrates complementary cues from cross-modal features using multi-dimensional attention mechanisms. By fostering cross-modal interactions, the APE module effectively preserves both detail and spatial location information. Furthermore, we propose an Iterative Guidance Refinement Decoder to handle boundary uncertainty. The decoder uses initial predictions to guide the decoding phase and iteratively refine results. Simultaneously, it minimizes noise from depth cues, yielding predictions with more accurate boundaries. Experimental comparisons with 22 state-of-the-art methods show that DINet exhibits superior performance while maintaining lightweight (11.98M) and real-time (55FPS) capabilities.

title: Standard Plans or Membership Bundles? Competitive Paid Membership Strategies for Video Platforms
authors: Shun Li, Li Li, Kun Zhang
abstract: Video platforms have increasingly been observed forming partnerships with other service providers (e.g., digital music service provider) through the launch of membership bundles. This paper analytically investigates such strategic choices of competing video platforms regarding two paid membership strategies, i.e., standard plans and membership bundles. In the basic model, the chosen service provider is assumed to exhibit similar horizontal attributes as the video platform. Therefore, compared to standard plans, membership bundles reinforce the intensity of mismatches, even though they bring incremental benefits. Our study unveils the following intriguing findings. First, when the incremental value consumers receive from membership bundles is sufficiently small (large), both platforms prefer to adopt standard plans (membership bundles). Second, in the scenario where the incremental value is moderate, both platforms can be better off by adopting asymmetric membership strategies if network effects are strong. Furthermore, we demonstrate that the provision of membership bundles will intensify platform competition. This result implies that the provision of membership bundles may hurt platforms' profitability when network effects are very weak and the incremental value is not very large. However, given that membership bundles can increase social welfare, policymakers may encourage their applications. In the model extensions, the robustness of our results is tested. We allow for alternative preference correlations across bundled services, endogenize the revenue-sharing rate via the incremental value created by bundling, and introduce asymmetric intensities of network effects for different plans.
