title: Hierarchical Fuzzy Learning With Virtual Tracking Targets for Optimal Tracking Control in Strict Feedback Systems
authors: Ying Yan, Huaguang Zhang
abstract: This paper proposes a hierarchical fuzzy learning (HFL) framework that restructures fuzzy control synthesis around Virtual Tracking Targets (VTTs). First, we introduce a VTT-driven hierarchical architecture in which each non-output state is guided by an autonomous virtual agent that simultaneously (i) directs state evolution toward task-consistent trajectories and (ii) self-organizes its auxiliary control role via satisfaction of Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman (HJB) conditions. This dual functionality departs from static virtual controls in fuzzy backstepping and endows the hierarchy with intrinsic adaptivity. Second, we establish a parallel computational paradigm for controller synthesis: instead of the canonical cascaded design that enforces strict layer-by-layer dependency, all VTTs are optimized concurrently. This parallelization not only removes the sequential bottleneck of adaptive/optimal backstepping but also yields scalability benefits for high-dimensional systems without sacrificing stability guarantees. Third, to handle unknown VTT derivatives that commonly hinder inverse/fuzzy designs, we embed a first-order low-pass filter to deliver real-time derivative surrogates, thereby avoiding explicit differentiation. A unified Lyapunov analysis proves uniformly ultimately bounded (UUB) of both the filtered tracking errors and the fuzzy weight estimation errors, providing a twofold convergence guarantee in fuzzy control. Comprehensive analyses characterize stability, and approximation properties; demonstrating improved tracking accuracy, reduced control energy due to parallel synthesis, and enhanced resilience under derivative uncertainty.

title: Fault-Tolerant Operation of Star- and Delta-Connected Cascaded H-Bridge Multilevel Inverters: A Comparative Study
authors: Carlos A. Munoz, Carlos R. Baier, Jesus C. Hernández, Victor S. Monteiro, Bruno W. França, Oscar Danilo Montoya
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: High renewable penetration requires mediumvoltage microgrids to remain operational even when converters, or portions of them, fail within the microgrid. This study employs simulations to compare two fault-tolerance strategies for Cascaded H-Bridge (CHB) multilevel converters with both star and delta connections. In the star configuration, an algorithm readjusts modulation indices and carrier phases after cell failures to maintain balanced line voltages. The delivered power is preserved, but harmonic distortion rises. In the delta connection, recovery is simpler: increasing the modulation index of the healthy cells is sufficient. The resulting distortion is lower, though it demands a DC bus 73% higher and an additional output filter. Results show that both strategies continue to supply the nominal voltage after a fault. The choice hinges on the trade-off between control and hardware: the star configuration offers greater robustness with existing equipment, whereas the delta configuration improves waveform quality at the cost of more demanding power electronics. The study provides clear guidelines for selecting the most suitable CHB topology when service continuity and power quality are of critical importance.

title: Traffic-based Air Pollution Monitoring System for Urban Intersections
authors: Asil Andrei B. Acasio, John Karlo N. Cenabre, Ken Zachary D. Rollo, Jaybie A. De Guzman, Isabel M. Austria, Marc D. Rosales, John Richard E. Hizon
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Traffic-related air pollution at road intersections where restricted traffic flow concentrates emissions is a critical public health concern. Existing air quality monitoring systems often rely on single sensor nodes covering wide areas, resulting in insufficient data that hinders accurate pollutant-dispersion analysis and informed urban planning. This study developed a cost-effective, multi-nodal, air quality and traffic monitoring system with its digital twin. It consists of four deployable air quality sensor nodes and one camera-based traffic monitoring node, linked to a gateway node that transmits data to a local and cloud database. An integrated platform is used to present and visualize the obtained data. A pollutant dispersion simulation was also implemented as part of a digital twin framework to dynamically represent the temporal changes in pollutant movement within the monitored area. On-site deployment of the system demonstrated consistent wireless communication performance, with an average of 97% network packet success rate between sensor nodes, and an average power consumption of 880 mW per sensor node given the array of sensors used, enabling continuous battery-powered operation. Elevated pollutant concentrations were observed in instances of heavy traffic flow near a sensor node or when vehicles nearby were idling or accelerating. Digital Twin Model evaluation showed that ENVI-met with the SUMO-based emissions profile yields the most similar CO2 estimates when compared to the sensor readings. It also verified that pollutant movement in the area is not only affected by vehicles but also by urban morphology, wind characteristics, and environmental factors.

title: Enhancing Intelligent Battery Management on Automotive Microcontrollers Using LightGBM
authors: Khaled Alamin, Chao Song, Sara Vinco, Francesco Daghero
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: State-of-Health (SoH) is a core metric of any Battery Management System (BMS), impacting operational safety and performance optimization. However, its on-board estimation remains challenging due to the dynamic nature of battery data and the tight memory and energy constraints of embedded systems, requiring frequent yet impractical model updates. We present a framework for training and deploying ensembles of decision trees on BMS hardware, delivering accurate SoH estimates across the entire battery lifespan without model updates, while also being resource-inexpensive on on-board Microcontrollers (MCUs). On two benchmark datasets, our method achieves up to 39% lower MAE than state-of-the-art deep-learning baselines. Moreover, when deployed on an industry-grade automotive MCU, it delivers inference speedups of 11–30x while occupying under 3% of the available memory.

title: Performance Analysis of Encoding Schemes in Hyperdimensional Computing for EEG Signals
authors: Jose Francois Abedejos, Fredrick Angelo Galapon, Lawrence Roman Quizon, Anastacia Alvarez, Adelson Chua
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Hyperdimensional computing (HDC) is a ‘brain-like’ system that represents data using high-dimensional vectors, or hypervectors. It performs simple bitwise operations on these hypervectors, enabling efficient classification in tasks such as biosignal applications. A major challenge in HDC is the encoding of analog signals into hypervectors. In seizure detection, features from the electroencephalogram (EEG) signal are typically extracted prior to encoding. Common features include local binary patterns (LBP), spectral power, line length, and mean amplitude. While these features have been individually evaluated in terms of classification accuracy, their comparative hardware performances remains largely unexamined. This work presents a comparative analysis of various encoding schemes for seizure detection, evaluating their classification accuracy, area, and energy efficiency. Among the approaches considered, single, distinctive features such as LBP are determined to be the most efficient choice for seizure detection, achieving 86.1% sensitivity and 71.7% specificity. In contrast, continuous-valued features like spectral power and line length offer less accuracy, while combining multiple features with LBP increases specificity by 6.7% but at the cost of 195% increase in area and a 309% increase in energy.

title: Biomarkers for Stress and Sleepless Evaluation
authors: Amaury Santiago-Horta, Biaani D. Delfín-García, Blanca Tovar-Corona, Laura I. Garay-Jiménez, Yesenia E. González-Navarro
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Sleepless and stress impair cognitive and physical performance. This study compares physiological responses under rested and sleepless state using two protocols: a 90-minute virtual driving task and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{2 5}$</tex>-minute physical exercise protocol. Participants included two drivers (Protocol 1) and eight healthy adults (Protocol 2). EEG analysis focused on spectral energy in theta, alpha, and beta bands and cognitive ratios. Photoplethysmography (PPG) signal was processed for heart rate (HR), HR variability (HRV), and a spectral energy band. Electrodermal Activity (EDA) signal was processed for Skin Conductance Level (SCL), Skin Conductance Response (SCR), and spectral energy of two bands. Results showed increased theta activity during sleep deprivation, particularly in posterior EEG channels (Pz, PO7, PO8, Oz). Cognitive ratios decrease in anterior EEG channels (Fz, C3, Cz, C4) and increases in posterior EEG channels for sleepless state. No significant differences between states were found in PPG and EDA during the physical exercise protocol using the Tukey's test <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{p}<0.05)$</tex>. However, events change were significant according to the multiple two-way ANOVA test.

title: Study of SiOxCy Films Deposited by Cat-CVD Using Methyltrimethoxysilane for Application in Optoelectronics
authors: M. Meneses, M. Moreno Moreno, J. R. Ramos-Serrano, Y. Matsumoto, J. Miguel Zarate, J. Federico Ramirez
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Silicon oxycarbide (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{S i O}_{\mathbf{x}} \mathbf{C}_{\mathbf{y}}$</tex>) films were deposited by catalytic chemical vapor deposition (Cat-CVD) using methyltrimethoxysilane (MTMS) as the precursor. The optical, structural, and morphological properties of the films, both as-deposited and after thermal treatment, were investigated. In addition, a device with an Al/p-type Si/ <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SiO}_{\mathrm{x}} \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{y}}$</tex> /ITO structure similar to a metal-insulatorsemiconductor (MIS) configuration was fabricated and analyzed. The device exhibited electroluminescence (EL) in the green to near-infrared (NIR) range, with emission onset at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{6 V}$</tex>. The visible emission was attributed to silicon-related oxygen-deficient centers (Si-ODCs) and non-bridging oxygen hole centers (NBOHCs). In contrast, the NIR emission was associated with intrinsic defects. These results indicate that the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SiO}_{\mathrm{x}} \mathrm{C}_{\mathrm{y}}$</tex> system is a promising candidate for photonic and optoelectronic applications, particularly in the field of optical communications.

title: Enabling Time-Aware Priority Traffic Management over Distributed FPGA Nodes
authors: Alberto Scionti, Paolo Savio, Francesco Lubrano, Federico Stirano, Antonino Nespola, Olivier Terzo, Corrado De Sio, Luca Sterpone
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: Network Interface Cards (NICs) greatly evolved from simple basic devices moving traffic in and out of the network to complex heterogeneous systems offloading host CPUs from performing complex tasks on in-transit packets. These latter comprise different types of devices, ranging from NICs accelerating fixed specific functions (e.g., on-the-fly data compression/decompression, checksum computation, data encryption, etc.) to complex Systems-on-Chip (SoC) equipped with both general purpose processors and specialized engines (Smart-NICs). Similarly, Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) moved from pure reprogrammable devices to modern heterogeneous systems comprising general-purpose processors, real-time cores and even AI-oriented engines. Furthermore, the availability of high-speed network interfaces (e.g., SFPs) makes modern FPGAs a good choice for implementing Smart-NICs. In this work, we extended the functionalities offered by an open-source NIC implementation (Corundum) by enabling time-aware traffic management in hardware, and using this feature to control the bandwidth associated with different traffic classes. By exposing dedicated control registers on the AXI bus, the driver of the NIC can easily configure the transmission bandwidth of different prioritized queues. Basically, each control register is associated with a specific transmission queue (Corundum can expose up to thousands of transmission and receiving queues), and sets up the fraction of time in a transmission window which the queue is supposed to get access the output port and transmit the packets. Queues are then prioritized and associated to different traffic classes through the Linux QDISC mechanism. Experimental evaluation demonstrates that the approach allows to properly manage the bandwidth reserved to the different transmission flows.

title: A Structured Approach to Verification of Digital Hardware in Scala
authors: Tjark Petersen, Luca Pezzarossa, Martin Schoeberl
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: Functional verification accounts for a significant portion of the design effort in modern digital hardware development. As projects grow in complexity, maintaining and extending verification code becomes increasingly difficult, particularly in collaborative environments. This calls for a methodology that defines a clear structure and promotes reuse through modular, composable testbench components. In this paper, we present a Scala-based verification framework that adopts a structured approach to building modular and reusable testbenches, inspired by the Universal Verification Methodology (UVM). We analyze the core mechanisms through which UVM achieves modularity and reusability, and identify a minimal subset that provides equivalent functionality with reduced complexity. The result is a lightweight verification framework in Scala 3 using Verilator as a backend, which allows for simple unit-test-style testing as well as complex UVM-style testbench environments.

title: Frequency-Constrained Optimal Power Flow under N-k Generator Contingencies Considering Inertia and Ramp-Rate-Based Reserve Modeling
authors: Juan Lazaro Herrera Duarte, Edson Tapia Torres, Guillermo Gutierrez-Alcaraz
abstract: Currently, when analyzing the primary frequency response for inertial energy response, such as the rotational inertia of all active machines in the system, as well as the effect of governor response on the performance of primary reserves, it is difficult to ensure delivery due to network congestion. This work establishes conditions for optimal allocation and deployment by the primary response through an Optimal Power Flow model based on the primary frequency response, which is linked to system inertia and the rates of change of system governors and deadbands. Additionally, transmission losses are included and modeled as a piecewise-linear approximation of the active power flows. The proposed formulations are validated and compared using the 24-bus test system. The results demonstrate that it is crucial to account for post-contingency transmission constraints to ensure reserve delivery and to optimize generator output under contingency conditions, including simultaneous N-2 generation contingencies.

title: EcoTech: A Wildfire Prediction and Detection System
authors: Aya Sharrouf, Rayan Emad, Nadine Boudargham, Mustapha Hamad, Abdallah Kassem
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper presents an integrated hardware and software system for the early detection, prediction, and alerting of forest fires. The proposed solution leverages a wireless sensor network of multiple ESP8266-based nodes, equipped with temperature, humidity, and gas sensors, to continuously monitor environmental conditions. Data is efficiently aggregated using the ESP-NOW protocol and transmitted to a scalable Node.js backend. The core intelligence of the system is driven by a dual machine-learning architecture: a Support Vector Machine (SVM) model performs real-time fire detection by analyzing live sensor data, while a Random Forest model predicts future temperature and humidity trends to anticipate fire risks. These insights are delivered to end-users through a mobile application, which provides real-time alerts, system status updates, and risk assessments for firefighters and forest managers. Designed with an emphasis on robustness and scalability, the system incorporates secure, role-based access control and fault-tolerant communication protocols. Experimental results confirm the system's efficacy in delivering reliable, low-latency warnings, demonstrating its potential to significantly mitigate the ecological and economic impact of wildfires.

title: Adjustable Setpoint Proportional (ASP) Control for Interleaved Switched Capacitor DC/DC Converter
authors: Ahmed Al-Qallaf, Ali Ridha Ali, Kamal El-Sankary
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper proposes a plug-and-play adjustable setpoint proportional (ASP) control for interleaved switched-capacitor DC/DC converters. The ASP control, based on the P-only algorithm, retains its fast response while eliminating offset error and large gain requirements by using a feedforward digital filter to adjust the setpoint. A pulse-width ADC with a voltage-controlled delay line (VCDL) and pulse-swallow time-to-digital converter (TDC) is used for A/D quantization. Designed CMOS 180nm technology, the controller demonstrates acceptable transient behavior and achieves 70.81% peak efficiency and 0.37-0.74 µs load settling (500 µA -500 mA)

title: Characterization-Guided Strategies for Transients Faults Mitigation in Digitals Circuits
authors: Le Bigot Maxime, Leroy François, Ghaffari Fakhreddine, Romain Olivier
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Understanding the potential failure modes of digital circuits is fundamental to implement effective protection mitigations. This work presents a sub-classification of events based on their failure modes and a characterization methodology to classify the observed events. The characterization is performed through fault injection campaigns on representative hardware designs, enabling a thorough evaluation of circuit behavior and reliability under various fault conditions. The developed framework provides valuable insights into the development and validation of mitigation strategies. To support this analysis, an ElectroMagnetic Fault Injection (EMFI) setup was designed and used to carry out the characterization and test different mitigation strategies.

title: Enhancing Hybrid Battery-Solar Return on Investment by Dynamic Battery Pack Usage and Charge Management
authors: Nithish Aravinthan, Madison Koester, Demy Alexander, Mary Peterson, Davi Soares
abstract: The convenience and decreased environmental impact of solar photovoltaic (PV) systems have made them more appealing to former consumers, encouraging the growth of prosumers, who produce and consume electricity. Many such prosumers are interested in increasing revenue, which can be accomplished using a hybrid battery-solar system since more energy is available to export during peak demand hours. This paper aims to maximize revenue considering charging time and coulombic efficiency. A two-stage approach is proposed: the first stage optimizes battery charging power for the state of charge per cell, utilizing a Taylor Series approximation for steady-state efficiency; the second stage optimizes battery sizing. When tested for different solar profiles using field solar and battery data and time-of-use rates, the proposed technique generates more revenue than non-optimized strategies, improves battery pack life, and uses a simple Taylor Series based algorithm.

title: A Reconfigurable and Scalable Ultra-Low-Power RISC-V Architecture Based on System Requirements for Battery-Based IoT Devices
authors: Mohamed A. Elshiemy, Ahmed Soltan
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: This paper offers a configurable architecture design utilizing Parallel ultra-low-power RISC-V cores tailor-made for IoT applications. The architecture integrates three cores (MicroRV32IMEC, Zero-RV32IMEC, and Riscy). It is managed by a controller that selects the correct core primarily based on the least significant bits of the input instruction opcode. In the 32-bit RISC-V instruction set architecture, these two bits (LSBs) permit 4 variations (00, 01, 10, 11), with only 11 being applied across all 32-bit RISC-V ISAs to be had within the available and their supported extensions except for the compressed extension and these bits guiding core activation: the Micro-Riscy core is enabled for opcode 00, the Zero-Riscy core for opcode 01, and the Riscy core for opcode 10. This selection mechanism optimizes power consumption and overall performance by specific system requirements, particularly after enhancements to the Zero-Riscy core (Zero-RV32IMEC). Specifically, after designing and integrating the approximate adder into this core, our proposed architecture conserves 48.27% less power than the original three cores, while it achieves 27.25% a better execution time. Therefore, it is suitable for wearable biomedical devices and energy-sensitive IoT applications. The proposed architecture strikes a balance between efficiency and flexibility, addressing the critical needs of low-power applications while providing the flexibility of RISC-V instruction sets.

title: Tool-Based Case Studies on Strategic Deployment of Untapped Micro-Pumped Hydro Storage in Michigan
authors: Sharaf K. Magableh, Xuesong Wang, Oraib Dawaghreh, Caisheng Wang, Erfan Mehdipour Abadi
abstract: With most classical hydropower sites already utilized and the global push for rapid integration of renewable energy sources accelerating, there is a critical need to identify alternative energy storage solutions. Pumped hydro energy storage, which accounts for the vast majority of global grid-scale storage, remains one of the most cost-effective and long-duration storage technologies available. Hence, this study presents a novel tool designed to assess the untapped potential of inland lakes and reservoirs for micro-PSH, using Michigan’s relatively flat landscape as a case study due to its extensive but underutilized water infrastructure. To ensure accuracy and reliability, the tool incorporates extensive data gathered from authorized sources, covering more than 420 water facilities and potential reservoirs in the state. The tool evaluates key parameters such as horizontal and vertical distances, volume, and the total storage capacity of each reservoir. Its robust assessment framework integrates these metrics to evaluate each site’s potential. The tool’s intuitive interface and geospatial visualizations support actionable insights for planners and scalable deployment of distributed storage infrastructure.

title: Predicting Farmers Adoption Intention of E-Commerce for Organic Produce using Machine Learning Approaches
authors: Reiven M. Bernardino, Gian Carlo M. Cabuguas, John Ray D. Cecilio, Norence Enoch G. Estrañero, Alexander A. Hernandez, Julius P. Claour
publish: 2025 23rd International Conference on ICT and Knowledge Engineering (ICT&amp;KE)
abstract: Despite the potential for e-commerce to boost productivity and market access for farmers, adoption remains low, particularly in rural areas of developing countries. This study addresses the research gap by predicting farmers' adoption of digital platforms in the National Capital Region, Philippines, using the Theory of Planned Behavior (TPB) and the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM). Based on a survey of 615 farmers and analysis with various machine learning models, with XGBoost as the top performer, the study found that perceived usefulness, trust, and price value are the most significant factors influencing adoption. Social influence and ease of use also play important roles. The findings provide guidance for policymakers and platform developers, highlighting the need to improve digital literacy, build trust, and ensure affordability to accelerate the digital transformation of the agricultural sector.

title: An Integrated Multi-Sensor Fusion Algorithm for Substation Localization Using UWB and Video
authors: Yang Su, Lisa Guo, Yuewei Tian, Wenqiang Zou, Zhong Ma, Dingguo Li, Fang Ren

title: The Evolving Role of Large Language Models in UX Design: A Bibliometric Analysis Study
authors: Ilhame Oudor, Khalid Nafil
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Context: The advent of large language models (LLMs) have changed the way artificial intelligence interacts with users by understanding and generating natural language. In the field of user experience (UX) design, they open up new ways to improve design processes, support user-centered approaches, and create more inclusive and personalized digital experiences. However, there is still limited research that looks closely at how LLMs are used in UX design. Objective: The primary role of this study is to explore how academic research is addressing the integration of large language models to UX Design. It focuses on identifying current themes, how researchers are working together, and how the focus of the studies has changed over time. Method: This bibliometrics study is based on 42 research papers published between 2022 and 2025, selected from the databases: SpringerLink, IEEE Xplore, ScienceDirect, ACM Digital Library, Scopus, Web of Science, Arxiv, and Dimensions by using the PRISMA method. Tools like Bibliometrix and RStudio were used to analyze publication trends, citation patterns, and the main topics covered in the literature. Results: The findings show that research on LLMs and UX has grown quickly in recent years, especially after the release of tools like ChatGPT. Most of the publications originate from researchers in the USA, China, and Canada. The most common topics include chatbots, co-creation with AI, personalization, and accessibility issues such as fairness and transparency. A few papers were cited often, but many received limited attention, showing that the field is still developing. Conclusion: This analysis synthesizes early research trends in LLM-driven UX design, revealing growing academic interest. Findings highlight the need for deeper investigation into how these models enable inclusive and user-centered solutions, while underscoring the value of cross-disciplinary collaboration between AI and UX fields to advance design innovation.

title: Efficient Parallel Rotation of Hyperspectral Images on FPGA-Accelerated Platforms
authors: Carlos E. Hernández, Jesús Barba, José L. Mira, Julián Caba, Fernando Rincón, Juan C. López
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: This work presents an efficient hardware architecture for hyperspectral image rotation, based on a geometric matrix transformation combined with bilinear interpolation to enhance pixel accuracy. These operations are commonly used in hyperspectral image (HSI) registration processes to compensate for motion in the observed scene. The primary objective of this research is to minimize the computational resource usage of the algorithm while optimizing overall efficiency. To achieve this, a reconfigurable hardware architecture based on FPGA is employed, where the rotation algorithm is implemented as an accelerator using the Vitis HLS synthesis tool and the block flow mechanism. The FPGA-based solution with four cores achieved a latency of 0,445 ms and a throughput of 1396,9 MB/s, with an energy consumption of only 1,09 mJ. Additionally, an alternative implementation was carried out on a GPU-based architecture (Jetson Nano), resulting in a higher latency of 12,55 ms and an energy consumption of 62,75 mJ. The evaluation included energy consumption, comparison with other solutions reported in the literature, and quality metrics. The results demonstrate that the FPGA-based solution is more efficient in terms of resource utilization and energy consumption, with minimal error.

title: An Autoencoder-based Solution to Detect Denial of Service Attack Variants
authors: Niroop Sugunaraj, Hossein Salehfar, Prakash Ranganathan
abstract: This work uses transmission control protocol (TCP) data derived from the Edge Testbed at the University of North Dakota to model three denial of service (DoS) attack variations: slow, random, and pulse, and detect them using the undercomplete and sparse autoencoder types. Reconstruction errors and standard classification metrics indicate that the sparse autoencoder type using L1 regularization performs better than the undercomplete type at differentiating normal samples from the attack variants. Additionally, a short analysis of the sparse autoencoder’s hidden layer for five pulse attack samples provides evidence that the model learns subtle neuron activation patterns to differentiate between samples but represents similar samples consistently with same neuron activations.

title: Optimizing the Accuracy and Efficiency of Short-term Load Forecasting Using a Hybrid Deep Learning Models
authors: Waleed Ahmed Atiq, Faisal Hammad Khan, Tahir Mahmood
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on Energy Conservation and Efficiency (ICECE)
abstract: Precision in short-term load forecasting (STLF) is essential to maintain the stability of power systems, facilitate the work of grid and reduce the operating costs. To enhance the domestic electricity demand forecasting, the paper examines advanced deep learning architectures, including Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), Bidirectional LSTM (BiLSTM), Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and a CNN-BiLSTM architecture. In order to measure accuracy and resilience, models were trained and tested with different initializations of random seed. Performance was measured using performance evaluation matrices (PEM) Mean Absolute error (MAE), Mean Squared error (MSE), and the root mean squared error (RMSE). Results reveal that LSTM occasionally achieves the lowest error values at seed =8 (MAE =0.155, RMSE =0.291 ) and lowest training losses were found with very high seed (4,8) at value (0.00144236 and 0.0014224) respectively. The BiLSTM model slightly higher but consistent loss across seeds because its ability to learn bidirectional temporal dependencies without significant overfitting. The hybrid CNN-BiLSTM achieves stable, competitive results, outperforming BiLSTM and closely matching CNN, with seed =8 (MAE =0.286, RMSE =0.362 ) showing balanced and reliable accuracy. The proposed hybrid framework not only enhance forecasting precision but also provide a scalable solution for broader time-series applications, contributing to smarter energy management, improved demand and supply balancing, and reliable grid operations.

title: Research on the Integration and Utilization Mechanism of Cyber Threat Intelligence Based on Data Fabric and Web 3.0
authors: Tianying Chen, Jianfeng Chen, Xiao Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: Threat intelligence, through the transmission, exchange, and reuse of critical cybersecurity content, facilitates the formation of collaborative defense trust alliances among enterprises and organizations. This enables collective identification, blocking, and tracking of intruders, making it a critical foundation for cybersecurity governance. However, as the intelligence ecosystem continues to evolve, key challenges persist in the areas of intelligence management, security, benefits, and sharing. The uneven quality of threat intelligence has resulted in users struggling to navigate a landscape of unpredictable “blind-box” information. By integrating the “next-generation application architecture” of Web 3.0 and the “next-generation data management” approach of data fabric, this paradigm introduces novel characteristics such as decentralization, strong trust, tamper-resistance, high consistency, and mutual recognition into threat intelligence sharing. This approach holds the potential to overcome current technical and management bottlenecks, enabling seamless integration and functional autonomy among defense entities. It fosters a deep “supply-demand synergy” for threat intelligence, achieving a new level of comprehensive fusion and collaborative security.

title: Research on UAV Narrowband Anti-jamming Communication Based on Improved Fruit Fly Optimization Algorithm
authors: Yongjiang Wang, Wenjing Sun, Ling Zhang, Lv Xianqiang, Lin Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: With the advancement of science and technology and the maturity of related techniques, unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) have been widely applied in numerous fields. However, the communication of UAVs based on narrowband communication is faced with severe interference problems. To effectively address such interference, this study proposes an improved fruit fly optimization algorithm. Specifically, by constructing a dynamic interference model, a multi-objective optimization strategy is employed to improve the olfactory search and visual search stages of the traditional fruit fly optimization algorithm, which significantly enhances the global search ability and convergence speed of the algorithm. Meanwhile, a communication interference model is established, and the frequency selection problem is ingeniously transformed into an optimization problem. The simulation results show that, under the interference environment, the improved algorithm can effectively enhance the anti-jamming performance of UAV narrowband communication, further improving the communication quality and reliability.

title: The Design and Research of a Microfluidic System with Force Feedback
authors: Dujinbin Yu, Runfeng Lv, Sibo Hao, Di Cui, Yong Cao, Xiaotian Long, Mingchuan Zhou
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: This study presents the design and implementation of a force-feedback-enabled aspiration fluid control system for ophthalmic surgery. The system features a dual-pump collaborative architecture that combines the rapid negative pressure response of a venturi pump with the high-precision flow control of a peristaltic pump. An intelligent mode-switching mechanism enables smooth transitions between pressure and flow control modes to meet varying surgical requirements. A segmented force-feedback foot pedal is integrated to support multimodal interaction, enhancing the surgeon's perception of system status and operational intuitiveness. Through closedloop control algorithms and multi-sensor feedback, the system achieves precise regulation of aspiration pressure and flow. Experimental results demonstrate good performance in control accuracy, responsiveness, and human-machine interaction, indicating strong potential for application in next-generation intelligent minimally invasive surgical systems. However, further optimization is needed to improve long-term stability and reliability.

authors: Tiago Cortez, Cian O’Donnell, Daniel O’Hare
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Low-power Analog-to-Digital Converters (ADCs) are critical for energy-constrained applications such as portable and biomedical systems. However, the input buffers required to drive large ADC sampling capacitors, neglected in ADC Figure of Merit (FoM) calculations, can dominate power consumption. This paper addresses the challenge of designing stable, low-power unity gain buffers capable of driving large sampling capacitors across a wide output swing. The sampling capacitor itself is leveraged to set the dominant pole, enabling a power-efficient pole placement strategy in a two-stage buffer configuration. We show how older technologies present an obstacle in stabilizing a two stage OTA while maintaining reasonable power consumption, and propose a more suitable architecture to enable energy efficiency – achieving better PM with a quarter of the power.

title: Application of Large Language Models for Cybersecurity of Power Distribution Grids: Challenges and Opportunities
authors: Md Moshiur Rahman, Airin Rahman, Wei Sun
abstract: This paper explores the application of domain-specific large language models (LLMs) as a transformative approach to enhancing cybersecurity in power distribution networks. We propose a comprehensive framework that integrates LLMs with existing grid infrastructure to enable predictive analytics, proactive vulnerability assessment, intelligent threat detection, and automated incident response. By incorporating reinforcement learning (RL) agents and a human-in-the-loop mechanism, the framework supports robust and trustworthy decision-making. Leveraging LLMs’ natural language processing capabilities, the system analyzes physical measurements and system logs, generates threat intelligence reports, and facilitates real-time operational decisions. The study identifies key cyber vulnerabilities in active distribution grids, including their sources, impacts, and attack taxonomy. It further discusses the challenges and risks of implementing LLMs in dynamic grid environments, alongside the opportunities they present for improving grid security. A roadmap is presented for curating domain-specific LLMs and validating their integration within standard industrial control architectures. Overall, this research demonstrates that LLMs can substantially enhance the resilience and cybersecurity of modern power distribution systems by enabling early threat detection and effective mitigation.

title: TitanLog: Hierarchical and Elastic Logging for High-Speed Network Data Stream
authors: Yuanpeng Li, Xian Niu, Yikai Zhao, Tong Yang, Yannan Hu, Yuchao Zhang, Xiangwei Deng, Qiuheng Yin, Ziyun Zhang, Ruwen Zhang, Yisen Hong, Kaicheng Yang, Ruijie Miao, Kun Meng, Dahui Wang, Yong Cui
abstract: Logging network traffic plays a crucial role as it serves as the foundation for various network applications. As network scale continues to expand, contemporary network traffic becomes increasingly high-speed, high-volume, and dynamic. This growth poses challenges to traditional server-based solutions. In this paper, we propose TitanLog, a hierarchical and elastic logging system designed specifically for large-scale network traffic. TitanLog utilizes the hierarchical logging methodology, which aims to identify the importance of each packet in real-time and log packet data of different importance at different levels. To enhance efficiency, we propose a co-design of the emerging programmable switch and the server, incorporating sketches and RDMA to boost performance. To achieve elasticity, we design mechanisms for run-time adjustments and monitoring for resource insufficiency. TitanLog possesses the capability to switch between these modes at run-time. We fully implement TitanLog on a testbed and conduct extensive evaluations. The experimental results demonstrate that TitanLog supports logging of 100Gbps traffic with a zero packet loss rate and reduces the log volume by up to 96.28%.

title: Nonlinear Error Correction Scheme Based on Feature Phase Consistency in Fringe Projection Profilometry
authors: Ji Cui, Siao Cai, Wei Li, Guoying Feng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Phase distortion caused by nonlinearity remains a critical challenge in high-accuracy fringe projection profilometry (FPP). Existing nonlinearity correction methods suffer from significant limitations. System calibration-based approaches are prone to failure under environmental disturbances, while recent data-driven compensation methods exhibit drawbacks such as heavy reliance on pre-training and poor interpretability. To address this current situation, this study proposes a physics principle-driven framework based on Feature Phase-Invariant Points (FPIPs). We reveal for the first time the existence of FPIPs in multi-step phase-shifting systems; these points maintain a constant phase value under arbitrary nonlinear distortions (ϕFPIPs≡ϕ0). Based on this core discovery, this work utilizes the intensity distributions of two sets of fringe patterns with different frequencies at the FPIPs to construct dual-frequency constraint equations, achieving the direct solution of the Gamma value. Combined with a statistical fusion strategy to obtain the global Gamma value, it effectively suppresses noise interference. Finally, a Gauss-Newton iterative algorithm is adopted to optimize phase compensation, realizing the correction of nonlinear measurement errors. Both numerical simulations and experimental results demonstrate that this algorithm significantly reduces the phase errors brought by nonlinearity, verifying the algorithm’s effectiveness and robustness. It is worth noting that the proposed framework employs a point-wise computation mode, ensuring precise recovery of measurement details. This physics-driven approach provides an innovative solution for nonlinearity correction in FPP that is calibration-free and eliminates reliance on data-driven methods, significantly enhancing measurement robustness and practicality.

title: Benchmark of the Beam Optics Simulation Against the Beam Acceleration Experiments of a Dual-Driver Radio Frequency Negative Ion Source for Fusion
authors: Jiahao Cheng, Yuwen Yang, Qinglong Cui, Zhengkun Cao, Yao Qin, Yongjian Xu, Lizhen Liang, Jianglong Wei
abstract: Neutral beam injection (NBI) is a key auxiliary heating technology used in magnetic confinement fusion devices. With the scale up of the device, the requirement of beam energy is higher. A negative ion source-based neutral beam injection (NNBI) system is an inevitable choice, but the NNBI system presents significant engineering complexity and technical challenges. To investigate and master core NNBI technologies, an NNBI test facility is currently being developed under the Comprehensive Research Facility for Fusion Technology (CRAFT) in China. The initial operational targets for the CRAFT NNBI system are to achieve a beam with energies in the range of 200400 keV, the neutral beam power of 2 MW, and the pulse duration of 100 s. In the negative ion source, the beam divergence is one of the important parameters that determines the pulse duration and energy of the beam. A large beam divergence will cause heavy thermal load on the electrode grids and additional heat load on the beamline components. These can cause the breakdown of grids and interrupt the acceleration process. The accelerator beam optics design for the CRAFT NNBI dual-driver negative ion source is based on IBSimu. Two diagnostic methods, beam emission spectroscopy (BES) and secondary electron emission (SEE), are adopted to analyze the optical characteristics of beam in the experiments. The experimental results verify the simulation results calculated by IBSimu, confirming the limitations and reliability of the simulation program.

title: Multi-Scale Samples Transformer for Hyperspectral Image Classification
authors: Wei-Tao Zhang, Nuo Xu, Yv Bai, Ya-Ru Zhang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Hyperspectral image (HSI) captures hundreds of narrow bands, offering abundant spatial and spectral information across various application domains. In recent years, deep learning techniques have shown strong potential in HSI processing, with a range of models being explored. However, the fixed geometric structure of convolutional kernels in CNN model impedes interactions between long-term dependencies, and existing transformer methods have not fully harnessed the spectral structural characteristics of HSI data. To address these issues, we proposed a multiscale samples transformer (MSST) that effectively extracts spatial and spectral features via two separate branches respectively. In spectral branch, the spectral sequence of the individual target pixel is used as input sample, a spectral transformer (SpecFormer) is proposed to comprehensively extract the spectral structural features. In spatial branch, three-dimensional tensor consisting of target pixel and their neighboring pixels is used as input sample, dimension reduction is performed, and a spatial transformer (SpatFormer) is designed to efficiently extract the deep spatial features of HSI data. Consequently, MSST enlarges the receptive field and captures the comprehensive joint spatial-spectral features. Extensive experiments conducted on five widely used HSI datasets demonstrate the superior classification performance of the proposed framework. Our source codes will be available at https://github. com/zhwt-xidian/Multi-Scale-Samples-Transformer_MSST.

title: Optimal Microgrid Sizing for Lunar Habitats in Non-Polar Regions
authors: Mohammad Hanif, Ali Bazzi
abstract: For the last few years, there has been a growing interest in implementing microgrids for space exploration purposes. In this case, optimization is crucial to determine the optimal combination of microgrid components. For microgrid sizing, heuristic algorithms are the most frequently employed techniques around the world. However, they can not guarantee global optimality. In this study, a deterministic optimization approach is employed for the optimal sizing of space-based microgrids for lunar habitats, utilizing the Sequential Quadratic Programming (SQP) algorithm to minimize the Annualized System Cost (ASC). Optimal sizing of the microgrid components varies with the level of nuclear base power. According to the approach, for 200 kW nuclear base power, the optimal solar and battery sizes are 101.19 kW and 9460.37 kWh, respectively. The results are validated through a comparative analysis of the outputs obtained from two widely used heuristic algorithms: Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) and Grey Wolf Optimization (GWO). Moreover, the sensitivity, statistical and uncertainty analyses are performed in this study. By properly sizing the microgrid components, the cost and weight of the power system components in the space mission can be reduced while maintaining reliability.

title: LLM4CVE: Enabling Iterative Automated Vulnerability Repair with Large Language Models
authors: Mohamad Fakih, Rahul Dharmaji, Halima Bouzidi, Gustavo Quiros Araya, Oluwatosin Ogundare, Mst Ayesha Siddika, Mohammad Abdullah Al Faruque
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: Software vulnerabilities remain pervasive, even with the rise of AI-powered code assistants, advanced static analysis tools, and comprehensive testing frameworks. It’s clear that we must move beyond merely preventing these bugs; we need to eliminate them swiftly and efficiently. However, manual code intervention is slow, expensive, and can often introduce new security flaws, especially in legacy codebases. The advent of highly advanced Large Language Models (LLMs) presents a significant opportunity for automated software defect patching. We introduce LLM4CVE, an LLM-based iterative pipeline designed for robust and accurate repair of vulnerable functions in real-world code. We evaluate our pipeline using State-of-the-Art LLMs, including GPT-3.5, GPT-4o, Llama 3 8B, and Llama 3 70B. Our results demonstrate a human-verified quality score of 8.51/10 and a 20% increase in ground-truth code similarity with Llama 3 70B. To foster further research in LLM-based vulnerability repair, we release our evaluation framework, fine-tuned model weights, and experimental results on our website: https://sites.google.com/view/llm4cve

title: Design-Space Exploration of Serialized Floating-Point Division for DLP Architectures
authors: Louis Ledoux
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: We propose a framework for generating floatingpoint division units that leverages data-level parallelism (DLP) at the hardware level to enhance scalability, energy efficiency, and design flexibility. While modern ISAs support DLP via SIMD and vector extensions, arithmetic units often remain optimized for latency and do not scale efficiently across parallel workloads. Our approach revisits the microarchitecture of division units by trading latency for area, exposing parallelism through the instantiation of multiple smaller, slower units replicated spatially to exploit data-level parallelism. The framework operates as a high-level generator written in Python, automatically producing synthesizable ASIC designs across multiple floating-point formats and technology nodes. It supports format-agnostic and processagnostic design exploration, enabling rapid evaluation of tradeoffs between latency, area, and power. We validate our contributions through extensive evaluations encompassing 11 floating-point formats, including posits, IEEE754, and recent formats like EXMY, as well as process nodes ranging from 180 nm to 7 nm, demonstrating the scalability of our approach. Notably, area and power reductions reach up to $9.18 \times$ and $61.28 \times$, respectively, for Posit64 and IEEE754 double precision. When constraining designs to preserve performance, the best gains reach $3.12 \times$ and $8.03 \times$, demonstrating the viability of the approach for parallel workloads and vector datapaths.

title: Synergistic Deep Learning Approaches for Pancreatic Cancer Diagnosis: Comparative Analysis of CNN Architectures and Multimodal Data Fusion
authors: Youssef Boughdad, Majdoulayne Hanifi, Boutaina Hdioud, Rachid Oulad Haj Thami
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) remains among the deadliest cancers due to late detection and limited therapeutic options. Recent deep learning advances, spanning CNNs, radiomics-DL hybrids, and early CNN-Transformer variants, show promise across CT/MRI/EUS/PET, yet clinical translation is hindered by single-center cohorts, scarce external validation, limited explainability, and weak integration of multiomics data. This paper offers a focused critical review and a feasibility-oriented methodological blueprint rather than a deployed system. Our contributions are threefold: (i) a structured synthesis of the PDAC literature by modality, task, and model family, highlighting recurring failure modes; (ii) an explainable multimodal framework that unifies imaging and clinical/radiomics (± omics) signals; and (iii) a concrete evaluation protocol specifying held-out external testing, task-appropriate metrics (AUROC with 95% CIs, sensitivity at 90% specificity, AUPRC; Dice/HD95; C-index/AUC <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(t)$</tex>), calibration and decision-curve analysis, plus statistical comparisons. We also detail deployment constraints, including compute/VRAM reporting, inference-time targets, and lightweight distilled/quantized variants for low-resource sites, together with model and data cards and Grad-CAM exemplars to support clinical interpretation. The blueprint is intended to guide rigorous, reproducible PDAC studies and credible prospective validations.

title: A High-sensitivity CMUT for Underwater Sensing Application
authors: Chi Zhang, Wenle Ye, Pengfei Niu, Zhuochen Wang, Hui Zhang
abstract: Capacitive micromachined ultrasonic transducers (CMUTs) feature small size, wide bandwidth and good matching with acoustic impedance of water. The application of CMUTs in underwater sensing systems has the potential to reduce power consumption and save space. However, compared to traditional piezoelectric transducer, CMUTs exhibit lower sensitivity. To address this issue, this study designed a high-sensitivity CMUT device by reducing the silicon membrane thickness and optimizing the thickness of package material, and then characterized its acoustic performance. The results indicate that the CMUT exhibits significant advantages in terms of transmit sensitivity and bandwidth, and holds potential for applications in underwater sensing systems.

title: The Story of NextPerception – A survey of the project vision and realisation with examples
authors: Johan Plomp, Michael Rölleke, Laura Belli, Felipe Gil-Castiñeira, Raúl Santos De La Cámara, Roberta Presta, Greet Bilsen, Fokke van Meulen, Luca Davoli, Jaromír Hubálek

abstract: This paper describes the NextPerception project’s outcomes organized as examples motivated by user stories. The project developed next-generation perception sensors and enhanced the distributed intelligence paradigm to build versatile, secure, reliable and proactive human monitoring systems, in turn applied in use cases in health and automotive domains.

title: Dimensional Optimization of a Three-DoF Differential Parallel Mechanism for a Wrist Prosthetic.*
authors: E. Tonatiuh Jimenez-Borgonio, Hiroshi Yokoi, Yoshiko Yabuki, J. Carlos Sanchez-Garcia
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Individuals with severe injuries or congenital malformations resulting in limb amputation face significant challenges in daily activities. Recent advancements in upper-limb prosthetic design have accelerated due to the adoption of novel technologies, and research efforts have focused on developing prosthetic prototypes with the objective to replicate the humanlike wrist movements. This paper proposes a differential parallel mechanism with three-degrees-of-freedom (3-DoF), designed to replicate natural wrist movements such as Flexion/Extension (F/E), Pronation/Supination (P/S), and Radial/Ulnar (R/U) deviation to achieve a human-like range of motion (ROM) within a compact structural layout. A comprehensive kinematic model of the system is presented, and the link dimensions are determined using a Modified Monte Carlo (MMC) optimization algorithm. Finally, a computer-aided design (CAD) model was developed to simulate the proposed configuration.

title: Analysis and Control on SO(3) of a Serial Spherical Wrist with Balanced Links
authors: Jessica Guadalupe Sierra, José M. Rico, Marco A. Gomez
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: We present the analysis of a serial spherical wrist with balanced links by counterweights. The proposed configuration allows a straightforward kinematic analysis, based on screw theory. Relying on known results in the literature, we provide a proportional derivative and a sliding mode based control schemes formulated on <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{SO}(3)$</tex>. The latter is based on the proposal of a Lie subgroup as a sliding surface. Numerical simulations illustrate the performance of the proposed design with control.

title: Design and Verification of an Innovative Spine Surgical Robot Based on Dynamic Compensation
authors: Weijun Zhang, Changsheng Li, Huanyu Tian, Jingwei Zhao, Tianming Hu, Xingguang Duan
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: In spine surgery, robotic system can achieve precise surgery planning and instrument positioning. However, millimeter-level displacements caused by respiratory motion may reduce guidewire placement accuracy. This study presents a spine surgical robot that is integrated with a real-time tracking system and a dynamic compensation system based on Kalman filter. The animal experiments (porcine model) demonstrated that the placement accuracy in the dynamic tracking group (83% level-A satisfaction) was improved compared with that in the no tracking group (42%). The result validated the system's clinical potential while maintaining similar operation time (32.5 min vs. 31.0 min) and overall workflow efficiency.

title: Voltage Regulation of Distribution Grid Based on Coordination of Regulator Tap and Volt-VAR Control
authors: Hongxia Wang, Wei Gao, Soumyabrata Talukder, Haosen Guo, Arun Kumar Karngala, Xiaoyuan Fan, Dongbo Zhao, Jinfeng Wu, David Wenzhong Gao
abstract: Voltage regulation in unbalanced distribution feeders with high DER penetration poses significant challenges. To overcome these, coordination of mechanical regulators and Volt–VAR–enabled PV inverters are modeled, and their support for voltage regulation is systematically evaluated. Using the linearized optimal power flow model, the Volt–VAR characteristic required by IEEE Std. 1547-2018 is embedded in LinDistFlow, with its breakpoints either fixed at IEEE-standard defaults or treated as decision variables. Discrete tap positions are represented by integer variables that likewise may be fixed or optimized. Case studies on the modified IEEE 123-node feeder system confirm the importance of embedding Volt–VAR control within OPF. Moreover, the coordination of Volt–VAR control and regulator tap positions to reduce voltage deviation is fully studied.

title: Proximal Gradient-Based Model Predictive Control for Obstacle Avoidance in Holonomic Robots
authors: Diego López Hernández, Carlos Sotelo, Antonio Favela-Contreras, Francisco Beltran-Carbajal, David Sotelo
publish: 2025 22nd International Conference on Electrical Engineering, Computing Science and Automatic Control (CCE)
abstract: Model Predictive Control (MPC) is a powerful tool for robotics. However, its high computational load poses a challenge for embedded systems. This paper proposes an efficient MPC with a Proximal Gradient method approach (PG-MPC) for controlling a Mecanum wheel robot in an obstacle-constrained environment. Comparing the proposed PG-MPC to a baseline MPC, two case studies are considered for simulation results. First, four representative points were set as goals in an obstacle-free environment. For the second case study, two obstacles are imposed along the trajectory leading to the goal of the vehicle. It is observed that the trajectories generated by both controllers are similar. However, under the PG-MPC architecture, the computational time is significantly improved compared to the MPC baseline.

title: Biomimetic Stingray Robot for Piping Flow Field Detection Using Deep Learning
authors: Jiancheng Qian, Hanrui Xu, Chen Jie, Tiezhu Qiao, Huijie Dong, Jian Wang, Zhengxing Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Flow field perception in underwater environments remains a significant challenge in robotics, particularly in the identification and detection of complex flow phenomena such as piping erosion. This paper proposes a piping flow field perception method by a bionic underwater robot with lateral line systems, which achieves precise identification of complex underwater flow fields by mimicking the lateral line sensing system of stingrays. First, an underwater robot electromechanical system is designed mimicking stingrays. Second, simulation analysis of piping flow fields is conducted to develop an optimal sensor array positioning algorithm. Finally, a GRU-based piping flow field feature recognition method is developed. Experimental results demonstrate that this method effectively accomplishes flow field data acquisition, analysis, and recognition, detecting piping phenomena. This research provides a new technological pathway for underwater flow field perception and holds significant application value in hydraulic facility maintenance, effectively replacing manual operations.

title: Optimal Data Center Load Scheduling in Power System Operation
authors: Irfanul Hasan, Yuanrui Sang, David Irwin, Golbon Zakeri
abstract: Data centers are fast-growing electricity consumers with significant potential to support power system operations. This study presents an optimization framework where data center workloads are scheduled based on system-level constraints rather than price signals. The approach integrates an economic dispatch model with a best-effort (BE) data center workload allocation strategy that shifts computing demand away from peak periods while meeting the total workload demand and preserving the quality of service (QoS) for latency-critical (LC) workloads. The model was implemented on the IEEE 24-bus RTS-96 system over a 24-hour horizon with 5-minute time intervals. Case studies demonstrate that flexible scheduling reduces system operating costs and peak demand. The results validate the effectiveness of the data center workload scheduling model in enhancing power grid flexibility regardless of the locations of the data centers.

title: A Reduced Gravity Simulation System for Astronauts Training Based on Lower Limb Exoskeleton Robot
authors: Haolan Xian, Yuanwen Zhang, Jingfeng Xiong, Changjiang Lei, Chenglong Fu, Yuquan Leng
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Cyborg and Bionic Systems (CBS)
abstract: Reduced gravity simulation systems are important for astronaut training because microgravity can have some adverse effects on the human body. However, there is a lack of a small device that can simulate a reduced gravity environment and fewer analyses of the effects of microgravity on the human body. For this reason, we designed a reduced gravity simulation system based on a vertical body weight support system (BWS) and an exoskeleton. The BWS simulates the effects of reduced weight of the whole body by suspending a certain weight. The exoskeleton monitors the angle of the wearer's lower limb joints through a inertial measurement unit net on the body to map the corresponding joint moments, and ultimately realizes the reduced gravity simulation of hip joint. Based on the system described above, we wish to explore the effects of microgravity on human biomechanics while trying to ensure the simulations are as accurate as possible. One subject was recruited to participate in a series of experiment. Walking experiment was conducted at two speeds under three wearing conditions: without the BWS and exoskeleton, with the BWS and with the BWS and exoskeleton. Biomechanical data, including joint angles, joint moments, and muscle activations, were recorded by a motion capture system and surface EMG during the experiments. Based on these measurements, the effects of reduced gravity simulation environment on the walking patterns were mainly in the joint angles, joint moments, muscle activation, and control strategies of the human body. It is worth noting that the activation intensity of some muscles increased by different magnitudes and shifted in phase under the simulation condition compared to the normal. These results were unexpected for us and promising to serve as an inspiration for the future development of astronauts training system. Data can be found at Github (https://github.com/Xianhl25/RGS.git).

title: Rethinking Decoupled Knowledge Distillation: A Predictive Distribution Perspective
authors: Bowen Zheng, Ran Cheng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Neural Networks and Learning Systems
abstract: In the history of knowledge distillation (KD), the focus has once shifted over time from logit-based to feature-based approaches. However, this transition has been revisited with the advent of decoupled KD (DKD), which reemphasizes the importance of logit knowledge through advanced decoupling and weighting strategies. While DKD marks a significant advancement, its underlying mechanisms merit deeper exploration. As a response, we rethink DKD from a predictive distribution perspective. First, we introduce an enhanced version, the generalized DKD (GDKD) loss, which offers a more versatile method for decoupling logits. Then, we pay particular attention to the teacher model’s predictive distribution and its impact on the gradients of GDKD loss, uncovering two critical insights often overlooked: 1) the partitioning by the top logit considerably improves the interrelationship of nontop logits and 2) amplifying the focus on the distillation loss of nontop logits enhances the knowledge extraction among them. Utilizing these insights, we further propose a streamlined GDKD algorithm with an efficient partition strategy to handle the multimodality of teacher models’ predictive distribution. Our comprehensive experiments conducted on a variety of benchmarks, including CIFAR-100, ImageNet, Tiny-ImageNet, CUB-200-2011, and Cityscapes, demonstrate GDKD’s superior performance over both the original DKD and other leading KD methods. The code is available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/ZaberKo/GDKD</uri>
