title: Broadband All-metal Slot Array Antenna Based on a Decoupled Concave-convex Layout Design
authors: Dong Xiang, Zhe Du, Lina Zhang, Qian Chen, Jingfeng Chen, Junping Geng, Ronghong Jin, Xianling Liang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Antennas and Propagation
abstract: This paper presents a broadband all-metal slot array antenna based on a concave-convex array (CCAA) layout. The CCAA offers significant reduction of Radar Cross Section (RCS) but suffers from coupling that limits radiation performance. To address this, open rectangular resonant slots (ORRS) are employed to suppress induced wall currents and restore bandwidth, patterns, and gain. A 4×4 prototype was designed, fabricated, and tested. Both simulation and measurement confirm a 10-dB impedance bandwidth of 43.5% (7.9-12.3 GHz) with radiation comparable to a planar array (PAA). In addition, relative to the PAA, the decoupled CCAA achieves 10-dB RCS reduction bandwidths of 35% and 15% under X- and Co-pol. incidences. These results verify that the ORRS-based decoupling design enables the CCAA to simultaneously realize broadband radiation and low observability.

title: Point-ITR: Task-Oriented Importance Sampling for Large-Scale 3D Point Clouds in Manufacturing
authors: Yichen Ma, Michael Biehler, Chiehyeon Lim, Jianjun Shi
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: The increasing adoption of advanced three-dimensional (3D) scanning technologies has made large-scale point clouds containing millions of 3D measurement points standard in applications like manufacturing. However, processing immense amounts of 3D data imposes significant computational loads, often resulting in discarded critical information and suboptimal outcomes for downstream tasks. This paper introduces Point-ITR, a task-oriented sampling method tailored for regression tasks, which selectively retains the most informative points within large-scale point clouds. Specifically, we propose a gradient-based importance sampling framework for intra-sample selection (selecting points within a 3D point cloud) and a feature-based weighting scheme for inter-sample selection (selecting among different 3D point cloud sub-samples). Additionally, we introduce an iterative random sampling (ItrRS) module for preprocessing and an Offset Residual Block that utilizes a reference design model to learn structural features and accelerate both training and testing, which allows a simple fully connected network to process large-scale point clouds. Our approach improves prediction accuracy across downstream tasks while ensuring that the rich details captured are fully utilized for interpretation, offering a more effective and efficient solution. We validate our methodology through simulation studies and real-world case applications in additive manufacturing, demonstrating its robustness and practical applicability.

title: An Analysis of Constraint-Based Multi-Agent Pathfinding Algorithms
authors: Hannah Lee, James D. Motes, Marco Morales, Nancy M. Amato
abstract: This study informs the design of future multi-agent pathfinding (MAPF) and multi-robot motion planning (MRMP) algorithms by guiding choices based on constraint classification for constraint-based search algorithms. We categorize constraints as conservative or aggressive and provide insights into their search behavior, focusing specifically on vanilla Conflict-Based Search (CBS) and Conflict-Based Search with Priorities (CBSw/P). Under a hybrid grid-roadmap representation with varying resolution, we observe that aggressive (priority constraint) formulations tend to solve more instances as agent count or resolution increases, whereas conservative (motion constraint) formulations yield stronger solution quality when both succeed. Findings are synthesized in a decision flowchart, aiding users in selecting suitable constraints. Recommendations extend to Multi-Robot Motion Planning (MRMP), emphasizing the importance of considering topological features alongside problem, solution, and representation features. A comprehensive exploration of the study, including raw data and map performance, is available in our public GitHub Repository.

title: Kinodynamic Trajectory Planning for Efficient UAV Exploration and Reconstruction of Unknown Environments_supp1-3641147.mp4
authors: Joao Felix Mendes
abstract: Autonomous exploration of unknown 3D environments requires motion planners that can efficiently identify informative regions to explore while continuously adapting to the evolving map of the environment. While existing sampling-based methods have demonstrated strong real-time performance, they often ignore the robot's kinodynamic model and constraints. Consequently, they generate only target positions, neglecting kinodynamic considerations in the next-best-view decision process. This results in frequent slowdowns and abrupt maneuvers, reducing coverage speed and exploration efficiency. In this work, we propose a kinodynamic motion planning framework designed for fast and efficient exploration of unknown environments. By incorporating the robot's kinodynamic model and constraints into a kinodynamic RRT, our approach bridges the gap between dynamically feasible motion and effective viewpoint selection, producing smoother and faster trajectories that improve exploration performance. Additionally, we present an Iterative Minimum Gain (IMG) approach to improve global coverage, and a novel informed yaw optimization method that accelerates optimal yaw selection, capable of achieving up to more than twice the speed of state-of-the-art methods. We validate our framework through extensive simulation and real-world experiments, demonstrating improved exploration rates, higher average velocities, and better global coverage over existing methods.

title: A Crossingly Merged Four-Port PV System Topology with Controllable Symmetry for Resonant Conversion
authors: Ting Qian, Yue Wang
abstract: This paper proposes a simple four-port resonant converter for standalone Photovoltaic (PV) systems. Specifically, the new topology combines an isolated resonant LLC converter and two bi-directional buck-boost converters by using only four MOSFETs on the primary side, and thus, fulfills PV voltage regulation and battery management in a low-cost manner. Then, by properly designing the control sequence for the power switches, the system can not only divide the PVs into two groups for distributed management, but also stack the PVs and the battery as the DC supply for LLC. This reduces the influence of PV voltage variation and eliminates the need of pre-regulation stage. In addition, the LLC part can either maintain a symmetrical mode to improve efficiency, or add asymmetry control when a wider regulation range is needed. Based on the theoretical analysis, experimental results verify the performance of the proposed concept.

title: Road Segment Traffic Flow Estimation from Sparse Vehicle Trajectory Data Using an Enhanced Macroscopic Fundamental Diagram
authors: Yanli Jiao, Jingya Gao, Mingmin Ham, Daan Zhu, Yufei Ji
abstract: To address the “data silo” challenge in traffic flow data acquisition, this paper proposes a method for estimating urban road segment traffic flow from sparse vehicle trajectory data, predicated on the Macroscopic Fundamental Diagram (MFD). Initially, the conventional MFD model is extended to represent a single, signalized road segment. This extension incorporates a lane-changing behavior model to quantify the impact of lane-level flow redistribution on the segment’s traffic capacity. Subsequently, an analytical relationship between signal control strategies and flow fluctuations is established, enabling the refinement of segment flow estimations based on phase cycle characteristics. Finally, an iterative parameter calibration algorithm, leveraging sparse trajectory data, is designed to facilitate the adaptive updating of model parameters, thereby reducing the reliance on large-scale labeled datasets. Validation conducted using a floating car dataset from Xuancheng City demonstrates the model’s superior performance on road segments with medium-flow (MAE = 67.97 pcu/h) and high-flow (MAE = 41.28 pcu/h) conditions. It achieves an error reduction of over 30% compared to baseline models that neglect lane-changing behavior and signal control. This research provides a highly interpretable solution for real-time traffic flow estimation under “data silo” constraints, offering critical support for dynamic urban traffic management and planning.

title: Influence and Mechanism Analysis of Interface Defects of High Voltage Cables and Accessories on Discharge Characteristics
authors: Xingda Li, Renyou Li, Rui Lan, Yanhui Wei, Yeshuang Zheng, Yubing Duan, Yuanwei Zhu, Guochang Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Dielectrics and Electrical Insulation
abstract: High-voltage cables and accessories are the key components of power transmission, and the insulation interface is the weakest part of the insulation system. In order to study the effect of interface defects on the interface discharge characteristics of cables and accessories, firstly, the cross-linked polyethylene (XLPE), silicone rubber (SIR) and semi-conductive (SEMI) samples are prepared, and the composite samples are fabricated (including XLPE/SIR and XLPE/SEMI composite samples). Secondly, the effects of interface defects on the breakdown, dielectric and interface discharge properties of composite samples are analyzed. Finally, the composite interface defect model of cable and accessories is established to calculate the electric field distortion caused by the defect. The results show that the breakdown strength and interface discharge voltage of XLPE/SIR interface with voids and semi-conductive defects are 36.7, 39.98 kV/mm and 12.07, 10.95 kV, respectively. The relative dielectric constant of the samples with defects increased significantly comparing with the samples without defects. The breakdown strength of XLPE/SEMI interface with void, metal and semi-conductive defect are 65.00, 72.79 and 75.23 kV/mm, respectively, and the existence of defect leads to the overall increase of relative dielectric constant. The simulation results show that the maximum electric field distortion caused by voids and semi-conductive defects in XLPE/SIR interface are 19.28 and 10.78 kV/mm, respectively, increasing by 155.70% and 42.97%. The maximum electric field distortion caused by voids, metal and semi-conductivity defects in the XLPE/SEMI interface are 19.09, 8.62 and 8.40 kV/mm, respectively, increasing by 186.21%, 29.24% and 25.94%. The simulation results of electric field distortion are consistent with the breakdown test. This study is helpful to understand the effect of interface defects of cable accessories on electric field distribution, and it can provide reference for the operation, maintenance and fault analysis of cable accessories.

title: Adversarial Analysis and Supervisory Control of Sensor Networks
authors: Damas P. Gruska
publish: 2025 28th Euromicro Conference on Digital System Design (DSD)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to formal modeling and analyzing the resilience of networked sensor and actuator systems against targeted cyber-attacks, leveraging Timed Process Algebra (TPA). Recognizing the critical role of these systems in modern infrastructures and their inherent vulnerabilities, we develop a formal TPA-based model to represent sensors, actuators, communication channels, and malicious intruders as interacting processes. This model captures the dynamic behavior of the network, including data flow, control commands, and timing constraints, enabling the analysis of attack scenarios such as sensor disabling, actuator compromise, and communication disruption. We demonstrate some decidable and undecidable properties regarding the precise modeling of intruders, as well as employ model checking and an equivalence approach to verify some safety properties concerning intruders and supervisors.

title: Automated Generation of Classical Tabla Compositions Using Evolutionary Algorithms
authors: Muhammad Azeem Haider, Mustafa Sohail, Ali Siddiqui, Syeda Saleha Raza
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: There remains a gap in the study of evolutionary music without interactive evolution and goal-based fitness functions for evolutionary music, and in particular for classical tabla music. This paper studies the potential of generating classical tabla compositions using evolutionary algorithms. Unlike traditional methods, this study eliminates interactive evolution and goal-based fitness functions, creating a fully automated process. Music quality and creativity are driven by two factors: the userprovided “good pairs,” and tempo. The algorithm optimizes for placement of good pairs and the total difference between the bols of the taal. Further analysis highlights the importance of key parameters and selection schemes in achieving optimal fitness values. title: Energy Consumption Characterization of Dual-Core Operations in the RP2040 Microcontroller for IoT Applications
authors: Ioannis Sofianidis, Vasileios Konstantakos, Spyridon Nikolaidis
publish: 2025 32nd IEEE International Conference on Electronics, Circuits and Systems (ICECS)
abstract: Optimizing energy efficiency in dual-core microcontroller systems requires careful consideration of processing resource allocation and operational states. This study analyzes the energy consumption characteristics of the Raspberry Pi Pico RP2040 microcontroller while utilizing both Cortex-M0+ cores for Internet of Things (IoT) workloads that consider an audio related case study with audio acquisition, digital signal processing, and wireless transmission. The experimental measurements compare single-core and dual-core operation while the microcontroller is operating in multiple voltage-frequency configurations and temperature conditions. The evaluation considers bare-metal implementation. The results characterize performance-energy trade-offs related to parallel task execution and establish quantitative relationships between processing configurations and energy consumption. The findings of this work contribute to the systematic design of energy-efficient embedded systems for sensor networks.

title: PrivSeek: Lightweight and Private Inference for Distilled DeepSeek-Qwen via Secret Sharing
authors: Ying Wang, Han Fu, Jipeng Li, Yuheng Xia, Xutong Mu, Ke Cheng, Xueli Geng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Networking and Network Applications (NaNA)
abstract: The open-source large models (LLMs) developed by DeepSeek have demonstrated substantial utility in various applications. However, such LLMs inference services usually require users to upload their private data to backend servers for computation, giving rise to severe risks of data security leakage. Cryptographic techniques such as secure multi-party computation (MPC) and homomorphic encryption provide feasible solutions to the above problems. However, the existing schemes do not securely and efficiently support Grouped Query Attention (GQA) mechanism, SiLU activation layer, etc., thus making it difficult to achieve secure and efficient inference for DeepSeek models. Therefore, we propose PrivSeek, a lightweight and private inference for distilled DeepSeek-Qwen via secret sharing. Firstly, we construct a secure and efficient improved causal self-attention mask mechanism based on secret sharing, and adopt a two-stage calculation method of lower triangle mask and dynamic row normalization to overcome the limitations of arithmetic logic in ciphertext environment while ensuring controllable complexity. Secondly, we construct a secure and efficient SiLU protocol by combining the look-up table(LUT) mechanism and blinding technology, which effectively reduces the nonlinear computational complexity and realizes the lightweight design of secure computing protocol. Experimental results show that PrivSeek achieves 22.52 seconds per token with only $1.2 \%$ deviation from the maximum accuracy of plaintext benchmarks on mainstream datasets.

title: Hybrid CNN-ICA Method for PLI Artifact Detection and Removal in sEMG
authors: Mohamed AIT Yous, Said Agounad, Siham Elbaz
publish: 2025 International Conference on Intelligent Systems: Theories and Applications (SITA)
abstract: Recent studies have demonstrated an increased interest in surface electromyogram (sEMG) signal-based applications. It has been established that the efficiency of these applications may be subject to decline because of the presence of various sMG signals' contaminants originating from diverse sources. Power line interference (PLI) is one of the most encountered artifacts in the recording of sEMG signals. The present study aims to characterize and suppress PLI on the sEMG signal. Convolutional neural networks (CNN) are proposed to automatically identify the artifactual epochs using PLI. The selected epochs as contaminated are processed through a denoising block in which they are decomposed into components using independent component analysis (ICA). Thereafter, based on the kurtosis, the artifactual components are selected to be denoised and preserve the artifact-free epochs. Finally, the denoised signal is reconstructed using filtered and untouched epochs and components. Using different assessments, the proposed method is evaluated and compared with some of the most used approaches in the literature. The results return the best performance of our method at all considered signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs).
